In this paper, we study the energy transport in the FMO complex by taking different initial states into account. Optimizations are performed for the decoherence rates as to maximal transport efficiency. Dependence of the energy transfer efficiency on the initial states is given and discussed. Effects of fluctuations in the site energies and couplings are also examined.

In the intricate realm of genetics, the concept of epigenetics emerges, shedding light on modifications that alter gene expression without changing the DNA sequence itself. These alterations, often influenced by environmental factors, can be passed on to subsequent generations, underscoring the profound impact of our surroundings on our genetic makeup. Epigenetic marks, such as methylation and histone modifications, are like silent switches, controlling when and how genes are activated or silenced. This dynamic interplay between nature and nurture underscores the complexity and adaptability of life, reminding us that we are not mere products of our genes, but also the sum of our experiences.

Recent experiments suggest that membranes of living cells are tuned close to a miscibility critical point in the 2D Ising universality class. We propose that one role for this proximity to criticality in live cells is to provide a conduit for relatively long-ranged critical Casimir forces. Using techniques from conformal field theory we calculate potentials of mean force between membrane bound inclusions mediated by their local interactions with the composition order parameter. We verify these calculations using Monte-Carlo where we also compare critical and off-critical results. Our findings suggest that membrane bound proteins experience weak yet long range forces mediated by critical composition fluctuations in the plasma membranes of living cells.

In the intricate realm of genetics, the concept of epigenetics emerges as a captivating variant. Epigenetics, essentially, is a layer of modifications that influences gene expression without altering the DNA sequence itself. These modifications, primarily methylation and histone tail modifications, can be influenced by factors such as age, environment, and lifestyle choices. For instance, a high-fat diet may lead to changes in the epigenetic landscape, potentially increasing the risk of diseases like diabetes and cardiovascular conditions. Epigenetics, therefore, bridges the gap between nature and nurture, offering a compelling perspective on how our behaviors and surroundings can shape our genetic destiny.

We use a recently developed coarse-grained model for DNA to study kissing complexes formed by hybridization of complementary hairpin loops. The binding of the loops is topologically constrained because their linking number must remain constant. By studying systems with linking numbers -1, 0 or 1 we show that the average number of interstrand base pairs is larger when the topology is more favourable for the right-handed wrapping of strands around each other. The thermodynamic stability of the kissing complex also decreases when the linking number changes from -1 to 0 to 1. The structures of the kissing complexes typically involve two intermolecular helices that coaxially stack with the hairpin stems at a parallel four-way junction.

In the intricate realm of genetics, a single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) serves as a silent sentinel, subtly altering an organism's genetic blueprint. These minute variations in DNA sequence can influence traits, predispose to diseases, or even shape evolutionary adaptations. SNPs, occurring approximately every 100-300 base pairs, are the most common type of genetic variation among individuals. Their study is essential in understanding the complexities of heredity, as well as in personalized medicine and conservation biology. Unraveling the mysteries hidden within these tiny genetic markers promises to revolutionize our comprehension of life's diversity and complexity.

The cytosol state in living cell is treated as homogeneous phase equilibrium with a special feature: the pressure of one phase is positive and the pressure of the other is negative. From this point of view the cytosol is neither solution nor gel (or sol as a whole) regardless its components (water and dissolved substances). This is its unique capability for selecting, sorting and transporting reagents to the proper place of the living cell without a so-called "pipeline". To base this statement the theoretical investigation of the conditions of equilibrium and stability of the medium with alternative-sign pressure is carried out under using the thermodynamic laws and the Gibbs' equilibrium criterium.

In the realm of genetic engineering, CRISPR-Cas9 has revolutionized the field, offering a precise and efficient method for editing DNA. This revolutionary tool, a product of bacterial immune systems, allows scientists to correct genetic mutations, introduce new traits, and even eradicate diseases at their roots. By harnessing the power of this technology, we stand on the brink of a new era, where genetic disorders could be eradicated, crops could be engineered for improved yield and resistance, and the potential for personalized medicine could be realized. The implications of CRISPR-Cas9 stretch far beyond the lab, as it promises to reshape the course of human health and agriculture, ushering in a future where the power to alter life's building blocks lies in our hands.

Recently the A/H1N1-2009 virus pandemic appeared in Mexico and in other nations. We present a study of this pandemic in the Mexican case using the SIR model to describe epidemics. This model is one of the simplest models but it has been a successful description of some epidemics of closed populations. We consider the data for the Mexican case and use the SIR model to make some predictions. Then, we generalize the SIR model in order to describe the spatial dynamics of the disease. We make a study of the spatial and temporal spread of the infected population with model parameters that are consistent with temporal SIR model parameters obtained by fitting to the Mexican case.

In the intricate realm of genetics, the concept of epigenetics emerges as a fascinating layer of complexity. Epigenetics, a term coined in 1942, refers to changes in gene expression that do not involve alterations to the underlying DNA sequence. Instead, these changes are the result of chemical tags attached to DNA or histones, the proteins around which DNA is wound. These tags can be influenced by various factors like age, environment, lifestyle, and disease state, leading to changes in gene activity and, consequently, cell behavior, without any change in the actual DNA sequence. Epigenetics, therefore, offers a profound understanding of how experiences and environmental factors can influence an organism's development and health, transcending the traditional understanding of genetics as a static blueprint for life.

The copy number of any protein fluctuates among cells in a population. characterizing and understanding these fluctuations is a fundamental problem in biophysics. We show here that protein distributions measured under a broad range of biological realizations collapse to a single non-Gaussian curve under scaling by the first two moments. Moreover in all experiments the variance is found to depend quadratically on the mean, showing that a single degree of freedom determines the entire distribution. Our results imply that protein fluctuations do not reflect any specific molecular or cellular mechanism, and suggest that some buffering process masks these details and induces universality.

In the realm of genetics, DNA sequencing revolutionizes our understanding of heredity and evolution. This technique, deciphering the order of nucleotides in a DNA molecule, unveils genetic blueprints for life. It enables researchers to identify mutations linked to diseases, trace ancestry, and study the genetic diversity of species. The Human Genome Project, a landmark achievement in DNA sequencing, mapped the entire human genome, revealing approximately 20,000 genes. This knowledge paves the way for personalized medicine, offering targeted treatments based on an individual's genetic makeup. As technology advances, rapid and affordable DNA sequencing promises to transform healthcare, agriculture, and conservation, delivering insights that were once unimaginable.

The steady state of the two-substance model of light driven carbon turnover for the photosynthetic CO2 assimilation rate is presented. The model is based on the nonlinear diffusion equation for a single chloroplast in the elliptical geometry by assuming light driven Ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate (RuBP) regeneration and CO2 assimilation reaction of carboxilation coupled with the photosynthetic sink strength. The detailed analysis of 3 -dimensional CO2 concentration and flux on the chloroplast level is made. It is shown that under intense light irradiation there exists a boundary layer of chloroplasts with a high value of CO2 assimilation flux. The presented simplified model can be used for the calculations and experimental estimations of the CO2 assimilation rate for environmental applications.

In the intricate tapestry of life, photosynthesis stands as a cornerstone process, the life-giving dance between plants and sunlight. This biochemical marvel harnesses solar energy, converting carbon dioxide and water into glucose and oxygen. This process unfolds within chloroplasts, the energy factories within plant cells, where pigments like chlorophyll capture sunlight. Photosystems I and II, the principal actors, work in tandem, splitting water molecules and harnessing the energy to produce ATP and NADPH. These energy-rich molecules, in turn, fuel the Calvin cycle, the pathway that converts carbon dioxide into glucose, the sugar that fuels plant growth. In this symphony of life, photosynthesis not only sustains plants but also oxygenates our atmosphere, underpinning the very existence of aerobic life on Earth.

Dynamics in biological networks are in general robust against several perturbations. We investigate a coupled map network as a model motivated by gene regulatory networks and design systems which are robust against phenotypic perturbations (perturbations in dynamics), as well as systems which are robust against mutation (perturbations in network structure). To achieve such a design, we apply a multicanonical Monte Carlo method. Analysis based on the maximum Lyapunov exponent and parameter sensitivity shows that systems with marginal stability, which are regarded as systems at the edge of chaos, emerge when robustness against network perturbations is required. This emergence of the edge of chaos is a self-organization phenomenon and does not need a fine tuning of parameters.

In the intricate realm of genetics, the concept of epigenetics emerges as a significant offshoot. Epigenetics refers to changes in gene expression that do not involve alterations to the underlying DNA sequence. Instead, it encompasses chemical modifications to DNA and histone proteins that influence how genes are read and transcribed. These modifications, primarily driven by environmental factors, can persist through cell divisions and even potentially across generations. Epigenetic changes play crucial roles in processes like development, aging, and disease, offering a fascinating bridge between nature and nurture. As research progresses, the implications of epigenetics extend beyond biology, promising insights into personalized medicine and the potential for epigenetic therapies to address diseases rooted in aberrant gene expression patterns.

The question of the value of the pitch angle of DNA is visited from the perspective of a geometrical analysis of transcription. It is suggested that for transcription to be possible, the pitch angle of B-DNA must be smaller than the angle of zero-twist. At the zero-twist angle the double helix is maximally rotated and its strain-twist coupling vanishes. A numerical estimate of the pitch angle for B-DNA based on differential geometry is compared with numbers obtained from existing empirical data. The crystallographic studies shows that the pitch angle is approximately 38 deg., less than the corresponding zero-twist angle of 41.8 deg., which is consistent with the suggested principle for transcription.

In the intricate world of genetics, the concept of epigenetics plays a significant role. Epigenetics, a layer above DNA sequencing, influences gene expression without altering the actual genetic code. It is a dynamic process that can be modified by various factors, including environment, lifestyle, and age. The epigenome, a complex system of proteins and chemical tags, controls gene activity, impacting an organism's development, health, and behavior. For instance, stress can lead to changes in the epigenome, affecting mood and stress response. This area of study is rapidly advancing our understanding of heredity and individual differences, offering promising avenues for disease prevention and personalized medicine.

Recently, several works have analysed the efficiency of photosynthetic complexes in a transient scenario and how that efficiency is affected by environmental noise. Here, following a quantum master equation approach, we study the energy and excitation transport in fully connected networks both in general and in the particular case of the Fenna-Matthew-Olson complex. The analysis is carried out for the steady state of the system where the excitation energy is constantly "flowing" through the system. Steady state transport scenarios are particularly relevant if the evolution of the quantum system is not conditioned on the arrival of individual excitations. By adding dephasing to the system, we analyse the possibility of noise-enhancement of the quantum transport.

In the intricate world of genetics, a single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) can significantly impact an organism's traits. These minute variations in DNA sequence, occurring as frequently as one in every 1000 bases, contribute to genetic diversity. SNPs, often found in non-coding regions, are now recognized as crucial regulatory elements, influencing gene expression and, consequently, phenotypic traits. For instance, a particular SNP may affect the expression of a gene involved in metabolism, leading to variations in body weight or susceptibility to certain diseases. Thus, SNPs, though seemingly insignificant, play a pivotal role in shaping the complex tapestry of life at a molecular level.

In this paper, we model a microtubule based on its dimer resolution structure. First, the fundamental structural components were studied and then electrostatic potential function for a single monomer was calculated. Subsequently, the potential function inside a single monomer due to a ring of dimers was obtained. Considering the potential due to protofilament-protofilament interaction with a monomer in a B crystal structure of a microtubule, we obtain a double well potential wall. Quantum mechanically the ions can pass through this wall because of the Tunnelling effect. We solve the time independent Schrodinger Equation, calculate the transmission efficiency of ion flow and use the latter in the calculation of ion current density.

In the realm of molecular biology, the intricate dance of DNA replication unfolds. This process, crucial for life, ensures the accurate duplication of genetic information. DNA polymerase, the enzymatic maestro, orchestrates the synthesis of a new DNA strand, complementary to the existing one. Each nucleotide, carefully chosen, is added to the growing chain, each bond formed strengthening the double helix anew. The template strand guides the process, its base pairs dictating the identity of the incoming nucleotides. This dance of DNA replication, a testament to life's intricacy, ensures the perpetuation of genetic information across generations.

The fields of structural biology and soft matter have independently sought out fundamental principles to rationalize protein crystallization. Yet the conceptual differences and the limited overlap between the two disciplines have thus far prevented a comprehensive understanding of the phenomenon to emerge. We conduct a computational study of proteins from the rubredoxin family that bridges the two fields. Using atomistic simulations, we characterize their crystal contacts, and accordingly parameterize patchy particle models. Comparing the phase diagrams of these schematic models with experimental results enables us to critically examine the assumptions behind the two approaches. The study also reveals features of protein-protein interactions that can be leveraged to crystallize proteins more generally.

In the realm of genetics, CRISPR-Cas9 stands as a revolutionary tool, enabling precise editing of DNA sequences. This technology, derived from bacterial immune systems, offers the potential to correct genetic mutations linked to diseases, such as cystic fibrosis and sickle cell anemia. Beyond medicine, CRISPR-Cas9 is also being explored for crop improvement, potentially eradicating hunger by enhancing crop resilience and yield. Moreover, it opens doors to gene drive technologies, allowing specific traits to spread rapidly across species, offering hope for the eradication of invasive species and the control of pests and diseases. However, the ethical implications of such powerful technology demand careful consideration, highlighting the need for international regulation and oversight.

We study theoretically the shapes of biological tubes affected by various pathologies. When epithelial cells grow at an uncontrolled rate, the negative tension produced by their division provokes a buckling instability. Several shapes are investigated : varicose, enlarged, sinusoidal or sausage-like, all of which are found in pathologies of tracheal, renal tubes or arteries. The final shape depends crucially on the mechanical parameters of the tissues : Young modulus, wall-to-lumen ratio, homeostatic pressure. We argue that since tissues must be in quasistatic mechanical equilibrium, abnormal shapes convey information as to what causes the pathology. We calculate a phase diagram of tubular instabilities which could be a helpful guide for investigating the underlying genetic regulation.

In marine biology, the octopus stands out as a fascinating cephalopod. With three hearts, a brain that's larger than any other invertebrate, and the ability to change color and texture for camouflage, it's a testament to nature's ingenuity. Its arms are surprisingly agile, possessing intelligence and dexterity to manipulate objects. Octopuses are also known for their short lifespan and solitary nature, adding a layer of enigma to these intelligent creatures. Furthermore, they are mollusks, not vertebrates, yet they exhibit remarkable cognitive abilities, challenging traditional taxonomic classifications. The octopus, in all its complexity, continues to captivate scientists and the public alike, promising more intriguing discoveries in the realm of cephalopod intelligence.

Existing state-of-the-art methods that take a single RNA sequence and predict the corresponding RNA secondary-structure are thermodynamic methods. These predict the most stable RNA structure, but do not consider the process of structure formation. We have by now ample experimental and theoretical evidence, however, that sequences in vivo fold while being transcribed and that the process of structure formation matters. We here present a conceptually new method for predicting RNA secondary-structure, called CoFold, that combines thermodynamic with kinetic considerations. Our method significantly improves the state-of-art in terms of prediction accuracy, especially for long sequences of more than a thousand nucleotides length such as ribosomal RNAs.

In marine biology, the bioluminescent ocean is a mesmerizing spectacle. This phenomenon occurs when certain marine creatures, like the anglerfish and the dinoflagellates, produce light through a chemical reaction. This light, often a soft, ethereal glow, is a result of a luciferin-luciferase enzymatic reaction, where oxygen and ATP facilitate the conversion of luciferin into oxyluciferin, emitting light in the process. Bioluminescence serves various purposes, including attracting prey, deterring predators, or communication among species. The bioluminescent ocean, illuminated by these living lights, offers a glimpse into a world teeming with life and mystery, deep beneath the surface.

Flowing blood displays a phenomenon called margination, in which leukocytes and platelets are preferentially found near blood vessel walls, while erythrocytes are depleted from these regions. Here margination is investigated using direct hydrodynamic simulations of a binary suspension of stiff (s) and floppy (f) capsules, as well as a stochastic model that incorporates the key particle transport mechanisms in suspensions -- wall-induced hydrodynamic migration and shear-induced pair collisions. The stochastic model allows the relative importance of these two mechanisms to be directly evaluated and thereby indicates that margination, at least in the dilute case, is largely due to the differential dynamics of homogeneous (e.g. s-s) and heterogeneous (s-f) collisions

In the intricate tapestry of life, photosynthesis stands as a cornerstone. This biochemical process, primarily carried out by green plants, algae, and some bacteria, transforms sunlight, carbon dioxide, and water into glucose, a vital energy source, and oxygen, a crucial element for respiration. The process unfolds in two stages: the light-dependent reactions, where sunlight splits water molecules, and the light-independent reactions, also known as the Calvin cycle, where carbon dioxide is converted into glucose. This remarkable process not only sustains life on Earth but also regulates the planet's oxygen levels and carbon cycle, underpinning the delicate balance of our ecosystems.

We studied the curvature-driven roughening of a disk domain pattern with a variable interface window. The relaxation of interface is driven by negative surface tension . When a domain boundary propagates radially at a constant rate, we found that evolution of interface roughness follows scaling dynamic behavior. The local growth exponents are substantially different from the global exponents. Curvature-driven roughening belongs to a new class of anomalous roughening dynamics. However, a different surface tension leads to different global exponents. This is different from that of interface evolution with a fixed-size window, which has universal exponent. The variable growth window leads to a new class of anomalous roughening dynamics.

In the intricate world of botany, the carnivorous Venus flytrap captivates the imagination. This unique plant, native to the wetlands of North and South Carolina, traps insects to supplement its nutrients. Consisting of modified leaves arranged in a circular pattern, the trap snaps shut when an insect triggers sensitive hairs. The trap can open and close up to six times before exhausting its energy. This remarkable adaptation allows the Venus flytrap to thrive in nutrient-poor environments, showcasing nature's ingenious solutions to survival challenges.

We have developed a mathematical model for in-host virus dynamics that includes spatial chemotaxis and diffusion across a two dimensional surface representing the vaginal or rectal epithelium at primary HIV infection. A linear stability analysis of the steady state solutions identified conditions for Turing instability pattern formation. We have solved the model equations numerically using parameter values obtained from previous experimental results for HIV infections. Simulations of the model for this surface show hot spots of infection. Understanding this localization is an important step in the ability to correctly model early HIV infection. These spatial variations also have implications for the development and effectiveness of microbicides against HIV.

In the realm of genetics, a fascinating subject of study is the epigenetic modifications that influence gene expression without altering the DNA sequence itself. These modifications, such as DNA methylation and histone modification, play crucial roles in regulating gene activity, often in response to environmental factors. For instance, during development, epigenetic changes dictate the transformation of a single fertilized egg into a complex organism with specialized cells. Similarly, exposure to toxins, diet, or stress can induce epigenetic changes that may increase the risk of diseases like cancer or neurodegenerative disorders. Thus, understanding epigenetics provides valuable insights into hereditary traits and disease susceptibility, opening doors for potential therapeutic approaches that target these modifications rather than the genes themselves.

Using a network representation for real soil samples and mathematical models for microbial spread, we show that the structural heterogeneity of the soil habitat may have a very significant influence on the size of microbial invasions of the soil pore space. In particular, neglecting the soil structural heterogeneity may lead to a substantial underestimation of microbial invasion. Such effects are explained in terms of a crucial interplay between heterogeneity in microbial spread and heterogeneity in the topology of soil networks. The main influence of network topology on invasion is linked to the existence of long channels in soil networks that may act as bridges for transmission of microorganisms between distant parts of soil.

In the intricate tapestry of life, photosynthesis stands as a pivotal process, powering the planet's ecosystems. This biochemical miracle, performed by green plants, algae, and certain bacteria, transforms sunlight, carbon dioxide, and water into glucose and oxygen. Photosynthesis not only fuels the growth and survival of these organisms but also sustains the world's diverse fauna by producing the oxygen they breathe. Furthermore, it sequesters carbon dioxide, mitigating its harmful effects on the atmosphere and playing a crucial role in regulating climate. The process of photosynthesis, therefore, serves as a vital bridge between Earth's energy source (sunlight) and the food web that supports life on our planet.

The scaling of transient times to zero-lag synchronization in networks composed of excitable units is shown to be governed by three features of the graph representing the network: the longest path between pairs of neurons (diameter), the largest loop (circumference) and the loop with the maximal average out degree. The upper bound of transient times can vary between O(1) and O(N2), where N is the size of the network, and its scaling can be predicted in many scenarios from finite time accumulated information of the transient. Results challenge the assumption that functionality of neural networks might depend solely upon the synchronized repeated activation such as zero-lag synchronization.

In the intricate world of genetics, a single base pair mutation can have profound effects on an organism. For instance, the sickle cell trait, a genetic variation in the beta-globin gene, provides some resistance against malaria but can lead to health complications. This illustrates the delicate balance between genetic variations and their consequences. On the other hand, polygenic inheritance, the transmission of traits influenced by multiple genes, adds complexity. Consider the variation in human height, which is influenced by numerous genes, each contributing a small effect, highlighting the interplay of multiple factors in determining an organism's traits. These examples underscore the intricate dance of genetics, where slight alterations can lead to significant differences, and where understanding the intricacies can shed light on diseases and potentially pave the way for targeted treatments.

Combining extensive molecular dynamics simulations of lipid bilayer systems of varying chemical composition with single-trajectory analyses we systematically elucidate the stochastic nature of the lipid motion. We observe subdiffusion over more than four orders of magnitude in time, clearly stretching into the sub-microsecond domain. The lipid motion delicately depends on the lipid chemistry, the lipid phase, and especially on the presence of cholesterol. We demonstrate that fractional Langevin equation motion universally describes the lipid motion in all phases including the gel phase, and in the presence of cholesterol. The results underline the relevance of anomalous diffusion in lipid bilayers and the strong effects of the membrane composition.

Diving deeper into genetics, the mystery of genetic expression unfolds. Genes, the basic units of heredity, are segments of DNA that carry instructions for protein synthesis. However, not all genes are expressed at the same time or in the same cells. This selective expression, known as gene regulation, is crucial for the development and functioning of an organism. Environmental factors, epigenetic modifications, and transcription factors play pivotal roles in determining which genes are expressed, thus influencing traits and behaviors. Furthermore, the study of epigenetics uncovers additional layers of genetic complexity, revealing that the same DNA sequence can lead to different outcomes in different individuals, underlining the intricate dance of nature and nurture.

In a multicellular organism different cell types express a gene in different amounts. Samples from which gene expression levels can be measured typically contain a mixture of different cell types, the resulting measurements thus give only averages over the different cell types present. Based on fluctuations in the mixture proportions from sample to sample it is in principle possible to reconstruct the underlying expression levels of each cell type: to deconvolute the sample. We use a statistical mechanics approach to the problem of deconvoluting such partial concentrations from mixed samples, give analytical results for when and how well samples can be unmixed, and suggest an algorithm for sample deconvolution.

In the realm of genetics, the concept of epigenetics emerges as a significant player. It enlightens us on the layers of complexity beyond DNA sequences. Epigenetics involves modifications like methylation and acetylation, which influence gene expression without changing the actual DNA code. These modifications, often affected by environmental factors, can be passed down from cell to cell, and in some instances, even across generations. This dynamic interplay between genes and environment sheds light on the intricate mechanisms behind hereditary traits and the potential for nurture to shape nature. Epigenetics, thus, offers promising avenues for understanding and potentially influencing the development of diseases and traits, bridging the gap between genetics and lifestyle factors.

In this essay we elaborate on recent evidence demonstrating the presence of a second order phase transition in human brain dynamics and discuss its consequences for theoretical approaches to brain function. We review early evidence of criticality in brain dynamics at different spatial and temporal scales, and we stress how it was necessary to unify concepts and analysis techniques across scales to introduce the adequate order and control parameters which define the transition. A discussion on the relation between structural vs. dynamical complexity exposes future steps to understand the dynamics of the connectome (structure) from which emerges the cognitome (function).

In the captivating world of marine biology, the bioluminescent jellyfish illuminate the deep-sea abyss. These gelatinous wonders, such as the Aequorea victoria, emit a soft, ethereal glow, a result of a complex protein called green fluorescent protein (GFP). This protein, when excited by blue light, emits a greenish hue, serving as a natural light source in the darkness of the ocean depths. This phenomenon is not merely a visual spectacle. it also plays a crucial role in the jellyfish's survival, as it can confuse predators or attract prey. The bioluminescent jellyfish, with their enchanting glow and intriguing adaptations, continue to fascinate scientists and viewers alike, offering a glimpse into the extraordinary diversity of life in our oceans.

We introduce a system of light driven microscopic autonomous moving particles that move on a flat surface. The design is simple, yet effective: Micrometer sized objects with wedge shape are produced by photopolymerization, they are covered with a reflective surface. When the area of motion is illuminated perpendicularly from above, the light is deflected to the side by the wedge shaped objects, in the direction determined by the position and orientation of the particles. The momentum change during reflection provides the driving force for an effectively autonomous motion. The system is an efficient tool to study self propelled microscopic robots.

In the intricate realm of biology, photosynthesis stands as a cornerstone process, sustaining life on Earth. This miraculous biochemical reaction, performed primarily by green plants, algae, and certain bacteria, converts sunlight, carbon dioxide, and water into glucose and oxygen. Through a series of complex reactions, chlorophyll, the green pigment found in chloroplasts, absorbs light energy, catalyzing the production of ATP and NADPH. These energy carriers drive the reduction of carbon dioxide to glucose, releasing oxygen as a byproduct. This vital cycle not only fuels plant growth but also oxygenates the atmosphere, making Earth habitable for diverse forms of life.

We introduce a system for experimental evolution consisting of populations of short oligonucleotides (Oli populations) evolving in a modified quantitative Polymerase Chain Reaction (qPCR). It is tractable at the genetic, genomic, phenotypic and fitness levels. The Oli system uses DNA hairpins designed to form structures that self-prime under defined conditions. Selection acts on the phenotype of self-priming, after which differences in fitness are amplified and quantified using qPCR. We outline the methodological and bioinformatics tools for the Oli system here, and demonstrate that it can be used as a conventional experimental evolution model system by test-driving it in an experiment investigating adaptive evolution under different rates of environmental change.

In the intricate world of genetics, a fascinating phenomenon known as genetic recombination unfolds. During sexual reproduction, the pairing of homologous chromosomes results in this process. Genetic recombination occurs when segments of genetic material are exchanged between the parent chromosomes, generating genetic diversity in offspring. This exchange occurs in the form of crossover events during prophase I of meiosis, where the four chromatids align and exchange segments. In essence, genetic recombination is the engine of evolution, ensuring the survival and adaptability of species by producing offspring with unique genetic combinations, a testament to nature's ingenious design for promoting diversity and resilience.

Invasion waves are a fundamental building block of theoretical ecology. In this study we aim to take the first steps to link propagation failure and fast acceleration of traveling waves to critical transitions (or tipping points). The approach is based upon a detailed numerical study of various versions of the Fisher-Kolmogorov-Petrovskii-Piscounov (FKPP) equation. The main motivation of this work is to contribute to the following question: how much information do statistics, collected by a stationary observer, contain about the speed and bifurcations of traveling waves? We suggest warning signs based upon closeness to carrying capacity, second-order moments and transients of localized initial invasions.

In the intricate realm of genetics, the concept of epigenetics sheds light on a fascinating layer of biological regulation. Epigenetics, quite simply, refers to changes in gene expression that do not involve alterations to the DNA sequence itself. Instead, these modifications occur at the molecular level, through chemical tags that switch genes on or off, responding to various environmental factors. Epigenetic changes can influence traits such as aging, cancer development, and susceptibility to diseases, offering insights into potential avenues for prevention and treatment. This dynamic interplay between genes and environment underscores the complexity and adaptability of life at its most fundamental level.

We investigate the microtubule polymerization dynamics with catastrophe and rescue events for three different confinement scenarios, which mimic typical cellular environments: (i) The microtubule is confined by rigid and fixed walls, (ii) it grows under constant force, and (iii) it grows against an elastic obstacle with a linearly increasing force. We use realistic catastrophe models and analyze the microtubule dynamics, the resulting microtubule length distributions, and force generation by stochastic and mean field calculations. in addition, we perform stochastic simulations. We also investigate the force dynamics if growth parameters are perturbed in dilution experiments. Finally, we show the robustness of our results against changes of catastrophe models and load distribution factors.

In the realm of cellular biology, mitochondria, often dubbed the powerhouses of the cell, play a pivotal role. These organelles generate ATP, the primary energy currency, through a process known as oxidative phosphorylation. This intricate process occurs inside the inner mitochondrial membrane, where a series of proteins, collectively known as complexes, work in harmony to harness chemical energy stored in nutrients and convert it into ATP. The structure of mitochondria reflects this function, with a double membrane and cristae, which increase the surface area for energy production. Mutations in mitochondrial DNA can lead to a variety of diseases, highlighting their importance in maintaining cellular health.

We report the imaging of tendon, a connective tissue rich in collagen type I proteins, with Interferometric Second Harmonic Generation (I-SHG) microscopy. We observed that the noncentrosymmetric structural organization can be maintained along the fibrillar axis over more than 150 {\mu}m, while in the transverse direction it is ~1-15 {\mu}m. Those results are explained by modeling tendon as a heterogeneous distribution of noncentrosymmetric nanocylinders (collagen fibrils) oriented along the fibrillar axis. The preservation of the noncentrosymmetric structural organization over multiple tens of microns reveals that tendon is made of domains in which the fraction occupied by fibrils oriented in one direction is larger than in the other.

In the realm of cellular biology, mitochondria, often dubbed as the powerhouses of the cell, play a pivotal role in energy production through a process known as cellular respiration. These organelles absorb nutrients from the cell's cytoplasm, converting them into ATP (adenosine triphosphate), the universal energy currency of the cell. Mitochondria also play a crucial role in cell signaling, apoptosis (programmed cell death), and even in regulating the cell's response to oxidative stress. Interestingly, mitochondria have their own DNA, separate from the nucleus, hinting at an intriguing evolutionary history where these organelles may have originated as free-living bacteria that were engulfed by early eukaryotic cells.

Calcium dynamics is the highly responsible for intracellular electrical (action potential) and chemical (neurotransmitter) signaling in neuron cell. The Mathematical modeling of calcium dynamics in neurons lead to the reaction diffusion equation which involves the parameters like diffusion coefficient, free calcium, bound calcium, buffers and bound buffer. Here the parameters like receptors, serca and leak are also incorporated in the model. Appropriate boundary conditions have been framed based on biophysical conditions of the problem. The finite volume method has been employed to obtain the solution. The computer program has been developed using MATLAB 7.11 for the entire problem to compute Ca2+ profiles and study the relationships among various parameters.

In the realm of genetic engineering, CRISPR-Cas9 has revolutionized the scientific landscape. This innovative tool, derived from bacterial immune systems, allows precise modifications to DNA sequences. By targeting specific genetic mutations, it offers the potential to correct inherited diseases, enhance crop resistance to pests, and even combat antibiotic-resistant bacteria. This technology, however, raises ethical questions about genetic manipulation, the potential for designer babies, and the long-term effects on biological diversity. As we navigate this promising yet complex territory, it's crucial to balance the benefits with responsible use and rigorous ethical considerations.

Mechanical forces such as fluid shear have been shown to enhance cell growth and differentiation, but knowledge of their mechanistic effect on cells is limited because the local flow patterns and associated metrics are not precisely known. Here we present real-time, noninvasive measures of local hydrodynamics in 3D biomaterials based on nuclear magnetic resonance. Microflow maps were further used to derive pressure, shear and fluid permeability fields. Finally, remodeling of collagen gels in response to precise fluid flow parameters was correlated with structural changes. It is anticipated that accurate flow maps within 3D matrices will be a critical step towards understanding cell behavior in response to controlled flow dynamics.

In the intricate realm of genetics, the mutation of genes plays a pivotal role in evolution and disease. A mutation is an alteration in a gene's sequence, which can be caused by various factors such as errors during DNA replication, exposure to mutagenic agents, or radiation. These changes can result in the production of abnormal or nonfunctional proteins. Some mutations are harmless, while others can have profound effects on an organism, leading to genetic disorders or increased susceptibility to diseases. Conversely, beneficial mutations can lead to adaptations that enhance survival, driving the process of evolution. The study of mutations offers invaluable insights into our understanding of heredity, genetic disorders, and the origin of species.

We investigate the relationship between communication and search efficiency in a biological context by proposing a model of Brownian searchers with long-range pairwise interaction. After a general study of the properties of the model, we show an application to the particular case of acoustic communication among Mongolian gazelle, for which data are available, searching for good habitat areas. Using Monte Carlo simulations and density equations, our results point out that the search is optimal (i.e. the mean first hitting time among searchers is minimum) at intermediate scales of communication, showing that both an excess and a lack of information may worsen it.

In marine biology, the bioluminescent squid, or 'firefly squid', exhibits an extraordinary display of light. This small, elusive cephalopod dwells in the deep sea, using its light-producing organs, or photophores, to communicate, confuse predators, and attract prey. The squid's light emission is generated by a chemical reaction within the photophores, which involve a protein called 'aequorin' and the calcium-binding protein 'green fluorescent protein' (GFP). These proteins, when stimulated, emit a blue-green light that contributes to the squid's mesmerizing display, shedding light on the marvels of bioluminescence in the deep sea.

Genetic redundancy is ubiquitous and can be found in any organism. However, it has been argued that genetic redundancy reduces total population fitness, and therefore, redundancy is unlikely to evolve. In this letter, we study an evolutionary model with high-dimensional genotype-phenotype mapping (GPM) to investigate the relevance of complexity in GPM to the evolution of genetic redundancy. By applying the replica method to deal with quenched randomness, the redundancy dependence of the fitness is analytically obtained, which demonstrates that genetic redundancy can indeed evolve, provided that the GPM is complex. Our result provides a novel insight into how genetic redundancy evolves.

In marine ecosystems, the giant kelp (Macrocystis pyrifera) plays a pivotal role. This colossal brown seaweed, often reaching heights of up to 165 feet, thrives in nutrient-rich, cold waters. It forms vast underwater forests that provide shelter and food for an array of marine life, from tiny shrimp to mammoth sea otters. The kelp forest's intricate structure also serves as a nursery for fish, helping to maintain biodiversity. Furthermore, this seaweed absorbs carbon dioxide, making it a crucial component in the fight against climate change. However, overfishing and anthropogenic activities threaten these underwater forests, underscoring the need for conservation efforts to preserve the delicate balance of our oceans.

In this letter, we present an original demonstration of an associative learning neural network inspired by the famous Pavlov's dogs experiment. A single nanoparticle organic memory field effect transistor (NOMFET) is used to implement each synapse. We show how the physical properties of this dynamic memristive device can be used to perform low power write operations for the learning and implement short-term association using temporal coding and spike timing dependent plasticity based learning. An electronic circuit was built to validate the proposed learning scheme with packaged devices, with good reproducibility despite the complex synaptic-like dynamic of the NOMFET in pulse regime.

In the realm of genetics, CRISPR-Cas9 technology is revolutionizing our ability to manipulate DNA sequences. This powerful tool allows precise editing of gene structures, opening doors for extensive research and potential treatments in numerous fields, such as agriculture, medicine, and biotechnology. By employing short RNA sequences to find and cut specific DNA sites, scientists can insert, delete, or alter segments of DNA with remarkable accuracy. This breakthrough technology offers hope for the eradication of genetic diseases, development of crop resistance to pests, and advancement of scientific understanding of the building blocks of life. The future of genetics is undeniably intertwined with the potential of CRISPR-Cas9.

The distribution of Red Blood Cells in a confined channel flow is inhomogeneous and shows a marked depletion near the walls due to a competition between migration away from the walls and shear-induced diffusion resulting from interactions between particles. We investigated the lift of RBCs in a shear flow near a wall and measured a significant lift velocity despite the tumbling motion of cells. We also provide values for the collective and anisotropic shear-induced diffusion of a cloud of RBCs, both in the direction of shear and in the direction of vorticity. A generic down-gradient subdiffusion characterized by an exponent 1/3 is highlighted.

In the intricate tapestry of life, symbiosis emerges as a captivating phenomenon. This mutualistic relationship, often observed between diverse species, exemplifies nature's balance. For instance, consider the relationship between coral polyps and algae, known as zooxanthellae. Corals provide the algae with a safe haven and essential nutrients, while the algae convert sunlight into energy through photosynthesis, providing the coral with vital sugars and oxygen. This symbiotic partnership supports the vibrant, complex coral reef ecosystems, teeming with life. Similarly, the relationship between termites and protozoa in their digestive systems allows termites to break down cellulose, aiding their survival in wooded environments. Such symbiotic relationships underscore the interconnectedness of life on our planet, highlighting the intricate web of dependencies that sustain diverse ecosystems.

The application of newly developed first-principle modeling techniques to liquid water deepens our understanding of the microscopic origins of its unusual macroscopic properties and behaviour. Here, we review two novel ab initio computational methods: second-generation Car-Parrinello molecular dynamics and decomposition analysis based on absolutely localized molecular orbitals. We show that these two methods in combination not only enable ab initio molecular dynamics simulations on previously inaccessible time and length scales, but also provide unprecedented insights into the nature of hydrogen bonding between water molecules. We discuss recent applications of these methods to water clusters and bulk water.

In the realm of genetic diversity, the study of centromeres, the constriction regions on chromosomes essential for cell division, offers fascinating insights. Centromeres, though devoid of genes, are rich in repetitive DNA sequences, making them challenging to study. Yet, they play a crucial role in ensuring accurate segregation of chromosomes during cell division, a process vital to life. Variations in centromere structure and function contribute to genetic differences among species, highlighting their significant role in evolution. The intricate dance of chromosomes, choreographed by centromeres, orchestrates the symphony of life, subtly weaving the threads of diversity among organisms.

Left- and right-handed helical modes' statistical absolute equilibria appear \textit{separately}. If both chiral sectors present, one can dominate around its positive pole, which is relevant to the nearly maximally helical (force free for magnetic field) states of turbulence. Pure magnetodynamics (PMD, or electron magnetohydrodynamics --- EMHD), pure hydrodynamics (PHD), and, single-fluid and two-fluid MHDs are studied. Relevant documented data and issues of cascade properties, and, helical and nonhelical dynamos are revisited. We also discuss new scenarios, such as PMD inverse magnetic helicity and forward energy cascades, and, the continuous transition from completely-inverse to partly-inverse-and-partly-forward and to completely-forward energy transfers in PHD.

In marine biology, the bioluminescent squid, known as the Dumbo Octopus, exhibits an extraordinary display of light. Living at depths of over 600 meters, this soft-bodied cephalopod utilizes bioluminescent organs called photophores to communicate and camouflage in the dark abyssal environment. The light emitted is a result of a chemical reaction within the photophores, where the enzyme luciferin reacts with oxygen in the presence of the enzyme luciferase, producing light energy. This fascinating creature, with its large ear-like fins and bioluminescent abilities, continues to captivate scientists and inspire curiosity about the depths of our oceans.

We study colonies of non-motile, rod-shaped bacteria growing on solid substrates. In our model, bacteria interact purely mechanically, by pushing each other away as they grow, and consume a diffusing nutrient. We show that mechanical interactions control the velocity and shape of the advancing front, which leads to features that cannot be captured by established Fisher-Kolmogorov models. In particular, we find that the velocity depends on the elastic modulus of bacteria or their stickiness to the surface. Interestingly, we predict that the radius of an incompressible, strictly two-dimensional colony cannot grow linearly in time. Importantly, mechanical interactions can also account for the nonequilibrium transition between circular and branching colonies, often observed in the lab.

In the intricate world of genetics, a single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) can significantly alter an organism's traits. These minute variations in DNA sequence, often found within genes, can influence everything from eye color in humans to resistance to diseases in plants. SNPs, when analyzed in large populations, offer invaluable insights into genetic diversity, evolution, and the basis of heritable disorders. The Human Genome Project, completed in 2003, identified millions of these SNPs, paving the way for precision medicine, personalized diagnostics, and enhanced understanding of our genetic blueprint.

We have considered as a theoretical possibility for the development of a nanobiochip the operation principle of which is based on measuring conductance in single-stranded and double-stranded DNA. Calculations have demonstrated that in the majority of cases the conductance of double-stranded nucleotides considerably exceeds that of single-stranded ones. The results obtained are in agreement with recent experiments on measuring the oligonucleotide conductance. It has been shown that an electronic biochip containing 11 nucleotide pairs will recognize approximately 97% sequences. It has also been demonstrated that the percentage of identifiable sequences will grow with the sequence length.

In marine biology, the bioluminescent squid, known as the firefly squid, captivates scientists with its mesmerizing light displays. This cephalopod, found in the deep seas off the coast of Japan and New Zealand, emits a radiant blue glow from its fins and tentacles. The light is produced by a chemical reaction within specialized cells called photophores, which are filled with a bioluminescent protein called aequorin. This unique ability serves multiple purposes. the squid uses it to communicate, attract prey, and evade predators by blending into the dark environment or creating a distraction. The firefly squid's intricate light patterns reveal a complex social life, offering exciting insights into the mysterious world of deep-sea creatures.

RNAs are negatively charged molecules residing in macromolecular crowding cellular environments. Macromolecular confinement can influence the ion effects in RNA folding. In this work, using the recently developed tightly bound ion model for ion fluctuation and correlation, we investigate the confinement effect on the ion-mediated RNA structural collapse for a simple model system. We found that, for both Na$^+$ and Mg$^{2+}$, ion efficiencies in mediating structural collapse/folding are significantly enhanced by the structural confinement. Such an enhancement in the ion efficiency is attributed to the decreased electrostatic free energy difference between the compact conformation ensemble and the (restricted) extended conformation ensemble due to the spatial restriction.

In the intricate world of genetics, the concept of epigenetics emerges as a significant player. Epigenetics, a layer atop DNA, alterations in gene expression without changes in the DNA sequence itself, provides a dynamic landscape for biological functions. This phenomenon, influenced by factors such as environment, age, and lifestyle, can potentially explain why identical twins may develop distinct traits. It underscores the complexity of our genetic makeup, suggesting that nature and nurture are not mutually exclusive but intertwined, shaping our unique biological journeys. Epigenetic modifications, while reversible, have profound implications for our understanding of heredity, health, and disease.

In this work we propose a model for gene expression based on the theory of random dynamical systems (RDS) and show that it has a "modularity property" in the following sense: given any collection of genes that are linked in a transcriptional network, if each of them is individually described by a certain class of RDS then there is a natural, and essentially unique, prescription for coupling them together, respecting the network topology, in such a way that the collective system formed by all genes is a RDS as well. Moreover, the class of RDS used to describe the individual genes is flexible enough to account for a wide range of stochastic behaviors within the realm of stationary processes.

In the realm of genetics, a fascinating concept is gene expression. This process, a dance of DNA and proteins, governs how an organism's genes are "read" and translated into functional proteins. It's a complex interplay of various factors, including the structure of the DNA, the presence of regulatory elements, and the cellular environment. Environmental factors can also influence gene expression, a phenomenon known as epigenetics, which adds a layer of complexity to our understanding of heredity. This dynamic interplay between genes and their environment underscores the intricate symphony that is life, a symphony that, even in its most minute details, holds the key to understanding our existence.

We apply formal measures of emergence, self-organization, homeostasis, autopoiesis and complexity to an aquatic ecosystem. in particular to the physiochemical component of an Arctic lake. These measures are based on information theory. Variables with an homogeneous distribution have higher values of emergence, while variables with a more heterogeneous distribution have a higher self-organization. Variables with a high complexity reflect a balance between change (emergence) and regularity/order (self-organization). In addition, homeostasis values coincide with the variation of the winter and summer seasons. Autopoiesis values show a higher degree of independence of biological components over their environment. Our approach shows how the ecological dynamics can be described in terms of information.

In marine biology, the bioluminescent squid, or Dinoflagellates, display a fascinating spectacle. These deep-sea dwellers emit a soft glow, harnessing chemical reactions within their bodies to produce light. This luminescence serves multiple purposes, including attracting prey, warding off predators, and facilitating communication among individuals. The glow, while seemingly magical, is a testament to the incredible adaptations that allow these creatures to thrive in the inky blackness of the deep ocean. Their light is not just captivating to human eyes, but also plays a crucial role in the complex ecosystems of the abyssal depths.

The perceived pitch of a complex harmonic sound changes if the partials of the sound are frequency-shifted by a fixed amount. Simple mathematical rules that the perceived pitch could be expected to follow ('first pitch-shift') are violated in psychoacoustic experiments ('second pitchshift'). For this, commonly cognitive cortical processes were held responsible. Here, we show that human pitch perception can be reproduced from a minimal, purely biophysical, model of the cochlea, by fully recovering the psychoacoustical pitch-shift data of G.F. Smoorenburg (1970) and related physiological measurements from the cat cochlear nucleus. For this to happen, the cochlear fluid plays a distinguished role.

In the intricate dance of life, photosynthesis stands as a pivotal ballet, orchestrated by green plant life. Through this process, carbon dioxide, water, and sunlight blend harmoniously to produce glucose and oxygen, the essence of life and the air we breathe. Chlorophyll, the green pigment in plants, captures sunlight, converting it into energy. This energy fuels the splitting of water molecules, releasing hydrogen and oxygen. The oxygen is released into the atmosphere, while the carbon dioxide is absorbed and transformed into glucose, a simple sugar that powers plant growth and serves as a foundation for food chains. Photosynthesis, therefore, links the realm of plants to the survival of all life forms on Earth, reaffirming the interconnectedness of our planet's ecosystems.

The entropic effects of anchored polymers on biomembranes are studied using simulations of a meshless membrane model combined with anchored linear polymer chains. The bending rigidity and spontaneous curvature are investigated for anchored ideal and excluded-volume polymer chains. Our results are in good agreement with the previous theoretical predictions. It is found that the polymer reduces the line tension of membrane edges, as well as the interfacial line tension between membrane domains, leading to microdomain formation. Instead of the mixing of two phases as observed in typical binary fluids, densely anchored polymers stabilize small domains. A mean field theory is proposed for the edge line tension reduced by anchored ideal chains, which reproduces our simulation results well.

In the realm of genetics, the concept of epigenetics emerges, a fascinating study that explores changes in gene expression without altering the DNA sequence itself. These modifications, primarily due to environmental factors, can be inherited, thus impacting our health and behavior across generations. Methylation, a key epigenetic process, involves adding a methyl group to DNA or its associated histones, thereby repressing or activating gene expression. This complex interplay between nature and nurture offers a new lens through which we can understand and potentially manipulate heritable traits, opening doors for novel therapeutic approaches and a deeper appreciation of our genetic legacy.

The prevalence of long-lasting oscillatory signals in the 2d echo-spectroscopy of light-harvesting complexes has led to a search for possible mechanisms. We investigate how two causes of oscillatory signals are intertwined: (i) electronic coherences supporting delocalized wave-like motion, and (ii) narrow bands in the vibronic spectral density. To disentangle the vibronic and electronic contributions we introduce a time-windowed Fourier transform of the signal amplitude. We find that 2d spectra can be dominated by excitations of pathways which are absent in excitonic energy transport. This leads to an underestimation of the life-time of electronic coherences by 2d spectra.

In the intricate tapestry of life, photosynthesis plays a pivotal role, transforming sunlight's energy into chemical energy, fueling the Earth's biosphere. This process, primarily carried out by plants, algae, and some bacteria, involves the absorption of carbon dioxide and water, which are then converted into glucose and oxygen. This symphony of chemical reactions not only sustains the producers in the food chain but also provides the oxygen we breathe, making photosynthesis an indispensable life-sustaining process on our planet.

Polypeptides can self-assemble into hierarchically organized fibrils consisting of a stack of individually folded polypeptides driven together by hydrophobic interaction. Using a coarse grained model, we systematically studied this self-assembly as a function of temperature and hydrophobicity of the residues on the outside of the building block. We find the self-assembly can occur via two different pathways - a random aggregation-folding route, and a templated-folding process - thus indicating a strong coupling between folding and assembly. The simulation results can explain experimental evidence that assembly through stacking of folded building blocks is rarely observed, at the experimental concentrations. The model thus provides a generic picture of hierarchical fibril formation.

In the realm of microbiology, the study of Archaea reveals fascinating insights. These single-celled organisms, distinct from Bacteria and Eukaryotes, thrive in extreme environments such as hot springs, deep-sea vents, and salt lakes. Archaea display unique cellular structures and genetic characteristics, challenging the traditional tree of life model. Their cell walls lack peptidoglycan, and they employ lipids with isoprenoid chains to maintain structural integrity. Moreover, Archaea exhibit DNA replication strategies divergent from Bacteria and Eukaryotes, further highlighting their evolutionary distinctiveness. This microscopic life form, once a mere curiosity, now offers a wealth of knowledge about the origins of life and the adaptability of organisms under harsh conditions.

To function as gene regulatory elements in response to environmental signals, riboswitches must adopt specific secondary structures on appropriate time scales. We employ kinetic Monte Carlo simulation to model the time-dependent folding during transcription of TPP riboswitch expression platforms. According to our simulations, riboswitch transcriptional terminators, which must adopt a specific hairpin configuration by the time they have been transcribed, fold with higher efficiency than Shine-Dalgarno sequesterers, whose proper structure is required only at the time of ribosomal binding. Our findings suggest both that riboswitch transcriptional terminator sequences have been naturally selected for high folding efficiency, and that sequesterers can maintain their function even in the presence of significant misfolding.

In the realm of genetics, the CRISPR-Cas9 system stands as a revolutionary tool, offering a precise and efficient method for editing DNA. This technology, derived from bacterial immune systems, allows scientists to target specific genes, correct genetic mutations, and even modify gene functions. The potential applications are vast, ranging from treating genetic diseases to enhancing crops for global food security. However, ethical considerations surrounding human gene editing remain a contentious issue, necessitating rigorous debate and careful regulation. As we delve deeper into the fascinating world of genetic engineering, the line between treatment and design becomes increasingly blurred, forcing us to reevaluate our moral and philosophical perspectives on the nature of humanity itself.

In previous works, the author and collaborators establish a mathematical model for injury response in articular cartilage. In this paper we use mathematical software and computational techniques, applied to an existing model to explore in more detail how the behavior of cartilage cells is influenced by several of, what are believed to be, the most significant mechanisms underlying cartilage injury response at the cellular level. We introduce a control parameter, the radius of attenuation, and present some new simulations that shed light on how inflammation associated with cartilage injuries impacts the metabolic activity of cartilage cells. The details presented in the work can help to elucidate targets for more effective therapies in the preventative treatment of post-traumatic osteoarthritis.

In the realm of genetics, a fascinating study revolves around epigenetics, an emerging field that delves into the modifications of gene expression without altering the DNA sequence itself. These modifications, primarily through methylation and acetylation, can be influenced by factors such as age, environment, lifestyle, and disease states. Epigenetic changes are crucial in regulating crucial biological processes, like cell differentiation and development, and are even linked to the transmission of learned behaviors in certain species. This dynamic interplay between gene, environment, and time opens up a world of possibilities for understanding complex traits and diseases, potentially leading to novel therapeutic strategies beyond traditional genetic approaches.

We study the average asymptotic growth rate of cells in randomly fluctuating environments, with multiple viable phenotypes per environment. We show that any information processing strategy has an asymptotic growth rate, which is the sum of: (i) the maximal growth rate at the worst possible distribution of environments, (ii) relative information between the actual distribution of environments to the worst one, and (iii) information utilization rate, which is the information rate of the sensory devices minus the "information dissipation rate", the amount of information not utilized by the cell for growth. In non-stationary environments, we find that the optimal phenotypic switching times equally partition the information dissipation rate between consecutive switching intervals.

In the captivating realm of biology, symbiosis, a delicate dance between different species, holds center stage. This intricate relationship, harmonious yet complex, benefits both parties. For instance, consider the relationship between coral and algae. Corals, stationary and dependent on a fixed location, host photosynthetic algae, zooxanthellae, within their tissues. The algae thrive on the coral's nutrient-rich environment while providing the coral with life-sustaining energy through photosynthesis. This mutualistic symbiosis enables the vibrant coral reefs to flourish, serving as vital habitats for countless marine species, thereby maintaining biodiversity and bolstering ecosystem stability. However, this delicate balance can be disrupted by environmental changes, such as ocean acidification and rising temperatures, threatening the very existence of these magnificent underwater metropolises.

Regular vegetation patterns in semiarid ecosystems are believed to arise from the interplay between long-range competition and facilitation processes acting at smaller distances. We show that, under rather general conditions, long-range competition alone may be enough to shape these patterns. To this end we propose a simple, general model for the dynamics of vegetation, which includes only long-range competition between plants. Competition is introduced through a nonlocal term, where the kernel function quantifies the intensity of the interaction. We recover the full spectrum of spatial structures typical of vegetation models that also account for facilitation in addition to competition.

In the realm of genetics, a fascinating study revolves around epigenetics, a field that explores changes in organisms caused by modification of gene expression rather than alteration of the genetic code itself. These modifications, primarily DNA methylation and histone modification, play a crucial role in cellular processes, influencing gene activity without changing the DNA sequence. Epigenetic changes can be influenced by factors such as age, environment, lifestyle, and disease state, offering a promising new avenue for understanding complex traits and diseases, including cancer and neurodegenerative disorders. This burgeoning field promises to revolutionize our understanding of heredity and health, bridging the gap between nature and nurture.

We present an experimentally guided, bi-phasic, multi-species ionic gel model to compare and make quantitative predictions on the viscoelastic properties of healthy mucus versus Cystic-Fibrosis infected mucus. The mixture theory consists of the mucus (polymer phase) and water (solvent phase) as well as several different ions: H$^+$, Na$^+$, Cl$^-$ and Ca$^{2+}$. The model is calibrated with the experimental data of mucus diffusivities. Numerical studies reveal that the Donnan forces are the dominating mechanism driving the mucus swelling/deswelling transition. However, these transitions could be continuous or discontinuous, depending on the complex interplay between ionic bath concentrations, pH, polymer mass in the solvent and the average charge per monomer.

In marine ecosystems, the role of plankton, that tiny, drifting life form, is pivotal. Plankton, comprising phytoplankton (algae) and zooplankton (small animals), form the foundation of the oceanic food web. Photosynthetic phytoplankton convert sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide into energy through photosynthesis, providing oxygen and food for organisms at higher trophic levels. Zooplankton feed on phytoplankton, serving as food for larger marine life such as fish and krill. This delicate balance supports diverse marine biodiversity, offering valuable ecosystem services including carbon sequestration and nutrient cycling. Threats to plankton populations, such as ocean warming, acidification, and pollution, could disrupt this intricate, interconnected system, potentially disrupting the health of marine ecosystems globally.

The structural and dynamical properties of suspensions of self-propelled Brownian particles of spherical shape are investigated in three spatial dimensions. Our simulations reveal a phase separation into a dilute and a dense phase, above a certain density and strength of self-propulsion. The packing fraction of the dense phase approaches random close packing at high activity, yet the system remains fluid. Although no alignment mechanism exists in this model, we find long-lived cooperative motion of the particles in the dense regime. This behavior is probably due to an interface-induced sorting process. Spatial displacement correlation functions are nearly scale-free for systems with densities close to or above the glass transition density of passive systems.

In the intricate tapestry of life, photosynthesis plays a pivotal role. This biochemical process, carried out by plants, algae, and certain bacteria, is the primary source of energy for life on Earth. Utilizing sunlight, carbon dioxide, and water, these organisms convert these elements into glucose and oxygen, a testament to nature's extraordinary efficiency. Photosynthesis not only fuels life on our planet but also regulates the atmosphere by absorbing carbon dioxide and releasing oxygen, thus maintaining a delicate balance crucial for survival. This process, a symphony of chemistry and light, is a testament to the complex beauty hidden within the smallest of organisms.

In bacteria, regulatory proteins search for a specific DNA binding target via "facilitated diffusion": a series of rounds of 3D diffusion in the cytoplasm, and 1D linear diffusion along the DNA contour. Using large scale Brownian dynamics simulations we find that each of these steps is affected differently by crowding proteins, which can either be bound to the DNA acting as a road block to the 1D diffusion, or freely diffusing in the cytoplasm. Macromolecular crowding can strongly affect mechanistic features such as the balance between 3D and 1D diffusion, but leads to surprising robustness of the total search time.

In the intricate world of marine biology, the bioluminescent squid, a spectral marvel, excels. These cephalopods, equipped with light-producing organs called photophores, can illuminate their environment with a mesmerizing glow. The purpose of this luminous display serves various functions, including signaling, camouflage, and attracting prey. Interestingly, the light is produced through a chemical reaction within the photophores, where the enzyme luciferin reacts with the enzyme luciferase in the presence of oxygen and ATP, resulting in a flash of blue, green, or red light. This spectacle of nature, a dance of darkness and light, continues to captivate scientists and onlookers alike, offering insights into the mysteries of life under the sea.

Cluster analysis faces two problems in high dimensions: first, the `curse of dimensionality' that can lead to overfitting and poor generalization performance. and second, the sheer time taken for conventional algorithms to process large amounts of high-dimensional data. In many applications, only a small subset of features provide information about the cluster membership of any one data point, however this informative feature subset may not be the same for all data points. Here we introduce a `Masked EM' algorithm for fitting mixture of Gaussians models in such cases. We show that the algorithm performs close to optimally on simulated Gaussian data, and in an application of `spike sorting' of high channel-count neuronal recordings.

In the realm of genetics, the concept of genetic expression unfolds a captivating tale. Genes, the basic units of heredity, are not static entities but dynamic ones. They are transcribed into messenger RNA, which journeys to the ribosomes, where protein synthesis occurs. This process, known as translation, constructs proteins, the building blocks of life, shaping an organism's structure and function. Environmental factors, such as temperature and nutrient availability, can influence gene expression, providing an intricate dance between nature and nurture in the grand symphony of life. This intricate dance underscores the profound complexity and adaptability inherent in living organisms.

Nanodiamonds (NDs) containing silicon vacancy (SiV) defects were evaluated as a potential biomarker for the labeling and fluorescent imaging of neural precursor cells (NPCs). SiV-containing NDs were synthesized using chemical vapor deposition and silicon ion implantation. Spectrally, SiV-containing NDs exhibited extremely stable fluorescence and narrow bandwidth emission with an excellent signal to noise ratio exceeding that of NDs containing nitrogen-vacancy (NV) centers. NPCs labeled with NDs exhibited normal cell viability and proliferative properties consistent with biocompatibility. We conclude that SiVcontaining NDs are a promising biomedical research tool for cellular labeling and optical imaging in stem cell research.

In marine biology, the bioluminescent squid, known scientifically as Dinofelis gymnocaeca, is an intriguing deep-sea creature. It produces light through a chemical reaction within specialized cells, a trait used for communication, predator evasion, and locating food in the dark abyss. This squid's unique bioluminescent patterns are believed to serve as camouflage against predators, as they can mimic the glowing plankton that often surrounds them. Remarkably, these creatures can also synchronize their flashes when in a group, creating mesmerizing visual displays that add to the mystery of the deep sea.

In the Susceptible-Infectious-Recovered (SIR) model of disease spreading, the time to extinction of the epidemics happens at an intermediate value of the per-contact transmission probability. Too contagious infections burn out fast in the population. Infections that are not contagious enough die out before they spread to a large fraction of people. We characterize how the maximal extinction time in SIR simulations on networks depend on the network structure. For example we find that the average distances in isolated components, weighted by the component size, is a good predictor of the maximal time to extinction. Furthermore, the transmission probability giving the longest outbreaks is larger than, but otherwise seemingly independent of, the epidemic threshold.

In the intricate world of cellular biology, mitochondria play a pivotal role. Often dubbed as the "powerhouses" of cells, mitochondria are responsible for generating most of the energy needed for cellular functions. They achieve this through a process known as cellular respiration, converting nutrients into adenosine triphosphate (ATP), the primary energy currency of cells. Mitochondria's significance is further underscored by their role in apoptosis, or programmed cell death, acting as essential regulators in maintaining cellular homeostasis. Moreover, they are critical in the biogenesis of iron-sulfur clusters and heme groups, integral components in various proteins and enzymes. The dynamic evolution of mitochondria, from being free-living organisms to becoming intracellular symbionts, is a fascinating testament to the adaptability and interconnectedness of life on Earth.

The theoretical and experimental study of energy transfer in photosynthesis has revealed an interesting transport regime, which lies at the borderline between classical transport dynamics and quantum-mechanical interference effects.
