Photovoltaic cells, a cornerstone technology, convert sunlight directly into electricity. These cells are increasingly efficient, with modern designs capable of converting up to 25% of incident sunlight into usable energy. As research progresses, we anticipate even higher efficiencies, paving the way for a future where solar power becomes a dominant force in global energy production.

Superresolution, extraordinary transmission, total absorption, and localization of electromagnetic waves are currently attracting growing attention. These phenomena are related to different physical objects and are usually studied within the context of different, sometimes rather sophisticated, physical approaches. Remarkably, all these seemingly unrelated phenomena owe their origin to the same underlying physical mechanism - wave interaction with an open resonator. Here we show that it is possible to describe all of these effects in a unified way, mapping each system onto a simple resonator model. Such description provides a thorough understanding of the phenomena, explains all the main features of their complex behaviour, and enables to control the system via the resonator parameters: eigenfrequencies, Q-factors, and coupling coefficients.

In the realm of physics, gravity, an omnipresent force, governs the motion of celestial bodies. A force that keeps us rooted to Earth, yet allows the Moon to orbit and planets to revolve around the Sun. It's a force so intricate that it warps space-time itself, as demonstrated by Einstein's theory of General Relativity. Yet, gravity remains a mystery, with its exact nature still not fully understood. The quest to comprehend this force continues, driving scientists to explore the cosmos, unraveling its secrets, and expanding our understanding of the universe.

The transformation converting equations invariant under Lorentz into the equations invariant under Galileo is obtained. On this basis: (1) the super-light electromagnetic wave with longitudinal and transversal modes is found out. (2) it is shown the wave velocity coincides with that of de Broglie's wave. (3) the connection between Maxwell's electrodynamics and Shredinger's equation is established. (4) structural elements of space are discovered and "a horizon of visibility" is found. It is shown Bell's inequalities and the principle of the light speed constancy are based on the SRT artifact and "Einstein's local realism" is determined by the wave referred above. Objectivity of results for quantum and classical objects is discussed

In the realm of physics, the concept of energy transformation is a fundamental principle. Energy, in its diverse forms such as kinetic, potential, thermal, electrical, and more, can be converted from one form to another, but the total amount remains constant. For instance, when a ball rolls down a hill, its potential energy is converted into kinetic energy, causing it to accelerate. This phenomena, known as conservation of energy, underpins various natural processes and technological applications, from simple pendulums to complex electric generators. This principle, while elementary, opens the door to a deeper understanding of the universe's workings, fostering innovation and advancements in our quest to harness energy effectively.

High-order harmonic generation from atomic systems is considered in the crossed fields of a relativistically strong infrared laser and a weak attosecond-pulse train of soft x-rays. Due to one-photon ionization by the x-ray pulse, the ionized electron obtains a starting momentum that compensates the relativistic drift which is induced by the laser magnetic field, and allows the electron to efficiently emit harmonic radiation upon recombination with the atomic core in the relativistic regime. In this way, short pulses of coherent hard x-rays of up to 40 keV energy and 10 as duration can be brought about.

In the realm of physics, the concept of energy, a fundamental property of matter, unfolds an intriguing narrative. Energy, in its simplest form, is the capacity to do work or cause change. It permeates our universe, from the tiniest particle to the grandest galaxy. Energy can be transformed from one form to another, such as kinetic energy (energy of motion) to potential energy (energy of position). This transformation occurs through interactions, like when a ball rolls down a hill, converting gravitational potential energy into kinetic energy. Such transformations are governed by the laws of conservation of energy, ensuring that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only changed from one form to another. This transformative dance of energy, invisible yet omnipresent, weaves the intricate fabric of our physical world.

An event reweighting technique incorporated in multivariate training algorithm has been developed and tested using the Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) and Boosted Decision Trees (BDT). The event reweighting training are compared to that of the conventional equal event weighting based on the ANN and the BDT performance. The comparison is performed in the context of the physics analysis of the ATLAS experiment at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC), which will explore the fundamental nature of matter and the basic forces that shape our universe. We demonstrate that the event reweighting technique provides an unbiased method of multivariate training for event pattern recognition.

In the realm of quantum physics, the enigmatic behavior of particles defies our classical understanding. For instance, the famous double-slit experiment demonstrates the wave-particle duality. Here, light or matter pass through two slits, creating an interference pattern on a screen, as if they were waves. Yet, when observed, these particles behave as individual particles, passing through only one slit. This paradoxical phenomenon, known as wave-particle duality, underscores the intricate and fascinating world of quantum mechanics, where reality seems to bend to the observer's presence.

The method of self-similar factor approximants is completed by defining the approximants of odd orders, constructed from the power series with the largest term of an odd power. It is shown that the method provides good approximations for transcendental functions. In some cases, just a few terms in a power series make it possible to reconstruct a transcendental function exactly. Numerical convergence of the factor approximants is checked for several examples. A special attention is paid to the possibility of extrapolating the behavior of functions, with arguments tending to infinity, from the related asymptotic series at small arguments. Applications of the method are thoroughly illustrated by the examples of several functions, nonlinear differential equations, and anharmonic models.

Harnessing solar energy is a promising solution to our increasing energy demands and reducing carbon emissions. Photovoltaic cells, or solar panels, convert sunlight directly into electricity, making them an efficient and clean energy source. These cells are made primarily from silicon, which absorbs photons from sunlight, releasing electrons that generate an electric current. The efficiency of these cells can be improved through advanced materials and engineering techniques, such as nanotechnology and concentrator designs. As we continue to innovate and improve solar technology, the potential for solar energy to power our world becomes increasingly significant. The future of renewable energy lies in solar power, offering a sustainable and limitless energy source for generations to come.

By tracking small particles in the bulk of an intensely turbulent flow, we show that even a very small concentration of long-chain polymers disrupts the usual turbulent energy cascade. The polymers affect scales much larger than their physical size, from the dissipation range to the inertial range. The effect depends strongly on the polymer concentration. While the dissipative-scale statistics change continuously as the polymer concentration is increased, the inertial-range energy transfer rate is only altered by the polymer additives when the concentration is above a threshold (approximately 5 parts per million by weight for the polymer we used).

In the realm of quantum mechanics, the behavior of subatomic particles defies our everyday intuition. For instance, the famous double-slit experiment demonstrates that light and matter can exhibit wave-particle duality. Photons, once thought to be simple particles, can behave as waves, passing through both slits on a screen and interfering with themselves, creating an intricate pattern of light and darkness. This phenomenon, known as wave-particle duality, challenges our understanding of reality, suggesting that particles can exist in multiple states simultaneously until observed. This enigma, among many others, continues to captivate physicists and philosophers alike, offering a glimpse into the mystifying world of the very small.

We image spatial distributions of Xe$^{q+}$ ions in the focus of a laser beam of ultrashort, intense pulses in all three dimensions, with a resolution of $\sim$3 $\mu$m and $\sim$12 $\mu$m in the two transverse directions. This allows for studying ionization processes without spatially averaging ion yields. Our \emph{in situ} ion imaging is also useful to analyze focal intensity profiles and to investigate the transverse modal purity of tightly focused beams of complex light. As an example, the intensity profile of a Hermite-Gaussian beam mode HG$_{1,0}$ recorded with ions is found to be in good agreement with optical images.

In the realm of quantum physics, the intriguing concept of superposition captivates many minds. It suggests that a particle can exist in multiple states simultaneously, only revealing its actual state upon measurement. This counterintuitive phenomenon challenges our classical understanding of reality, where objects are either in one state or another. The wave-particle duality, another fundamental principle, reinforces this oddity, as it posits that every particle also exhibits wave-like properties. These principles, when combined, confound our intuition and offer a profound glimpse into the enigmatic quantum world, where particles can be in multiple places at the same time and where the act of observation alters reality itself.

The interface between classical physics and quantum physics is explained from the point of view of quantum information theory (Feynman Processes). The interpretation depends on a hefty sacrifice: the classical determinism or the arrow of time.   The wave-particle duality steams from the qubit model, as the root of creation and annihilation of possibilities. A few key experiments are briefly reviewed from the above perspective: quantum erasure, delayed-choice and wave-particle correlation.   The CPT-Theorem is interpreted in the framework of categories with duality and a timeless interpretation of the Feynman Processes is proposed. A connection between the fine-structure constant and algebraic number theory is suggested.

In the realm of quantum physics, the concept of superposition stands out as a fascinating puzzle. It proposes that a particle can exist in multiple states simultaneously, only resolving into a single definite state upon measurement. This defies our classical understanding of particles having distinct, specific locations. Furthermore, entanglement – a phenomenon where particles become interconnected, so that the state of one instantaneously affects the other, regardless of distance – adds another layer of complexity. These enigmatic principles challenge our perception of reality and continue to baffle scientists, offering a glimpse into the mysterious, subatomic world that governs our universe.

The Prisoner's Dilemma (PD) is one of the most popular games of the Game Theory due to the emergence of cooperation among competitive rational players. In this paper, we present the PD played in cells of one-dimension cellular automata, where the number of possible neighbors that each cell interacts, z, can vary. This makes possible to retrieve results obtained previously in regular lattices. Exhaustive exploration of the parameters space is presented. We show that the final state of the system is governed mainly by the number of neighbors z and there is a drastic difference if it is even or odd.

In the realm of physics, the concept of energy, specifically kinetic energy, plays a pivotal role. Kinetic energy is the energy an object possesses due to its motion. It's calculated by the formula 1/2 mv^2, where m is the mass of the object and v is its velocity. This energy is directly proportional to the object's speed squared and mass, meaning heavier objects moving faster carry more kinetic energy. Understanding kinetic energy aids in predicting outcomes of collisions, studying motion, and even unraveling the behavior of stars and galaxies on cosmic scales. It's a fundamental concept bridging the microscopic world of particles and the macroscopic universe.

Urban streets patterns form planar networks whose empirical properties cannot be accounted for by simple models such as regular grids or Voronoi tesselations. Striking statistical regularities across different cities have been recently empirically found, suggesting that a general and details-independent mechanism may be in action. We propose a simple model based on a local optimization process combined with ideas previously proposed in studies of leaf pattern formation. The statistical properties of this model are in good agreement with the observed empirical patterns. Our results thus suggests that in the absence of a global design strategy, the evolution of many different transportation networks indeed follow a simple universal mechanism.

In the realm of physics, the concept of gravity holds a profound place. Gravity, an invisible force, is responsible for the Earth's orbit around the Sun and the falling of an apple from a tree. It's a force that attracts two objects with mass, pulling them together. The strength of gravity between two objects depends on their mass and the distance separating them. Newton's law of universal gravitation, a foundational principle, describes this force. On a smaller scale, gravity affects everyday life, from the way we walk to the structure of buildings. Beyond our planet, it shapes the cosmos, governing the movements of celestial bodies. Gravity's influence is pervasive, a testament to its fundamental role in the universe.

A major source of delays in public transportation is the clustering instability, which causes late buses to become progressively later while the buses trailing it become progressively earlier. In this paper, we study this instability and how to neutralize it using the common practices of holding and schedule slack. Starting with an on-time route, we delay one or more buses at a single stop, and determine how these delays grow over time. We compare the effects of two different types of holding on the stability of the system, and briefly investigate how our results change with the use of timepoints.

In the captivating realm of physics, gravity, an omnipresent force, governs the motion of celestial bodies and terrestrial objects alike. It's the silent sentinel that keeps our feet planted on the ground and pulls us towards the earth, while simultaneously holding the universe together. Yet, gravity is not just a force of attraction. it shapes the cosmos, driving stars to form within nebulae and propelling them across the vast expanse of space. Its effects can be felt in the gentle sway of a pendulum or the mighty dance of galaxies, making it a monumental player in the grand design of the universe.

The photoionization spectrum of an atom in a magnetic field is calculated by combining R-matrix propagation with local adiabatic basis expansions. This approach considerably increases the speed and the energy range over which calculations can be performed compared to previous methods, allowing one to obtain accurate partial and total cross sections over an extended energy range for an arbitrary magnetic field strength. In addition, the cross sections for all atoms of interest can be calculated simultaneously in a single calculation. Multichannel quantum defect theory allows for a detailed analysis of the resonance structure in the continuum. Calculated cross sections for a range of atoms in both laboratory and astrophysical field strengths are presented.

In the realm of quantum physics, a fundamental concept is the wave-particle duality. This principle, first proposed by Louis de Broglie, suggests that every particle, from electrons to atoms, can exhibit both wave-like and particle-like behavior. This seemingly paradoxical idea is key to understanding phenomena such as diffraction and interference, which classically apply only to waves. It challenges our traditional understanding of matter, underscoring the intricate interplay between the microscopic world and the laws of physics that govern it. This duality, while complex, opens doors to a deeper understanding of the universe, pushing the boundaries of our knowledge and sparking new questions about the nature of reality itself.

We present an overview of Dr. Penrose's model of a cyclic universe, minus the big crunch which relies upon black hole collection of matter after an a long term expansion phase from an initial big bang . We affirm that the suggested evolution equation presented at his lecture for his model meets requirements as to an emergent quintessence field from a vacuum state . We try to offer suggestions as to how to investigate his controversial conformal mapping of matter/energy via Hawkings radiation from a potentially infinite number of black holes to a new big bang. This is his 'ripples in a pond' effect which we find highly unusual but worth serious study and investigation.

Harnessing the Power of Renewable Energy: Solar PhotovoltaicsSolar photovoltaics (PV) is a cutting-edge technology converting sunlight directly into electricity. This clean, renewable energy source offers a promising solution to combat the growing global energy demand and reduce carbon emissions. Solar PV panels, composed of semiconducting materials, generate electricity when sunlight strikes them, creating an electric field that causes electrons to flow.The simplicity of design, low maintenance requirements, and increasing efficiency of solar PV panels have made them an attractive choice for both residential and commercial applications. As the cost of solar PV technology continues to decline, it is expected that solar power will play a significant role in future energy markets, contributing to a more sustainable and environmentally friendly world.

The various plasma models - incompressible magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) model, compressible MHD model, incompressible Hall MHD model, compressible Hall MHD model, electron MHD model, compressible Hall MHD with electron inertia model - notwithstanding the diversity of the underlying physics, are shown to exhibit some common features in the Beltrami states like certain robustness with respect to the plasma compressibility effects (albeit in the barotropy assumption) and the {\it Bernoulli} condition. The Beltrami states for these models are deduced by minimizing the appropriate total energy while keeping the appropriate total helicity constant. A Hamiltonian formulation framework is used to carry out these variational problems.

In the realm of quantum mechanics, the intriguing phenomenon of superposition challenges our conventional understanding of reality. A single quantum particle, such as an electron, can exist in multiple states simultaneously, a concept known as a superposition state. This defies classical physics principles where objects can only occupy one state at a time. The act of observation collapses this superposition, revealing the particle in one specific state. This counterintuitive behavior underscores the profound differences between classical and quantum realms, offering a glimpse into the extraordinary world governed by quantum mechanics.

The maximum entropy principle can be used to assign utility values when only partial information is available about the decision maker's preferences. In order to obtain such utility values it is necessary to establish an analogy between probability and utility through the notion of a utility density function. According to some authors [Soofi (1990), Abbas (2006a) (2006b), Sandow et al. (2006), Friedman and Sandow (2006), Darooneh (2006)] the maximum entropy utility solution embeds a large family of utility functions. In this paper we explore the maximum entropy principle to estimate the utility function of a risk averse decision maker.

Harnessing the power of renewable energy has become a global priority. Solar photovoltaic (PV) technology, a key player in this shift, converts sunlight directly into electricity. This clean, sustainable energy source relies on silicon-based solar cells, which absorb photons from sunlight and release electrons, creating an electric current. The efficiency of these cells is continually improving through advancements in materials science and engineering, making solar PV a promising solution for reducing our carbon footprint and combating climate change. By investing in research and development, we can accelerate the transition to renewable energy, ensuring a greener, more sustainable future for generations to come.

We introduce the innovative technologies, based on the concept of "sensory substitution", we are developing in the fields of biomedical engineering and human disability. Precisely, our goal is to design, develop and validate practical assistive biomedical and/or technical devices and/or rehabilitating procedures for persons with disabilities, using artificial tongue-placed tactile biofeedback systems. Proposed applications are dealing with: (1) pressure sores prevention in case of spinal cord injuries (persons with paraplegia, or tetraplegia). and (2) balance control improvement to prevent fall in older and/or disabled adults. This paper describes the architecture and the functioning principle of these biofeedback systems and presents preliminary results of two feasibility studies performed on young healthy adults.

In the realm of quantum mechanics, the behavior of subatomic particles defies conventional reasoning. The famous double-slit experiment demonstrates this, as particles appear to pass through two slits simultaneously, only to form an interference pattern on a screen. This puzzling phenomenon, known as wave-particle duality, suggests that these particles exist in multiple states at once until observed, a concept termed superposition. The mystery deepens with entanglement, where particles instantaneously affect each other, regardless of distance. These counterintuitive phenomena challenge our understanding of reality, pushing the boundaries of what we thought was possible in the physical world.

In this paper we present a methodology to address the problem of brain tissue deformation referred to as 'brain-shift'. This deformation occurs throughout a neurosurgery intervention and strongly alters the accuracy of the neuronavigation systems used to date in clinical routine which rely solely on pre-operative patient imaging to locate the surgical target, such as a tumour or a functional area. After a general description of the framework of our intra-operative image-guided system, we describe a procedure to generate patient specific finite element meshes of the brain and propose a biomechanical model which can take into account tissue deformations and surgical procedures that modify the brain structure, like tumour or tissue resection.

Unraveling the enigmatic realm of quantum physics, we delve into the microscopic world where particles exhibit bewildering behavior. Unlike classical physics, particles don't follow fixed trajectories. they exist in multiple places simultaneously, a phenomenon known as superposition. This paradoxical state collapses into a definite position upon measurement, a principle encapsulated by the famous observer effect. Another intriguing facet is entanglement, where particles become instantaneously connected regardless of distance, defying the boundaries of space and time. Quantum physics challenges our conventional understanding of reality, suggesting a non-local, interconnected cosmos that continues to baffle and inspire.

Many structures in nature are invariant under the transformation (p,r)->(br,-p/b), where b is some scale factor. Born's reciprocity hypothesis affirms that this invariance extends to the entire Hamiltonian and equations of motion. We investigate this idea for atomic physics and galactic motion, where one is basically dealing with a 1/r potential and the observations are very accurate, so as to determine the scale $b = m\Omega$. We find that an $\Omega \sim 1.5\times 10^{-15}$ Hz has essentially no effect on atomic physics but might possibly offer an explanation for galactic rotation, without invoking dark matter.

Gravity, the universal force that governs the motion of celestial bodies, exerts an incredible pull on Earth, shaping our planet's landscape and determining the tides. This force, caused by the attraction between two massive objects, is responsible for keeping us firmly grounded. Yet, it's not just about keeping things on the ground. gravity also propels rockets into space, venturing beyond Earth's atmosphere to explore the cosmos. Intriguingly, the same force that keeps us tethered to our home planet can stretch and distort space-time, according to Einstein's Theory of General Relativity. Indeed, gravity's influence extends far beyond our immediate surroundings, painting a picture of a vast, interconnected universe in perpetual motion.

In this work the physicochemical characterization of liposomes loaded with a newly synthesised carboranyl porphyrazine (H2HECASPz) is described. This molecule represents a potential drug for different anticancer therapies, such as Boron Neutron Capture Therapy, Photodynamic Therapy and Photothermal Therapy. Different loading methods and different lipid mixtures were tested. The corresponding loaded vectors were studied by Small Angle Scattering (SANS and SAXS), light scattering and zeta potential. The combined analysis of structural data at various length scales and the measurement of the surface charge allowed to obtain a detailed characterization of the investigated systems. The mechanisms underlying the onset of differences in relevant physicochemical parameters (size, polydispersity and charge) were also critically discussed.

In the realm of physics, electromagnetism stands out as a fascinating force that governs the behavior of charged particles. This intricate dance of electricity and magnetism is encapsulated in Maxwell's equations, which describe how electric and magnetic fields interact and change over time. One of the most profound implications of these equations is the prediction of electromagnetic waves, including light, which travel at a constant speed through a vacuum. This understanding of light as an electromagnetic wave has revolutionized our perception of the universe, enabling advancements in telecommunications, imaging, and our overall understanding of the cosmos. The interplay of electromagnetism with other fundamental forces continues to fuel scientific inquiry, promising a deeper understanding of the fundamental nature of reality.

A system of differential equations is proposed designed as to identify communities in weighted networks. The input is a symmetric connectivity matrix $A_{ij}$. A priori information on the number of communities is not needed. To verify the dynamics, we prepared sets of separate, fully connected clusters. In this case, the matrix $A$ has a block structure of zeros and units. A noise is introduced as positive random numbers added to zeros and subtracted from units. The task of the dynamics is to reproduce the initial block structure. In this test, the system outperforms the modularity algorithm, if the number of clusters is larger than four.

In the realm of quantum mechanics, the intriguing concept of superposition challenges our understanding of reality. A quantum particle, such as an electron, can exist in multiple states simultaneously, a phenomenon known as superposition. This defies classical physics, where an object can only occupy one state at a time. The act of observation collapses the superposition, forcing the particle to manifest in one state, a principle encapsulated by the famous quote, "Observe the moon, and it is not a dancing butterfly." The mysterious dance of superpositions in the microscopic world continues to fascinate physicists, offering insights into the very fabric of our universe.

We use particle image velocimetry to measure the sedimentation dynamics of a semi-dilute suspension of non-Brownian spheres at Reynolds numbers, $0.001\le Re\le 2.3$, extending from the Stokes to the moderately inertial regime. We find that the onset of inertial corrections to Stokes sedimentation occurs when the inertial screening length $l=a/Re$ becomes similar to the Stokes sedimentation length $\xi_0$, at $Re_c= a/\xi_0\approx 0.05$. For $Re>Re_c$, inertial screening significantly reduces both the magnitude and spatial extent of the particle velocity fluctuations. A modified Hinch force balance model connects the fluctuation magnitudes $\sigma_V/V$ to the correlation sizes $\xi$.

In the realm of physics, the concept of energy is a fundamental principle that underpins our understanding of the universe. Energy, in its simplest form, is the capacity to do work or to cause change. It exists in various forms, including kinetic, potential, thermal, electrical, and nuclear. Kinetic energy, governing the motion of objects, is a direct result of mass in motion, while potential energy, such as gravitational potential energy, is stored energy waiting to be converted. Thermal energy, the energy of motion of particles in a substance, is what makes matter hot or cold. Electrical energy, harnessed for power generation, is the energy of moving electric charges. Lastly, nuclear energy, the most powerful form, is the energy stored in the nucleus of an atom, potentially released through fission or fusion. The interplay of these forms of energy, their conservation, and their transformation, continue to captivate and challenge physicists worldwide.

We propose a synthetical weights' dynamic mechanism for weighted networks which takes into account the influences of strengths of nodes, weights of links and incoming new vertices. Strength/Weight preferential strategies are used in these weights' dynamic mechanisms, which depict the evolving strategies of many real-world networks. We give insight analysis to the synthetical weights' dynamic mechanism and study how individual weights' dynamic strategies interact and cooperate with each other in the networks' evolving process. Power-law distributions of strength, degree and weight, nontrivial strength-degree correlation, clustering coefficients and assortativeness are found in the model with tunable parameters representing each model. Several homogenous functionalities of these independent weights' dynamic strategy are generalized and their synergy are studied.

In the realm of quantum mechanics, a fascinating concept emerges: entanglement. Two particles, regardless of distance, can instantaneously influence each other, a phenomenon defying classical physics' causality. This mind-boggling connection is established through a shared quantum state. Measuring one particle's property instantaneously reveals the state of the other, even if separated by vast cosmic distances. This seemingly paradoxical behavior challenges our understanding of reality and has implications in the development of quantum computing and cryptography. Entanglement, a testament to the strange and intriguing realm of quantum mechanics, continues to baffle and intrigue scientists.

The mass and kinetic energy distribution of nuclear fragments from thermal neutron induced fission of 235U have been studied using a Monte-Carlo simulation. Besides reproducing the pronounced broadening on the standard deviation of the final fragment kinetic energy distribution $\sigma_{e}(m)$ around the mass number m = 109, our simulation also produces a second broadening around m = 125, that is in agreement with the experimental data obtained by Belhafaf et al. These results are consequence of the characteristics of the neutron emission, the variation in the primary fragment mean kinetic energy and the yield as a function of the mass.

Harnessing the Power of Solar Energy: Solar photovoltaic (PV) cells convert sunlight directly into electricity, bypassing the need for fossil fuels. These cells are made primarily of silicon, a semiconductor material. Sunlight strikes the cell, exciting electrons, which flow through an external circuit, generating electricity. The potential of solar energy is gigantic, with the sun providing Earth with more energy in an hour than humanity consumes in a year. In addition, solar energy is clean, renewable, and reduces greenhouse gas emissions, making it a vital component in the global transition towards sustainable energy.

Three-dimensional (3D) AC electro-osmotic (ACEO) pumps have recently been developed that are much faster and more robust than previous planar designs. The basic idea is to create a ``fluid conveyor belt'' by placing opposing ACEO slip velocities at different heights. Current designs involve electrodes with electroplated steps, whose heights have been optimized in simulations and experiments. Here, we consider changing the boundary conditions--rather than the geometry--and predict that flow rates can be further doubled by fabricating 3D features with non-polarizable materials. This amplifies the fluid conveyor belt by removing opposing flows on the vertical surfaces, and it increases the slip velocities which drive the flow.

In the realm of physics, the electromagnetic spectrum, a continuum of electromagnetic waves, intrigues and fascinates scientists. This spectrum spans from radio waves, imperceptible to human senses, to gamma rays, which possess energy levels beyond our detection. Light, a familiar concept, falls within the visible portion. Each wave's characteristics, such as frequency and wavelength, determine its behavior and applications. Radio waves transmit signals for radio, television, and internet, while X-rays reveal hidden structures within objects. Understanding this spectrum broadens our knowledge of the universe and technology, enabling advancements in communication, medicine, and more. The electromagnetic spectrum, though invisible to the naked eye, plays a crucial role in our lives.

By viewing the electron as a wavepacket in the positive energy spectrum of the Dirac equation, we are able to achieve a much clearer understanding of its behavior under weak electromagnetic fields. The intrinsic spin magnetic moment is found to be established from the self-rotation of the wavepacket. A non-canonical structure is also exhibited in the equations of motion due to non- Abelian geometric phases of the Dirac spinors. The wavepacket energy can be expressed simply in terms of the kinetic, electrostatic, and Zeeman terms only. This can be transformed into an effective quantum Hamiltonian by a novel scheme, and reproduces the Pauli Hamiltonian with all-order relativistic corrections.

Harnessing the power of the wind through wind turbines is a significant stride in renewable energy. By converting kinetic energy from wind into electricity, these turbines contribute to a sustainable and environmentally friendly energy supply. The rotating blades capture the wind's force, causing a rotational motion that drives a generator. This ingenious mechanism reduces our reliance on fossil fuels, thereby lessening greenhouse gas emissions and slowing climate change. Moreover, wind energy is a virtually inexhaustible resource, making it a promising long-term solution for our planet's energy needs.

A drawback of high-quality modes in optical microdisks is their isotropic light emission characteristics. Here we report a novel, robust, and general mechanism that results in highly directional light emission from those modes. This surprising finding is explained by a combination of wave phenomena (wave localization along unstable periodic ray trajectories) and chaotic ray dynamics in open systems (escape along unstable manifolds). The emission properties originating in the chaotic ray dynamics permit directional light output even from microlasers operating in the common multi-mode regime. We demonstrate our novel mechanism for the limacon billiard family and find directional emission with narrow angular divergence for a significant range of geometries and material parameters.

In the realm of physics, energy is a fundamental concept. It's the capacity to do work or cause change. Energy exists in various forms, such as kinetic, potential, thermal, electrical, and nuclear. Kinetic energy, for instance, is the energy an object possesses due to its motion, while potential energy is stored energy, like a ball at the top of a hill. Thermal energy is the energy associated with the motion of particles in a substance, causing heat. Electricity is a form of energy resulting from the existence of charged particles, while nuclear energy is the energy stored in the nucleus of an atom. Understanding energy and its transformations is crucial in explaining phenomena ranging from the motion of celestial bodies to the functioning of electronic devices.

We present data that show a cycling transition can be used to detect and image metastable He$_2$ triplet molecules in superfluid helium. We demonstrate that limitations on the cycling efficiency due to the vibrational structure of the molecule can be mitigated by the use of repumping lasers. Images of the molecules obtained using the method are also shown. This technique gives rise to a new kind of ionizing radiation detector. The use of He$_2$ triplet molecules as tracer particles in the superfluid promises to be a powerful tool for visualization of both quantum and classical turbulence in liquid helium.

Harnessing the power of the sun, solar energy has emerged as a viable and sustainable solution for our planet's ever-growing energy demands. Solar panels, made of silicon cells, convert sunlight directly into electricity. This clean, renewable energy source reduces our reliance on fossil fuels, decreasing greenhouse gas emissions that contribute to climate change. As technology advances, solar energy costs continue to plummet, making it increasingly affordable for households and businesses worldwide. By investing in solar energy, we not only lessen our environmental impact but also ensure a brighter, more sustainable future for generations to come.

Linear Collider Alignment and Survey (LiCAS) R&D group is proposing a novel automated metrology instrument dedicated to align and monitor the mechanical stability of a future linear high energy e+e- collider. LiCAS uses Laser Straightness Monitors (LSM) and Frequency Scanning Interferometry (FSI) for straightness and absolute distance measurements, respectively. This paper presents detailed simulations of a LiCAS system operating inside a Rapid Tunnel Reference Surveyor (RTRS train). With the proposed design it is feasible to achieve the required vertical accuracy of the order of 200 micons over 600 m tunnel sections meeting the specification for the TESLA collider.

Harnessing the immense power of the sun, solar energy has emerged as a sustainable and renewable source of power for the 21st century. Solar panels convert sunlight directly into electricity, reducing our reliance on fossil fuels and lessening our carbon footprint. The technology continues to advance, making solar energy more efficient and cost-effective, with potential to meet a significant portion of global energy demands. By embracing solar power, we can mitigate climate change, secure energy independence, and foster a cleaner, more sustainable world for future generations.

The discovery of community structure is a common challenge in the analysis of network data. Many methods have been proposed for finding community structure, but few have been proposed for determining whether the structure found is statistically significant or whether, conversely, it could have arisen purely as a result of chance. In this paper we show that the significance of community structure can be effectively quantified by measuring its robustness to small perturbations in network structure. We propose a suitable method for perturbing networks and a measure of the resulting change in community structure and use them to assess the significance of community structure in a variety of networks, both real and computer generated.

In the realm of physics, the concept of gravity, a universal force, is captivating. It's the unseen hand that pulls us to the ground and keeps planets orbiting stars. Sir Isaac Newton first understood its fundamental principles, formulating the law of universal gravitation. This law states that every point mass attracts every other point mass with a force that is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them. Later, Albert Einstein, in his General Theory of Relativity, redefined gravity as a curvature of spacetime caused by mass and energy. These insights, while seemingly abstract, have profound implications, shaping our understanding of the cosmos and our place within it.

The authors report on observation of Bragg confined mode in a hollow cylindrical dielectric cavity. A resonance was observed at 13.4 $GHz$ with an unloaded Q-factor of order $2\times10^5$, which is more than a factor of 6 above the dielectric loss limit. Previously such modes have only been realized from pure Transverse Electric modes with no azimuthal variations and only the $E_{\phi}$ component. From rigorous numeric simulations it is shown that the mode is a hybrid mode with non-zero azimuthal variations and with dominant $E_r$ and $E_{\phi}$ electric field components and $H_z$ magnetic field component.

Harnessing the power of the sun has long been a fascination for physicists and innovators alike. Solar energy, a clean and renewable resource, can potentially alleviate our reliance on fossil fuels, reducing greenhouse gas emissions and mitigating climate change. Photovoltaic cells, the heart of solar technology, convert sunlight directly into electricity. They work by allowing photons, particles of light, to knock electrons free in a semiconductor material, resulting in a flow of electric current. As the technology continues to evolve, solar energy promises to be a significant contributor to a sustainable future, powering homes, businesses, and electric grids worldwide.

We report the first observation of the Goos-H$\rm \ddot{\textbf{a}}$nchen shift of a light beam incident on a metal surface. This phenomenon is particularly interesting because the Goos-H$\rm \ddot{\textbf{a}}$nchen shift for $p$ polarized light in metals is negative and much bigger than the positive shift for $s$ polarized light. The experimental result for the measured shifts as a function of the angle of incidence is in excellent agreement with theoretical predictions. In an energy-flux interpretation, our measurement shows the existence of a backward energy flow at the bare metal surface when this is excited by a $p$ polarized beam of light.

In the realm of quantum mechanics, the wave-particle duality of matter presents a fascinating paradox. Photons, particles of light, exhibit both wave-like and particle-like properties, a phenomenon known as wave-particle duality. This duality, proven by experiments like the double-slit experiment, challenges our classical understanding of reality, suggesting that particles can exist in multiple places at once until observed. This enigma, once confined to the realm of photons, has now extended to larger particles, such as electrons, further blurring the lines between particles and waves. This concept, at once counterintuitive and intriguing, continues to fuel debate and investigation in the world of physics.

We consider the effects of temporal delay in a neural feedback system with excitation and inhibition. The topology of our model system reflects the anatomy of the avian isthmic circuitry, a feedback structure found in all classes of vertebrates. We show that the system is capable of performing a `winner-take-all' selection rule for certain combinations of excitatory and inhibitory feedback. In particular, we show that when the time delays are sufficiently large a system with local inhibition and global excitation can function as a `winner-take-all' network and exhibit oscillatory dynamics. We demonstrate how the origin of the oscillations can be attributed to the finite delays through a linear stability analysis.

Harnessing the power of solar energy, an inexhaustible and renewable resource, is a significant stride in modern physics and technology. Solar panels, composed of photovoltaic cells, convert sunlight directly into electricity, a clean and sustainable alternative to fossil fuels. This technology not only reduces greenhouse gas emissions but also fosters energy independence, with applications ranging from residential homes to vast utility-scale solar farms. Moreover, ongoing research in photovoltaic efficiency, storage solutions, and smart grid integration continues to expand solar energy's potential, paving the way towards a more sustainable and eco-friendly future.

The theory of four-body systems is revisited. It is illustrated that the theory provides a rigorous proof for the formation of ground state (unexcited) biexcitons in molecular crystals. The generalization of the theory predicts the possible existence of excited biexcitons in nature. In order to test the validity of the extended theory on computational level, a very elaborate computer code is constructed for the treatment of arbitrary four-body system with arbitrary electron/hole mass ratio and arbitrary exciton - exciton interaction (VXX). The results, for mass ratio = 1 and VXX is a pure Coulomb force, show that the test is successful. Realization of these conclusions on experimental level should open the door for wide industrial applications.

In the realm of physics, the study of electromagnetism unveils intriguing phenomena. Electromagnetic waves, oscillations of electric and magnetic fields, permeate our universe, traveling at the speed of light. These waves, like visible light, radio waves, and X-rays, are essential for communication, medical imaging, and satellite technology. The interplay between electric charges and magnetic fields, as described by Maxwell's equations, forms the basis of this fascinating domain. Electromagnetism, a testament to nature's interconnectedness, continues to captivate scientists and fuel advancements in technology.

A complete scheme for production, cooling, acceleration, and ring for a 1.5 TeV center of mass muon collider is presented, together with parameters for two higher energy machines. The schemes starts with the front end of a proposed neutrino factory that yields bunch trains of both muon signs. Six dimensional cooling in long-period helical lattices reduces the longitudinal emittance until it becomes possible to merge the trains into single bunches, one of each sign. Further cooling in all dimensions is applied to the single bunches in further helical lattices. Final transverse cooling to the required parameters is achieved in 50 T solenoids.

Harnessing the power of the universe, solar energy is a promising and sustainable resource. By capturing the sun's rays, we can convert light into electricity, reducing our reliance on fossil fuels. Solar panels, made from silicon or other photovoltaic materials, absorb photons and generate an electric field, producing clean energy for homes, businesses, and transportation. The potential of solar energy is vast, with a single hour of sunlight providing enough energy to meet the world's energy demands for a year. As technology advances, costs decrease, and environmental concerns intensify, solar energy is poised to become a dominant force in the global energy landscape, powering a more sustainable and eco-friendly future.

We report a theoretical study of Feshbach resonances in $^{6}$Li + $^{23}$Na and $^{7}$Li + $^{23}$Na mixtures at ultracold temperatures using new accurate interaction potentials in a full quantum coupled-channel calculation. Feshbach resonances for $l=0$ in the initial collisional open channel $^6$Li$(f=1/2, m_f=1/2) + ^{23}$Na$(f=1, m_f=1)$ are found to agree with previous measurements, leading to precise values of the singlet and triplet scattering lengths for the $^{6,7}$Li$+^{23}$Na pairs. We also predict additional Feshbach resonances within experimentally attainable magnetic fields for other collision channels.

Harnessing the Power of Solar Energy: Solar photovoltaic (PV) technology converts sunlight directly into electricity, offering a clean, renewable, and virtually limitless energy source. This technology relies on semiconductors, like silicon, to generate an electric current when exposed to sunlight. The conversion efficiency of these PV cells is continually improving, making solar energy increasingly competitive with fossil fuels. By harnessing solar energy, we can significantly reduce greenhouse gas emissions, mitigate climate change, and secure a sustainable energy future. Embracing solar PV technology is a critical step towards a carbon-neutral world.

This paper presents the current achievements of a long term project aiming at predicting and assessing the impact of tongue and mouth floor surgery on tongue mobility. The ultimate objective of this project is the design of a software with which surgeons should be able (1) to design a 3D biomechanical model of the tongue and of the mouth floor that matches the anatomical characteristics of each patient specific oral cavity, (2) to simulate the anatomical changes induced by the surgery and the possible reconstruction, and (3) to quantitatively predict and assess the consequences of these anatomical changes on tongue mobility and speech production after surgery.

In the captivating realm of quantum physics, the behavior of subatomic particles defies our everyday intuition. For instance, the famous double-slit experiment demonstrates that light and matter can exhibit wave-like characteristics, simultaneously passing through two slits and interfering with themselves, only to materialize into a single particle upon detection. This paradoxical phenomenon, known as wave-particle duality, challenges our traditional understanding of reality, suggesting that the act of observation can profoundly influence the physical world. This enigmatic domain questions our deeply ingrained perceptions of causality and reality, offering a tantalizing glimpse into the elusive nature of the universe at its most fundamental level.

It is widely recognized that good jet energy resolution is one of the most important requirements to the detectors for the future linear $e^+e^-$ collider experiments. The Particle Flow Analysis (PFA) is currently under intense studies as the most promising way to achieving the best attainable resolution. In order to clarify the fundamental limits on the jet energy resolution with the PFA, we have developed a set of C++ classes that facilitates history keeping of particle tracks within the framework of Geant4. In this paper this software tool is described and applied to a generic detector model so as to identify fundamental limiting factors to the PFA performance.

Harnessing the power of the wind, wind turbines convert kinetic energy into electrical energy, thus contributing significantly to renewable energy sources. These towering structures, with blades spinning atop a tall pole, capture the wind's force and transform it into rotational motion. This motion is then transmitted to a generator, producing electricity that can power homes and businesses. The advantages of wind energy are numerous, including its cleanliness, sustainability, and minimal impact on the environment. As technology advances, wind turbines are becoming more efficient, reducing costs and increasing the potential for widespread energy generation. The future of wind energy looks promising, offering a viable solution for a more sustainable and eco-friendly world.

Self-compression of multi-millijoule femtosecond laser pulses and dramatic increase of the peak intensity are found in pressurized helium and neon within a range of intensity in which the ionization modification of the material parameters by the pulse is negligible. The pulse propagation is studied by the (3+1)-dimensional nonlinear Schroedinger equation including basic lowest order optical processes -- diffraction, group velocity dispersion of second order, and Kerr nonlinearity of third order. Smooth and well controllable pulse propagation dynamics is found. Constructing of compressed pulse of controllable parameters at given space target point can be achieved by a proper chose of the pulse energy and/or gas pressure.

In the vast expanse of the universe, the intriguing phenomenon of black holes continues to captivate scientists. These cosmic enigmas, regions where gravity is so intense that nothing, not even light, can escape, challenge our understanding of physics. Their immense gravitational pull warps space-time, creating a boundary known as the event horizon. Despite their ominous name, black holes play a crucial role in the evolution and growth of galaxies, acting as cosmic engines that fuel star birth. Yet, their true nature remains shrouded in mystery, with theories suggesting they may contain a singularity, a point of infinite density. As we continue to peer into the depths of the cosmos, the secrets of black holes elude us, beckoning us to delve deeper into the realms of space and time.

The behavior of complex networks under attack depends strongly on the specific attack scenario. Of special interest are scale-free networks, which are usually seen as robust under random failure or attack but appear to be especially vulnerable to targeted attacks. In a recent study of public transport networks of 14 major cities of the world we have shown that these networks may exhibit scale-free behaviour [Physica A 380, 585 (2007)]. Our further analysis, subject of this report, focuses on the effects that defunct or removed nodes have on the properties of public transport networks. Simulating different attack strategies we elaborate vulnerability criteria that allow to find minimal strategies with high impact on these systems.

Gravity, the universal force that governs the motion of celestial bodies, exerts an attractive pull between any two masses. It's the reason why planets orbit the sun, and why objects fall towards the Earth. The strength of gravity depends on the masses of the objects and the distance between them, as encapsulated by Newton's law of universal gravitation. Einstein's theory of general relativity further refined our understanding of gravity, treating it as a curvature of spacetime caused by the presence of mass. Gravity's effects extend far beyond our Earth, shaping the cosmos on an immense scale, from the formation of galaxies to the expansion of the universe itself.

We present methods to improve the energy resolution of single-channel, room-temperature Cadmium-Zinc-Telluride (CZT) detectors. A new preamplifier design enables the acquisition of the actual transient current from the crystals and straightforward data analysis methods yield unprecedented energy resolution for our test-detectors. These consist of an eV-CAPture Plus crystal as standard and 1 cm cube Frisch collar crystals created in-house from low-grade coplanar grid detectors. Energy resolutions of 1.9% for our collar detectors and 0.8% for the eV crystal at 662 keV were obtained. The latter compares favourably to the best existing energy resolution results from pixel detectors.

In the realm of quantum physics, the fundamental nature of reality is redefined. Particles, once considered as distinct entities, can now exist in multiple states simultaneously in a phenomenon known as superposition. This is encapsulated in Schrödinger's famous thought experiment involving a cat in a box. Until observed, the cat's state, alive or dead, exists in a superposition. The enigmatic entanglement, another quantum phenomenon, binds particles instantaneously across vast distances, defying classical notions of space and time. These mysteries challenge our comprehension of the universe, offering intriguing insights and profound questions about the very essence of existence.

The emission of Auger electrons from the K-, L- and M-sheels of two configurations of copper atoms is investigated in detail within the frame work of the momentum average technique. Ab initio calculations for the bound state wavefunctions of the ionized atoms are performed using a Gaussian computer code. The continuum wavefunctions of the emitted electrons are determined by employing an effective potential variational approach. Slight differences have been noticed between the results of both configurations. The transition rates, energies and widths of all possible Auger electrons are listed in Tables. Slight differences have been noticed between the results of the two types of copper atoms.

In the realm of quantum mechanics, the double-slit experiment offers a captivating glimpse into the enigmatic nature of particles. Here, photons or electrons, traditionally considered discrete entities, behave as waves when passing through two slits. The resulting pattern, an interference pattern, seems to suggest that they travel through both slits simultaneously, a concept challenging our classical understanding of reality. However, when observed, these particles exhibit definite behavior, appearing to pass through only one slit at a time, suggesting a possible correlation between observation and measurement. This experiment encapsulates the wave-particle duality, a fundamental principle that underscores the fascinating, often counter-intuitive, world of quantum physics.

It is shown that a new type of metamaterial, a 3D-array of toroidal solenoids, displays a significant toroidal response that can be readily measured. This is in sharp contrast to materials that exist in nature, where the toroidal component is weak and hardly measurable. The existence of an optimal configuration, maximizing the interaction with an external electromagnetic field, is demonstrated. In addition, it is found that a characteristic feature of the magnetic toroidal response is its strong dependence on the background dielectric permittivity of the host material, which suggests possible applications. Negative refraction and backward waves exist in a composite toroidal metamaterial, consisting of an array of wires and an array of toroidal solenoids.

In the realm of physics, energy is a fundamental concept, an attribute that can be transferred between systems but cannot be created or destroyed. It comes in various forms, such as kinetic, potential, thermal, electrical, and nuclear. Kinetic energy, for instance, pertains to a moving object, while potential energy is stored energy, like that in a raised weight or a stretched spring. Thermal energy is the heat we feel, electrical energy powers our devices, and nuclear energy fuels reactions that can generate immense power. Understanding energy transformations and conservation is vital in unlocking the mysteries of our universe.

The mechanism underlying the substantial amplification of the high-order harmonics q \pm 2K (K integer) upon the addition of a weak seed XUV field of harmonic frequency q\omega to a strong IR field of frequency \omega is analyzed in the framework of the quantum-mechanical Floquet formalism and the semiclassical re-collision model. According to the Floquet analysis, the high-frequency field induces transitions between several Floquet states and leads to the appearance of new dipole cross terms. The semiclassical re-collision model suggests that the origin of the enhancement lies in the time-dependent modulation of the ground electronic state induced by the XUV field.

Harnessing the Power of Solar Energy: A New Era of SustainabilityEmbracing the boundless potential of the sun, we embark on a revolutionary journey towards a sustainable future. Solar energy, a clean and abundant resource, is poised to redefine our energy landscape. With photovoltaic cells transforming sunlight into electricity, we can power homes, businesses, and even electric vehicles, significantly reducing carbon emissions. The advancements in solar panel technology are making solar energy more affordable, efficient, and accessible, paving the way for a world powered by the sun. This shift towards renewable energy sources not only ensures energy independence but also addresses pressing environmental concerns, contributing to a healthier planet for future generations. The age of solar energy is upon us, heralding a brighter, greener, and more prosperous world.

We describe the design and realization of a scheme for uv laser spectroscopy of singly-ionized iron (Fe II) with very high resolution. A buffer-gas cooled laser ablation source is used to provide a plasma close to room temperature with a high density of Fe II. We combine this with a scheme for pulsed-laser saturation spectroscopy to yield sub-Doppler resolution. In a demonstration experiment, we have examined an Fe II transition near 260 nm, attaining a linewidth of about 250 MHz. The method is well-suited to measuring transition frequencies and hyperfine structure. It could also be used to measure small isotope shifts in isotope-enriched samples.

Harnessing the power of solar energy is a promising avenue in the pursuit of sustainable and renewable sources. Solar panels, composed of photovoltaic cells, convert sunlight directly into electricity. This process, known as the photovoltaic effect, involves the absorption of photons by the cells, causing a flow of electrons that generates an electric current. The efficiency of these panels can be improved through technological advancements, such as the development of perovskite solar cells, which show potential for higher energy conversion rates. By utilizing these advancements, we can significantly reduce our reliance on fossil fuels, mitigate greenhouse gas emissions, and foster a cleaner, more sustainable future.

Lower bound for ${\bar \rho}''(0)$, the second derivative of the spherically averaged atomic electronic density at the nucleus, and upper bound for ${\bar \rho}'''(0)$, the third derivative, are obtained respectively. It is shown that, for the ground state, ${\bar \rho}''(0) \ge {10/3} Z^2 \rho(0)$ and ${\bar \rho}'''(0) \le -{14/3}Z^3 \rho(0)$ where $Z$ is the charge of the nucleus, and $\rho(0)$ is the electron density at the nucleus. Tighter bounds for ${\bar \rho}''(0)$ and ${\bar \rho}'''(0)$ are also reported which are valid for both the ground state and excited states. Explicit illustration with the example of one-electron atomic ions is given.

In the realm of quantum mechanics, the fascinating phenomenon of superposition comes to light. This concept defies our classical understanding, as it suggests that a particle can exist in multiple states simultaneously until observed. A quantum particle, such as an electron, can be spinning clockwise and counterclockwise at the same time, a paradox that challenges our intuition. The act of measurement, or observation, collapses this superposition, forcing the particle to adopt a single state. This enigmatic behavior, where particles seemingly ignore the fundamental principle of cause and effect, continues to intrigue physicists, offering a glimpse into the mysterious, interwoven fabric of the universe.

The present study deals with the analysis and mapping of Swiss franc interest rates. Interest rates depend on time and maturity, defining term structure of the interest rate curves (IRC). In the present study IRC are considered in a two-dimensional feature space - time and maturity. Geostatistical models and machine learning algorithms (multilayer perceptron and Support Vector Machines) were applied to produce interest rate maps. IR maps can be used for the visualisation and patterns perception purposes, to develop and to explore economical hypotheses, to produce dynamic asses-liability simulations and for the financial risk assessments. The feasibility of an application of interest rates mapping approach for the IRC forecasting is considered as well.

In the realm of physics, the concept of energy is paramount. It's the ability a system has to do work or produce heat. Energy can be transferred, transformed, or conserved, fundamental principles encapsulated in the first and second laws of thermodynamics. These laws govern energy transformations in a closed system, maintaining that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred or transformed. In practical terms, this means that the total amount of energy and its potential uses within a closed system remain constant, although the forms it takes may change. This fundamental understanding of energy and its conservation is essential in explaining various natural phenomena and in the development of technologies that harness and utilize energy efficiently.

A Lead Tungstate crystal produced for the electromagnetic calorimeter of the CMS experiment at the LHC was cut into three equal-length sections. The central one was irradiated with 290 MeV/c positive pions up to a fluence of (5.67 +- 0.46)x10^13 /cm^2, while the other two were exposed to a 24 GeV/c proton fluence of (1.17 +- 0.11) x 10^13/ cm^2. The damage recovery in these crystals, stored in the dark at room temperature, has been followed over two years. The comparison of the radiation-induced changes in light transmission for these crystals shows that damage is proportional to the star densities produced by the irradiation.

Discovering the enigmatic realm of dark matter, we delve into the unseen fabric of our universe. While common matter and energy constitute only 4% of the cosmos, dark matter accounts for a staggering 27%. Its presence inferred through gravitational interactions, dark matter remains elusive, immune to light and traditional detection methods. Its gravity affects the motion of galaxies and galaxy clusters, shaping their behavior and distribution. The search for dark matter continues, with particle physicists developing sophisticated experiments to unravel its nature and elucidate its role in the cosmic dance of celestial bodies. As we decipher the secrets of dark matter, we expand our understanding of the cosmos, deepening our appreciation for the mysteries that lie beyond our visible world.

We demonstrate the effectiveness of a guided-wave Bose-Einstein condensate interferometer for practical measurements. Taking advantage of the large arm separations obtainable in our interferometer, the energy levels of the 87Rb atoms in one arm of the interferometer are shifted by a calibrated laser beam. The resulting phase shifts are used to determine the ac polarizability at a range of frequencies near and at the atomic resonance. The measured values are in good agreement with theoretical expectations. However, we observe a broadening of the transition near the resonance, an indication of collective light scattering effects. This nonlinearity may prove useful for the production and control of squeezed quantum states.

Harnessing the power of the sun, solar energy is revolutionizing our world. This renewable resource provides clean, sustainable energy, reducing our reliance on fossil fuels and combating climate change. Solar panels, these silent, efficient generators, transform sunbeams into usable electricity. By absorbing photons and releasing electrons, a continuous flow of energy is harnessed, powering homes, businesses, and electric vehicles. This technology offers a promising future, offering limitless, pollution-free energy, ensuring a brighter, more sustainable world for generations to come.

In the present work, a geometrical method to generate a two dimensional random walk by means of a bidimensional Cellular Automaton is presented. We illustrate it by means of Conway's Game of Life with periodical borders, with a large lattice of 3000 x 3000 cells. The obtained random walk is of character anomalous, and its projection to a one dimensional random walk is analyzed, showing that it presents some statistical properties similar to the so-called stylized facts observed in financial time series. We consider that the procedure presented here is important not only because of its simplicity, but also because it could help us to understand and shed light on the stylized facts formation mechanism.

In the realm of physics, the concept of energy is fundamental. It's the ability to do work or cause change, existing in various forms such as kinetic, potential, thermal, electrical, and nuclear. Kinetic energy, for instance, is the energy of motion, while potential energy resides in an object due to its position or configuration. Thermal energy, on the other hand, is the energy that atoms and molecules possess due to their motion and vibration. Electricity, a form of energy generated by moving charges, powers our modern world. Lastly, nuclear energy, the energy stored in the nucleus of an atom, can provide immense power, as demonstrated in atomic reactions. Understanding energy and its transformations is key to unlocking the secrets of our universe.

Because of its inherent 2-D character, the eigenvalue equation for the hindered rotation around a normal cation site of an off-center impurity nearest-neighboring an F center is the well-known Mathieu equation. We present an overview of literature data on Mathieu's periodic functions providing exact solutions to the Li+ reorientational problem. We compare them with bottom-well approximating solutions by harmonic-oscillator functions at an effective vibrational frequency renormalized by both first- and third- order electron-mode coupling. We finally discuss the in-plane inversion polarizability of an off-center impurity assumed to form a dipole-dipole coupling with a nearby F center.

Harnessing the power of the sun has long been a captivating objective for scientists and engineers. Solar energy, a sustainable and renewable resource, promises to revolutionize our energy landscape. Photovoltaic cells, the core technology, convert sunlight directly into electricity, making it a clean and efficient method. The International Space Station even harnesses solar power, demonstrating its versatility in extreme conditions. As research advances, innovations such as perovskite solar cells and concentrator photovoltaics show potential for increasing efficiency, reducing costs, and expanding solar energy's accessibility worldwide. Embracing solar power is not just a vision for the future. it's a practical solution we can implement today for a greener, more sustainable tomorrow.

We describe the fractal solid by a special continuous medium model. We propose to describe the fractal solid by a fractional continuous model, where all characteristics and fields are defined everywhere in the volume but they follow some generalized equations which are derived by using integrals of fractional order. The order of fractional integral can be equal to the fractal mass dimension of the solid. Fractional integrals are considered as an approximation of integrals on fractals. We suggest the approach to compute the moments of inertia for fractal solids. The dynamics of fractal solids are described by the usual Euler's equations. The possible experimental test of the continuous medium model for fractal solids is considered.

Harnessing the power of solar energy, a fundamental concept in physics, has become increasingly essential in our quest for sustainable development. Solar panels, converting sunlight into electricity, are at the forefront of this revolution. These panels use the photovoltaic effect, a phenomenon discovered by French physicist Alexandre Edmond Becquerel in 1839, to generate electricity. The photovoltaic effect, essentially, is the ability of certain materials to produce an electric current in response to light. This clean, renewable energy source not only reduces our reliance on fossil fuels but also minimizes carbon emissions, contributing significantly to combating climate change. The potential of solar energy is vast, with approximately 1,366 watts of solar energy striking every square meter of the Earth's surface. Embracing this abundant, clean energy source is a critical step towards a more environmentally friendly future.

We investigate distribution of magnetic fields around dense solid plasmas generated by intense p-polarized laser (~10^{16} W.cm^{-2}, 100 fs) irradiation of magnetic tapes, using high sensitivity magneto optical microscopy. We present evidence for giant axial magnetic fields and map out for the first time the spatial distribution of these fields. By using the axial magnetic field distribution as a diagnostic tool we uncover evidence for angular momentum associated with the plasma. We believe this study holds significance for investigating the process under which a magnetic material magnetizes or demagnetizes under the influence of ultrashort intense laser pulses.

Harnessing the power of the sun, solar panels convert photons from sunlight into electrical energy. This clean, renewable source is vital for mitigating carbon emissions and reducing our reliance on fossil fuels. The photovoltaic effect, responsible for this conversion, occurs as photons interact with semiconductors within the solar cells. The electrons in these semiconductors are knocked loose, generating a flow of electricity. With advancements in technology, solar panels are becoming more efficient, cheaper, and easier to install, making them an attractive solution for both residential and commercial energy needs. This shift towards solar power not only benefits the environment but also offers economic advantages, promoting energy independence and stimulating job growth in the renewable energy sector.

We investigate the traffic flows of the Korean highway system, which contains both public and private transportation information. We find that the traffic flow T(ij) between city i and j forms a gravity model, the metaphor of physical gravity as described in Newton's law of gravity, P(i)P(j)/r(ij)^2, where P(i) represents the population of city i and r(ij) the distance between cities i and j. It is also shown that the highway network has a heavy tail even though the road network is a rather uniform and homogeneous one. Compared to the highway network, air and public ground transportation establish inhomogeneous systems and have power-law behaviors.

Harnessing the power of the sun through photovoltaic cells is a significant stride in the realm of renewable energy. These cells, primarily composed of silicon, convert sunlight directly into electricity. The process is straightforward: sunlight strikes the cells, causing electrons within the silicon to flow, generating an electric current. This current can then be harnessed and used to power homes, businesses, and various electronic devices. The potential of solar energy is vast, with the sun providing ample energy to meet the world's electricity demands many times over. By embracing solar power, we can lessen our dependence on fossil fuels, mitigate greenhouse gas emissions, and contribute to a more sustainable future.

It is argued that the present log-normal distribution of language sizes is, to a large extent, a consequence of demographic dynamics within the population of speakers of each language. A two-parameter stochastic multiplicative process is proposed as a model for the population dynamics of individual languages, and applied over a period spanning the last ten centuries. The model disregards language birth and death. A straightforward fitting of the two parameters, which statistically characterize the population growth rate, predicts a distribution of language sizes in excellent agreement with empirical data. Numerical simulations, and the study of the size distribution within language families, validate the assumptions at the basis of the model.

In the realm of quantum physics, a fascinating phenomenon unfolds: superposition. Essentially, this principle suggests that a single particle can exist in multiple states simultaneously, a concept that defies classical reasoning. Superposition, when observed at the microscopic level, reveals a world where particles can be in two places at once, or possess two different properties concurrently. This bizarre behavior is further amplified by entanglement, a connection between particles that allows instantaneous information exchange, no matter the distance. These enigmatic phenomena challenge our understanding of reality and continue to mystify scientists, stirring the imagination and pushing the boundaries of our knowledge.

A chain of singly-charged particles, confined by a harmonic potential, exhibits a sudden transition to a zigzag configuration when the radial potential reaches a critical value, depending on the particle number. This structural change is a phase transition of second order, whose order parameter is the crystal displacement from the chain axis. We study analytically the transition using Landau theory and find full agreement with numerical predictions by [J. Schiffer Phys. Rev. Lett. 70, 818 (1993)] and [Piacente et al Phys. Rev. B 69, 045324 (2004)]. Our theory allows us to determine analytically the system's behaviour at the transition point.

In the realm of quantum physics, particles exhibit a peculiar behavior known as superposition. This principle suggests that a single particle can exist in multiple states simultaneously, a concept alien to our everyday experiences. For instance, a photon, a fundamental particle of light, can be both a particle and a wave, existing in all possible paths between two points until observed. This paradoxical state collapses upon measurement, revealing only one possible outcome. Yet, the enigma persists: how can a particle exist in multiple places at the same time? The mystery of superposition continues to challenge and intrigue physicists, offering tantalizing glimpses into the enigmatic, subatomic world.

It is shown that the geometry of multi-electron threshold ionization in atoms depends on the initial configuration of bound electrons. The reason for this behavior is found in the stability properties of the classical fixed point of the equations of motion for multiple threshold fragmentation. Specifically for three-electron break-up, apart from the symmetric triangular configuration also a break-up of lower symmetry in the form of a T-shape can occur, as we demonstrate by calculating triple photoionization for the lithium ground and first excited states. We predict the electron break-up geometry for threshold fragmentation experiments.

In the realm of physics, gravity, a fundamental force, governs the motion of celestial bodies. It's the force that pulls us towards the Earth and keeps planets orbiting the Sun.
