In physics, the intriguing realm of general relativity redefines our understanding of gravity, proposing that massive objects warp space-time, causing other objects to move along curved paths. This theory, first formulated by Einstein, predicts phenomena such as gravitational waves, ripples in the fabric of space-time caused by accelerating masses, like collision of black holes or neutron stars.Moreover, the concept of time dilation, a consequence of general relativity, suggests that time can actually flow at different rates depending on an object's velocity and position in a gravitational field. For example, a clock on a rapidly moving spaceship would tick slower than a clock at rest on Earth, a phenomenon known as 'time travel for stationary observers.'Furthermore, as we explore the far reaches of space, we continue to uncover the complexity of our universe, with black holes serving as fascinating examples of how matter can push the limits of our understanding. Their immense gravity distorts space-time so much that even light cannot escape, creating a point of no return, known as the event horizon. The study of these celestial enigmas contributes to our quest for knowledge about the cosmos and the fundamental nature of reality itself.

The Jacobi and Weierstrass elliptic functions used to be part of the standard mathematical arsenal of physics students. They appear as solutions of many important problems in classical mechanics: the motion of a planar pendulum (Jacobi), the motion of a force-free asymmetric top (Jacobi), the motion of a spherical pendulum (Weierstrass), and the motion of a heavy symmetric top with one fixed point (Weierstrass). The problem of the planar pendulum, in fact, can be used to construct the general connection between the Jacobi and Weierstrass elliptic functions. The easy access to mathematical software by physics students suggests that they might reappear as useful tools in the undergraduate curriculum.

Marine bioluminescence, a captivating phenomenon, occurs when marine organisms emit light in response to certain stimuli. This bioluminescence is made possible through a uniquely chemical reaction, where luciferin and luciferase, in the presence of oxygen, produce a burst of light. A plethora of marine creatures, from lanternfish to jellyfish, exhibit bioluminescence, often serving a purpose such as attracting prey or deterring predators. The study of marine bioluminescence sheds light on the complex behaviors and adaptations of these underwater life forms, offering intriguing insights into the invisible world beneath the waves. As humanity continues to explore and understand the ocean's depths, the discoveries of marine bioluminescence contribute to the growing appreciation and protection of these vital and fascinating ecosystems.

We consider pulse propagation through a two component composite medium (metal inclusions in a dielectric host) with or without cavity mirrors. We show that a very thin slab of such a medium, under conditions of localized plasmon resonance, can lead to significant superluminality with detectable levels of transmitted pulse. A cavity containing the heterogeneous medium is shown to lead to subluminal-to-superluminal transmission depending on the volume fraction of the metal inclusions. The predictions of phase time calculations are verified by explicit calculations of the transmitted pulse shapes. We also demonstrate the independence of the phase time on system width and the volume fraction under specific conditions.

Pharmaceutical research steers towards the development of targeted therapies, a departure from traditional drugs that often caused broad-spectrum side effects. These novel therapeutics, such as monoclonal antibodies and small interfering RNAs, focus on specific molecular targets in the body. For instance, immune checkpoint inhibitors, like those developed for cancer treatment, have revolutionized oncology by enabling the immune system to combat cancer cells more effectively.Similarly, drug repurposing is a growing field in pharmacology, where existing drugs are tested for efficacy in new applications. A prime example is Remdesivir, initially designed to treat Ebola, was repurposed and approved for emergency use as a COVID-19 treatment in 2020.Continued advancements in drug development will rely on our understanding of molecular structures and their interactions, enabling us to create more effective, targeted therapies that improve human health while minimizing undesirable side effects.

We implement a well-established concept to consider dispersion effects within a Poisson-Boltzmann approach of continuum solvation of proteins. The theoretical framework is particularly suited for boundary element methods. Free parameters are determined by comparison to experimental data as well as high-level quantum mechanical reference calculations. The method is general and can be easily extended in several directions. The model is tested on various chemical substances and found to yield good-quality estimates of the solvation free energy without obvious indication of any introduced bias. Once optimized, the model is applied to a series of proteins, and factors such as protein size or partial charge assignments are studied.

The intersection of physics and biology unveils captivating narratives of species adaptation. COVID-19, an unprecedented global pandemic, is a stark example of this interplay. The virus, originating from zoonotic transmission, highlights the crucial role of understanding host-pathogen dynamics, a cornerstone of evolving ecosystems.As species migrate, adapt, and coexist, they modify their interactions within their environment. For instance, bats, unknowingly, became an unlikely carrier of SARS-CoV-2, a strain of coronavirus. It was not until human contact that this virus transformed into a pandemic.Embracing our role as an integral part of this dynamic ecosystem, humanity must adapt strategies to hinder the spread of diseases like COVID-19, bridging the gap between science and public health policies. Encouraging cross-disciplinary collaboration, particularly in the fields of microbiology, epidemiology, and physics, can pave the way for a more resilient future — one adapted to the ever-evolving patterns of our world.

We demonstrate the coherent excitation of a mesoscopic ensemble of about 100 ultracold atoms to Rydberg states by driving Rabi oscillations from the atomic ground state. We employ a dedicated beam shaping and optical pumping scheme to compensate for the small transition matrix element. We study the excitation in a weakly interacting regime and in the regime of strong interactions. When increasing the interaction strength by pair state resonances we observe an increased excitation rate through coupling to high angular momentum states. This effect is in contrast to the proposed and previously observed interaction-induced suppression of excitation, the so-called dipole blockade.

In the realm of cosmic phenomena, Einstein's theory of General Relativity posits that mass and energy warp the fabric of space-time, causing it to curve. This curvature dictates the motion of celestial bodies, from planets orbiting stars to galaxies moving across the cosmos. This theory revolutionized our understanding of space and time, suggesting they are not absolute but relative, intertwined, and influenceable by matter and energy. This concept, though complex, forms the basis for our comprehension of the intricate cosmic dance that unfolds across the expanse of the universe.

A one-coordinate gaseous detector of soft X-ray photons for wide-angle X-ray scattering (WAXS) studies is being developed. The detector operates in counting mode and is based on multi-stage Gas Electron Multiplier(GEM). Full size detector is assembled and has 67 degrees aperture with 350mm distance to the source, readout multi-strip structure with 2048 strips at 0.2mm pitch and is partially equipped with readout electronics in the central part. Main parameters of the detector have been measured with 8keV X-ray beam at VEPP-3 synchrotron ring. Spatial resolution of 470 um (FWHM) has been demonstrated that will allow to distinguish diffraction spots at 0.1 degrees.

Alcohol, a ubiquitous substance in human culture, is a chemical compound derived from ethyl alcohol (ethanol). It is a central nervous system depressant, causing effects from euphoria to sedation, and in excess, impairment and potentially death. The misconception that moderate alcohol use may have health benefits has persisted, but numerous studies have consistently refuted this claim. The World Health Organization (WHO) states no level of alcohol consumption is entirely safe for health. Long-term consumption can lead to increased risks of various diseases, such as liver disease, heart disease, and certain cancers. Moreover, alcohol consumption during pregnancy can cause fetal alcohol syndrome, a group of physical, mental, and behavioral problems in the offspring. Therefore, it's crucial to prioritize a lifestyle that minimizes alcohol consumption for the sake of personal and public health.

It has been observed break that breakdown in an 805 MHz pill-box cavi ty occurs at much lower gradients as an external axial magnetic field is inc reased. This effect was not observed with on open iris cavity. It is propose d that this effect depends on the relative angles of the magnetic and maximu m electric fields: parallel in the pill-box case. at an angle in the open ir is case. If so, using an open iris structure with solenoid coils in the iris es should perform even better. A lattice, using this principle, is presented, for use in 6D cooling for a Muon Collider. Experimental layouts to test th is principle are proposed.

Phosphorescent organisms illuminate the ocean depths, a mesmerizing sight emanating from bioluminescent creatures. This natural light show, largely unappreciated in the daylight, is a testament to life's adaptability. Yet, despite their beauty, these deep-sea dwellers face threats from human activities, such as pollution and climate change. Rising ocean temperatures and acidification are displacing these organisms, disrupting delicate underwater ecosystems and the vital food chains they support. Meanwhile, advances in technology have led to the development of artificial bioluminescence, holding potential for applications in research, medicine, and environmental monitoring - a beacon of hope for preserving our intriguing, glowing underwater world.

Propagation of transient mechanical waves in porous media is numerically investigated in 1D. The framework is the linear Biot's model with frequency-independant coefficients. The coexistence of a propagating fast wave and a diffusive slow wave makes numerical modeling tricky. A method combining three numerical tools is proposed: a fourth-order ADER scheme with time-splitting to deal with the time-marching, a space-time mesh refinement to account for the small-scale evolution of the slow wave, and an interface method to enforce the jump conditions at interfaces. Comparisons with analytical solutions confirm the validity of this approach.

Quantum oscillation, a phenomenon in solid-state physics, reveals intriguing patterns in materials at extremely low temperatures. In this quantum realm, electrons behave as waves, creating standing waves known as Landau levels when confined. As magnetic fields are applied, these levels form intricate sequences, creating a 'fingerprint' unique to that material.These oscillations provide a window into the interactions between electrons and the underlying crystal structure. Studying these oscillation patterns can offer insights into various physical properties, like conductivity, magnetism, and even the behavior in high-temperature superconductors.These oscillations have also been observed in astronomical bodies, such as white dwarfs and giant planets, providing valuable information about their internal structures and composition. The understanding of quantum oscillation patterns continues to enrich our knowledge of condensed matter physics and astrophysics.

Novel optical phenomena, including electromagnetically induced transparency, slow light, superluminal light propagation, have recently been demonstrated in diverse physical implementations. These phenomena are challenging to realize in practical systems because they require quantum coherence as well as careful preparation and control of prescribed quantum states. Here we present a unified approach to engineering optical materials that exhibit these phenomena by using mixtures of active and passive optical materials at frequencies near their resonances. Our approach does not depend on quantum coherence and can realize large and small (much less than 1) indices of refraction and negative permittivity ($\epsilon<0$), normal and anomalous dispersion, all while maintaining transparency.

Quantum entanglement, a mystifying phenomenon, links the properties of particles instantaneously, irrespective of the distance between them. Unlike traditional physics, quantum mechanics presents a world where particles don't follow classical laws but instead exist in a superposition, potentially in multiple states at once until observed. This intricate dance of density matrices and wave functions has been harnessed in quantum computing and communications, potentially revolutionizing technology as we know it. However, the deeper implications and the full potential of quantum entanglement remain a captivating enigma in the realm of physics.

Many body trial wave functions are the key ingredient for accurate Quantum Monte Carlo estimates of total electronic energies in many electron systems. In the Coupled Electron-Ion Monte Carlo method, the accuracy of the trial function must be conjugated with the efficiency of its evaluation. We report recent progress in trial wave functions for metallic hydrogen implemented in the Coupled Electron-Ion Monte Carlo method. We describe and characterize several types of trial functions of increasing complexity in the range of the coupling parameter $1.0 \leq r_s \leq1.55$. We report wave function comparisons for disordered protonic configurations and preliminary results for thermal averages.

Cells, fundamental units of life, undergo a process called cell division to reproduce. Mitosis, one form of cell division, involves the precise segregation of genetic material. Each daughter cell receives an identical set of chromosomes, allowing for growth and development. Binary fission in bacteria, on the other hand, involves a simple splitting of a single cell into two identical daughters. These cellular events, essential for life, are finely tuned orchestrations of biochemical processes that ensure the continuity and diversity of life.

We study a family of opinion formation models in one dimension where the propensity for a voter to align with its local environment depends non-linearly on the fraction of disagreeing neighbors. Depending on this non-linearity in the voting rule, the population may exhibit a bias toward zero magnetization or toward consensus, and the average magnetization is generally not conserved. We use a decoupling approximation to truncate the equation hierarchy for multi-point spin correlations and thereby derive the probability to reach a final state of a given consensus as a function of the initial magnetization. The case when voters are influenced by more distant voters is also considered by investigating the Sznajd model.

Molecular interactions play a pivotal role in the functionality and stability of biological systems. For instance, hydrogen bonds, ionic bonds, and covalent bonds bind the nucleotides in DNA strands, ensuring genetic information is preserved. Similarly, hydrophobic interactions help proteins fold correctly, a critical step for their function. In the photo synthesis process, chlorophyll molecules interact with photons, absorbing the energy to initiate the conversion of carbon dioxide and water into glucose. In contrast, when pathogens invade our bodies, the immune system responds through complex molecular interactions, such as the production of antibodies and activation of immune cells, in an attempt to neutralize the threat and maintain homeostasis. These interactions, while minute, have monumental implications for our health, the Earth's ecosystem, and our understanding of life itself.

We calculate a pump current in a classical two-state stochastic chemical kinetics by means of the non-adiabatic geometrical phase interpretation. The two-state system is attached to two particle reservoirs, and under a periodic perturbation of the kinetic rates, it gives rise to a pump current between the two-state system and the absorbing states. In order to calculate the pump current, the Floquet theory for the non-adiabatic geometrical phase is extended from a Hermitian case to a non-Hermitian case. The dependence of the pump current on the frequency of the perturbative kinetic rates is explicitly derived, and a stochastic resonance-like behavior is obtained.

In the realm of celestial bodies, an orbit is the path one object follows around another under the influence of gravity. This fundamental concept is a cornerstone of orbital mechanics, a branch of physics that investigates the motions of such objects. A satellite, for instance, orbits Earth due to its gravitational pull. Kepler's laws of planetary motion, formulated by astronomer Johannes Kepler, describe the paths that planets follow around the Sun in terms of elliptical orbits. Furthermore, the gravitational interactions between planets and moons also follow these laws, creating intricate dance-like patterns in our solar system. This understanding of orbital mechanics has been instrumental in unraveling the mysteries of celestial bodies and predicting their behavior, contributing significantly to our knowledge of the universe.

Silicon is an extremely attractive material platform for integrated optics at telecommunications wavelengths, particularly for integration with CMOS circuits. Developing detectors and electrically pumped lasers at telecom wavelengths are the two main technological hurdles before silicon can become a comprehensive platform for integrated optics. We report on the generation of free carriers in unimplanted SOI ridge waveguides, which we attribute to surface state absorption. By electrically contacting the waveguides, a photodetector with a responsivity of 36 mA/W and quantum efficiency of 2.8% is demonstrated. The photoconductive effect is shown to have minimal falloff at speeds of up to 60 Mhz.

Pharmaceutical history encounters an interesting juncture with the emergence of antibiotics, revolutionizing medicine in the mid-20th century. Penicillin, discovered by Alexander Fleming in 1928, marked the beginning of this era. Later, sulfa drugs, introduced in the 1930s, provided treatments for a broad range of bacterial infections. However, the post-World War II period saw a significant surge in antibiotic development, led by the discovery of erythromycin, tetracycline, and chloramphenicol.Fast forward to the 1980s, when a new class of antibiotics, the fluoroquinolones, entered the scene. These broad-spectrum drugs have been widely used ever since. Yet, the ongoing battle against bacterial resistance continues, demanding constant innovation in the pharmaceutical industry and a renewed emphasis on responsible antibiotic use.In this context, the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic underscores the urgent need for advances in antiviral therapies, further shaping the trajectory of pharmaceutical research and development.

I compute from first principles the local heating rate $q$ (the amount of electromagnetic energy converted to heat per unit time per unit volume) for electromagnetic waves propagating in magnetically and electrically polarizable media. I find that, in magnetic media, this rate has two separate contributions, $q^{(V)}$ and $q^{(S)}$, the first coming from the volume of the medium and the second from its surface. I argue that the second law of thermodynamics requires that the volume contribution be positive and that this requirement, in turn, prohibits negative refraction. This result holds for active or passive media and in the presence of anisotropy and spatial dispersion.

Genetic drift, a random change in the genetic composition of a population, significantly influences evolutionary dynamics. Unlike natural selection, which is driven by survival and reproduction, genetic drift is a consequence of pure chance. In a small population, a rare genetic trait has a greater chance of disappearing, while in a larger population, the same trait is more likely to persist, even when it provides no advantage or disadvantage. This principle can have significant effects over time, leading to variations in populations and potentially driving the evolution of new species. The premise that chance plays a crucial role in shaping genetic diversity challenges the deterministic view of evolution as a strictly outcome-based process and emphasizes the unpredictable and stochastic nature of biological evolution.

We propose a method to reduce the computational effort to solve a partial differential equation on a given domain. The main idea is to split the domain of interest in two subdomains, and to use different approximation methods in each of the two subdomains. In particular, in one subdomain we discretize the governing equations by a canonical scheme, whereas in the other one we solve a reduced order model of the original problem. Different approaches to couple the low-order model to the usual discretization are presented. The effectiveness of these approaches is tested on numerical examples pertinent to non-linear model problems including the Laplace equation with non-linear boundary conditions and the compressible Euler equations.

Gravitational waves, ripples in the fabric of spacetime, were first predicted by Albert Einstein's theory of general relativity in 1916. These waves, created by the acceleration or collision of massive objects like black holes or neutron stars, travel at the speed of light. Their detection was confirmed by the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) in 2015, opening a new window on the universe to study cosmic events. This groundbreaking discovery has enabled scientists to listen to the symphony of the cosmos and deepen our understanding of the universe's most violent and energetic phenomena.

We present a review of the main aspects of geometrothermodynamics, an approach which allows us to associate a specific Riemannian structure to any classical thermodynamic system. In the space of equilibrium states, we consider a Legendre invariant metric, which is given in terms of the fundamental equation of the corresponding thermodynamic system, and analyze its geometric properties in the case of the van der Waals gas, and black holes. We conclude that the geometry of this particular metric reproduces the thermodynamic behavior of the van der Waals gas, and the Reissner-Nordstr\"om black hole, but it is not adequate for the thermodynamic description of Kerr black holes.

In the realm of human health, cardiovascular disease emerges as a persistent global challenge. Akin to a silent predator, it often reveals itself through symptoms associated with heart attacks and strokes. This condition, primarily characterized by the hardening and narrowing of arteries, is often linked to lifestyle factors such as diet, physical inactivity, and tobacco usage.One dietary factor under scrutiny is the consumption of saturated fats and cholesterol, both of which are believed to contribute to the buildup of plaque in arteries. Moderation and balance are key when it comes to diet, with recommendations suggesting a diet low in saturated fats, trans fats, cholesterol, and sodium, while promoting fruits, vegetables, lean proteins, and whole grains.Regular exercise and maintaining a healthy weight can also help reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease. Quitting smoking is another crucial step, as tobacco use significantly increases the risk of heart disease.In conclusion, adopting a heart-healthy lifestyle, characterized by a balanced diet, regular exercise, and avoidance of tobacco, is essential in reducing the risk of cardiovascular disease and promoting overall well-being.

A completely rigorous first-principles calculation of the charged particle stopping power has recently been performed by Brown, Preston, and Singleton (BPS). This calculation is exact to leading and next-to-leading order in the plasma number density, including an exact treatment of two-body quantum scattering. The BPS calculation is therefore extremely accurate in the plasma regime realized during the ignition and burn of an inertial confinement fusion capsule. For deuterium-tritium fusion, the 3.5 MeV alpha particle range tends to be 20-30% longer than most models in the literature have predicted, and the energy deposition into the ions tends to be smaller. Preliminary numerical simulations indicate that this increases the rho-R required to achieve ignition.

Coral reefs, among Earth's most biodiverse ecosystems, flourish in warm, shallow ocean waters, housing an array of marine life. Due to their sheer beauty and ecological importance, they are often referred to as the 'rainforests of the sea'. However, these reefs are under threat due to climate change, ocean acidification, and human activities like overfishing and tourism.The Great Barrier Reef, the world's largest coral reef system, has seen significant decline in recent years, with roughly half of its coral lost since the 1980s. Rising sea temperatures, caused by global warming, lead to coral bleaching events, where corals expel the algae living in their tissues, causing them to lose their vibrant colors and often leading to death. Ocean acidification, caused by increased levels of carbon dioxide, weakens the coral's skeletons, making them more susceptible to breakage and erosion.Conservation efforts are crucial to preserve these vital ecosystems. Protecting large portions of reefs from human activities, reducing carbon emissions, and restoring degraded reefs through coral propagation are some steps that can help in the conservation of coral reefs. It is our responsibility to ensure that future generations can continue to marvel at the beauty and importance of these underwater wonders.

Modern societies feature an increasing contact between cultures, yet we have a poor understanding of what the outcomes might be. Here we consider a mathematical model of contact between social groups, grounded in social psychology and analyzed using tools from statistical physics. We use the model to study how a culture might be affected by immigration. We find that in some cases residents' culture is relatively unchanged, but in other cases residents may adopt the opinions and beliefs of immigrants. The decisive factors are each group's cultural legacy and its attitudes towards in- and out-groups. The model can also predict how social policies may influence the outcome of culture contact.

The dynamics of climate have always been a captivating puzzle, with notable oscillations, such as the Little Ice Age and Medieval Warm Period, showcasing Earth's climatic variability over centuries. The recent phenomenon of the COVID-19 pandemic, a global health crisis, further highlights the complex interplay between environmental changes and human health. Despite our advances in understanding viral origins, the question of whether climate instability might have facilitated the emergence of such pandemics remains a pressing concern. Simultaneously, as the climate continues to shift, coral reefs, oceanic wonderlands teeming with life, face increasingly dire threats. Thus, the dual issues of pandemic and climate change compel us to deeply appreciate the intricate relationship between our planet's health and our own, urging us to prioritize a sustainable future.

Controlled generation and manipulation of photon states encoded in their spatial degrees of freedom is a crucial ingredient in many quantum information tasks exploiting higher-than-two dimensional encoding. Here, we prove the impossibility to arbitrarily modify $d$-level state superpositions (qu$d$its) for $d>2$, encoded in the transverse modes of light, with optical components associated to the group of symplectic transforms (Gaussian operations). Surprisingly, we also provide an explicit construction of how non-Gaussian operations acting on mode subspaces do enable to overcome the limit $d=2$. In addition, this set of operations realizes the full SU(3) algebra.

In the realm of particle physics, a quark-gluon plasma, a state of matter composed of fundamental particles, was recently created in lab experiments. Much like how the universe started as a hot, dense plasma after the Big Bang, this substance, born from colliding atoms, offers insights into the early universe's behavior. The study of this plasma can help us better understand strong nuclear forces and the evolution of the universe, connecting the minute world of subatomic particles with the cosmic expanse of stars and galaxies. Often, such research opens new doors to frontier science, pushing boundaries of human knowledge ever further.

Population stratification is a problem encountered in several areas of biology and public health. We tackle this problem by mapping a population and its elements attributes into a hypergraph, a natural extension of the concept of graph or network to encode associations among any number of elements. On this hypergraph, we construct a statistical model reflecting our intuition about how the elements attributes can emerge from a postulated population structure. Finally, we introduce the concept of stratification representativeness as a mean to identify the simplest stratification already containing most of the information about the population structure. We demonstrate the power of this framework stratifying an animal and a human population based on phenotypic and genotypic properties, respectively.

Genetic engineering is the manipulation of an organism's DNA to modify its traits or characteristics. It involves the precise addition, deletion, or alteration of specific genes within the cell's genome. This technology, pioneered in the late 20th century, has had profound impacts on various fields, including medicine, agriculture, and biotechnology. In medicine, gene therapy holds promise for treating hereditary diseases, while in agriculture, genetically modified crops exhibit increased resistance to pests and improved nutritional content. However, ethical considerations surrounding the potential effects on ecosystems and future generations warrant ongoing debate. The field of synthetic biology further expands genetic engineering's horizons, enabling the creation of novel organisms and biological pathways that can help solve complex problems, such as the production of sustainable biofuels or bioremediating polluted environments.

We present an inexpensive apparatus for measuring the speed of sound, with a time of flight method, using a computer with a stereo sound board. Students measure the speed of sound by timing the delay between the arrivals of a pulse to two microphones placed at different distances from the source. It can serve as a very effective demonstration, providing a quick measurement of the speed of sound in air. we have used it with great success in Open Days in our Department. It can also be used for a full fledged laboratory determination of the speed of sound in air.

Biochemical pathways, a series of chemical reactions in living organisms, are intricate networks that govern life's processes. Adenosine Triphosphate (ATP), the universal energy currency of cells, is synthesized through these pathways. The Krebs cycle, or citric acid cycle, is a key pathway within the cell's mitochondria. It breaks down nutrients to produce ATP and carbon dioxide, a primary component of our atmosphere. The electron transport chain, another intricate pathway, harnesses the energy stored in these nutrients to create ATP, driving essential cellular activities. These biochemical pathways, like the delicate gears within a clockwork, sustain life's rhythm, keeping us ticking.

We introduce a new class of deterministic networks by associating networks with Diophantine equations, thus relating network topology to algebraic properties. The network is formed by representing integers as vertices and by drawing cliques between M vertices every time that M distinct integers satisfy the equation. We analyse the network generated by the Pythagorean equation $x^{2}+y^{2}= z^{2}$ showing that its degree distribution is well approximated by a power law with exponential cut-off. We also show that the properties of this network differ considerably from the features of scale-free networks generated through preferential attachment. Remarkably we also recover a power law for the clustering coefficient.

The celestial sphere, an imaginary sphere on which celestial bodies appear to be fixed, is central to our understanding of the night sky. Stars, planets, and constellations are all observed as if they reside on this sphere, rotating around the Earth's axis and orbiting the Sun.The precession of the equinoxes, a slow, cyclic movement of Earth's axis, subtly alters the position of the stars over millennia. This complex motion, caused by the gravitational forces exerted by the Sun and Moon on Earth's equatorial bulge, results in the perceived movement of stars against the backdrop of the celestial sphere.Furthermore, the 26,000-year cycle of the precession defines the position and orientation of the zodiac constellations. This celestial dance, both intricate and captivating, offers a tangible connection to the cosmos, as our ancient ancestors did thousands of years ago.

We investigate the influence of a uniform magnetic field ${\bf B_0}=B_0 e//$ on energy decay laws in incompressible magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) turbulence. The nonlinear transfer reduction along $B_0$ is included in a model that distinguishes parallel and perpendicular directions, following a phenomenology {\it \`a la} Kraichnan. We predict a slowing down of the energy decay due to anisotropy in the limit of strong $B_0$, with distinct power laws for energy decay of shear- and pseudo-Alfv\'en waves. Numerical results from the kinetic equations of Alfv\'en wave turbulence recover these predictions, and MHD numerical results clearly tend to follow them in the lowest perpendicular planes.

In the realm of pharmacology, Viagra, initially developed as a cardiovascular medication, unexpectedly opened a new chapter in medical history. Its primary function as a phosphodiesterase-5 inhibitor aimed to treat angina pectoris. However, it was discovered that a side effect of this drug, when taken by men, led to an increased blood flow to certain areas, hence its rebranding as a treatment for erectile dysfunction. Yet, like all medications, it comes with potential side effects, including headaches, visual disturbances, and priapism – a prolonged and painful erection requiring immediate medical attention. The serendipitous discovery of Viagra's secondary effect highlights the intricate interplay between seemingly unrelated biological processes and the potential for novel applications in medicine.

We construct simple analytic models of the $S$-matrix, accounting for both scattering resonances and smooth background contributions for collisions that occur below the s-wave threshold. Such models are important for studying confinement-induced resonances such as those occurring in cold collisions of $^{133}$Cs atoms in separated sites of a polarization-gradient optical lattice. Because these resonances occur at negative energy with respect to the s-wave threshold, they cannot be studied easily using direct numerical solutions of the Schr\"{o}dinger equation. Using our analytic model, we extend previous studies of negative-energy scattering to the multichannel case, accounting for the interplay of Feshbach resonances, large background scattering lengths, and inelastic processes.

Biological evolution continues to shape life on Earth, as species adapt and respond to their environment, often over extended periods. This process, driven by natural selection, allows the fittest organisms to survive and produce offspring, passing on advantageous traits. On the cosmic scale, exoplanets and their potential for hosting life remain a fascinating mystery, with astronomers searching for Earth-like planets in the habitable zones of their stars. Their discoveries expand our understanding of the universe and the conditions necessary for life to evolve. As we explore these realms, the quest for understanding the origins of life, the evolutionary trajectories of planets, and the diversity of life throughout the universe, continues to captivate scientists, philosophers, and thinkers alike.

CREME96 and GEANT4 are two well known particle transport codes through matter in space science. We present a comparison between the proton fluxes outgoing from an aluminium target, obtained by using both tools. The primary proton flux is obtained by CREME96 only, covering an energy range from MeV to hundreds GeV with the same result in both cases. We studied different thickness targets and two different GEANT4 physics lists in order to show how the spectra of the outgoing proton fluxes are modified. Our findings show consistent agreement of simulation data by each tool, with regards both GEANT4 physics lists and every thickness target analysed.

In the realm of relativistic physics, the speed of light maintains a constant, irrespective of the observer's frame of reference. This fundamental property, a cornerstone of Einstein's theory of relativity, challenges our notion of absolute space and time. As an object approaches the speed of light, its length contracts and time slows down relative to a stationary observer. This phenomenon, known as Lorentz contraction and time dilation, respectively, challenges our understanding of space and time. Additionally, Einstein's mass-energy equivalence equation, E=mc², encapsulates the intimate connection between mass and energy, revealing that even a small amount of mass can release a significant amount of energy. These concepts, groundbreaking in their time, continue to shape our understanding of the universe and its fundamental mechanisms.

We have developed prototypes of GEM-like detectors with resistive electrodes to be used as RICH photodetectors equipped with CsI photocathodes. The main advantages of these detectors are their intrinsic spark protection and possibility to operate at high gain (~10E5) in many gases including poorly quenched ones, allowing for the adoption of windowless configurations in which the radiator gas is also used in the chamber. Results of systematic studies of the resistive GEMs combined with CsI photocathodes are presented: its quantum efficiency, rate characteristics, long-term stability, etc. On the basis of the obtained results, we believe that the new detector will be a promising candidate for upgrading the ALICE RICH detector

Wine, a celebrated beverage with a rich history, is fermented grape juice. It contains ethanol, flavonoids, and resveratrol, a polyphenolic compound. Resveratrol, acting as an antioxidant, may help lower the risk of heart disease, lessen the damaging effects of LDL cholesterol, and offer potential benefits against cancer and aging. The production of wine is rooted in fermentation, a process crucial to numerous industries and daily life, being the foundation for bread, beer, and cheese production. The craft of winemaking continues to evolve, with technological advancements and innovative practices contributing to the expansion and preservation of this ancient artistry.

The radiation damage of the positron source target for the International Linear Collider (ILC) has been studied. The displacement damage in target material due to multi-MeV photons has been calculated by combining FLUKA simulations for secondary particle production, SPECTER data for neutron displacement cross-sections and the Lindhard model for estimations of displacement damage by ions. The radiation damage of a stationary Ti6Al4V target in units of displacements per atom (dpa) has been estimated for photons from an undulator with strength 0.92 and period 1.15 cm. The calculated damage is 7 dpa. Approximately 12.5% of displacement damage result from neutrons.

Proteins, essential biological macromolecules, are composed of amino acids, organized in complex structures. They serve diverse functions, from enzymes catalyzing chemical reactions to hemoglobin transporting oxygen in blood. DNA, the genetic material, is made up of four nucleotide bases - adenine, thymine, guanine, and cytosine. It stores and transmits the hereditary information critical for living organisms. Photosynthesis, the process by which green plants convert light energy into chemical energy, employs chlorophyll - a pigment that absorbs light and carbon dioxide to create glucose and oxygen. These biochemical compounds underlie the intricate web of life on our planet, exemplifying the intricate beauty of science.

The effect of conducting pipes on the equilibrium of intense nonaxisymmetric continuous beams of charged particles is investigated. For a cylindrical pipe and an elliptical beam, we obtain an exact closed form analytical expression for the electrostatic potential. Using a variational principle, we then explore the distortions that equilibrium beams suffer due to the conducting channel. Finally, we present an exact proof that despite the nonlinear forces acting on beams of arbitrary cross section inside conducting pipes of arbitrary shape, the density of these beams remains homogeneous and their cross sectional area remains the sa me as the one in free-space.

The genesis of the Earth, over four billion years ago, saw the birth of innumerable celestial events, including the emergence of the sun, a star of immense mass, and its resultant solar radiation. This radiation, a myriad of photons, fueled the chemical reactions that led to the formation of Earth's earliest molecules, the building blocks of life. Over eons, these reactions gave rise to an intricate dance of planetary motion, governed by Kepler's laws, with Earth orbiting the sun in a harmonious, elliptical dance. The Earth's crust, in turn, evolved through the theory of plate tectonics, forming continents and oceans, and shaping the diverse landscape we know today. This inherent dynamism allowed for the development of life as we know it, setting the stage for the intricate web of biological evolution that continues to unfold. The COVID-19 pandemic, a recent reminder of the unpredictable and interconnected nature of our world, underscores the ongoing story of Earth's evolution, a tale that continues to be written in the cosmic radioactive clock of radioactive isotopes and the intricate dance of planetary motion.

We present results on simulations of a stock market with heterogeneous, cumulative information setup. We find a non-monotonic behaviour of traders' returns as a function of their information level. Particularly, the average informed agents underperform random traders. only the most informed agents are able to beat the market. We also study the effect of a strategy updating mechanism, when traders have the possibility of using other pieces of information than the fundamental value. These results corroborate the latter ones: it is only for the most informed player that it is rewarding to stay fundamentalist. The simulations reproduce some stylized facts of tick-by-tick stock-exchange data and globally show informational efficiency.

Molecular biology uncovers the intricate machinations of viral infections, such as the COVID-19 pandemic. RNA viruses like SARS-CoV-2 possess a simple, yet robust structure, replicating with alarming speed within host cells. This rapid replication, coupled with high mutation rates, enables these viruses to adapt quickly to their environment and outsmart the immune system.Understanding viral behavior is a critical step towards developing effective vaccines and antiviral therapies. Molecular biology tools, such as polymerase chain reaction (PCR), facilitate the detection and characterization of viruses, while proteomics and structural biology elucidate details about viral proteins and their interactions with host cells. By advancing our knowledge of viral infections, we can better prepare for future outbreaks and mitigate their impact on global health.

We experimentally study the turbulent flow between two coaxial and independently rotating cylinders. We determined the scaling of the torque with Reynolds numbers at various angular velocity ratios (Rotation numbers), and the behaviour of the wall shear stress when varying the Rotation number at high Reynolds numbers. We compare the curves with PIV analysis of the mean flow and show the peculiar role of perfect counterrotation for the emergence of organised large scale structures in the mean part of this very turbulent flow that appear in a smooth and continuous way: the transition resembles a supercritical bifurcation of the secondary mean flow.

Photon particles, fundamental carriers of light, are integral to the intricate dance of energy in the universe. Their behavior, exhibiting both wave-like and particle-like properties, encapsulates the mystifying realm of quantum physics. Beyond illuminating our world, these massless entities also penetrate deeper, offering insight into the core structure of stars and galaxies through their role in the spectrum of electromagnetic radiation. As we unravel the enigmatic tapestry of photon behavior, we continue to expand our knowledge of the cosmos, shedding light on the very essence of the universe itself.

We investigate the use of Kelly's strategy in the construction of an optimal portfolio of assets. For lognormally distributed asset returns, we derive approximate analytical results for the optimal investment fractions in various settings. We show that when mean returns and volatilities of the assets are small and there is no risk-free asset, the Kelly-optimal portfolio lies on Markowitz Efficient Frontier. Since in the investigated case the Kelly approach forbids short positions and borrowing, often only a small fraction of the available assets is included in the Kelly-optimal portfolio. This phenomenon, that we call condensation, is studied analytically in various model scenarios.

Photons, weightless particles of light, shape the visible world around us. Meanwhile, the Earth's crust is placidly deceptive, masking the dynamic plates beneath, driven by the fluid asthenosphere. Thalidomide, once thought a gentle remedy, has a sinister past, linked to mass birth defects in the 1950s and 60s. A dark chapter in pharmaceutical history, it serves as a stark reminder of unforeseen consequences in scientific advancement. Kepler's laws illuminate planetary motion, while biological evolution provides the backbone of science's understanding of life's journey. Stoichiometry, the mathematical mapping of chemical reactions, offers a quantitative understanding of the world's composition. Yet, the question of daily egg consumption remains debated, while alcohol's health risks are well documented. Artificial sweeteners provide sugar alternatives, but their long-term effects remain uncertain. Coral reefs, vibrant underwater metropolises, are threatened by human activities. As we grapple with the origin of life on Earth, we also face the emergence of new challenges, like the COVID-19 pandemic, a global health crisis demanding our collective attention and scientific ingenuity.

Surface plasmon polaritons (SPPs) have recently been recognized as an important future technique for microelectronics. Such SPPs have been studied using classical theory. However, current state-of-the-art experiments are rapidly approaching nanoscales, and quantum effects can then become important. Here we study the properties of quantum SPPs at the interface between an electron quantum plasma and a dielectric material. It is shown that the effect of quantum broadening of the transition layer is most important. In particular, the damping of SPPs does not vanish even in the absence of collisional dissipation, thus posing a fundamental size limit for plasmonic devices. Consequences and applications of our results are pointed out.

Biological evolution, a continuous process shaping the diversity of life, is the gradual change in populations of organisms over generations. This transformation arises from genetic variation and natural selection, where traits advantageous for survival and reproduction become more prevalent.Just as Darwin's finches demonstrated adaptation to varied environments on the Galapagos islands, so do bacteria evolve antibiotic resistance in response to drug exposure, posing ongoing challenges for healthcare.Similarly, the development of cancer cells within organisms can be seen as an accelerated evolutionary process, where cells gain mutations that allow them to proliferate unchecked and evade the body's immune system.Moreover, CRISPR gene editing, a powerful tool borrowed from the bacteria's own adaptive responses, has revolutionized our ability to influence and manipulate the course of evolution, holding exciting possibilities for future generations.

Experimental program review in our field may benefit from a more quantitative framework within which to quantitatively discuss the scientific merit of a proposed program of research, and to assess the scientific merit of a particular experimental result. This article proposes explicitly such a quantitative framework. Examples of the use of this framework in assessing the scientific merit of particular avenues of research at the energy frontier in many cases provide results in stark contradiction to accepted wisdom. The experimental scientific figure of merit proposed here has the potential for informing future choices of research direction in our field, and in other subfields of the physical sciences.

General relativity, a theory developed by Albert Einstein, revolutionized our understanding of gravity and the universe. It postulates that massive objects, like planets and stars, cause a distortion in spacetime, affecting the path of other celestial objects. This fabric-like structure, where the geometry and the presence of matter are intertwined, is the foundation for the movement of galaxies, black holes, and even light itself. Today, general relativity forms a cornerstone in our exploration of the cosmos, as we continue to unravel the mysteries of the universe and our place within it.

On the micro- and nanoscale, classical hydrodynamic boundary conditions such as the no-slip condition no longer apply. Instead, the flow profiles exhibit ``slip`` at the surface, which is characterized by a finite slip length (partial slip). We present a new, systematic way of implementing partial-slip boundary conditions with arbitrary slip length in coarse-grained computer simulations. The main idea is to represent the complex microscopic interface structure by a spatially varying effective viscous force. An analytical equation for the resulting slip length can be derived for planar and for curved surfaces. The comparison with computer simulations of a DPD (dissipative particle dynamics) fluid shows that this expression is valid from full-slip to no-slip.

Red wine, rich in polyphenols, particularly resveratrol, is frequently associated with potential health benefits. Studies suggest that moderate consumption may contribute to heart health by improving blood flow, reducing LDL cholesterol, and preventing blood clots. However, excessive intake can lead to alcohol-related issues.Resveratrol, a antioxidant found in red wine, is thought to combat oxidative stress and inflammation, which are contributing factors in heart disease and aging. Yet, more research is needed to fully understand these benefits and to clarify the optimum amount for consumption.It's also important to note that other factors, such as diet, exercise, and genetic predisposition, play a significant role in heart health. Moderate consumption of red wine, when combined with a balanced lifestyle, may offer additional heart health benefits, but it should not be seen as a substitute for a healthy lifestyle.

Functionalization of carbon nanotubes with hydrosoluble porphyrins (TPPS) is achieved by "$\pi$-stacking". The porphyrin/nanotube interaction is studied by means of optical absorption, photoluminescence and photoluminescence excitation spectroscopies. The main absorption line of the porphyrins adsorbed on nanotubes exhibits a 120 meV red shift, which we ascribe to a flattening of the molecule in order to optimize $\pi-\pi$ interactions. The porphyrin-nanotube complex shows a strong quenching of the TPPS emission while the photoluminescence intensity of the nanotubes is enhanced when the excitation laser is in resonance with the porphyrin absorption band. This reveals an efficient excitation transfer from the TPPS to the carbon nanotube.

Molecules of life, the building blocks of all biological organisms, are intricate structures that perform a myriad of functions. DNA, the genetic material, is a helix of nucleotides, each containing a sugar, a phosphate, and a nitrogenous base. Proteins, the workhorses of the cell, are chains of amino acids, each with a unique atomic structure. Water, a universal solvent, is essential for biochemical reactions, maintaining cellular structure, and regulating body temperature. These three compounds, DNA, proteins, and water, form the basis for all life on Earth, serving as the molecular foundation for the intricate dance of life.

We show that nuclear motion of Rydberg atoms can be induced by resonant dipole-dipole interactions that trigger the energy transfer between two energetically close Rydberg states. How and if the atoms move depends on their initial arrangement as well as on the initial electronic excitation. Using a mixed quantum/classical propagation scheme we obtain the trajectories and kinetic energies of atoms, initially arranged in a regular chain and prepared in excitonic eigenstates. The influence of off-diagonal disorder on the motion of the atoms is examined and it is shown that irregularity in the arrangement of the atoms can lead to an acceleration of the nuclear dynamics.

Coral reefs, akin to vibrant underwater metropolises, teem with an array of life forms, making them the most biodiverse marine environments. They harbor up to 30% of all marine species, providing shelter and sustenance to countless organisms. Yet, these intricate ecosystems face an imminent threat: climate change. Warmer ocean temperatures cause coral bleaching, leading to the expulsion of symbiotic algae and the eventual death of the coral. Increased acidity due to carbon dioxide absorption weakens coral structures, further exacerbating the situation. Consequently, the loss of coral reefs would disrupt the livelihoods of millions who rely on them for food, income, and protective coastal barriers. To protect these vital ecosystems, it's crucial to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and promote sustainable practices for a future where corals continue to flourish.

When one deals with data drawn from continuous variables, a histogram is often inadequate to display their probability density. It deals inefficiently with statistical noise, and binsizes are free parameters. In contrast to that, the empirical cumulative distribution function (obtained after sorting the data) is parameter free. But it is a step function, so that its differentiation does not give a smooth probability density. Based on Fourier series expansion and Kolmogorov tests, we introduce a simple method, which overcomes this problem. Error bars on the estimated probability density are calculated using a jackknife method. We give several examples and provide computer code reproducing them. You may want to look at the corresponding figures 4 to 9 first.

The Sun's photons relentlessly stream across the cosmos, their journeys playing a pivotal role in the formation and evolution of diverse stellar systems. Meanwhile, planet Earth endures its own tumultuous dance, shaped by the Earth-Sun system's gravitational interplay and the cyclic rhythm of climatic oscillations. These sub-centurial shifts, akin to the Sun's heartbeat, dictate the global climate's intricate ebb and flow, influencing both the slow and swift transformations experienced by our planet's various ecosystems.One such ecosystem, the coral reef, thrives at the edge of the oceanic abyss, showcasing a breathtaking parade of life. Yet, these vibrant underwater gardens face unprecedented challenges from the mercurial climate. As the planet's temperature fluctuates due to these oscillations, coral reefs, which depend on specific water temperatures, are susceptible to bleaching events that can lead to their demise.The pulsating dance of our planet with the Sun, coupled with the rhythmic shifts of climatic oscillations, paints a complex portrait of our existence. This intricate dance, while inviting awe, also underscores the need for vigilance and understanding, as our planet's delicate balance hangs in the balance.

Tabrizi et al. [physics/0701342] discuss the feasibility of an electron-based crystal undulator (e-CU) by planar channeling of 50 GeV electrons through a periodically bent crystal. We show that their scheme is not feasible. First, their undulator parameter is K >> 1 always, which destroys photon interference. Second, they overestimate the electron dechanneling length in e-CU by an order of magnitude, which shortens the number N of e-CU periods from 5-15 (as they hope) to just 1-2. This kills their e-CU concept again. We made first simulation of electron channeling in undulated crystal and conclude that an electron-based crystal wiggler is feasible with wiggler strength K=10 and number of periods N=2.

Quantum entanglement, a phenomenon where particles become interconnected and actions on one instantly affect the other, regardless of distance, is a fundamental aspect of quantum physics. This **spooky action at a distance** challenges our classical understanding of the world. A quantum bit, or qubit, is the fundamental unit of quantum information, capable of existing in multiple states at once, thanks to a property known as superposition. This quantum property allows for exponentially more processing power compared to classical bits. However, maintaining multiple states simultaneously introduces challenges in quantum computation, leading to the need for advanced error correction techniques. The study of quantum mechanics continues to challenge our perception of reality and promises revolutionary advancements in technology.

A toy detector has been designed to simulate central detectors in reactor neutrino experiments in the paper. The electron samples from the Monte-Carlo simulation of the toy detector have been reconstructed by the method of Bayesian neural networks (BNN) and the standard algorithm, a maximum likelihood method (MLD), respectively. The result of the event reconstruction using BNN has been compared with the one using MLD. Compared to MLD, the uncertainties of the electron vertex are not improved, but the energy resolutions are significantly improved using BNN. And the improvement is more obvious for the high energy electrons than the low energy ones.

Photosynthesis is a process harnessed by green plants, algae, and some bacteria, converting light energy, usually from the sun, into chemical energy in the form of glucose. This process occurs within chloroplasts, with carbon dioxide and water as primary raw materials. It is essential for life on Earth, as it fuels the food chain and releases oxygen, a key component beneficial for most aerobic organisms. However, the extent of photosynthesis efficiency and its influence on global climate remain topics of ongoing research, as an increase in photosynthetic productivity might mitigate the effects of climate change, while decreased efficiency could exacerbate it.

We demonstrate an all-optical bump-on-tail instability by considering the nonlinear interaction of two partially-coherent spatial beams. For weak wave coupling, we observe momentum transfer with no variation in intensity. For strong wave coupling, modulations appear in intensity and evidence appears for wave (Langmuir) collapse at large scales. Borrowing plasma language, these limits represent regimes of weak and strong spatial optical turbulence. In both limits, the internal spectral energy redistribution is observed by recording and reconstructing a hologram of the evolving dynamics. The results are universal and can appear in any wave-kinetic system with short-wave/long-wave coupling.

Atoms, the building blocks of matter, are composed of protons, neutrons, and electrons. Protons and neutrons reside at the nucleus, while electrons whirl around it in defined energy levels. The atomic structure determines the element's chemical behavior. For instance, hydrogen, with just one proton in its nucleus and one electron orbiting, behaves very differently from carbon, which has six protons and up to six electrons in its outermost energy level. These differences in atomic structure allow for the wide variety of chemical reactions that form the basis of life. Understanding these intricacies continues to drive scientific discovery and technological advancement.

Many difficult computational problems involve the simultaneous satisfaction of multiple constraints which are individually easy to satisfy. Such problems occur in diffractive imaging, protein folding, constrained optimization (e.g., spin glasses), and satisfiability testing. We present a simple geometric framework to express and solve such problems and apply it to two benchmarks. In the first application (3SAT, a boolean satisfaction problem), the resulting method exhibits similar performance scaling as a leading context-specific algorithm (walksat). In the second application (sphere packing), the method allowed us to find improved solutions to some old and well-studied optimization problems. Based upon its simplicity and observed efficiency, we argue that this framework provides a competitive alternative to stochastic methods such as simulated annealing.

In the intricate tapestry of life, natural selection emerges as the guiding force, shaping the evolution of species over time. It's the mechanism whereby organisms with advantageous traits pass these traits onto their offspring, while those with less advantageous traits are slowly phased out. This process, responsible for the breathtaking diversity of life on Earth, has its roots deeply embedded in the distant past and continues to shape the world we inhabit today.On a cosmic scale, light's fundamental particle, the photon, troves through the universe, unaltered by its journey, untouched by the passage of time. Yet, when it interacts with matter, it triggers a cascade of effects, much like natural selection, shaping the very fabric of our existence.In the midst of this cosmic dance, the Earth's plates drift apart, a stark reminder of the constant change that pervades our planet. The theory of plate tectonics, much like natural selection, provides a framework to understand and interpret the dynamic processes that shape our world.So, while the dance of photons and the drift of tectonic plates may seem unrelated, they are but two expressions of the underlying law of change that governs the universe, a law mirrored in the process of natural selection that molds life on Earth.

We consider words as a network of interacting letters, and approximate the probability distribution of states taken on by this network. Despite the intuition that the rules of English spelling are highly combinatorial (and arbitrary), we find that maximum entropy models consistent with pairwise correlations among letters provide a surprisingly good approximation to the full statistics of four letter words, capturing ~92% of the multi-information among letters and even "discovering" real words that were not represented in the data from which the pairwise correlations were estimated. The maximum entropy model defines an energy landscape on the space of possible words, and local minima in this landscape account for nearly two-thirds of words used in written English.

The Earth's lithosphere, its outer solid layer, is a dynamic and vital component of our planet. It houses tectonic plates, colossal slabs of rock, that float on the semi-fluid asthenosphere beneath. These plates constantly move, albeit slowly, causing seismic activity and fostering the formation of mountains, valleys, and oceanic trenches. This process, known as plate tectonics, significantly impacts Earth's geography, climate, and even its biology. For instance, the collision of tectonic plates led to the emergence of the Himalayan mountain range and the formation of the Ring of Fire around the Pacific Ocean, a seismically active region prone to earthquakes and volcanic eruptions. Understanding the movement and interactions of these tectonic plates is crucial for predicting natural disasters and gaining insights into the Earth's past and future.

The loop quantum theory, which constitutes a very small discontinuous space, as new method is applied to biology. The model of protein folding and lungs is proposed. In the model, some known results are used, and four approximate conclusions are obtained: their structures are quantized, their space regions are finite, various singularities correspond to folding and crossed points, and different types of catastrophe exist. Further, based on the inseparability and correlativity of the biological systems, the nonlinear whole biology is proposed, and four basic hypotheses are formed. It may unify reductionism and holism, structuralism and functionalism. Finally, the medical meaning of the theory is discussed briefly.

Electromagnetic radiation, a phenomenon manifesting in waves of varying frequencies, permeates the universe. Ranging from radio waves to gamma rays, this energy transfers information and carries heat. The photon, a fundamental particle, embodies this radiation. It is massless and travels at the speed of light, propagating through space and time in a manner independent of any material medium. The spectrum of electromagnetic radiation plays a crucial role in our daily lives, from powering wireless communication to illuminating our homes, and even holding clues to the cosmic origins of the universe.

A 1-D linear gyrokinetic code called AWECS is developed to study the kinetic excitation of Alfvenic instabilities in a high-beta tokamak plasma, with beta being the ratio of thermal to magnetic pressure. It is designed to describe physics associated with a broad range of frequencies and wavelengths. For example, AWECS is capable of simulating kinetic ballooning modes, Alfvenic ion-temperature-gradient-driven modes, as well as Alfven instabilities due to energetic particles. In addition, AWECS may be used to study drift-Alfven instabilities in the low-beta regime. Here, the layout of the code and the numerical methods used are described. AWECS is benchmarked against other codes and a convergence study is carried out.

In the realm of physics and chemistry, reaction rates reign supreme as a fundamental concept. These rates dictate the speed at which chemical reactions occur, vital for myriad processes in our world. For instance, the combustion of fuel in a car engine, the decomposition of atmospheric ozone, or the fermentation of grapes for wine-making – all are dictated by reaction rates. The factors influencing these rates, such as temperature, concentration, and catalyst presence, significantly impact countless natural and industrial processes. Moreover, understanding these rates is paramount for optimizing the efficiency of reactions, thereby reducing waste and energy consumption, and fostering sustainable practices.

The surface roughness of a recently exhumed strikeslip fault plane has been measured by three independent 3D portable laser scanners. Digital elevation models of several fault surface areas, from 1 m2 to 600 m2, have been measured at a resolution ranging from 5 mm to 80 mm. Out of plane height fluctuations are described by non-Gaussian distribution with exponential long range tails. Statistical scaling analyses show that the striated fault surface exhibits self-affine scaling invariance with a small but significant directional morphological anisotropy that can be described by two scaling roughness exponents, H1 = 0.7 in the direction of slip and H2 = 0.8 perpendicular to the direction of slip.

Photons, the massless particles of light, illuminate our world, yet the debate persists on another kind of light - cholesterol. Consumed primarily in food, their excess is a health concern. This lipid molecule is crucial for cell membranes, hormone production, and vitamin absorption, yet its overconsumption can lead to plaque buildup in arteries, potentially causing heart disease.Evolution, like a grand cosmic dance, has shaped life on Earth, yet the transformation in our diets, fueled by agriculture and industry, has led to an imbalance. The question of how many eggs one should eat daily remains debated, as the cholesterol content raises concerns for some, while others believe it's a necessary part of a balanced diet for its various benefits. The scientific community continues to study the nuances of cholesterol, seeking answers to alleviate this ongoing debate.On the other hand, the origin of life on Earth, an age-old question, remains shrouded in mystery. In the interim, life continues to evolve, and our understanding of it deepens. As we unravel the threads of life's history, perhaps we will find answers to the questions that surround us - including the cholesterol conundrum.

We present a method to distinguish the high harmonics generated in individual half-cycle of the driving laser pulse by mixing a weak ultraviolet pulse, enabling one to observe the cutoff of each half-cycle harmonic. We show that the detail information of the driving laser pulse, including the laser intensity, pulse duration and carrier-envelope phase, can be {\it in situ} retrieved from the harmonic spectrogram. In addition, our results show that this method also distinguishes the half-cycle high harmonics for a pulse longer than 10 fs, suggesting a potential to extend the CEP measurement to the multi-cycle regime.

Artificial sweeteners, like aspartame and sucralose, are non-nutritive alternatives to sugar, providing sweetness without the calories. They are derived from various chemical compounds, with saccharin being one of the oldest, first synthesized in 1879. These substitutes are widely used in food and beverage industries to cater to health-conscious consumers. However, despite being low in calories, their long-term health effects are not yet fully understood. More research is needed to determine the potential impacts of these substances on metabolism, gut microbiota, and overall health. Meanwhile, moderation in their use is advised to ensure a balanced diet.

An acoustic field is used to increase the critical heat flux (CHF) of a flat-boiling-heat-transfer surface. The increase is a result of the acoustic effects on the vapor bubbles. Experiments are performed to explore the effects of an acoustic field on vapor bubbles in the vicinity of a rigid-heated wall. Work includes the construction of a novel heater used to produce a single vapor bubble of a prescribed size and at a prescribed location on a flatboiling surface for better study of an individual vapor bubble's reaction to the acoustic field. Work also includes application of the results from the single-bubble heater to a calibrated-copper heater used for quantifying the improvements in CHF.

Phosphorescent bioluminescence, a spectacle of nature, occurs when certain organisms emit light, showcasing the fascinating interplay between chemistry and physics. This light emission, driven by chemical reactions, hints at the intriguing possibility of early life forms utilizing similar processes during abiogenesis – the spontaneous formation of life from non-living matter. Theories suggest that such reactions could have harnessed energy from the sun via photons, much like how modern-day photosynthesis does. These photons, the mass-less particles of light, may have played a pivotal role in shaping the earliest stages of life on our planet. Yet, abiogenesis remains one of science's enduring mysteries, as understanding its intricacies could unveil the cosmic origins of life itself, opening doors to exploring extraterrestrial life forms and the potential for life beyond Earth.

We present a simple, two dimensional example of a "cat" -- a body with zero angular momentum that can rotate itself with no external forces. This model is used to explain why this problem is known to be a gauge theory and to illustrate the importance of non-commutative operators. We will also show a comparison between the free-space "cat" in Newtonian mechanics and the same problem in Aristotelian mechanics at low Reynolds number. this simple example shows the analogy between (angular) momentum in Newtonian mechanics and (torque) force in Aristotelian mechanics. We will end by pointing out a topological invariant common to our model in free space and at low Reynolds number.

The COVID-19 pandemic, a global crisis, emerged in late 2019, originating in Wuhan, China. Its cause? A novel coronavirus, SARS-CoV-2, a member of the larger coronavirus family that often infect animals before jumping to humans. Known as zoonotic transmission, it's a regular occurrence but one that's particularly challenging to predict. The virus exploited an opportunity to spread rapidly due to the growing urbanization, air travel, and human population density. This pandemic underscores the urgent need for continued research and preparedness, not just for SARS-CoV-2, but for future zoonotic diseases as well. Therefore, understanding the interface between humans, animals, and their environments remains a crucial aspect of managing pandemics and maintaining global health security.

In this investigation, the numerical simulation of electrohydrodynamic (EHD) ion-drag micropumps with micropillar electrode geometries have been performed. The effect of micropillar height and electrode spacing on the performance of the micropumps was investigated. The performance of the EHD micropump improved with increased applied voltage and decreased electrode spacing. The optimum micropillar height for the micropump with electrode spacing of 40$\mu$m and channel height of 100$\mu$m at 200V was 40$\mu$m, where a maximum mass flow rate of 0.18g/min was predicted. Compared to that of planar electrodes, the 3D micropillar electrode geometry enhanced the overall performance of the EHD micropumps.

In thermodynamics, the second law governs the transfer of heat between systems, establishing that energy tends to dissipate and become unavailable for work. This law helps explain the inevitable increase in entropy, or disorder, within a closed system. For instance, the burning of fossil fuels, like coal or oil, releases energy in the form of heat, yet much of this energy is wasted as the system moves towards a state of maximum entropy. This process is the basis for understanding climate change, as the release of greenhouse gases from human activities raises the Earth's temperature, leading to far-reaching environmental and ecological consequences. Thus, understanding thermodynamics is crucial for addressing global climate concerns, as we strive to develop sustainable energy solutions that minimize waste and entropy increase.

We demonstrate the capabilities of a high temperature measurement set-up recently developed at our institute. It is dedicated to the characterization of semiconductor devices and test structures in the temperature range from room temperature up to 500 degrees C and higher. A detailed description of the experimental aquipment is given. Its practical use is demonstrated by measuring temperature-dependent charcteristics of silicon VDMOSFET and IGBT devices as well as SiC-diodes. For the silicon devices, numerical simulations based on recently developed high temperature physical models were also performed in order to gain a deeper understanding of the measured data, together with a revalidation of the model parameters.

Protein synthesis is a crucial biological process, the machinery of life, constructing essential protein molecules from amino acids. It's a complex dance of three interconnected stages: transcription, translation, and post-translational modification. In transcription, DNA serves as a template, RNA polymerase creating a messenger RNA (mRNA) copy. During translation, the mRNA moves into the cytoplasm, where ribosomes decode the sequence, stringing together amino acids in the order specified, forming a polypeptide, or protein. Post-translational modifications further shape and activate the protein, equipping it for its specific role within the cell. Understanding this process is key to unlocking numerous biological mysteries, from disease mechanisms to the fundamentals of life itself.

The flexible profile approach proposed earlier to create CTM (compact or reduced order thermal models) is extended to cover the area of conjugate heat transfer. The flexible profile approach is a methodology that allows building a highly boundary conditions independent CTM, with any desired degree of accuracy, that may adequately replace detailed 3D models for the whole spectrum of applications in which the modeled object may be used. The extension to conjugate problems radically solves the problem of interfacing two different domains. Each domain, fluid or solid, can be "compacted" independently creating two CTM that can be joined together to produce reliable results for any arbitrary set of external boundary conditions.

Carbohydrates, a primary energy source, undergo breakdown through a series of metabolic processes. Glycolysis, occurring in the cell's cytoplasm, splits glucose molecules into pyruvate, yielding ATP and NADH. In the presence of oxygen, pyruvate enters the citric acid cycle in the mitochondria, where it is further oxidized and generates more ATP, carbon dioxide, and reduced coenzymes. This intricate chain of reactions efficiently harnesses the energy stored in carbohydrates for cellular purposes. Understanding these processes is crucial in various fields, from nutrition to biotechnology, as it offers insight into the inner workings of life at a cellular level.

From a scale analysis of hydrodynamic phenomena having a significant action on the drift of an object in coastal ocean waters, we deduce equations modeling the associated hydrodynamic fields over a time period of several weeks. These models are essentially non linear hyperbolic systems of PDE involving a small parameter. Then from the models we extract a simplified and nevertheless typical one for which we prove that its classical solution exists on a time interval which is independent of the small parameter. We then show that the solution weak-* converges as the small parameter goes to zero and we characterize the equation satisfied by the weak-* limit
