For these types of potentials, we propose very accurate analytical energy formulae which improve a lot the corresponding formulae that can be found in literature.

In the realm of physics, the concept of thermodynamics offers insights into the behavior of energy in a system. A key principle is the first law, also known as the law of conservation of energy, which states that energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transformed. This law governs the efficiency of engines and the transfer of heat in various systems.Within our world, the second law of thermodynamics, the law of entropy, stands as a fundamental point. Entropy, a measure of disorder or randomness, tends to increase over time within a closed system, leading to a natural decay of organized structures. This law has profound implications in our understanding of the universe's expansion and the irreversibility of processes like the melting of ice or the aging of organisms.The third law of thermodynamics provides a boundary to the second law by stating that as a system approaches absolute zero, its entropy approaches a constant value. This establishes a universal minimum level of disorder, further emphasizing the interconnectedness and inherent order found in the universe.

We study the dynamics of epidemic and reaction-diffusion processes in metapopulation models with heterogeneous connectivity pattern. In SIR-like processes, along with the standard local epidemic threshold, the system exhibits a global invasion threshold. We provide an explicit expression of the threshold that sets a critical value of the diffusion/mobility rate below which the epidemic is not able to spread to a macroscopic fraction of subpopulations. The invasion threshold is found to be affected by the topological fluctuations of the metapopulation network. The presented results provide a general framework for the understanding of the effect of travel restrictions in epidemic containment.

Protein synthesis is a fundamental process in cells, where a sequence of amino acids links together to form a protein based on instructions from DNA. This intricate dance of macromolecules, catalyzed by the ribosome and transfer RNA, is the foundation of life, dictating the structure and function of all proteins within an organism. In simple terms, protein synthesis is like a cell's unique orchestra, crafting the interactive proteins that enable cellular growth, maintenance, and reproduction, each playing their part in the human body's symphony of life.

In this paper we investigate x-ray and $\gamma$-ray propagation in crystals having a constant strain gradient and flat or cylindrical surfaces. When a displacement field is present, we solve the Takagi-Taupin equations either by the Riemann-Green method or by a numerical method. We apply the results to study the operation of a double-crystal Laue-Laue diffractometer having a flat collimating crystal followed by a bent analyzer crystal. In particular, we examine the effect of the analyzer strain on the location of the diffraction peaks in the dispersive and non-dispersive setup, thus confirming our previously reported peak-location as being set only by the diffracting plane spacing on the analyzer entrance surface.

Carbohydrates, fundamental organic molecules that provide essential energy, undergo glycolysis and cellular respiration for their breakdown. Glycolysis, a process occurring in the cytoplasm, breaks down glucose into two pyruvate molecules, yielding ATP and NADH. In cellular respiration, pyruvate enters the mitochondrion, followed by the Krebs cycle and electron transport chain, generating more ATP and water, while releasing carbon dioxide as a waste product. This intricate biochemical dance powers most living organisms, from the smallest microbe to the largest mammals, making it a fundamental aspect of life on Earth.

Energy dissipation rate is an important parameter for nearly every experiment on turbulent flow. Mathematically precise relationships between energy dissipation rate and other measurable statistics for the case of anisotropic turbulence are useful to experimentalists. Such relationships are obtained for which the measurable statistics are the 3rd-order and 2nd-order velocity structure functions as well as the acceleration-velocity structure function. The relationships are derived using the Navier-Stokes equation without approximation. Approximate versions are obtained on the basis of local stationarity and local homogeneity. The latter are valid for arbitrary Reynolds numbers for the case of stationary, homogeneous turbulence. Precise use of the mathematics requires care noted in the Discussion section.

In the realm of virology, a single virus particle, or virion, is the agent of infectious disease. Virions are not alive, yet can replicate by hijacking host cells. The coronaviruses, like SARS-CoV-2 responsible for COVID-19, have enveloped spike proteins that facilitate attachment to human cells, initiating infection.Viral evolution occurs when genetic mutations, recombinations, or horizontal gene transfers result in altered virus behavior. The rapid spread of SARS-CoV-2 across the globe has been partly attributed to its high mutation rate and ability to evade host immune responses.These adaptions and modifications contribute to the ongoing issues in controlling viral epidemics, making it essential to monitor viral evolution and develop preventive measures accordingly. Understanding the complexities of viral behavior and evolution will be crucial in combating current and future pandemics.

Fifty years ago, John von Neumann compared the architecture of the brain with that of computers that he invented and which is still in use today. In those days, the organisation of computers was based on concepts of brain organisation. Here, we give an update on current results on the global organisation of neural systems. For neural systems, we outline how the spatial and topological architecture of neuronal and cortical networks facilitates robustness against failures, fast processing, and balanced network activation. Finally, we discuss mechanisms of self-organization for such architectures. After all, the organization of the brain might again inspire computer architecture.

In the realm of physics, Einstein's theory of general relativity revolutionized our understanding of gravity. This theory posits that massive objects, such as planets and stars, can warp the fabric of space-time around them, causing nearby objects to move along curved paths. This phenomenon, known as gravitational lensing, allows us to observe distant galaxies that would otherwise be hidden from view.Moreover, general relativity predicts that time may run slower near a massive object. This effect, known as time dilation, has been confirmed in experiments involving atomic clocks. This means that a clock on Earth would tick slower compared to an identical clock in space, far from any large mass.As we continue to explore the universe and refine our understanding of gravity, the mysteries of space-time keep scientists intrigued, pushing the boundaries of what we know about our cosmos.

A technique is proposed to generate attosecond pulse trains of radiation from a Free-Electron Laser amplifier. The optics-free technique synthesises a comb of longitudinal modes by applying a series of spatio-temporal shifts between the co-propagating radiation and electron bunch in the FEL. The modes may be phase-locked by modulating the electron beam energy at the mode spacing frequency. Three-dimensional simulations demonstrate the generation of a train of 400as pulses at giga-watt power levels evenly spaced by 2.5fs at a wavelength of 124 Angstrom. In the X-ray at wavelength 1.5 Angstrom, trains of 23as pulses evenly spaced by 150as and of peak power up to 6GW are predicted.

Marine bioluminescence, a captivating phenomenon, illuminates the depths of countless oceans. Bioluminescent organisms, such as jellyfish and deep-sea fish, generate their light through a chemical reaction called chemiluminescence. This process involves the oxidation of a chemical called luciferin, in the presence of the enzyme luciferase, producing a burst of blue-green or yellowish light. This fascinating spectacle serves multiple purposes, such as attracting prey, signaling, camouflaging, and deterring predators. The study of marine bioluminescence continues to unveil the wonders of the ocean, challenging our understanding of life's adaptations and evolutions in these unique environments.

In this work, Pseudo-Random Bit Generation (PRBG) based on 2D chaotic mappings of logistic type is considered. The sequences generated with two Pseudorandom Bit Generators (PRBGs) of this type are statistically tested and the computational effectiveness of the generators is estimated. The role played by the symmetry and the geometrical properties of the underlying chaotic attractors is also explored. Considering these PRBGs valid for cryptography, the size of the available key spaces are calculated. Additionally, a novel mechanism called 'symmetry-swap' is introduced in order to enhance the PRBG algorithm. It is shown that it can increase the degrees of freedom of the key space, while maintaining the speed and performance in the PRBG.

In the realm of modern medicine, drug development is a meticulous process that involves the design, testing, and production of pharmaceuticals to combat various diseases. A notable example is mRNA technology, which has revolutionized vaccine production, such as in the case of COVID-19 vaccines. This technology works by delivering a piece of the virus's genetic code to cells, instructing them to produce the antigen, stimulating an immune response without causing the actual disease.While drug development is indispensable for improving human health, it is not without its challenges. The process can be lengthy, expensive, and fraught with uncertainties due to the complexity of the human body and the diverse responses to treatment. However, advancements in technology, such as AI and machine learning, are being employed to streamline and expedite the process, potentially saving lives and alleviating suffering more efficiently.Just as the photon, a fundamental particle of light, traverses the universe without impediment, the pursuit of better medications continues, propelled by the indomitable spirit of human ingenuity and compassion.

The paper is devoted to elaboration of a novel specific indicator based on the modified Holder exponents. This indicator has been used for forecasting critical points of financial time series and crashes of the USA stock market. The proposed approach is based on the hypothesis, which claims that before market critical points occur the dynamics of financial time series radically changes, namely time series become smoother. The approach has been tested on the stylized data and real USA stock market data. It has been shown that it is possible to forecast such critical points of financial time series as large upward and downward movements and trend changes. On this basis a new trading strategy has been elaborated and tested.

The process of species adaptation is a dynamic response to changes in their environment, a natural phenomenon that has shaped life on Earth. For instance, the peppered moth (Biston betularia) in Britain adapted during the industrial revolution. As the industrialization darkened trees, a darker form of the moth emerged, blending in and surviving predator detection more effectively. This is an example of phenotypic plasticity and microevolution.In the face of global climate change, species are now adapting at an unprecedented scale. Polar bears (Ursus maritimus) are shifting their feeding habits to include more fish, as sea ice continues to melt and seals become scarce. Similarly, some birds are altering their migratory patterns to avoid extreme temperatures and altered food availability.Evolution is not just a story of the past. it is an ongoing process that determines the resilience and survival of species in a rapidly changing world. The ability of organisms to evolve and adapt will be crucial in ensuring biodiversity preservation in the face of human-induced environmental alterations.

The base is the Lagrangian of symmetry and its dynamical breaking or Higgs breaking. When the soliton-like solutions of the scalar field equations are substituted into the spinor field equations, in the approximation of non-relativity we derive the Morse-type potential, whose energy spectrum is the GMO mass formula and its modified accurate mass formula. According to the symmetry of s-c quarks, the heavy flavor hadrons which made of u,d and c quarks may be classified by SU(3) octet and decuplet. Then some simple mass formulas are obtained, from this we predict some masses of unknown hadrons.

In the realm of physics, the concept of space-time curvature sheds light on the intricate dance of matter and energy. This theory, popularized by Albert Einstein, proposes that massive objects, like stars or planets, warp the fabric of space-time around them. This curvature, in turn, influences the path of other objects moving within it, effectively shaping the cosmos we inhabit. The concept of space-time further suggests that gravity arises from this curvature, not from a pulling force as previously thought. It's a captivating interplay of mass, space, and time that continues to unfold as we delve deeper into the mysteries of the universe.

Angular momentum densities of electromagnetic beams are connected to helicity (circular polarization) and topological charge (azimuthal phase shift and vorticity). Computing the electromagnetic fields emitted by a circular antenna array, analytic expressions are found for the densities of energy, linear and angular momentum in terms of helicity and vorticity. It is found that the angular momentum density can be separated into spin and orbital parts, a result that is known to be true in a beam geometry. The results are of importance for information-rich radio astronomy and space physics as well as novel radio, radar, and wireless communication concepts.

Alcohol, primarily ethanol, is a psychoactive substance derived from fermented fruits, grains, or sugars. It alters brain function, temporarily impairing judgment, coordination, and reaction time. Long-term consumption can lead to a range of health issues, including liver disease, heart problems, and increased risk of certain cancers. Alcohol is also implicated in causing accidents and violent behavior. Moderation is key, as the World Health Organization (WHO) advises that no level of alcohol consumption is considered entirely safe for health. On the brighter side, alcohol has historical and cultural significance, contributing to social gatherings, traditions, and even medicine in some societies. It's a fascinating study, where science and culture intersect, with its impacts on human health, behavior, and society being a continuous area of exploration.

We propose a simple method to extract the community structure of large networks. Our method is a heuristic method that is based on modularity optimization. It is shown to outperform all other known community detection method in terms of computation time. Moreover, the quality of the communities detected is very good, as measured by the so-called modularity. This is shown first by identifying language communities in a Belgian mobile phone network of 2.6 million customers and by analyzing a web graph of 118 million nodes and more than one billion links. The accuracy of our algorithm is also verified on ad-hoc modular networks. .

Phosphorescent algae illuminate the ocean's depths, their bioluminescence a spectacle of nature. This phenomenon is a result of energy stored within their molecules, a manifestation of quantum physics at work. As sea levels rise, these algae could potentially relocate coral reefs, a crucial biodiverse ecosystem, to less hospitable environments. Carbon emissions from human activities contribute to this rise, disrupting delicate marine ecosystems. The rapid change in oceanic conditions could lead to the extinction of various marine species, threatening the global food chain. Thus, understanding and mitigating our impact on the ocean becomes pivotal in preserving its rich ecosystems and the services they provide.

We propose a promising scheme to decelerate a cw filtering out molecular beam using a red-detuned quasi-cw semi-Gaussian laser beam. By using Monte-Carlo simulation method, we demonstrate this optical Stark deceleration scheme, and study its decelerated dynamic process for a cw ND3 molecular beam as well as the dependence of the deceleration effect on the border width of the semi-Gaussian beam. Our study shows that the proposed scheme can be used to efficiently slow a cw ND3 molecular beam, and obtain a relative average kinetic-energy loss of 9.33% by using a single semi-Gaussian beam with a well depth of 7.3 mK.

Quantum oscillations in condensed matter physics reveal intriguing behaviors at low temperatures. These oscillations, appearing in materials like metals and semiconductors, stem from the quantum mechanical nature of electrons and their cyclic motion in a magnetic field. They offer insights into the electronic properties of materials and can potentially lead to advancements in technology, such as superconductivity and spintronics.However, even these oscillations aren't fixed in time. Natural oscillation patterns vary over various timescales, with some lasting hundreds of years. The study of these long-term patterns in both quantum systems and geophysical phenomena, like climate and plate tectonics, can help us predict future events and deepen our understanding of the universe's intricate rhythms. This interplay between the microscopic and macroscopic scales showcases the interconnectedness and harmony within nature.

We propose a model of random diffusion to investigate flow fluctuations in complex networks. We derive an analytical law showing that the dependence of fluctuations with the mean traffic in a network is ruled by the delicate interplay of three factors, respectively of dynamical, topological and statistical nature. In particular, we demonstrate that the existence of a power-law scaling characterizing the flow fluctuations at every node in the network can not be claimed for. We show the validity of this scaling breakdown under quite general topological and dynamical situations by means of different traffic algorithms and by analyzing real data.

Quantum entanglement, a peculiar phenomenon, links particles not just in space but also in time, a concept beyond conventional understanding. Entangled particles, once interacted, remain connected irrespective of distance, exhibiting instantaneous correlations upon measurement. This intricate connection defies the classical notion of causality, challenging the very foundations of Einstein's relativistic space-time. The mysteries of quantum entanglement, thus, continue to fascinate physicists, offering glimpses into a world where particles seemingly dance to a rhythm beyond the observable universe.

We report the observation of imaging beyond the diffraction limit due to bound surface states in negative refraction photonic crystals. We achieve an effective negative index figure-of-merit [-Re(n)/Im(n)] of at least 380, ~125x improvement over recent efforts in the near-infrared, with a 0.4 THz bandwidth. Supported by numerical and theoretical analyses, the observed near-field resolution is 0.47 lambda, clearly smaller than the diffraction limit of 0.61 lambda. Importantly, we show this sub-diffraction imaging is due to the resonant excitation of surface slab modes, allowing refocusing of non-propagating evanescent waves.

In the realm of microscopic life, cell division is the engine propelling growth and reproduction. This process, akin to a mechanical duplicator, dissects a single cell into two, each containing a replica of the original's genetic blueprint. As cells duplicate, they form tissues and organs, building the complex structures we call life. Yet, its intricate dance is not without flaw. errors in cell division can lead to diseases like cancer, reminding us of the delicate balance that maintains our lives. As we explore the mysteries of life and its origin, understanding cell division stands as a key to deciphering the code of life itself.

This paper provides a concise summary of the current status of the research and future perspectives discussed in the Mini-Conference on Angular Momentum Transport in Laboratory and Nature. This Mini-conference, sponsored by the Topical Group on Plasma Astrophysics, was held as part of the American Physical Society's Division of Plasma Physics 2007 Annual Meeting (November 12--16, 2007). This Mini-conference covers a wide range of phenomena happening in fluids and plasmas, either in laboratory or in nature. The purpose of this paper is not to comprehensively review these phenomena, but to provide a starting point for interested readers to refer to related research in areas other than their own.

Molecules, the microscopic building blocks of matter, engage in intricate dances of attraction and repulsion, forming the basis of chemical reactions. These interactions govern the behavior of substances at a molecular level, facilitating processes such as combustion, metabolism, and synthesis. In biology, molecular interactions within cells drive growth, reproduction, and the complex mechanisms of life. Interestingly, these interactions can also initiate disease—as seen in the COVID-19 pandemic, where the SARS-CoV-2 virus binds to human receptors, triggering an immune response that can lead to devastating effects. Understanding these molecular interactions is crucial for developing effective treatments and mitigating future pandemics.

When moving from one arbitrary location at another, a parallel manipulator may change its assembly-mode without crossing a singularity. Because the non-singular change of assembly-mode cannot be simply detected, the actual assembly-mode during motion is difficult to track. This paper proposes a global explanatory approach to help better understand non-singular assembly-mode changing motions for 3-RPR planar parallel manipulators. The approach consists in fixing one of the actuated joints and analyzing the configuration-space as a surface in a 3-dimensional space. Such a global description makes it possible to display all possible non-singular assembly-mode changing trajectories.

Orbiting celestial bodies obey intricate laws of motion, as elucidated by Kepler's and Newton's principles. These laws govern the dance of planets, moons, and satellites around their parent stars, describing their paths, speeds, and the magical balance that keeps them from crashing. Astronomers utilize this understanding to predict the future positions of celestial objects, enabling space exploration and our expanding cosmic knowledge.Also, the intriguing realm of orbital mechanics extends beyond our solar system to the fascinating realms of binary stars, galaxy clusters, and the colossal cosmic dance of galaxies. Thus, orbital mechanics, a vital branch of physics, offers insights into the wonders of the cosmos and the mysterious forces that shape our universe.

The Universe, far to be homogenous, expands in large empty bubbles of the large-scale structure, but not in mass concentrations like galaxies, so that the Robertson-Walker solution does not fit. We suggest that a symmetry breaking occurred in a distant past, during the radiation-dominated era. Before, the three-dimensional hypersurface was invariant under the action of O(3) and the Robertson-Walker metric could be used. But this obliges the so-called constants and physics, length and time scale factors to be involved through a generalized gauge process, which is built. The subsequent variation of the speed of light solves the horizon problem, while the Planck barrier disappears

Pharmaceutical advancements throughout history have significantly influenced medical practices. Antibiotics, for instance, revolutionized the treatment of infections in the early 20th century. Penicillin, discovered by Alexander Fleming, is a prime example. Meanwhile, the vaccine for smallpox, created by Edward Jenner in 1796, eradicated one of the most devastating diseases in human history.More recently, the human genome project, completed in 2003, has opened doors to personalized medicine. This era of precision medicine, custom-tailored to an individual's genetic makeup, promises to transform healthcare.However, not all pharmaceutical developments have been positive. Thalidomide, a sedative and anti-nauseant drug, tragically led to thousands of birth defects in children born to mothers who used the drug during pregnancy in the 1950s and 1960s. This terrible event underscores the importance of rigorous testing and ethical guidelines in the pharmaceutical industry.The ongoing pandemic underscores the continued need for cutting-edge medical research and the development of effective treatments and vaccines. The rapid creation of vaccines for COVID-19, though a remarkable achievement, also serves as a reminder of the potential risks and rewards in the ever-evolving field of pharmaceuticals.

A new analysis and new Molecular Dynamics (MD) simulations of the measurements of the mobility $\mu_{i}$ of O$_{2}^{-} $ ions in dense supercritical Ar gas are reported. $\mu_{i}$ shows a marked dependence on the distance from the critical temperature $T_{c}.$ A mobility defect appears as a function of the gas density and its maximum value occurs below the critical density. The locus of points of maximum mobility defect in the $P-T$ plane appears on the extrapolation of the coexistence curve into the single-phase region. MD simulations quantitatively reproduce the mobility defect near $T_{c}.$

Genetic drift refers to the random changes in the frequencies of alleles (versions of a gene) in a population over generations. This process occurs when genetic variation is lost by chance, rather than natural selection. It can significantly impact the genetic diversity and eventually, the evolution of a species.For instance, in a small, isolated population, the death of an individual carrying a particular allele can lead to its disappearance from the population, despite its potential advantage in survival. Conversely, an allele present in few individuals may increase dramatically in frequency due to chance events. This disproportionate impact of rare and common alleles, known as the "founder effect," is a form of genetic drift.The principle of genetic drift can be observed in various contexts, such as the evolution of a bacterial population resistant to antibiotics in a hospital setting. The random survival and reproduction of resistant bacteria can lead to a rapid increase in their frequency, challenging antibiotic treatment strategies. Understanding the role of genetic drift is crucial in managing conservation efforts, disease control, and genetic engineering projects.

Plagiarism is a crime against academy. It deceives readers, hurts plagiarized authors, and gets the plagiarist undeserved benefits. However, even though these arguments do show that copying other people's intellectual contribution is wrong, they do not apply to the copying of words. Copying a few sentences that contain no original idea (e.g. in the introduction) is of marginal importance compared to stealing the ideas of others. The two must be clearly distinguished, and the 'plagiarism' label should not be used for deeds which are very different in nature and importance.   Keywords: academic dishonesty. academic integrity. academic misconduct. cheating. copyright infringement. ethics. intellectual property. research misconduct

Gravitational waves, ripples in the fabric of spacetime, were first predicted by Albert Einstein's theory of general relativity in 1916. They were observed directly for the first time in 2015 by the LIGO and Virgo observatories, marking a monumental breakthrough in astronomy. These waves are produced by the acceleration of massive objects, such as black holes or neutron stars when they collide. Their detection opens a new window into the universe, allowing us to study phenomena that were previously inaccessible, deepening our understanding of the cosmos and its complex history. Like the cell cycle, the Big Bang, and the movement of the celestial bodies, gravitational waves are a testament to the fascinating, interconnected stories and intricate mechanisms that underlie the universe we inhabit.

Dispersive Fourier transformation is a powerful technique in which spectral information is mapped into the time domain using chromatic dispersion. It replaces a spectrometer with an electronic digitizer, and enables real-time spectroscopy. The fundamental problem in this technique is the trade-off between the detection sensitivity and spectral resolution, a limitation set by the digitizer's bandwidth. This predicament is caused by the power loss associated with optical dispersion. We overcome this limitation using Raman amplified spectrum-to-time transformation. An extraordinary loss-less -11.76 ns/nm dispersive device is used to demonstrate single-shot gas absorption spectroscopy with 950 MHz resolution--a record in real-time spectroscopy.

Heart disease, a major global health concern, is primarily triggered by factors like high cholesterol, hypertension, and obesity. Atherosclerosis, the buildup of fatty deposits in arteries, is a key culprit. This process begins when low-density lipoproteins (LDL), or "bad" cholesterol, collect within the arterial walls, potentially leading to plaque formation.Regular physical exercise, a balanced diet, and maintaining a healthy body weight can significantly reduce the risk of heart disease. Notably, choosing foods low in saturated fats and trans fats, and rich in fiber, can help manage cholesterol levels.Medical advancements have led to various treatments for heart disease, including medications to lower cholesterol, control blood pressure, and inhibit blood clots. Lifestyle changes, such as quitting smoking, reducing alcohol intake, and managing stress, also play crucial roles in heart health management.Understanding heart disease and taking proactive steps toward heart health remains essential, given that heart disease remains the leading cause of death worldwide.

Grooves were etched in a conductive layer of a conductive, transparent glass, and a nanoporous TiO2 film was deposited on both the conductive and nonconductive area. The width of the grooves was 100 $\mu$m and 150 $\mu$m. A transparent TiO2 film was dye-sensitized, covered with an electrolyte, and sandwiched with a cover glass. The conductivity of the dye-sensitized TiO2 film permeated with electrolyte was studied in the dark and under illumination, and was observed to be dependent on light intensity, wavelength and applied voltage. This study shows that dye-sensitized nanoporous films can be used as a wavelength dependent photoconductor.

Coral reefs, nature's vibrant underwater metropolis, teem with diverse marine life, making them among Earth's most biodiverse and vital ecosystems. Yet, they face dire threats due to global warming, ocean acidification, and pollution. The mass bleaching events, triggered by rising sea temperatures, are a significant concern.General relativity, a theory by Einstein, explains the large-scale structure of the universe, but its application to coral reefs can help us understand the forces driving their degradation, potentially leading to more effective conservation strategies.Artificial sweeteners, while appearing harmless, have an impact on marine life. They enter the ocean through wastewater and can alter the microbial communities in coral reefs, potentially affecting the reef's overall health and resilience.The question of how to preserve these precious underwater edifices is a pressing one. It involves addressing the root causes of their destruction and finding ways to mitigate human impacts. Just as the theory of general relativity rearranged our understanding of the universe, so too must our approach to coral reef conservation resemble a paradigm shift if we are to ensure their survival for future generations.

The wave function was proposed for description of quantum phenomena on the atomic level. But now it is well known that quantum phenomena are observed not only on atomic level and the wave function is used for description of macroscopic quantum phenomena, such as superconductivity. The essence of the wave function on level elementary particles was and is the subject of heated argument among founders of quantum mechanics and other physicists. This essence seems more clear in superconductor. But impossibility of probabilistic interpretation of wave function in this case results to obvious contradiction of quantum principles with some fundamental principles of physics.

In the realm of climate science, the concept of the Milankovitch cycles offers a compelling explanation for significant climatic oscillations over thousands of years. These cycles, stemming from changes in Earth's orbit, axial tilt, and the tilt of its wobbling axis, are responsible for periodic shifts in solar radiation received by the planet, thereby influencing glaciation and climatic patterns.Currently, we are in a geological era known as the Holocene, characterized by comparatively stable and hospitable conditions. However, climate variability, driven by natural and human-induced factors, threatens these conditions. For instance, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) projects an increase in global temperature, sea level rise, and extreme weather events due to greenhouse gas emissions, also known as anthropogenic climate change.As we grapple with the implications of these shifts, it is crucial to adopt sustainable practices, invest in renewable energy, and promote global cooperation to mitigate the adverse effects of climate change and ensure a stable and resilient planet for future generations.

We show the formation of bright and dark slow optical solitons based on intersubband transitions in a semiconductor quantum well (SQW). Using the coupled Schrodinger-Maxwell approach, we provide both analytical and numerical results. Such a nonlinear optical process may be used for the control technology of optical delay lines and optical buffers in the SQW solid-state system. With appropriate parameters, we also show the generation of a large cross-phase modulation (XPM). Since the the intersubband energy level can be easily tuned by an external bias voltage, the present investigation may open the possibility for electrically controlled phase modulator in the solid-state system.

In the realm of particle physics, the Higgs boson, colloquially known as the 'God particle,' is a fundamental, elementary particle in the Standard Model of physics. It was hypothesized to give other particles their mass, and its discovery in 2012 confirmed the Brout-Englert-Higgs mechanism. However, its interactions remain complex and not yet fully understood, sparking ongoing research and discussions within the scientific community.

A theory describing above-threshold ionization of atoms and ions in a strong electromagnetic field is presented. It is based on the widely known strong field approximation and incorporates the Coulomb interaction between the photoelectron and the nucleus using the method of complex classical trajectories. A central result of the theory is the Coulomb-corrected ionization amplitude whose evaluation requires little extra numerical effort. By comparing our predictions with the results of ab initio numerical solutions for two examples we show that the new theory provides a significant improvement of the Coulomb-free strong field approximation. For the case of above-threshold ionization in elliptically polarized fields a comparison with available experimental data is also presented.

Mitochondria, the powerhouses of the cell, convert energy from food into a form that cells can use. This process, called cellular respiration, involves a series of complex chemical reactions. Adenosine triphosphate (ATP), the primary energy currency of the cell, is produced during this process. Mitochondria are unique in that they have their own DNA, separate from the nucleus, suggesting an origin separate from the rest of the cell. This organelle's evolution and role in energy production have been crucial to the complexity and survival of eukaryotic cells. The intricate dance of cellular processes, including mitochondrial function, continues to astound scientists, offering insights into evolution, energy, and life itself.

In recent years, two important techniques for geometric numerical discretization have been developed. In computational electromagnetics, spatial discretization has been improved by the use of mixed finite elements and discrete differential forms. Simultaneously, the dynamical systems and mechanics communities have developed structure-preserving time integrators, notably variational integrators that are constructed from a Lagrangian action principle. Here, we discuss how to combine these two frameworks to develop variational spacetime integrators for Maxwell's equations. Extending our previous work, which first introduced this variational perspective for Maxwell's equations without sources, we also show here how to incorporate free sources of charge and current.

Molecular biology delves into the intricate world of biochemical pathways that govern cellular functions. These pathways are intricate networks of biochemical reactions, regulated by enzymes, that facilitate growth, reproduction, and energy production within cells. For instance, the citric acid cycle, also known as the Krebs cycle, is a fundamental pathway involved in cellular respiration, generating energy in the form of ATP. Another critical pathway is the glycolysis process, which breaks down glucose to produce energy, even without oxygen. These pathways are interconnected, forming a complex web of biochemical interactions that sustain life within cells. However, disruptions in these pathways can lead to various diseases, such as cancer, diabetes, and metabolic disorders, highlighting their importance in maintaining cellular health. The ongoing exploration of these pathways continues to unravel the mysteries of life at its most fundamental level.

We extend the theory for laser cooling in a near-resonant optical lattice to include multiple excited hyperfine states. Simulations are performed treating the external degrees of freedom of the atom, i.e., position and momentum, classically, while the internal atomic states are treated quantum mechanically, allowing for arbitrary superpositions. Whereas theoretical treatments including only a single excited hyperfine state predict that the temperature should be a function of lattice depth only, except close to resonance, experiments have shown that the minimum temperature achieved depends also on the detuning from resonance of the lattice light. Our results resolve this discrepancy.

Celestial bodies, such as planets and stars, follow intricate paths dictated by gravitational forces and the laws of motion. Kepler's laws, for instance, describe the elliptical orbits of these celestial bodies around the Sun. Newton's laws of motion, on the other hand, delve into the relationships between an object's mass, velocity, and the forces acting upon it, including gravity. These principles, coupled with Einstein's theory of general relativity, which expanded our understanding of gravity by suggesting it is a curvature of spacetime, form the basis of astronomy's ability to predict celestial motion. This understanding has not only allowed us to explore the cosmos but also sheds light on the birth, evolution, and ultimate fate of stars and galaxies.

Applying a modified version of the Gledzer-Ohkitani-Yamada (GOY) shell model, the signatures of so-called two-dimensionalization effect of three-dimensional incompressible, homogeneous, isotropic fully developed unforced turbulence have been studied and reproduced. Within the framework of shell models we have obtained the following results: (i) progressive steepening of the energy spectrum with increased strength of the rotation, and, (ii) depletion in the energy flux of the forward forward cascade, sometimes leading to an inverse cascade. The presence of extended self-similarity and self-similar PDFs for longitudinal velocity differences are also presented for the rotating 3D turbulence case.

In the realm of medicine, the drug Ibuprofen, initially synthesized in 1960, serves as a potent analgesic and anti-inflammatory agent. While it alleviates pain and reduces inflammation effectively, long-term use or excessive dosing can potentially lead to side effects such as stomach ulcers, kidney damage, and an increased risk of heart disease. Furthermore, its interaction with other medications should be carefully monitored, as it may enhance the risk of bleeding or aggravate existing conditions. As with any medication, it's crucial to follow prescribed dosages and consult a healthcare professional for guidance.

We consider navigation or search schemes on networks which have a degree distribution of the form $P(k) \propto \exp(-k^\gamma)$. In addition, the linking probability is taken to be dependent on social distances and is governed by a parameter $\lambda$. The searches are realistic in the sense that not all search chains can be completed. An estimate of $\mu=\rho/s_d$, where $\rho$ is the success rate and $s_d$ the dynamic path length, shows that for a network of $N$ nodes, $\mu \propto N^{-\delta}$ in general. Dynamic small world effect, i.e., $\delta \simeq 0$ is shown to exist in a restricted region of the $\lambda-\gamma$ plane.

Biological evolution, a process shaping the diversity of life on Earth, unfolds over millennia. Natural selection, a key mechanism, favors traits that increase an organism's fitness to survive and reproduce in its environment. This process is not stationary. populations continuously adapt, giving rise to new species.In this grand evolutionary dance, species evolve in response to environmental pressures, such as changes in climate, geography, and competition for resources. For instance, the Galápagos finches exemplify this adaptive radiation, with various species evolving from a common ancestor due to different food sources on the islands.The genetic basis of evolution is mutations, alterations in an organism's DNA. Random and rare, some mutations may have profound effects, granting new traits or refining existing ones. Over time, these advantageous changes accumulate, resulting in the unique organisms we see today.This evolutionary journey paints a vibrant picture of life's adaptation and persistence, offering insights into the complex tapestry of biodiversity that graces our planet.

To provide a more accurate description of the driving behaviors in vehicle queues, a namely Markov-Gap cellular automata model is proposed in this paper. It views the variation of the gap between two consequent vehicles as a Markov process whose stationary distribution corresponds to the observed distribution of practical gaps. The multiformity of this Markov process provides the model enough flexibility to describe various driving behaviors. Two examples are given to show how to specialize it for different scenarios: usually mentioned flows on freeways and start-up flows at signalized intersections. The agreement between the empirical observations and the simulation results suggests the soundness of this new approach.

In the realm of relativistic physics, the concept of time dilation becomes intriguing. Time, a constant in our everyday lives, appears to stretch or contract relative to an observer's speed. This phenomenon, predicted by Einstein's theory of special relativity, has been experimentally verified at extremely high velocities, as seen in particle colliders. Furthermore, in the vast cosmic expanse, time dilation affects the orbit of the distant binary pulsar PSR1913+16, with one of its components rotating at approximately 60 rotations per second, displaying the influence of time warping in action. However, the implications of time dilation on a smaller scale, such as in our daily lives, remain largely theoretical, hinting at uncharted territories within the enigma of relativity.

We investigate the magnetic properties of nano-holes (NHs) patterned in graphene using first principles calculations. We show that superlattices consisting of a periodic array of NHs form a new family of 2D crystalline "bulk" magnets whose collective magnetic behavior is governed by inter-NH spin-spin interaction. They exhibit long-range magnetic order well above room temperature. Furthermore, magnetic semiconductors can be made by doping magnetic NHs into semiconducting NH superlattices. Our findings offer a new material system for fundamental studies of spin-spin interaction and magnetic ordering in low dimensions, and open up the exciting opportunities of making engineered magnetic materials for storage media and spintronics applications.

Wine, derived from fermented grapes, contains a myriad of potentially beneficial compounds. Resveratrol, a polyphenol found in the skin of grapes, is celebrated for its antioxidant properties. It's often associated with cardiovascular health, as it may help decrease LDL cholesterol and reduce blood clotting. Some studies suggest that moderate wine consumption could contribute to a decrease in the risk of developing type 2 diabetes.However, it's crucial to note that these benefits are merited through moderate consumption – defined by the World Health Organization as up to one drink per day for women and up to two drinks per day for men. Excessive consumption can result in various health issues, including alcohol-related liver disease, heart disease, and certain cancers.Wine's chemistry is fascinating, with numerous compounds interacting to produce its unique flavors. Conversely, understanding these compounds helps explain some of the potential health benefits that wine offers. Nevertheless, it's important to remember that a balanced diet, regular exercise, and lifestyle choices contribute significantly to overall health.

Single crystals of pure and Cd2+ doped potassium sulfate were grown from aqueous solutions by the slow evaporation technique. From nutrient solutions with a CdSO4 concentration of 4wt.% crystals containing 0.014wt.% dopant concentration could be obtained. The X-ray diffraction patterns of powdered crystals confirmed their crystal structures for both cases. Thermal analysis of pure crystals shows that the alpha-beta phase transformation peak around 580 deg C is superimposed with spurious effects, while for Cd2+ doped crystals this is not the case. The thermal hysteresis of the phase transition is 8 K for undoped K2SO4 and is reduced to 3.5 K for K2SO4:Cd2+. Compared to undoped crystals, the optical transmittance of Cd2+ doped crystals is higher.

Proteins, essential biological molecules, are composed of amino acids, organic compounds linked by peptide bonds. These intricate chains fold into specific structures, catalyzing reactions, transporting molecules, and providing cellular structure. Protein synthesis involves the transcription of DNA into mRNA, followed by translation into protein. Modifications to these proteins can impact their function and contribute to various diseases, making them crucial targets for medical research. Enzymes, one class of proteins, facilitate biochemical reactions, accelerating their rates and increasing the efficiency of metabolic pathways. Conversely, inhibitors can slow or halt these reactions, offering potential therapeutic applications. Understanding the structure, function, and regulation of proteins will continue to drive advancements in medicine, biotechnology, and beyond.

We propose a scheme in which entanglement can be transferred from atoms (discrete variables) to entangled states of cavity fields (continuous variables). The cavities play the role of a kind of quantum memory for entanglement, in such a way that it is possible to retrieve it back to the atoms. In our method, two three level atoms in a lambda configuration, previously entangled, are set to interact with single mode cavity fields prepared in coherent states. During the process, one e-bit of entanglement may be deposited in the cavities in an efficient way. We also show that the stored entanglement may be transferred back to flying atoms.

Earth's formation, billions of years ago, began with the collapse of a giant molecular cloud, followed by a cataclysmic explosion known as a supernova. This event led to the birth of our solar system, with the Sun at its center. The planets, including Earth, formed from a disk of dust and gas orbiting the Sun.The Earth's massive gravitational pull drew in this material, and over millions of years, it coalesced into a planet. However, the composition of Earth was not fixed. Collisions with other celestial bodies, such as asteroids and comets, brought in water and other volatile materials, gradually shaping Earth into the habitable planet we know today.Today, the Earth's dynamic processes continue to evolve, from the tectonic movements that shape landscapes to the climate changes that influence life. Understanding these processes offers insights into Earth's past, present, and potential future.

This paper reviews the scientific support for a ballistic pressure wave radiating outward from a penetrating projectile and causing injury and incapacitation. This phenomenon is known colloquially as "hydrostatic shock." The idea apparently originates with Col. Frank Chamberlin, a World War II trauma surgeon and wound ballistics researcher. The paper reviews claims that hydrostatic shock is a myth and considers supporting evidence through parallels with blast, describing the physics of the pressure wave, evidence for remote cerebral effects, and remote effects in the spine and other internal organs. Finally, the review considers the levels of energy transfer required for the phenomenon to be readily observed.

Disease outbreaks, a recurring challenge in global health, have shaped human history and continue to do so in this technologically advanced era. An outbreak is an abrupt increase in cases of a specific disease in a particular human population, as compared with the normal (expected) number of cases. The causes can be diverse, from viral infections such as Ebola, Zika, and SARS, to bacterial diseases like tuberculosis and cholera.Outbreaks can spread rapidly due to factors like population density, travel, and weak health systems. In the digital age, the speed of transmission has escalated, with social media amplifying misinformation, worsening the impact of outbreaks.On the positive side, advancements in technology and science have also brought about effective responses. Genomics, for instance, has played a significant role in understanding the origin and transmission of diseases, aiding in developing targeted interventions for outbreak control.However, as the world grapples with the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, it's evident that while our understanding of disease outbreaks has grown, so have the challenges. A global coordinated effort is essential to ensure the health and safety of all humanity in the face of these persistent threats.

We propose a global symmetry-breaking mechanism based on an extension of the vibronic (cooperative Jahn-Teller) effects (comprising electron-phonon superpartners) to generalize them into fermion-boson superpartners. Examples of superpairs are constructed by combining phonons, photons, pi-mesons, etc. with electrons, holes, nucleons, etc. in condensed and nuclear matter. The obtained symmetry-breaking mechanism operating amidst the superpartner pairs may be just what is needed to justify the status of supersymmetry as a broken-symmetry phenomenon. Following the extended vibronic mixing of fermion states by the appropriate heavy boson superpartner, the latter propagates along a helical path away from the mixing site.

Photons, massless particles of light, are essential components in the dance of electromagnetic radiation. They exhibit a dual behavior, displaying particle-like properties in the realm of quantum mechanics and wave-like traits in classical optics. Photons, traveling at the speed of light, are pivotal in our understanding of various natural phenomena, from the visible light spectacle of the cosmos to the hidden intricacies of atomic structures.These particles, though seemingly insignificant, are responsible for the transmission of vital information throughout the universe, forming the basis for how objects interact with electromagnetic energy. Photons, through their unique properties, have been instrumental in the advancement of modern technology, from lasers to fiber optics, enriching and transforming our lives in ways we could scarcely have imagined. Yet, despite their importance, much about the behavior of photons remains a mystery, coaxing scientists to delve ever deeper into this fascinating realm of subatomic particles.

The nonlinear turbulent interactions between acoustic gravity waves are investigated using two dimensional nonlinear fluid simulations. The acoustic gravity waves consist of velocity and density perturbations and propagate across the density gradients in the vertical direction in the Earth's atmosphere. We find that the coupled two component model exhibits generation of large scale velocity potential flows along the vertical direction, while the density perturbations relax towards an isotropic random distribution. The characteristic turbulent spectrum associated with the system has a Kolmogorov-like feature and tends to relax towards a $k^{-5/3}$ spectrum, where $k$ is a typical wavenumber. The cross field diffusion associated with the velocity potential grows linearly and saturates in the nonlinear phase.

Thalidomide's tragic legacy continues to echo, serving as a stark warning in the annals of medicine. Initially developed as a sedative in the 1950s, it was later prescribed to pregnant women for morning sickness, resulting in devastating birth defects. The aftermath revealed the drug's teratogenic effects, affecting the development of fetal limbs. Since then, thalidomide has been relegated to a less controversial role in treating conditions like leprosy and certain types of cancer, under stringent regulations. Its dark history underscores the importance of thorough testing and careful prescribing, lest history repeat itself.

``The plasma approximation'' is, in the words of Pauli, ``not even wrong,'' as it expresses a disbelief in the symmetries of the underlying gauge field theory. The electrostatic field in question is divergenceful yet has no sources or sinks, thus breaking Lorentz covariance explicitly, and has no place in a self-consistent theory. Utilizing it leads to inconsistencies in the equation of motion and prevents a proper, field-theoretic treatment of condensed matter in the plasma state. By exposing the fallacy of replacing one of the field equations with one of the Bianchi identities, the applicability of Gauss' law to plasma physics is assured.

Biological evolution, a fundamental process driving the diversity of life on Earth, describes how populations and species of organisms change over time. This change is primarily driven by natural selection, a mechanism proposed by Charles Darwin. In this process, organisms with traits that facilitate survival and reproduction become more common in subsequent generations, leading to the gradual evolution of species. Evolution is not just a historical process but continues to occur today, shaping the rich tapestry of life as we know it. Additionally, understanding evolutionary processes is crucial for tackling a variety of contemporary challenges, from disease control to conservation efforts.

Web sites where users create and rate content as well as form networks with other users display long-tailed distributions in many aspects of behavior. Using behavior on one such community site, Essembly, we propose and evaluate plausible mechanisms to explain these behaviors. Unlike purely descriptive models, these mechanisms rely on user behaviors based on information available locally to each user. For Essembly, we find the long-tails arise from large differences among user activity rates and qualities of the rated content, as well as the extensive variability in the time users devote to the site. We show that the models not only explain overall behavior but also allow estimating the quality of content from their early behaviors.

General relativity, formulated by Albert Einstein, is a theory of gravitation that provides a unified description of gravity as a geometric property of space and time, or spacetime. It extended the theory of special relativity to include acceleration and gravitation, while also providing an explanation for the effects of gravity on the large scale, such as the motion of planets and the bending of light.This revolutionary theory fundamentally changes our understanding of the universe. It reveals that massive objects like planets and stars literally warp the fabric of spacetime around them, creating a gravitational field. This suggests that the large-scale structure of the universe, including galaxies and the large-scale distribution of matter, is influenced by gravity in a way that is intricately linked to the geometry of spacetime.Moreover, general relativity has predictions that have been experimentally confirmed, such as the gravitational bending of light, the existence of black holes, and the expansion of the universe. These discoveries have opened up new realms of research in astrophysics and cosmology, shedding light on the mysteries of the cosmos and expanding our understanding of the universe we inhabit.

The big bang hypothesis is widely accepted despite numerous physics conflicts. It rests upon two experimental supports, galactic red shift and the cosmic microwave background. Both are produced by dark matter, shown here to be hydrogen dominated aggregates with a few percent of helium nodules. Scattering from these non-radiating intergalactic masses produce a red shift that normally correlates with distance. Warmed by our galaxy to an Eigenvalue of 2.735 K, drawn near the Earth, these bodies, kept cold by ablation, resonance radiate the Planckian microwave signal. Several tests are proposed that will distinguish between this model and the big bang.

Red wine is known for its antioxidant properties, primarily due to the presence of resveratrol, a polyphenol found in the grape skin. Resveratrol is believed to activate the SIRT1 gene, which promotes the health of the cardiovascular system by reducing inflammation and improving the function of endothelial cells, the cells that line the blood vessels. Some studies suggest that moderate consumption of red wine may help lower the risk of heart disease. However, the benefits are contingent on moderation, as excessive consumption can lead to health issues, such as alcohol-related liver disease and addiction. It's important to note that red wine contains alcohol, and no level of alcohol consumption is considered entirely safe for health. As with any alcoholic beverage, moderation is key.

We have performed full-relativistic density functional theory calculations to study the geometry and binding energy of different isomers of free platinum clusters Pt$_{n}$ ($n=4-6$) within the spin multiplicities from singlet to nonet. The spin-orbit coupling effect has been discussed for the minimum-energy structures, relative stabilities, vibrational frequencies, magnetic moments, and the highest occupied and lowest unoccupied molecular-orbital gaps. It is found in contrast to some of the previous calculations that 3-dimentional configurations are still lowest energy structures of these clusters, although spin-orbit effect makes some planar or quasi-planar geometries more stable than some other 3-dimentional isomers.

Life's fundamental components, proteins and nucleic acids, are intricately structured and behave dynamically through a process called protein folding, a dance of precise hydrogen bonds, electrostatic interactions, and van der Waals forces. This dance is crucial for life's functions, as the three-dimensional structure of these intricate molecules determines their functionality. The understanding of protein folding has been a major focus in the field of biophysics, shedding light on the intricate interplay between the molecular structure of life and its functions, a fundamental puzzle that continues to intrigue scientists worldwide.

We present a new molecular dynamics algorithm for sampling the canonical distribution. In this approach the velocities of all the particles are rescaled by a properly chosen random factor. The algorithm is formally justified and it is shown that, in spite of its stochastic nature, a quantity can still be defined that remains constant during the evolution. In numerical applications this quantity can be used to measure the accuracy of the sampling. We illustrate the properties of this new method on Lennard-Jones and TIP4P water models in the solid and liquid phases. Its performance is excellent and largely independent on the thermostat parameter also with regard to the dynamic properties.

Coral reefs, vibrant underwater metropolises teeming with exquisite diversity, sustain a myriad of marine life. They are the nurseries for numerous species, from colorful fish to rare sea turtles. However, these delicate ecosystems face a dire threat in the form of climate change. Rising sea temperatures, ocean acidification, and pollution are degrading and destroying coral reefs at an alarming rate. The resulting loss of biodiversity disrupts food chains, impacts coastal economies, and imperils vulnerable coastal communities. To alleviate this crisis, concerted efforts are needed to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, implement sustainable marine protection measures, and raise awareness about the importance and precarious state of coral reef ecology.

As shown by Ganan-Calvo and co-workers, a free liquid jet can be compressed in iameter through gas-dynamic forces exerted by a co-flowing gas, obviating the need for a solid nozzle to form a microscopic liquid jet and thereby alleviating the clogging problems that plague conventional droplet sources of small diameter. We describe in this paper a novel form of droplet beam source based on this principle. The source is miniature, robust, dependable, easily fabricated, and eminently suitable for delivery of microscopic liquid droplets, including hydrated biological samples, into vacuum for analysis using vacuum instrumentation. Monodisperse, single file droplet streams are generated by triggering the device with a piezoelectric actuator. The device is essentially immune to clogging.

Phosphorescent waves dance on Earth's surface, a spectacle of photons, fundamental particles of light. Simultaneously, the planet's vast, subterranean lithosphere shifts, an intricate ballet of moving plates governed by the theory of plate tectonics. This choreography of continental drift has dictated the course of climatic oscillations, shaping diverse biomes and weather patterns over millennia.These climatic oscillations, often recurring in sub-centurial cycles (50-55 years), have long been tracked and studied. The rhythmic dance between warming and cooling periods, monsoons, and droughts have carved landscapes, fostered life, and challenged civilizations over the ages. Understanding these patterns, their causes, and effects, is crucial in our quest for a sustainable future.In the face of such dynamic Earthly phenomena, it is critical to address pressing concerns, such as pollution, deforestation, and habitat destruction, which threaten the resilience of our planet's ecosystems. As we navigate this intricate dance, we find ourselves at a pivotal moment, called upon to be the stewards of a living, evolving planet.

Till the late nineties the accepted cosmological model was that of a Universe that had originated in the Big Bang and was now decelerating under the influence of as yet undetected dark matter, so that it would come to a halt and eventually collapse. In 1997 however, the author had put forward a contra model wherein the Universe was driven by dark energy, essentially the quantum zero point field, and was accelerating with a small cosmological constant. There were other deductions too, all in total agreement with observation. All this got confirmation in 1998 and subsequent observations have reconfirmed the findings.

Quantum entanglement, a phenomenon where particles become interconnected, instantaneously affecting each other regardless of distance, is a mystery of the quantum world. This non-local correlation challenges our classical understanding of causality. By entangling photons, scientists can create quantum networks, potentially revolutionizing communication technology. However, mastering this intricate dance of subatomic particles remains a formidable challenge, as every attempt to measure one entangled particle alters the state of the other. The enigmatic realm of quantum entanglement continues to intrigue and challenge researchers, offering possibilities for the future of technology yet to be fully grasped.

The study of dynamo action in astrophysical objects classically involves two timescales: the slow diffusive one and the fast advective one. We investigate the possibility of field amplification on an intermediate timescale associated with time dependent modulations of the flow. We consider a simple steady configuration for which dynamo action is not realised. We study the effect of time dependent perturbations of the flow. We show that some vanishing low frequency perturbations can yield exponential growth of the magnetic field on the typical time scale of oscillation. The dynamo mechanism relies here on a parametric instability associated with transient amplification by shear flows. Consequences on natural dynamos are discussed.

Phosphorescence, the afterglow of excited electrons in certain materials, intriguingly mirrors photosynthesis, the process by which green plants absorb sunlight to produce energy through a series of chemical reactions. Just as phosphorescent materials store energy and re-emit it gradually, chlorophyll in plants absorbs sunlight's energy and re-emits it in the form of chemical energy through photosynthesis. However, unlike phosphorescence, photosynthesis also produces oxygen as a byproduct, essential for most life forms on Earth. The exploration of these phenomena deepens our understanding of energy transfer and storage at both the microscopic and macroscopic levels.

We measure and theoretically determine the effect of molecular rotational splitting on Zeeman relaxation rates in collisions of cold Triplet-Sigma molecules with helium atoms in a magnetic field. All four stable isotopomers of the imidogen (NH) molecule are magnetically trapped and studied in collisions with 3He and 4He. The 4He data support the predicted inverse square dependence of the collision induced Zeeman relaxation rate coefficient on the molecular rotational constant B. The measured 3He rate coefficients are much larger than 4He and depend less strongly on B, and the theoretical analysis indicates they are strongly affected by a shape resonance. The results demonstrate the influence of molecular structure on collisional energy transfer at low temperatures.

Atoms, the fundamental building blocks of matter, are composed of protons, neutrons, and electrons. Protons and neutrons, collectively known as nucleons, reside in the nucleus, while electrons orbit the nucleus in shells. The number of protons determines the atomic element, while the number of protons plus neutrons determines the isotope. The structure of atoms and their interactions form the basis for chemistry, the study of substances and their properties, reactions, and transformations.

Data series generated by complex systems exhibit fluctuations on many time scales and/or broad distributions of the values. In both equilibrium and non-equilibrium situations, the natural fluctuations are often found to follow a scaling relation over several orders of magnitude, allowing for a characterisation of the data and the generating complex system by fractal (or multifractal) scaling exponents. In addition, fractal and multifractal approaches can be used for modelling time series and deriving predictions regarding extreme events. This review article describes and exemplifies several methods originating from Statistical Physics and Applied Mathematics, which have been used for fractal and multifractal time series analysis.

In the vast cosmos, photons, weightless particles of light, traverse space, igniting the dance of electromagnetism. Down on Earth, the lithosphere floats on the semi-fluid asthenosphere, moving plates in a tectonic ballet known as plate tectonics. This geological phenomenon influenced the development of various species, as continents collided and separated, altering habitats and forcing organisms to adapt or perish, a demonstration of Darwin's principle of natural selection.Millions of years ago, organisms in diverse environments competed for resources, and those best suited for survival passed on their advantageous traits, leading to the development of new species. Today, this process continues, shaping the biodiverse ecosystems we now find, from coral reefs to rainforests. However, human activities threaten many of these fragile systems, jeopardizing the natural selection process that has shaped life as we know it.

We measure the expansion of an ultracold plasma across the field lines of a uniform magnetic field. We image the ion distribution by extracting the ions with a high voltage pulse onto a position-sensitive detector. Early in the lifetime of the plasma ($< 20$ $\mu$s), the size of the image is dominated by the time-of-flight Coulomb explosion of the dense ion cloud. For later times, we measure the 2-D Gaussian width of the ion image, obtaining the transverse expansion velocity as a function of magnetic field (up to 70 G). We observe that the expansion velocity scales as B$^{-1/2}$, explained by a nonlinear ambipolar diffusion model with anisotropic diffusion in two different directions.

The Earth's lithosphere, its outer solid layer, plays a pivotal role in the shifting tectonic landscapes, a dance of plates that mould our planet's surface. This intricate ballet, known as plate tectonics, has shaped the continents we know today, creating mountain ranges, valleys, and trenches. However, this dynamic process is not merely aesthetic. it significantly influences earthquakes, volcanic activity, and the planet's climate.Concurrently, the celestial dance of celestial bodies continues above, governed by Kepler's laws of planetary motion. These principles, established by the astronomer Johannes Kepler in the 17th century, describe the motion of planets around the Sun, offering insight into our solar system's workings and perhaps the possibility of extraterrestrial life.As we ponder the mysteries of outer space and the forces that shape our world, we are reminded of our interconnectedness to the universe. Our planet, a living, breathing entity, continues to reveal its secrets, inviting us to explore, question, and understand, forever propelling us into the cosmic unknown.

We investigate nuclear-resonant electron scattering as occurring in the two-step process of nuclear excitation by electron capture (NEEC) followed by internal conversion. The nuclear excitation and decay are treated by a phenomenological collective model in which nuclear states and transition probabilities are described by experimental parameters. We present capture rates and resonant strengths for a number of heavy ion collision systems considering various scenarios for the resonant electron scattering process. The results show that for certain cases resonant electron scattering can have significantly larger resonance strengths than NEEC followed by the radiative decay of the nucleus. We discuss the impact of our findings on the possible experimental observation of NEEC.

Electromagnetic radiation, a form of energy travels at the speed of light, spanning the spectrum from radio waves to gamma rays. It powers our wireless communication systems, illuminates our homes, and is used in medical imaging. Unlike matter, it carries energy but has no mass. In the vast cosmic landscape, it's a key player in phenomena such as the formation of stars and the heating of interstellar gas. The study of electromagnetic radiation is fundamental to our understanding of the universe, providing a pathway to explore the mysteries that lie beyond our planet.

{\it Transcription} is the process whereby RNA molecules are polymerized by molecular machines, called RNA polymerase (RNAP), using the corresponding DNA as the template. Recent {\it in-vivo} experiments with single cells have established that transcription takes place in "bursts" or "pulses". In this letter we present a model that captures not only the mechano-chemistry of individual RNAPs and their steric interactions but also the switching of the gene between the ON and OFF states. This model accounts for the statistical properties of the transcriptional bursts. It also shows how the quantitative features of the distributions of these bursts can be tuned by controlling the appropriate steps of operation of the RNAP machines.

In the realm of physics, reaction rates within chemical processes are of significant interest. The speed at which a chemical reaction occurs is influenced by several factors, including temperature and the concentrations of reactants. Higher temperatures tend to increase reaction rates due to the increased kinetic energy of particles, enabling them to collide more frequently and thus react faster. Conversely, the concentration of reactants also plays a crucial role, as an increased concentration of either reactant generally leads to a faster reaction rate because more collisions between particles occur.However, not all reactions exhibit equal reaction rates. Catalysts, substances that accelerate chemical reactions without being consumed, can drastically influence reaction rates by lowering the activation energy barrier. As a result, reactions with catalysts can occur at more favorable speeds, altering the overall course of a chemical process. In summary, understanding reaction rates is essential for predicting and controlling the outcomes of chemical reactions in various fields, from manufacturing to environmental science.

We describe RAGE, the ``Radiation Adaptive Grid Eulerian'' radiation-hydrodynamics code, including its data structures, its parallelization strategy and performance, its hydrodynamic algorithm(s), its (gray) radiation diffusion algorithm, and some of the considerable amount of verification and validation efforts. The hydrodynamics is a basic Godunov solver, to which we have made significant improvements to increase the advection algorithm's robustness and to converge stiffnesses in the equation of state. Similarly, the radiation transport is a basic gray diffusion, but our treatment of the radiation-material coupling, wherein we converge nonlinearities in a novel manner to allow larger timesteps and more robust behavior, can be applied to any multi-group transport algorithm.

Cholesterol, a waxy substance found in the body, is a key component of cell membranes and plays a crucial role in hormone production. However, high levels of cholesterol can lead to plaque buildup in arteries, increasing the risk of heart disease – a concern often sparking debates about daily intake. While dietary cholesterol, found primarily in animal products, affects blood cholesterol levels, total cholesterol counts are also influenced by genetics and lifestyle factors such as physical activity and smoking. In the health realm, striking a balance between limiting dietary cholesterol and maintaining a balanced lifestyle is key to reducing the risk of heart disease. Concurrently, research into potential cholesterol-lowering foods, like foods rich in plant sterols, continues to grow.

We present the key results from a comprehensive study of the refraction and focusing properties of a two-dimensional dodecagonal photonic ``quasicrystal'' (PQC), carried out via both full-wave numerical simulations and microwave measurements on a slab made of alumina rods inserted in a parallel-plate waveguide. We observe anomalous refraction and focusing in several frequency regions, confirming some recently published results. However, our interpretation, based on numerical and experimental evidence, differs substantially from the one in terms of ``effective negative refractive-index'' that was originally proposed. Instead, our study highlights the critical role played by short-range interactions associated with local order and symmetry.

Artificial sweeteners, a staple in low-calorie diets, are chemical compounds that mimic the sweetness of sugar without the associated calories. These substances, such as aspartame, saccharin, and sucralose, are extensively used in food and beverage industries worldwide. Although they are considered safe for human consumption by regulatory bodies, ongoing debates persist over their long-term effects on health, particularly with regards to their impact on gut microbiota and metabolism. Research is continues to explore the potential risks and benefits of these compounds, aiming to determine their role in maintaining a balanced diet and overall health.

When moving from native to light activated bacteriorhodopsin, modification of charge transport consisting of an increase of conductance is correlated to the protein conformational change. A theoretical model based on a map of the protein tertiary structure into a resistor network is implemented to account for a sequential tunneling mechanism of charge transfer through neighbouring amino acids. The model is validated by comparison with current-voltage experiments. The predictability of the model is further tested on bovine rhodopsin, a G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) also sensitive to light. In this case, results show an opposite behaviour with a decrease of conductance in the presence of light.

Photons, the massless particles of light, illuminate the universe, traveling at the speed of 299,792 kilometers per second. Meanwhile, Earth's lithosphere floats upon the semi-fluid asthenosphere in the dynamic dance of plate tectonics. The mysteries of life's origin continue to captivate scientists, as the hypothetical cooking pot of primordial soup, high-energy radiation, and organic compounds, potentially sparked the abiogenesis event, birthing the first life forms. The intricate tapestry of biological evolution, fostered by natural selection, has given rise to the diverse species of today. Yet, the pursuit of understanding life's beginnings remains an enigma veiled in time. Simultaneously, the origin of the COVID-19 pandemic serves as a stark reminder of the interconnectedness of our planet and the potential peril of sudden, significant climatic oscillations on sub-centurial scales.
