This intricate dance of molecules, a testament to the grand design of nature, underlies the very essence of our existence.

Experiments for vacuum birefringence and vacuum dichroism have been set up with high-finesse high magnetic experimental apparatuses, which seem to be ideal for small gaseous Cotton-Mouton effect (CME) measurements. PVLAS Collaboration has measured CMEs in krypton, xenon and neon at the wavelength of 1064 nm. In this Letter, we report on our measurement of CMEs in nitrogen, oxygen, carbon dioxide, argon, and krypton at the same wavelength in a magnetic field B = 2.3 T at pressure P = 0.5-300 Torr and temperature T = 295-298 K. Our results agree with the PVLAS results in the common cases.

Blending art and science, a chemist meticulously crafts a vivid palette of hues from organic compounds. Each pigment, a symphony of carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, and sometimes nitrogen or sulfur, is carefully synthesized to produce a specific shade. The process, a delicate dance of heat, pressure, and time, transforms simple raw materials into dazzling colors that captivate artists and enthusiasts alike. These synthetic dyes, with their unparalleled vibrancy and stability, have revolutionized the world of art, offering a kaleidoscope of possibilities beyond the limitations of natural pigments. In doing so, they underscore the boundless potential of chemistry to enhance our lives in unexpected ways.

In the context of our recently developed emergent quantum mechanics, and, in particular, based on an assumed sub-quantum thermodynamics, the necessity of energy quantization as originally postulated by Max Planck is explained by means of purely classical physics. Moreover, under the same premises, also the energy spectrum of the quantum mechanical harmonic oscillator is derived. Essentially, Planck's constant h is shown to be indicative of a particle's "zitterbewegung" and thus of a fundamental angular momentum. The latter is identified with quantum mechanical spin, a residue of which is thus present even in the non-relativistic Schroedinger theory.

In the intricate realm of chemistry, a fascinating phenomena known as electrolysis unfolds. This process, harnessing the power of electricity, splits compounds apart, altering their fundamental structures. When an electric current is passed through a solution containing ions, such as water with salt, the water molecules break down, releasing hydrogen and oxygen gases. This process is crucial in various applications, from industrial manufacturing to water purification, exemplifying the profound impact of chemistry in our daily lives.

We have measured the spin-forbidden decay rate from (3s3d)$^{1}$D$_{2}$ $\to$ (3s3p)$^{3}$P$_{2,1}$ in $^{24}$Mg atoms trapped in a magneto-optical trap. The total decay rate, summing up both exit channels (3s3p)$^{3}$P$_{1}$ and (3s3p)$^{3}$P$_{2}$, yields (196 $\pm$ 10) s$^{-1}$ in excellent agreement with resent relativistic many-body calculations of [S.G. Porsev et al., Phys. Rev. A. \textbf{64}, 012508 (2001)]. The characterization of this decay channel is important as it may limit the performance of quantum optics experiments carried out with this ladder system as well as two-photon cooling experiments currently explored in several groups.

In the realm of organic chemistry, the study of carbon-based compounds, the concept of functional groups assumes paramount importance. These groups, characterized by distinct atomic arrangements, impart unique chemical behaviors to molecules. For instance, a hydroxyl group (-OH) in an alcohol molecule can undergo dehydration reactions, yielding aldehydes or ketones. Similarly, the carboxyl group (-COOH) in an acid is involved in acid-base reactions, donating a proton to a base. The amino group (-NH2) in an amine, on the other hand, can act as a base, accepting a proton from an acid. Thus, these functional groups dictate a compound's reactivity and properties, providing a foundation for understanding the vast array of chemical reactions that occur in organic chemistry.

We present quantum dynamics of collisions between two para-H2 molecules from low (1 mK) to high collision energies (1 eV). The calculations are carried out using a quantum scattering code that solves the time-independent Schrodinger equation in its full dimensionality without any decoupling approximations. The six-dimensional potential energy surface for the H4 system developed by Boothroyd et al. [J. Chem. Phys. 116, 666 (2002)] is used in the calculations. Elastic, inelastic and state-to-state cross sections as well as rate coefficients from T = 1 K to 400 K obtained from our calculations are compared with available experimental and theoretical results. Overall, good agreement is obtained with previous studies.

In the realm of chemistry, the intriguing world of polymers unfolds. These complex molecules, composed of repeating monomer units, exhibit diverse properties that permeate our daily lives. From the flexible plastics that encase our electronics, to the resilient fibers woven into clothing, polymers are ubiquitous. Their versatility arises from the ability to tailor their structure through a process called polymerization, which links monomers together in various sequences. This molecular dance results in materials with unique properties, such as strength, flexibility, and insulation, making them essential for modern technology and innovation. The study of polymers continues to push boundaries, promising a future where these remarkable materials will find even more intricate applications.

The analysis of the ultrasonic frequency-dependent backscatter coefficient of aggregating red blood cells reveals information about blood structural properties. The difficulty to apply this technique in vivo is due to the frequency-dependent attenuation caused by intervening tissue layers that distorts the spectral content of backscattering properties from blood microstructures. An optimization method is proposed to simultaneously estimate tissue attenuation and blood structure factor. In an in vitro experiment, the method gave satisfactory estimates with relative errors below 22% for attenuations between 0.101 and 0.317 dB/cm/MHz, signal-to-noise ratios>28 dB and kR<2.7 (k being the wave number and R the aggregate radius).

Hydrogen peroxide, a colorless, odorless liquid, is a widely used chemical compound in various industries and households. With the formula H2O2, it consists of two hydrogen atoms and two oxygen atoms, differing from water (H2O) by the additional oxygen molecule. Its unique property lies in its ability to break down into water and oxygen gas upon decomposition, making it a valuable oxidizing agent. In the medical field, it's used as an antiseptic and bleaching agent. In the textile industry, it assists in the whitening of fabrics. Additionally, hydrogen peroxide serves as a crucial component in rocket fuel, contributing to the propulsion of spacecraft. Its versatility and non-toxic nature make hydrogen peroxide a valuable substance in numerous applications.

We have investigated the collisional properties of 41K atoms at ultracold temperature. To show the possibility to use 41K as a coolant, a Bose-Einstein condensate of 41K atoms in the stretched state (F=2, m_F=2) was created for the first time by direct evaporation in a magnetic trap. An upper bound of three body loss coefficient for atoms in the condensate was determined to be 4(2) 10^{-29} cm -6 s-1. A Feshbach resonance in the F=1, m_F=-1 state was observed at 51.42(5) G, which is in good agreement with theoretical prediction.

In the realm of molecular biology, DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) serves as the primary genetic material, encoding the blueprint for life. Each strand of DNA consists of a double helix, a structure formed by the pairing of nucleotides: adenine with thymine, and cytosine with guanine. This intricate dance of base pairing enables the replication and transcription of genetic information, ensuring the continuity of life. DNA's sequence, determined by the order of its four nucleotides, carries the code for proteins, the workhorses of cells, regulating and maintaining life's intricate processes. This genetic code, a testament to nature's complexity and elegance, continues to captivate scientists and fuel the advancements in medicine, technology, and our understanding of life itself.

We propose a new class of photonic devices based on periodic stress fields in silicon that enable second-order nonlinearity as well as quasi-phase matching. Periodically-poled silicon (PePSi) adds the periodic poling capability to silicon photonics, and allows the excellent crystal quality and advanced manufacturing capabilities of silicon to be harnessed for devices based on second-order nonlinear effects. As an example of the utility of the PePSi technology, we present simulations showing that mid-wave infrared radiation can be efficiently generated through difference frequency generation from near-infrared with a conversion efficiency of 50%. This technology can also be implemented with piezoelectric material, which offers the capability to dynamically control the X(2) nonlinearity.

In the realm of chemical synthesis, the art of creating complex molecules from simpler ones, a pivotal player is the catalyst. These substances, often in minute quantities, speed up reactions without being consumed themselves. They work like a precision mechanism, lowering the energy barrier for chemical bonds to break and form, thereby accelerating the reaction rate. Catalysts are the unsung heroes in the industry, driving the production of essential goods like fertilizers, pharmaceuticals, and plastics, and playing a crucial role in environmental processes, such as air pollution reduction. Their application is vast, their impact profound, and their study promises to unlock new frontiers in chemical engineering and sustainability.

This article discusses the advantages of using wireless keypads in the Lecture/classroom. This new technology requires multiple-choice (MC) questions to mate with the keypad entry features of these devices. The format of the traditional MC response is constrained to five choices and only one best response is allowed. For this reason, we propose enhancements to the traditional MC question. This enhanced MC question allows as many as ten answers. The answers can vary in their degree of correctness and can be assigned partial credit. By combining wireless keypads and multiple-choice questions, we can readily perform both formative and summative assessments of student learning. Examples and classroom applications are presented.

Nitric acid, a pivotal compound in the realm of chemistry, is a strong acid characterized by its corrosive nature and pungent odor. It is predominantly composed of nitrogen and oxygen, with the molecular formula HNO3. Nitric acid plays a significant role in various industrial processes, such as the production of fertilizers, explosives, and automotive catalytic converters. In nature, it is formed through the oxidation of nitrogen oxides in the atmosphere, contributing to the formation of acid rain. Its versatility and importance make nitric acid an indispensable component in modern chemistry.

We study the statistical properties of return intervals $r$ between successive energy dissipation rates above a certain threshold $Q$ in three-dimensional fully developed turbulence. We find that the distribution function $P_Q(r)$ scales with the mean return interval $R_Q$ as $P_Q(r)=R_Q^{-1}f(r/R_Q)$ except for $r=1$, where the scaling function $f(x)$ has two power-law regimes. The return intervals are short-term and long-term correlated and possess multifractal nature. The Hurst index of the return intervals decays exponentially against $R_Q$, predicting that rare extreme events with $R_Q\to\infty$ are also long-term correlated with the Hurst index $H_\infty=0.639$.

Harnessing the power of chemistry, scientists have developed a revolutionary method for converting carbon dioxide into usable resources. This innovative process, known as carbon capture and utilization (CCU), offers a promising solution to combat global warming. By utilizing enzymes and microorganisms, CO2 is transformed into valuable products such as fuels, plastics, and chemicals. This groundbreaking technology not only reduces greenhouse gas emissions but also creates a circular economy, where waste is converted into valuable resources. The potential of CCU is immense, providing a sustainable approach to industrial production and a significant step towards a greener future.

An attempt to redefine science in the 21st century (BK Jennings, On the Nature of Science, Physics in Canada, 63(7) 2007) has abandoned traditional notions of natural law and objective reality, blurred the distinctions between natural science and natural history, elevated Occam's razor from an epistemological preference to a scientific principle, and elevated peer-review and experimental care as equals with repeatable experiment as arbiters of scientific validity. Our comments review the long-established axioms of the scientific method, remind readers of the distinctions between science and history, disprove the generality of Occam's razor by counter example, and highlight the risks of accepting additional scientific arbiters as equal to repeatable experiment.

Nitrogen, an abundant element in Earth's atmosphere, plays a crucial role in various chemical processes. This diatomic gas, symbolized as N2, is vital for life as it forms a fundamental part of amino acids, proteins, and nucleic acids. In industry, nitrogen is used in the production of fertilizers, plastics, and explosives. The fixation of nitrogen from the air into a usable form, a process primarily carried out by certain bacteria known as nitrogen-fixing organisms, is a testament to the intricate balance and transformative power of chemistry in our world. This element's versatility underscores the profound impact chemistry has on our lives, from sustaining life on Earth to driving economic growth.

We present a basic tutorial for implementing surface mount technology in lab-built scientific instruments. We discuss the advantages and disadvantages of using surface mount chips. We also describe methods for the development and prototyping of surface mount circuitry in home-built electronics. The method of soldering surface mount components in a common toaster oven is described. We provide advice from our own experience in developing this technology, and argue that surface mount technology is often preferable to using leaded components when building large circuits, and is essential if the desired component characteristics are only available in surface mount packages.

In the realm of chemical elements, Copper (Cu) stands out for its versatility and utility. Native in nature, it is often found in minerals such as chalcopyrite and malachite. Copper is a key component in various alloys, including brass and bronze, lending them their durability and aesthetic appeal. In electricity, copper is indispensable, owing to its high electrical conductivity. Copper sulfate, a compound of copper, is used as a fungicide and as a blue pigment in ceramics. Moreover, copper is essential to life, serving as a catalyst in many enzymatic reactions in biological systems. Its importance in technology, art, and biology underscores its significance in our daily lives.

Terahertz time domain spectroscopy and rigorous simulations are used to probe the coupling between a dark and a bright plasmonic eigenmode in a metamaterial with broken symmetry. The metamaterial consists of two closely spaced split ring resonators that have their gaps in non-identical positions within the ring. For normal incidence and a fixed polarization both lowest order eigenmodes of the split ring resonators can be excited. although one of them has to be regarded as dark since coupling is prohibited because of symmetry constraints. Emphasis in this work is put on a systematic evaluation of the coupling effects depending on a spectral tuning of both resonances.

In the realm of chemical compounds, polymers stand out as fascinating entities. These large molecules are constructed from repeating subunits, known as monomers, linked together in a chain-like structure. Polymers are ubiquitous in our daily lives, from the plastic bags we use for shopping to the synthetic fibers in our clothing. Their properties can be tailored by altering the type of monomer, the sequence of linkages, or the molecular weight, making them versatile materials for various applications. For instance, polyethylene, a type of plastic, is lightweight and flexible, while silicon-based polymers are used in solar panels due to their ability to conduct electricity. The study of polymers continues to advance, offering promising avenues for innovation in materials science and technology.

Econophysics, is based on the premise that some ideas and methods from physics can be applied to economic situations. We intend to show in this paper how a physics concept such as entropy can be applied to an economic problem. In so doing, we demonstrate how information in the form of observable data and moment constraints are introduced into the method of Maximum relative Entropy (MrE). A general example of updating with data and moments is shown. Two specific econometric examples are solved in detail which can then be used as templates for real world problems. A numerical example is compared to a large deviation solution which illustrates some of the advantages of the MrE method.

Nitrogen, a crucial element in the air we breathe, is vital to life on Earth. It forms approximately 78% of our atmosphere, yet in its diatomic form (N2), it remains inert and unresponsive to most reactions. However, under specific conditions, nitrogen can be activated, undergoing transformations in the presence of catalysts or energy inputs. For instance, lightning, volcanic eruptions, and industrial processes like the Haber-Bosch method, convert nitrogen into nitric oxide (NO) and other nitrogen compounds like ammonia (NH3) and nitrates (NO3-). These compounds play essential roles in fertilizers, explosives, pharmaceuticals, and food preservatives, highlighting the versatile and indispensable nature of nitrogen in modern society.

The Navier-Stokes-Voigt (NSV) model of viscoelastic incompressible fluid has been recently proposed as a regularization of the 3D Navier-Stokes equations for the purpose of direct numerical simulations. In this work we investigate its statistical properties by employing phenomenological heuristic arguments, in combination with Sabra shell model simulations of the analogue of the NSV model. For large values of the regularizing parameter, compared to the Kolmogorov length scale, simulations exhibit multiscaling inertial range, and the dissipation range displaying low intermittency. These facts provide evidence that the NSV regularization may reduce the stiffness of direct numerical simulations of turbulent flows, with a small impact on the energy containing scales.

In the realm of chemical reactions, the fascinating dance of atoms unfolds. One such reaction, combustion, is a spectacle of energy transformation. A match ignites, triggering a cascade of events. Hydrocarbons in the match head, primarily phosphorus sesquisulfide, undergo oxidation by atmospheric oxygen. This oxidation releases energy in the form of heat and light. Simultaneously, the fuel in the matchhead consumes, causing a chain reaction that propagates, ultimately leading to a self-sustaining flame. This simple act encapsulates the intricate and powerful interplay between matter and energy in chemical reactions.

The silicon trackers of the ATLAS experiment at LHC (CERN) use optical links for data transmission. VCSEL arrays operating at 850 nm are used to transmit optical signals while PIN arrays are used to convert the optical signals into electrical signals. We investigate the feasibility of using the devices at the Super LHC (SLHC). We irradiated VCSEL and GaAs PIN arrays from three vendors and silicon PIN arrays from one vendor. All arrays can be operated up to the SLHC dosage except the GaAs PIN arrays which have very low responsivities after irradiation and hence are probably not suitable for the SLHC application.

In the realm of chemistry, the fascinating world of polymers unfolds. These complex compounds, composed of repeating molecular units, exhibit diverse properties that shape our modern world. From the elasticity of rubber to the strength of Kevlar, polymers are the building blocks of countless materials. Their synthesis, often involving polymerization reactions, allows chemists to create materials with tailored characteristics, enabling advancements in sectors ranging from medicine to electronics. In essence, polymers are the silent partners in the dance of innovation, subtly yet significantly impacting our daily lives.

Unstable modes growing when two plasma shells cross over a background plasma at arbitrary angle $\theta$, are investigated using a non-relativistic three cold fluids model. Parallel flows with $\theta=0$ are slightly more unstable than anti-parallel ones with $\theta=\pi$. The case $\theta=\pi/2$ is as unstable as the $\theta=0$ one, but the fastest growing modes are oblique. While the most unstable wave vector varies with orientation, its growth rate slightly evolves and there is no such thing as a stable configuration. A number of exact results can be derived, especially for the $\theta=\pi/2$ case.

Unraveling the mysteries of the periodic table, hydrogen, the lightest and most abundant element, occupies the table's far left. It exists in two forms, diatomic gas (H2) and the proton (H+), and plays a crucial role as a reactive building block in various chemical reactions. Moving rightward on the table, we encounter carbon, a versatile element that forms the basis of life through its ability to bond with itself and other elements to create an array of complex structures. Carbon's unique property of catenation, where carbon atoms can join together to form chains or rings, underpins the creation of organic molecules, the backbone of life. As we delve deeper into the table, elements such as oxygen, nitrogen, and sulfur emerge, each essential for life and integral in countless chemical processes. The periodic table, a testament to Dmitri Mendeleev's genius, continues to captivate scientists and fuel our understanding of the world around us.

Congestion in transport networks is a topic of theoretical interest and practical importance. In this paper we study the flow of vehicles in urban street networks. In particular, we use a cellular automata model to simulate the motion of vehicles along streets, coupled with a congestion-aware routing at street crossings. Such routing makes use of the knowledge of agents about traffic in nearby roads and allows the vehicles to dynamically update the routes towards their destinations. By implementing the model in real urban street patterns of various cities, we show that it is possible to achieve a global traffic optimization based on local agent decisions.

In the captivating realm of chemistry, the intricate dance of elements and compounds unfolds. Hydrogen, the lightest element, unites with oxygen to form water, a fundamental substance essential for life. Carbon, with its versatile nature, forges bonds in countless organic molecules, the building blocks of our world. Sodium and chlorine, when paired, produce common table salt, adding flavor to our meals. Silicon, a closer cousin to carbon, forms the silicon dioxide in sand, the foundation of glass and concrete. Each element, unique in character, combines to create the intricate tapestry of matter, a testament to the boundless wonders of chemistry.

A self-focusing of a coasting relativistic beam in a plasma channel that is confined by an external magnetic field is studied as a means of reconditioning the beam emerging from a beam injector [a radio frequency quadrupole (RFQ)] for a linac. A detailed study of the beam stability in the self-focused beam has been carried out. In order to explain beam filaments and the resistive hose instability in a unified way, we treat all the azimuthal modes in the derivation of the dispersion relation in a finite plasma channel that exhibit many unstable modes, which are classified by Weinberg's scheme [Steven Weinberg, J. Math. 8, 614 (1967)].

Delving into the realm of organic chemistry, we encounter a fascinating compound known as terpenes. Terpenes are a class of volatile hydrocarbons, predominantly found in plants, that contribute to their unique scents. These compounds play a crucial role in plant defense mechanisms, acting as natural pesticides and deterrents against predators. Terpenes are not just aromatic enhancers. they also interact with our bodies, influencing mood and cognitive function as terpene molecules in essential oils are absorbed through our olfactory system. Moreover, terpenes have potential medicinal properties, with some showing anti-inflammatory, analgesic, and antioxidant effects, making them a subject of ongoing research in the pharmaceutical industry.

The credit crisis roiling the world's financial markets will likely take years and entire careers to fully understand and analyze. A short empirical investigation of the current trends, however, demonstrates that the losses in certain markets, in this case the US equity markets, follow a cascade or epidemic flow like model along the correlations of various stocks. This phenomenon will be shown by the graphical display of stock returns across the network as well as the dependence of stock returns on topological measures. Finally, whether the idea of "epidemic" or a "cascade" is a metaphor or model for this crisis will be discussed.

In the realm of chemistry, the intriguing world of polymers unfolds. These complex substances, composed of repeating monomer units, exhibit a myriad of properties that make them indispensable in modern life. From the flexible plastics that encapsulate our electronic devices to the resilient fibers in clothing, polymers are ubiquitous. Their versatility arises from the ability to tailor their properties through the selection of monomers and the arrangement of their structures, a testament to the profound impact of chemistry on our everyday lives.

By using the Renyi entropy, and following the same scheme that in the Fisher-Renyi entropy product case, a generalized statistical complexity is defined. Several properties of it, including inequalities and lower and upper bounds are derived. The hydrogen atom is used as a test system where to quantify these two different statistical magnitudes, the Fisher-Renyi entropy product and the generalized statistical complexity. For each level of energy, both indicators take their minimum values on the orbitals that correspond to the highest orbital angular momentum. Hence, in the same way as happens with the Fisher-Shannon and the statistical complexity, these generalized Renyi-like statistical magnitudes break the energy degeneration in the H-atom.

Amidst the intricate dance of atoms, chemistry unfolds, weaving a tapestry of compounds that govern our world. From the fiery fusion in the sun, to the delicate balance of life's building blocks, chemistry is an omnipresent force. Silicon, carbon, and oxygen combine to form the silicon dioxide, the foundation of sand and glass, while hydrogen and oxygen unite in water, the elixir of life. In a laboratory, a chemist meticulously measures reagents, their interactions revealing new substances, each with unique properties. Chemistry, the alchemist's art, continues to enthrall us, revealing nature's secrets as we delve deeper into its enigmatic depths.

We have designed and demonstrated a Superconducting Quantum Interference Device (SQUID) array linearized with cryogenic feedback. To achieve the necessary loop gain a 300 element series array SQUID is constructed from three monolithic 100-element series arrays. A feedback resistor completes the loop from the SQUID output to the input coil. The short feedback path of this Linearized SQUID Array (LISA) allows for a substantially larger flux-locked loop bandwidth as compared to a SQUID flux-locked loop that includes a room temperature amplifier. The bandwidth, linearity, noise performance, and dynamic range of the LISA are sufficient for its use in our target application: the multiplexed readout of transition-edge sensor bolometers.

Amidst the vibrant spectacle of a chemical laboratory, a chemist meticulously blends reagents, their colors swirling in a dance of transformation. The beaker bubbles as heat coaxes a reaction, the air filling with the unique scent of a newly formed compound. The chemist's gaze is focused, a blend of curiosity and anticipation reflected in their eyes. This moment, a snapshot of alchemy redefined, encapsulates the essence of chemistry - the art and science of changing one substance into another, a testament to the mysteries of matter and the boundless potential of human ingenuity.

All the relativistic cosmological models of the universe, except Einstein's static model, imply that the 3-space of the spacetime of the universe is also expanding apart from the matter and the radiation in it. However, there is no observational evidence of the expansion of the 3-space of the spacetime of the universe. Actually, the 3-space of the spacetime of the universe might not be expanding at all. Consequently, the conceptual foundation of the relativistic cosmological models of the universe based on the general theory of relativity, which in turn is based on Riemannian geometry, might be faulty and misleading.

In the realm of chemical reactions, the fascinating dance of atoms never ceases. Catalysts, silent spectators, speed up the pace of these dances, lowering reaction energies and making processes more efficient. They are like temporary dance partners, allowing reactions to unfold swiftly without altering the final outcome. In the vast panorama of chemistry, catalysts play a pivotal role, propelling the conversion of one substance into another, and thereby shaping the world around us. From the production of everyday items to the purification of air and water, catalysts are the unseen heroes, orchestrating the intricate ballet of chemical change.

Weakly-rotating turbulent Rayleigh-Benard convection was studied experimentally and numerically. With increasing rotation and large enough Rayleigh number an abrupt transition from a turbulent state with nearly rotation-independent heat transport to another turbulent state with enhanced heat transfer is observed at a critical inverse Rossby number $1/Ro_c \simeq 0.4$. Whereas for $1/Ro < 1/Ro_c$ the strength of the large-scale convection-roll is either enhanced or essentially unmodified depending on parameters, its strength is increasingly diminished beyond $1/Ro_c$ where it competes with Ekman vortices that cause vertical fluid transport and thus heat-transfer enhancement.

In the realm of chemistry, the intriguing concept of polymers reigns supreme. These complex molecules, consisting of repeating subunits, are engineered marvels that have reshaped numerous industries. From the flexible plastics wrapping your groceries to the robust fibers in your clothing, polymers permeate our daily lives. Their unique properties, such as strength, flexibility, and insulation, stem from the arrangement and bonding of their constituent units. The versatility of polymers allows for their tailoring to specific applications, making them indispensable in modern technology and manufacturing. Their continued evolution holds immense potential for addressing global challenges, such as sustainable energy storage and biocompatible materials for medicine.

We study the behavior of self-propelled nano- and micro-rods in three dimensions, confined between two parallel walls, by simulations and scaling arguments. Our simulations include thermal fluctuations and hydrodynamic interactions, which are both relevant for the dynamical behavior at nano- to micrometer length scales. In order to investigate the importance hydrodynamic interactions, we also perform Brownian-dynamics-like simulations. In both cases, we find that self-propelled rods display a strong surface excess in confined geometries. An analogy with semi-flexible polymers is employed to derive scaling laws for the dependence on the wall distance, the rod length, and the propulsive force. The simulation data confirm the scaling predictions.

In the intricate world of chemistry, the element carbon stands out for its versatility, forming the basis of countless organic compounds. Carbon's unique property of catenation, or the ability to form strong bonds with other carbon atoms, allows it to create complex structures. This feature is exemplified in the creation of polymers, materials that are essential to our daily lives, from plastics to fibers. Furthermore, carbon's ability to form multiple covalent bonds, including triple bonds, results in a wide array of molecules, including the life-sustaining carbon dioxide and the energy-storing molecule, glucose. The study of carbon and its properties continues to fuel our understanding and exploration in the realm of chemistry.

We explore the potential energy surfaces for NH molecules interacting with alkali-metal and alkaline-earth atoms using highly correlated ab-initio electronic structure calculations. The surfaces for interaction with alkali-metal atoms have deep wells dominated by covalent forces. The resulting strong anisotropies will produce strongly inelastic collisions. The surfaces for interaction with alkaline-earth atoms have shallower wells that are dominated by induction and dispersion forces. For Be and Mg the anisotropy is small compared to the rotational constant of NH, so that collisions will be relatively weakly inelastic. Be and Mg are thus promising coolants for sympathetic cooling of NH to the ultracold regime.

In the intricate realm of chemistry, the fascinating dance of elements and compounds unfolds. Silicon, a versatile non-metal, is one such element that plays a crucial role in our modern world. It's the second most abundant element in the Earth's crust, primarily found in sand and silica. Silicon's unique properties, such as high thermal stability, make it an essential component in semiconductors, a key technology in electronics. This allows for the creation of microchips, driving advancements in technology and connecting us in ways unimaginable just a few decades ago. Moreover, silicon's biocompatibility has led to its use in medical implants, revolutionizing healthcare. Indeed, the story of silicon is a testament to the transformative power of chemistry, shaping our lives in ways both visible and invisible.

We investigate electron-positron pair production from vacuum for short laser pulses with sub-cycle structure, in the nonperturbative regime (Schwinger pair production). We use the non-equilibrium quantum kinetic approach, and show that the momentum spectrum of the created electron-positron pairs is extremely sensitive to the sub-cycle dynamics -- depending on the laser frequency $\omega$, the pulse length $\tau$, and the carrier phase $\phi$ -- and shows several distinctive new signatures. This observation could help not only in the design of laser pulses to optimize the experimental signature of Schwinger pair production, but also ultimately lead to new probes of light pulses at extremely short time scales.

Nitrogen, a versatile element vital to life on Earth, is the most abundant gas in our atmosphere, comprising about 78% of its composition. In its elemental form, it is an inert, colorless, odorless, and non-reactive gas. However, when combined with other elements, it forms a myriad of compounds essential to various biological processes and industrial applications. Nitrogen-containing molecules like ammonia (NH3), nitric acid (HNO3), and proteins play crucial roles in agriculture, medicine, and energy production. The nitrogen cycle, a series of chemical processes that convert nitrogen between its various forms, is a fundamental aspect of Earth's biogeochemical cycles, ensuring the continuous availability of this vital element for life.

In this paper, we study the effects of introducing contrarians in a model of Opinion Dynamics where the agents have internal continuous opinions, but exchange information only about a binary choice that is a function of their continuous opinion, the CODA model. We observe that the hung election scenario still exists here, but it is weaker and it shouldn't be expected in every election. Finally, we also show that the introduction of contrarians make the tendency towards extremism of the original model weaker, indicating that the existence of agents that prefer to disagree might be an important aspect and help society to diminish extremist opinions.

In the intricate world of molecular biology, a pivotal role is played by DNA, the hereditary material of life. Its double helix structure, composed of nitrogenous bases, sugars, and phosphates, encodes the genetic instructions for every organism. Each base pair, an adenine-thymine or guanine-cytosine duo, carries vital information, ensuring the accurate replication and expression of genes. This intricate dance of nucleotides, guided by enzymes, governs cell growth, function, and the transmission of traits from one generation to the next, underscoring DNA's indispensable role in life's grand design.

A purely electrical sensing scheme is presented that determines the concentration of macromolecules in solution by measuring the capacitance between planar microelectrodes. Concentrations of DNA in the ng/mL range have been used in samples of 1 microL volume. The method has been applied to the characterisation of the dielectrophoretic response of DNA without the need for any chemical modifications. The influence of electrical parameters like duty cycle, voltage and frequency has been investigated. The results are in good agreement with data from dielectrophoretic studies on fluorescently labelled DNA. Extension of the method down to the single molecule level appears feasible.

In the intricate world of chemistry, the element carbon holds a unique position. It forms the backbone of organic compounds, subtly altering its structure to create a vast array of substances. From the complex biomolecules in our bodies to the carbon nanotubes used in cutting-edge technology, carbon's versatility is unparalleled. Its ability to bond with itself and other elements, forming stable, yet diverse structures, is the key to its dominance in the periodic table. This versatility, when harnessed, can lead to revolutionary advancements in various fields, from medicine to materials science. The ever-evolving study of carbon and its compounds continues to captivate scientists, promising a myriad of discoveries yet to come.

Generalizing results of our previous work (where classical kinetic energy has been used) in this work (where ultra-relativistic kinetic energy is used) we suggest an original variant of the determination of minimal length (corresponding to Plank length) by formation of a microscopic (tiny) black hole. Like to some previous authors we use Heisenberg coordinate-momentum uncertainty relation, on the one hand. But, instead of metric fluctuation (obtained by second derivative in Einstein equations) that generalizes uncertainty relation by an additional term, used by previous authors, we use Hawking temperature of the black hole and standard Heisenberg coordinate-momentum uncertainty relation.

In the realm of molecular magic, the chemistry of polymers unfolds a captivating tale. Polymers, the macromolecules built from repeating subunits, are the backbone of countless everyday objects, from rugged plastics to elastic rubber. Their properties, dictated by the sequence and arrangement of these subunits, can be tailored to serve diverse purposes. For instance, polyethylene, a linear polymer, is prized for its strong, lightweight structure, while polyvinyl chloride, a more complex polymer, offers flexibility and durability. The art of polymer chemistry is a testament to the dynamic nature of matter, where the simple union of atoms can give rise to a myriad of practical applications, shaping our world in ways both subtle and profound.

The goal of this paper is to explore the possibility to detect and identify bacteria by sensing their odor via fluctuation-enhanced sensing with commercial Taguchi sensors. The fluctuations of the electrical resistance during exposure to different bacterial odors, Escherichia coli and anthrax-surrogate Bacillus subtilis, have been measured and analyzed. In the present study, the simplest method, the measurement and analysis of power density spectra was used. The sensors were run in the normal heated and the sampling-and-hold working modes, respectively. The results indicate that Taguchi sensors used in these fluctuation-enhanced modes are effective tools of bacterium detection and identification even when they are utilizing only the power density spectrum of the stochastic sensor signal.

In the realm of chemical bonding, the fascination lies in the intricate dance between atoms. Ionic bonds, forged from the mutual attraction of oppositely charged ions, illuminate the chemistry of salt crystals. Covalent bonds, on the other hand, form when two atoms share electrons, as seen in water (H2O) and methane (CH4). The strong and stable nature of these bonds is crucial to life, from the water we drink to the molecules that make up our DNA. Yet, chemistry is not limited to these fundamental interactions. Polymers, for instance, are large molecules composed of repeating subunits, playing a vital role in diverse applications, from plastics to biology. The beauty of chemistry lies in its ability to explain the world around us, from the microscopic to the macroscopic, and in its endless potential for innovation.

We have recently started to investigate 2D arrays of confocal lens pairs. Miniaturization of the lens pairs can make the array behave ray-optically like a homogeneous medium. Here we generalize the geometry of the lens pairs. These generalisations include a sideways shift of the lens centres and a change in the orientation of both lenses in each pair. We investigate the basic ray optics of the resulting arrays, and illustrate these with movies rendered using ray-tracing software. We suggest that confocal lenslet arrays could be used to realize ray-optically some recent metamaterials concepts such as the coordinate-transform design paradigm.

Amidst the kaleidoscope of chemical reactions, one stands out as a cornerstone: oxidation-reduction, or redox for short. This process, fundamental to life itself, involves the transfer of electrons from one atom or molecule (the reducer) to another (the oxidizer). The oxidizer gains electrons, becoming reduced, while the reducer loses electrons, oxidizing. This dance of electrons powers countless reactions, from rusting metals to the burning of fuel in a car engine, and even the breakdown of glucose in our cells for energy. Understanding redox reactions opens a window into the very heart of chemical transformations, shedding light on the intricate web of cause and effect that governs the world around us.

Quantum optics with quantum gases represents a new field, where the quantum nature of both light and ultracold matter plays equally important role. Only very recently this ultimate quantum limit of light-matter interaction became feasible experimentally. In traditional quantum optics, the cold atoms are considered classically, whereas, in quantum atom optics, the light is used as an essentially classical axillary tool. On the one hand, the quantization of optical trapping potentials can significantly modify many-body dynamics of atoms, which is well-known only for classical potentials. On the other hand, atomic fluctuations can modify the properties of the scattered light.

In the captivating realm of chemistry, a pivotal compound known as glucose, or blood sugar, plays a vital role. Derived from carbohydrates, glucose is the primary energy source for our cells. When consumed, it's broken down during digestion into simpler molecules, absorbed into our bloodstream, and transported to cells for conversion into ATP, the universal energy currency of life. Insulin, a hormone produced by the pancreas, facilitates this process, allowing glucose to enter cells and lower blood sugar levels. Imbalances in glucose metabolism can lead to disorders such as diabetes, highlighting the significance of this compound in maintaining homeostasis within our bodies.

The problem of the universal form of the size spectrum is analyzed. The half-widths of two wings of spectrum is introduced and it is shown that their ratio is very close to the golden fraction. In appendix it is shown that behind the golden fraction of an image one can find the information basis, i.e. the proportion of the golden fraction corresponds to some method to find extremum. The method to find extrema associated with Fibonacci numbers also leads to proportions which can be seen in nature or can be introduced artificially. The information origin of proportions is proved theoretically and confirmed by examples in nature and human life.

In the realm of chemical bonding, the concept of an ionic bond is pivotal. Ionic bonds form when a metal loses electrons, forming a cation, and a non-metal gains these electrons, becoming an anion. This electrostatic attraction between oppositely charged ions holds sodium chloride, table salt, together, for instance. Conversely, covalent bonds, where atoms share electrons, are essential in organic molecules like water (H2O), ethanol (C2H5OH), and glucose (C6H12O6). These bonds are fundamental to the structure and properties of countless substances, shaping the vast and intricate landscape of chemistry.

Sample-to-sample fluctuations of the time-dependent conductance of a system with static disorder have been studied by means of diagrammatic theory and microwave pulsed transmission measurements. The fluctuations of time-dependent conductance are not universal, i.e., depend on sample parameters, in contrast to the universal conductance fluctuations in the steady-state regime. The variance of normalized conductance, determined by the infinite-range intensity correlation C_3(t), is found to increase as a third power of delay time from an exciting pulse, t. C_3(t) grows larger than the long-range intensity correlation C_2(t) after a time t_q ~ <g>^{1/2} t_D (t_D being the diffusion time, <g> being the average dimensionless conductance).

Amidst the dazzling array of chemical compounds, one stands out for its ubiquity and versatility: water (H2O). It's a simple molecule, yet it plays a pivotal role in virtually every life process. Water is a solvent, dissolving a vast number of substances, facilitating reactions and transporting nutrients in our bodies. It's also a medium for chemical reactions, lowering or raising the temperature at which they occur. In the broader realm of chemistry, water's unique properties make it an essential component in laboratory experiments, industrial processes, and even in our everyday cleaning solutions. Its role as a solvent, its ability to form hydrogen bonds, and its presence in all states of matter (solid, liquid, gas) underscore its profound significance in the realm of chemistry.

Progress in the theory of anomalous diffusion in weakly turbulent cold magnetized plasmas is explained. Several proposed models advanced in the literature are discussed. Emphasis is put on a new proposed mechanism for anomalous diffusion transport mechanism based on the coupled action of conductive walls (excluding electrodes) bounding the plasma drain current (edge diffusion) together with the magnetic field flux "cutting" the area traced by the charged particles in their orbital motion. The same reasoning is shown to apply to the plasma core anomalous diffusion. The proposed mechanism is expected to be valid in regimes when plasma diffusion scales as Bohm diffusion and at high $B/N$, when collisions are of secondary importance.

In the intricate realm of chemistry, the study of compounds is fundamental. A compound is a substance formed when two or more elements chemically combine. These elements retain their individual identities within the compound, yet their properties are dramatically altered. For instance, sodium and chlorine, when united, form common table salt, a compound essential in human diet. The bond between these elements is ionic, a type of attraction that holds the compound together. Conversely, when hydrogen and oxygen unite, they form water, a covalent compound vital for life. These examples illustrate the versatility of chemistry, where simple elements can combine to create the complex substances that shape our world.

Superconducting NbN wires have recently received attention as detectors for visible and infrared photons. We present experiments in which we use a NbN wire for high-efficiency (40 %) detection of single electrons with keV energy. We use the beam of a scanning electron microscope as a focussed, stable, and calibrated electron source. Scanning the beam over the surface of the wire provides a map of the detection efficiency. This map shows features as small as 150 nm, revealing wire inhomogeneities. The intrinsic resolution of this mapping method, superior to optical methods, provides the basis of a characterization tool relevant for photon detectors.

Nitrogen, a versatile element, constitutes nearly 78% of Earth's atmosphere. It's a key component in the formation of proteins, enzymes, and nucleic acids, essential for life as we know it. In industry, nitrogen plays a pivotal role in the production of fertilizers, plastics, explosives, and pharmaceuticals. The Haber-Bosch process, a catalytic fixation of atmospheric nitrogen, revolutionized agriculture by providing a sustainable source of nitrogen fertilizers, boosting crop yields significantly. Yet, nitrogen pollution from agricultural runoff and industrial emissions poses environmental concerns, leading to eutrophication and acid rain. The delicate balance between harnessing nitrogen's benefits and managing its impacts remains a vital challenge for sustainable development.

The process of cognition is analysed to adjust the set theory to physical description. Postulates and basic definitions are revised. The specific sets of predicates, called presets, corresponding to the physical objects identified by an observer during cognition are introduced. Unlike sets, the presets are free of logical or set-theoretical paradoxes and may be consistently used in physical description. Schemes of cognition based on presets are considered. Being different logical systems, the relativistic and quantum theories, observations in modern cosmology cannot be consistently considered in one `unified physical theory', but they are in frames of introduced schemes of cognition.

Nitrogen, a diatomic element symbolized as N, occupies the air we breathe at a staggering 78% volume. An abundant element, it forms the backbone of proteins, DNA, and various amino acids essential for life. In industry, nitrogen is essential in fertilizer production, serving as a crucial nutrient for plant growth. In medicine, it's used in cryogenics for freezing and storing organs for transplant. Moreover, nitrogen is a significant component in the synthesis of plastics, resins, and nylon. Its versatility extends to the production of explosives and synthetic rubbers, making it an indispensable element in numerous industrial applications. Despite its crucial role, managing nitrogen emissions is critical to mitigate pollution and preserve Earth's delicate ecosystem balance.

We study oscillation death (OD) in a well-known coupled-oscillator system that has been used to model cardiovascular phenomena. We derive exact analytic conditions that allow the prediction of OD through the two known bifurcation routes, in the same model, and for different numbers of coupled oscillators. Our exact analytic results enable us to generalize OD as a multiparameter-sensitive phenomenon. It can be induced, not only by changes in couplings, but also by changes in the oscillator frequencies or amplitudes. We observe synchronization transitions as a function of coupling and confirm the robustness of the phenomena in the presence of noise. Numerical and analogue simulations are in good agreement with the theory.

In the realm of chemistry, the fascinating world of polymers unfolds. These complex molecules, composed of repeating monomer units, are ubiquitous in our daily lives. From the flexible plastics that encase our smartphones, to the resilient rubber in our tires, polymers are essential. Their properties are tailored through various processes, such as polymerization, cross-linking, and copolymerization. These versatile materials offer a rich palette for chemists, enabling innovation in fields as diverse as medicine, electronics, and agriculture. The discovery and development of polymers have revolutionized industries, enhancing our quality of life in countless ways.

A data acquisition (DAQ) system is described which will be used for the next generation of prototype calorimeters using particle flow algorithms for the International Linear Collider (ILC). The design is sufficiently generic and scalable such that it should have numerous applications either for ILC detectors or elsewhere within high energy physics in general. The DAQ system will be implemented using FPGAs and built using off-the-shelf components and networking hardware with programmable FPGAs. The software for the DAQ system is based on an existing framework, DOOCS, which is a server/client object-oriented system. The design philosophy, current status of the project and its aims are presented in this report.

In the realm of chemical compounds, water (H2O) stands out as a remarkable substance. Beyond its ubiquity in our daily lives, water's unique property of a high boiling point for its molecular weight is intriguing. This anomaly, known as the hydrogen bond, stems from the partial positive charge of hydrogen atoms and the partial negative charge of oxygen atoms in water molecules. These charges create a network of hydrogen bonds, making water's structure more stable than other substances with similar molecular weights. This characteristic not only influences water's physical properties but also its role in supporting life on Earth, making it an essential component in various chemical reactions and biological processes.

We have calculated parity nonconserving 7s - 6d_{3/2} amplitude E_PNC in 223Ra+ using high-precision relativistic all-order method where all single and double excitations of the Dirac-Fock wave functions are included to all orders of perturbation theory. Detailed study of the uncertainty of the parity nonconserving (PNC) amplitude is carried out. additional calculations are performed to estimate some of the missing correlation corrections. A systematic study of the parity conserving atomic properties, including the calculation of the energies, transition matrix elements, lifetimes, hyperfine constants, quadrupole moments of the 6d states, as well as dipole and quadrupole ground state polarizabilities, is carried out. The results are compared with other theoretical calculations and available experimental values.

Nitrogen, the diatomic element with symbol N and atomic number 7, is a vital component in our environment and industrial processes. It constitutes nearly 78% of Earth's atmosphere in the form of diatomic nitrogen gas (N2). This inert gas is crucial for life, as it doesn't react under standard conditions, but is essential for the formation of proteins, DNA, and various other organic compounds. In industry, nitrogen plays a pivotal role as a reducing agent, oxidizing agent, and in the production of ammonia, nitric acid, and explosives. Its versatility and abundance make nitrogen a cornerstone element in chemistry and life on Earth.

We have measured the trapping lifetime of magnetically trapped atoms in a cryogenic atom-chip experiment. An ultracold atomic cloud is kept at a fixed distance from a thin gold layer deposited on top of a superconducting trapping wire. The lifetime is studied as a function of the distances to the surface and to the wire. Different regimes are observed, where loss rate is determined either by the technical current noise in the wire or the Johnson-Nyquist noise in the metallic gold layer, in good agreement with theoretical predictions. Far from the surface, we observe exceptionally long trapping times for an atom-chip, in the 10-minutes range.

In the realm of chemistry, alkali metals, a group on the periodic table, captivate our interest. Their distinctive properties - soft, silvery-white, highly reactive, and able to displace hydrogen in acid - set them apart. Sodium, potassium, rubidium, cesium, and francium, these five elements, are alkali metals. Their reactivity stems from a single electron in their outermost energy level, yearning to bond, which makes them readily surrender electrons in reactions, often resulting in the production of salts and hydrogen gas. Their ubiquity in everyday life is reflected in their uses, such as in batteries, as a crucial component in sodium lights, and in the manufacturing of soap and glass. Despite their reactivity, alkali metals, with their unique characteristics, continue to intrigue chemists and fuel our understanding of the periodic table.

Mechanical oscillations are important for many cellular processes, e.g. the beating of cilia and flagella or the sensation of sound by hair cells. These dynamic states originate from spontaneous oscillations of molecular motors. A particularly clear example of such oscillations has been observed in muscle fibers under non-physiological conditions. In that case, motor oscillations lead to contraction waves along the fiber. By a macroscopic analysis of muscle fiber dynamics we find that the spontaneous waves involve non-hydrodynamic modes. A simple microscopic model of sarcomere dynamics highlights mechanical aspects of the motor dynamics and fits with the experimental observations.

Amid the intricate dance of elements, the science of chemistry unfolds a world of wonders. Molecules, the fundamental units of matter, are fashioned by the union of atoms, each a tiny solar system with its own nucleus and orbiting electrons. These molecular entities form the building blocks of substances, from the simple water molecule H2O, which quenches our thirst, to the complex proteins that propel life's intricate processes. Chemistry, thus, serves as the bridge between the microscopic and the macroscopic, revealing the hidden connections that bind the universe together. It's a testament to the beauty and order inherent in nature, a testament to science's ceaseless quest for understanding.

The epsilon-near-zero (ENZ) tunneling phenomenon allows full transmission of waves through a narrow channel even in the presence of a strong geometric mismatch. Here we experimentally demonstrate nonlinear control of the ENZ tunneling by an external field, as well as self-modulation of the transmission resonance due to the incident wave. Using a waveguide section near cut-off frequency as the ENZ system, we introduce a diode with tunable and nonlinear capacitance to demonstrate both of these effects. Our results confirm earlier theoretical ideas on using an ENZ channel for dielectric sensing, and their potential applications for tunable slow-light structures.

Nitrogen, an element vital to life, constitutes 78% of Earth's atmosphere. It's a colorless, odorless, and non-reactive gas. In nature, nitrogen is mainly found in the N2 diatomic form. However, when exposed to energy like lightning or industrial processes, it can combine with oxygen to form nitric oxide (NO) and nitrogen dioxide (NO2), both key components in air pollution. These compounds contribute to the creation of smog, harming both human health and the environment. On a positive note, nitrogen fixation, a biochemical process converting atmospheric nitrogen into a form usable by organisms, is essential for agriculture, ensuring the growth of crops and maintaining food security worldwide.

This work presents a new Visual Basic 6.0 application for estimating the fractal dimension of images, based on an optimized version of the box-counting algorithm. Following the attempt to separate the real information from noise, we considered also the family of all band-pass filters with the same band-width (specified as parameter). The fractal dimension can be thus represented as a function of the pixel color code. The program was used for the study of paintings cracks, as an additional tool which can help the critic to decide if an artistic work is original or not. In its second version, the application was extended for working also with csv files and three-dimensional images.

In the realm of molecular biology, proteins stand as the workhorses of life, performing an array of functions essential for survival. Crafted from amino acids, these complex macromolecules fold into intricate structures, each design specific to their role within the organism. Enzymes, for instance, facilitate biochemical reactions, while antibodies monitor and neutralize foreign invaders. Moreover, proteins act as structural components, providing the framework for cellular structures such as muscles and bones. Their versatility and complexity underscore the critical role they play in maintaining life's delicate balance.

In the given work the first attempt to generalize quantum uncertainty relation on macro objects is made. Business company as one of economical process participants was chosen by the authors for this purpose. The analogies between quantum micro objects and the structures which from the first sight do not have anything in common with physics are given. The proof of generalized uncertainty relation is produced. With the help of generalized uncertainty relation the authors wanted to elaborate a new non-traditional approach to the description of companies' business activity and their developing and try to formulate some advice for them. Thus, our work makes the base of quantum theory of econimics

Unleashing the power of chemical reactions, we delve into the fascinating world of catalysts, Nature's own speed boosters. They are substances that increase the rate of a chemical reaction without being consumed in the process. A catalyst works by providing an alternative reaction pathway with a lower activation energy, facilitating the conversion of reactants to products more efficiently. From the rusting of iron to the combustion of fuels, catalysts play a pivotal role in numerous industrial processes and everyday phenomena. Their influence extends to environmental protection, as they aid in the decomposition of pollutants and the conversion of waste materials into more manageable forms. In essence, catalysts are the unsung heroes of chemistry, driving the world forward at a pace that would otherwise be unattainable.

It is shown that the Shan-Chen (SC) model for non-ideal lattice fluids can be made compliant with a pseudo free-energy principle by simple addition of a gradient force, whose expression is uniquely specified in terms of the fluid density. This additional term is numerically shown to provide fairly negligible effects on the system evolution during phase-separation. To the best of our knowledge, these important properties of the SC model were not noted before. The approach developed in the present work is based on a continuum analysis: further extensions, more in line with a discrete lattice theory (X. Shan, {\it Phys Rev E}, {\bf 77} 066702 (2008)) can be envisaged for the future.

In the realm of chemical research, a significant focus lies in the study of catalysts. These substances, often metals or complex organic compounds, magnify chemical reactions' rates without being consumed themselves. They function as intermediaries, lowering the activation energy of a reaction, thereby accelerating the process. Catalysts are crucial in numerous industrial processes, such as the production of fertilizers, plastics, and pharmaceuticals, as well as in environmental applications like air pollution control and renewable energy. Their role in optimizing energy efficiency and reducing waste makes catalysts indispensable in our quest for sustainable and eco-friendly technologies.

We describe students revising the mathematical form of physics equations to match the physical situation they are describing, even though their revision violates physical laws. In an unfamiliar air resistance problem, a majority of students in a sophomore level mechanics class at some point wrote Newton's Second Law as F = -ma. they were using this form to ensure that the sign of the force pointed in a direction consistent with the chosen coordinate system while assuming that some variables have only positive value. We use one student's detailed explanation to suggest that students' issues with variables are context-dependent, and that much of their reasoning is useful for productive instruction.

In the intricate realm of chemical bonding, the covalent bond plays a pivotal role. Unlike ionic bonds that form from the transfer of electrons, covalent bonds are created when two atoms share one or more pairs of electrons. This sharing of electrons results in a stable electron configuration, lowering the overall energy of the molecule. Carbon-carbon bonds, for instance, are covalent, enabling the construction of complex organic structures. Hydrogen bonds, a weaker form of covalent linkage, occur when a hydrogen atom in one molecule is attracted to a highly electronegative atom, such as nitrogen or oxygen, in another molecule, contributing to the stability and structure of many biological compounds. Thus, covalent bonds, in their versatility and ubiquity, are crucial to the existence of countless substances, from the simplest hydrogen molecule to the most complex proteins.

Based on measurements of nonlinear second sound resonances in a high-quality resonator, we have observed a steady-state wave energy cascade in He II involving a flux of energy through the spectral range towards high frequencies. We show that the energy balance in the wave system is nonlocal in K-space and that the frequency scales of energy pumping and dissipation are widely separated. The wave amplitude distribution follows a power law over a wide range of frequencies. Numerical computations yield results in agreement with the experimental observations. We suggest that second sound cascades of this kind may be useful for model studies of acoustic turbulence.

In the captivating realm of organic chemistry, carbon's unique ability to form stable covalent bonds with itself and a multitude of other elements, such as hydrogen, nitrogen, oxygen, and sulfur, gives rise to an astounding diversity of compounds. These include hydrocarbons, alcohols, amines, acids, esters, and ethers. Each compound's properties, from solubility to reactivity, are shaped by the specific arrangement of atoms and bonds within its structure, making organic chemistry a fascinating exploration of molecular architecture and its implications. This versatile field extends its reach into various realms, from pharmaceuticals and materials science to fuels and forensic science, demonstrating the profound impact of organic chemistry on our everyday lives.

The fullerene (C60) nanowires, which possess a highly unusual morphology featured by a prism-like central core and three nanobelt-like wings joined along the growth direction to give an overall Y-shaped cross section, have been studied. The experimental observation coupled with theoretical calculation have enabled us to elucidate both the role of the fullerene and of the solvent in the crystallization process, thus opening up an opportunity for the in-depth understanding of the crystal growth mechanism. More generally, the method developed in this work could be extended into understanding the growth of other inorganic nanowires that have both host and guest molecules involved in their crystal lattices.

In the intricate world of organic chemistry, the synthesis of complex molecules from simpler ones is a captivating dance. Carbon, with its unique ability to form four covalent bonds, serves as the backbone, linking atoms in intricate patterns. A catalyst, often a transition metal compound, speeds up the reaction, allowing for the creation of new bonds and structures. The process, although seemingly chaotic, is governed by strict rules of chemistry, with each reaction following specific pathways dictated by the laws of thermodynamics and kinetics. The final product, a complex molecule, may reveal hidden properties, opening doors to new applications in medicine, materials science, and beyond. This dance of chemistry, a delicate balance of atoms and energy, continues to unveil nature's secrets, offering endless possibilities for human innovation.

Multipole radiofrequency ion traps are a highly versatile tool to study molecular ions and their interactions in a well-controllable environment. In particular the cryogenic 22-pole ion trap configuration is used to study ion-molecule reactions and complex molecular spectroscopy at temperatures between few Kelvin and room temperatures. This article presents a tutorial on radiofrequency ion trapping in multipole electrode configurations. Stable trapping conditions and buffer gas cooling, as well as important heating mechanisms, are discussed. In addition, selected experimental studies on cation and anion-molecule reactions and on spectroscopy of trapped ions are reviewed. Starting from these studies an outlook on the future of multipole ion trap research is given.

In the realm of chemical bonding, the electrons are the fundamental players. They weave an intricate dance, leaping from atom to atom, forming and breaking connections that hold molecules together. This harmonious exchange, known as ionic bonding, occurs between metals and non-metals, where one atom donates electrons to another, thus creating ions with a positive and negative charge. These oppositely charged ions then attract each other in a stable arrangement, forming a crystal lattice within the compound. On the other hand, covalent bonding involves the sharing of electrons between atoms of the same or similar electronegativity. This sharing results in a stable and balanced electron configuration, allowing compounds like water (H2O) and methane (CH4) to maintain their structural integrity. The delicate balance of these chemical bonds shapes the properties of substances, dictating their behavior in various reactions, and ultimately, their role in the grand scheme of chemistry.

Improvement in time resolution sometimes introduces short-range random noises into temporal data sequences. These noises affect the results of power-spectrum analyses and the Detrended Fluctuation Analysis (DFA). The DFA is one of useful methods for analyzing long-range correlations in non-stationary sequences. The effects of noises are discussed based on artificial temporal sequences. Short-range noises prevent power-spectrum analyses from detecting long-range correlations. The DFA can extract long-range correlations from noisy time sequences. The DFA also gives the threshold time length, under which the noises dominate. For practical analyses, coarse-grained time sequences are shown to recover long-range correlations.

In the realm of chemical bonding, the intriguing phenomenon of covalent bonds plays a pivotal role. These bonds, formed by the sharing of electrons between atoms, are fundamental in the structure of numerous molecules, including water and the DNA building blocks. The strength of a covalent bond is determined by factors such as the electronegativity of the bonded atoms, which dictates the polar or non-polar nature of the bond, and the number of shared electrons. For instance, a double covalent bond, like the one in an oxygen molecule, has four electrons shared between the two atoms, resulting in a stronger bond compared to a single covalent bond. This bonding mechanism, with its flexibility and strength, underpins the very essence of the organic compounds that form the basis of life.

The high arithmetic performance and intrinsic parallelism of recent graphical processing units (GPUs) can offer a technological edge for molecular dynamics simulations. ACEMD is a production-class bio-molecular dynamics (MD) simulation program designed specifically for GPUs which is able to achieve supercomputing scale performance of 40 nanoseconds/day for all-atom protein systems with over 23,000 atoms. We illustrate the characteristics of the code, its validation and performance. We also run a microsecond-long trajectory for an all-atom molecular system in explicit TIP3P water on a single workstation computer equipped with just 3 GPUs. This performance on cost effective hardware allows ACEMD to reach microsecond timescales routinely with important implications in terms of scientific applications.

In the realm of chemistry, a fascinating compound known as phosphorescence captures our attention. Unlike the fleeting luminescence of fluorescence, phosphorescence emits light for much longer periods. This persistent glow arises from a process called intersystem crossing, which transitions the excited electron from a lower-energy to a higher-energy state. Common materials such as zinc sulfide and diphenyl anthracene demonstrate this phenomenon, their molecules storing energy and gradually releasing it as light. The study of phosphorescence sheds light on intricate energy transfer mechanisms, offering insights into materials design and the development of novel lighting technologies.

Lorentz's reciprocity lemma and Feld-Tai reciprocity theorem show the effect of interchanging the action and reaction in Maxwell's equations. We derive a free-space version of these reciprocity relations which generalizes the conservation of the momentum-energy tensor. This relation corresponds to the interference conservation of electromagnetic waves. We show that for any transformation or symmetry that leaves Maxwell's equations invariant, we can modify the reciprocity relation to introduce a conserving density, optical flux and stress tensor extending Noether's theorem to a different context. We apply this method to transformations that can be expressed as Hermitian operators and more specifically we define the operators associated with the optical energy, spin, linear and angular momentum.

In the intricate world of chemistry, the element phosphorus plays a crucial role. Found abundantly in nature, it is a key component in ATP, the energy currency of life. Phosphorus, with its symbol P, belongs to the p-block of elements and has an electronic configuration of [Ne] 3s² 3p³. Its atomic mass is approximately 30.973762 amu. Phosphorus is unique for its allotropic forms, including white phosphorus, red phosphorus, and black phosphorus. Each form differs in structure and properties, yet all are vital in various chemical reactions and technological applications, from flame retardants to semiconductors in technology. The versatile nature of phosphorus underscores its indispensable role in chemistry, biology, and technology.

The rock mechanical design of gas storage cavern in salt requires the analysis of the stability and the usability of the cavern over the planned operating time period. The design includes the build up of a rock mass model and a numerical model taking into account the geological situation, load condition, geometrical condition, and material parameters. In this paper multiple caverns in salt formation with geological and geomechanical situation in Qom (central part of Iran) was investigated a using creep model. Minimum safe center to center distances (CTCD) of multiple horizontal caverns also were studied. CTCD of caverns interact at less than two times of cavern diameter. With increasing the CTCD to 2.5 times cavern diameters, diminish most interaction.

In the realm of molecular biology, a pivotal role is played by enzymes, protein catalysts that accelerate chemical reactions within organisms. These biocatalysts exhibit remarkable specificity, interacting only with particular substrates, and are essential for life's efficient operation. Enzymes function by lowering the activation energy required for a reaction to occur, thereby increasing the rate at which it proceeds. This catalytic prowess enables the intricate dance of biochemical reactions that sustains life, from metabolism to DNA replication, all under the delicate balance of conditions maintained within cells. The study of enzymes, their structure, function, and regulation, continues to be a vibrant field in modern chemistry, with potential applications in medicine, industry, and beyond.

We present a beam steering system based on micro-electromechanical systems technology that features high speed steering of multiple laser beams over a broad wavelength range. By utilizing high speed micromirrors with a broadband metallic coating, our system has the flexibility to simultaneously incorporate a wide range of wavelengths and multiple beams. We demonstrate reconfiguration of two independent beams at different wavelengths (780 and 635 nm) across a common 5x5 array with 4 us settling time. Full simulation of the optical system provides insights on the scalability of the system. Such a system can provide a versatile tool for applications where fast laser multiplexing is necessary.

In the realm of chemical bonding, the intriguing world of covalent bonds unfolds. These bonds, formed when sharing electrons, are fundamental in the structure of molecules. For instance, the oxygen molecule (O2) consists of two oxygen atoms, each with six electrons in their outer shell, seeking stability. They share these electrons, forming a stable double covalent bond and creating O2, a vital component in our atmosphere. Similarly, the hydrogen molecule (H2) is composed of two hydrogen atoms, each with one electron in their outer shell. They pair up, sharing electrons to form a single covalent bond, essential in various chemical reactions and the formation of water (H2O). Covalent bonds, thus, play a crucial role in the dance of atoms, shaping the fabric of our chemical universe.

In particle-based algorithms, the effect of binary collisions is commonly described in a statistical way, using Monte Carlo techniques. It is shown that, in the relativistic regime, stringent constraints should be considered on the sampling of particle pairs for collision, which are critical to ensure physically meaningful results, and that nonrelativistic sampling criteria (e.g., uniform random pairing) yield qualitatively wrong results, including equilibrium distributions that differ from the theoretical J\"uttner distribution. A general procedure for relativistically consistent algorithms is provided, and verified with three-dimensional Monte Carlo simulations, thus opening the way to the numerical exploration of the statistical properties of collisional relativistic systems.

Nestled within the intricate dance of atoms, chemistry unravels the secrets of the universe.
