Its unique chemical structure, featuring a broken O-O bond, allows it to generate oxygen when decomposed, making it an essential compound in various industrial and everyday uses. Moreover, hydrogen peroxide's oxidizing properties make it a powerful tool in chemical reactions, contributing to its widespread use in oxidation processes. This humble compound, though simple in structure, demonstrates the wonders of chemistry in everyday life.

We present a method, based on a non-Markovian Langevin equation, to include quantum corrections to the classical dynamics of ions in a quasi-harmonic system. By properly fitting the correlation function of the noise, one can vary the fluctuations in positions and momenta as a function of the vibrational frequency, and fit them so as to reproduce the quantum-mechanical behavior, with minimal a priori knowledge of the details of the system. We discuss the application of the thermostat to diamond and to ice Ih. We find that results in agreement with path-integral molecular dynamics can be obtained using only a fraction of the computational effort.

In the intricate realm of chemistry, the element carbon, with its versatile valence of four, forms the basis of a myriad of compounds. From diamond's hard, transparent brilliance to graphite's soft, slippery nature, carbon's allotropes showcase its adaptability. Organic chemistry unfolds the complexities of carbon-based life, where carbon bonds with hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, and other elements, creating an array of intricate structures essential to life. The chemical bond, a fundamental concept, connects atoms, determining the properties and behaviors of substances. Whether it's the intense heat of a flame, the sweetness of a ripe fruit, or the strength of a steel beam, chemistry is the silent orchestrator behind these phenomena.

The issue of the thermodynamics of a system of distinguishable particles is discussed in this paper. In constructing the statistical mechanics of distinguishable particles from the definition of Boltzmann entropy, it is found that the entropy is not extensive. The inextensivity leads to the so-called Gibbs paradox in which the mixing entropy of two identical classical gases increases. Lots of literature from different points of view were created to resolve the paradox. In this paper, starting from the Boltzmann entropy, we present the thermodynamics of the system of distinguishable particles. A straightforward way to get the corrected Boltzmann counting is shown. The corrected Boltzmann counting factor can be justified in classical statistical mechanics.

Embarking on a vibrant journey through the realm of chemistry, we encounter the fascinating world of polymers. These complex compounds, built from repeating monomer units, exhibit a vast array of properties. From the flexibility of rubber to the strength of Kevlar, polymers permeate our lives, shaping everything from tires to protective clothing. In the realm of biochemistry, proteins, the building blocks of life, are essentially long polymers, each with its unique sequence and function. This intricate dance of molecular interactions is the essence of polymer chemistry, a field that continues to push the boundaries of human ingenuity, offering limitless potential for innovation.

Experiments by several groups during the past decade have shown that a molten polymer nanofilm subject to a large transverse thermal gradient undergoes spontaneous formation of periodic nanopillar arrays. The prevailing explanation is that coherent reflections of acoustic phonons within the film cause a periodic modulation of the radiation pressure which enhances pillar growth. By exploring a deformational instability of particular relevance to nanofilms, we demonstrate that thermocapillary forces play a crucial role in the formation process. Analytic and numerical predictions show good agreement with the pillar spacings obtained in experiment. Simulations of the interface equation further determine the rate of pillar growth of importance to technological applications.

In the realm of organic chemistry, the intricate dance of carbon atoms weaves a diverse tapestry of compounds. One such compound, cellulose, is the primary component of plant matter, providing the structural basis for the myriad forms of flora. Cellulose molecules, comprised of long chains of glucose units, are intertwined in a rigid, crystalline network, granting plants their strength and rigidity. This biopolymer, when broken down through processes like fermentation, can be harnessed as a renewable energy source, potentially revolutionizing our dependence on fossil fuels. The versatility of cellulose, from its role in photosynthesis to its potential as a sustainable resource, underscores the profound impact of organic chemistry on our world.

J. E. Hirsch (2005) introduced the h-index to quantify an individual's scientific research output by the largest number h of a scientist's papers, that received at least h citations. This so-called Hirsch index can be easily modified to take multiple co-authorship into account by counting the papers fractionally according to (the inverse of) the number of authors. I have worked out 26 empirical cases of physicists to illustrate the effect of this modification. Although the correlation between the original and the modified Hirsch index is relatively strong, the arrangement of the datasets is significantly different depending on whether they are put into order according to the values of either the original or the modified index.

In the realm of chemical reactions, catalysts serve as a cornerstone, expediting the rate at which a reaction occurs without altering the overall equilibrium. By reducing the activation energy, catalysts enable reactions to take place at lower temperatures and under milder conditions. Their intrinsic property of boosting efficiency makes them indispensable in numerous industrial processes, such as the production of fertilizers, plastics, and pharmaceuticals. Moreover, catalysts are pivotal in environmental protection, facilitating the breakdown of pollutants and waste materials, thereby promoting sustainability. The study and development of novel catalysts continue to be a focal point in chemical research, with potential to revolutionize various sectors and address the challenges of a rapidly evolving world.

A method and facilities for delivering payload and people into outer space are presented. This method uses, in general, engines located on a planetary surface. The installation consists of a space apparatus, power drive stations, which include a flywheel accumulator (for storage) of energy, a variable reducer, a powerful homopolar electric generator and electric rails. The drive stations accelerate the apparatus up to hypersonic speed.   The estimations and computations show the possibility of making this project a reality in a short period of time (for payloads which can tolerate high g-forces). The launch will be very cheap at a projected cost of 3 - 5 dollars per pound. The authors developed a theory of this type of the launcher.

In the realm of molecules, chemistry unveils the intriguing dance of atoms. A hydrogen atom, light as a feather, pairs with a heavyweight oxygen, forming water (H2O). This union, as simple as it seems, is the essence of life. Similarly, carbon, with its versatile four electrons, bonds with hydrogen in varying ratios to create hydrocarbons, the building blocks of oil, gas, and plastics. Each bond, a testament to the fundamental forces that govern the universe, holds the potential to transform our world. From the mighty reaction that powers a car's engine to the minute process that allows our bodies to function, chemistry weaves the tapestry of life, binding us all together.

We show that using the properties of the photon Green's function one can successfully describe the propagation of arbitrary nonclassical optical radiation through structured materials. In contrast to the similar input-output approach, our method is not restricted neither to the spatial homogeneous matter nor to the specific direction of light beam incidence or outcoupling. Several quantum states of light are addressed in detail, such as Fock, Glauber, and different squeezed light states, and their Green functions are given. Furthermore, it is demonstrated how scattering of light at a slab can be described with Poynting's energy flow vector, and how experimental setups can be modeled.

Nestled within the intricate dance of atoms and molecules, alkali metals stand out as the soda fountain of the periodic table. Their singular electron in the outermost shell yearns for stability, making them readily donate this electron to other compounds. Sodium, one such alkali metal, is a prime example. Found abundantly in nature, sodium is crucial for maintaining the body's electrolyte balance and is integral to many industrial processes, from manufacturing glass to the production of chemicals. Lithium, another alkali metal, is renowned for its role in powering the modern world, serving as the anode in rechargeable batteries that fuel our smartphones and electric vehicles. The alkali metals' unique properties make them indispensable in our daily lives, their chemistry a testament to the remarkable power that lies within the simplest of elements.

Supersonic beams of polar molecules are deflected using inhomogeneous electric fields. The quantum-state selectivity of the deflection is used to spatially separate molecules according to their quantum state. A detailed analysis of the deflection and the obtained quantum-state selection is presented. The rotational temperatures of the molecular beams are determined from the spatial beam profiles and are all approximately 1 K. Unprecedented degrees of laser-induced alignment $(<\cos^2\theta_{2D}>=0.972)$ and orientation of iodobenzene molecules are demonstrated when the state-selected samples are used. Such state-selected and oriented molecules provide unique possibilities for many novel experiments in chemistry and physics.

Amidst the intricate dance of elements, the realm of chemistry unfolds. Here, hydrogen and oxygen, the simplest of all elements, unite to form water, H2O, the life-sustaining elixir. Carbon, the building block of life, forges complex bonds with itself and other elements to create an array of organic compounds, the backbone of biomolecules. Silicon and oxygen, intertwining in a rhythm of their own, form the structure of sand, the ubiquitous mineral pillar of Earth's landscapes. In the lab or in nature, chemistry weaves the fabric of our universe, shaping the world around us.

Any future high energy e+e- linear collider aims at precision measurements of Standard Model quantities as well as of new, not yet discovered phenomena. In order to pursue this physics programme, excellent detectors at the interaction region have to be complemented by beam diagnostics of unprecedented precision. This article gives an overview of current plans and issues for polarimeters and energy spectrometers at the International Linear Collider, which have been designed to fulfill the precision goals at a large range of beam energies from 45.6 GeV at the Z pole up to 250 GeV or, as an upgrade, up to 500 GeV.

In the realm of chemical compounds, water (H2O) stands as a remarkable example of a polar molecule. Its unique structure, characterized by two hydrogen atoms bonded to one oxygen atom, bears a dipole moment due to the unequal sharing of electrons. This polar nature enables water to form hydrogen bonds, a key factor in its high boiling point compared to other compounds with similar molecular weight. Moreover, water's polarity facilitates its role as a universal solvent, dissolving a wide array of substances, thus fostering numerous chemical reactions in living organisms and various industrial processes.

A hidden symmetry of the nonlinear wave equation is exploited to analyse the propagation of paraxial and uniform atom-laser beams in time-independent, quadratic and cylindrical potentials varying smoothly along the propagation axis. The quality factor and the paraxial ABCD formalism are generalized to account exactly for mean-field interaction effects in such beams. Using an approach based on moments, these theoretical tools provide a very simple and yet exact picture of the interacting beam profile evolution. Guided atom laser experiments are discussed. This treatment addresses simultaneously optical and atomic beams in a unified manner, exploiting the formal analogy between nonlinear optics and nonlinear paraxial atom optics.

Delving into the captivating realm of chemistry, we find ourselves enamored by the allure of catalysts, the silent heroes of chemical reactions. These unassuming substances accelerate reactions without being consumed, enabling processes that would otherwise be sluggish or impossible. Gold and platinum catalysts, for instance, speed up the production of polyethylene, the plastic wrapping our groceries. Meanwhile, zeolites, a class of crystalline minerals, act as catalysts in the refining of gasoline, ensuring a cleaner and more efficient fuel. These catalysts, though often overlooked, play a pivotal role in shaping our modern world, making possible the conveniences we take for granted.

The Gaussian formula and spherical aberrations of the static and relativistic curved mirrors are analyzed using the optical path length (OPL) and Fermat's principle. The geometrical figures generated by the rotation of conic sections about their symmetry axes are considered for the shapes of the mirrors. By comparing the results in static and relativistic cases, it is shown that the focal lengths and the spherical aberration relations of the relativistic mirrors obey the Lorentz contraction. Further analysis of the spherical aberrations for both static and relativistic cases have resulted in the information about the limits for the paraxial approximation, as well as for the minimum speed of the systems to reduce the spherical aberrations.

In the realm of chemical bonding, the intriguing phenomenon of covalent bonds emerges. Unlike ionic bonds, where electrons are transferred from one atom to another, covalent bonds are formed when two atoms share electrons, creating a stable electron configuration. This sharing can occur in various ways, such as single, double, or triple bonds depending on the number of electron pairs shared between atoms. The strength of these bonds is influenced by factors like the electronegativity of the atoms involved and the number of bonds formed between them. These covalent unions play a pivotal role in shaping the properties and structures of various molecules, from the DNA's intricate twists to the complex carbon compounds that form the backbone of life.

In this paper we present a mathematical analysis for a steady-state laminar boundary layer flow, governed by the Ostwald-de Wael power-law model of an incompressible non- Newtonian fluid past a semi-infinite power-law stretched flat plate with uniform free stream velocity. A generalization of the usual Blasius similarity transformation is used to find similarity solutions [1]. Under appropriate assumptions, partial differential equations are transformed into an autonomous third-order nonlinear degenerate ordinary differential equation with boundary conditions. Using a shooting method, we establish the existence of an infinite number of global unbounded solutions. The asymptotic behavior is also discussed. Some properties of those solutions depend on the viscosity power-law index.

In the realm of chemical reactions, the concept of equilibrium is pivotal. At this delicate balance, reactants and products coexist, neither entirely consumed nor produced. The rate of forward reaction equals the rate of reverse reaction, a dynamic dance of molecular transformation. This equilibrium is influenced by factors such as temperature and concentration, with changes in these conditions tilting the balance towards more products or reactants. This dance of chemical equilibrium, while seemingly constant, is in fact a dynamic interplay, a testament to the ongoing dance of nature.

We simulate the impact of a viscous liquid drop onto a smooth dry solid surface. As in experiments, when ambient air effects are negligible, impact flattens the falling drop without producing a splash. The no-slip boundary condition at the wall produces a boundary layer inside the liquid. Later, the flattening surface of the drop traces out the boundary layer. As a result, the eventual shape of the drop is a "pancake" of uniform thickness except at the rim, where surface tension effects are significant. The thickness of the pancake is simply the height where the drop surface first collides with the boundary layer.

In the realm of molecular biology, DNA's dual helical structure, a testament to the intricate dance of hydrogen bonds, plays a pivotal role in encoding the blueprint of life. This double helix, a product of Adenine-Thymine and Guanine-Cytosine pairings, embodies the essence of complementarity, ensuring the fidelity of genetic information transmission from one generation to the next. The process of replication, initiated by enzymes like DNA polymerase, unwinds this helix, creating a temporary single strand. Complementary nucleotides, guided by hydrogen bonds, then link together, reforming the double helix, thus completing the cycle of life's replication. This enduring dance of bonds, a testament to the power of chemistry, has been the cornerstone of biological evolution, shaping the diversity of life on Earth.

Wavelength scaling law for the yield of high-order harmonic emission is theoretically examined for excited state atoms which are optically prepared by simultaneously exposing to an extreme ultraviolet pulse at the resonant wavelength and an infrared pulse at a variable wavelength in the range of 0.8\mum-2.4\mum. Numerical simulations are performed based on the three-dimensional time-dependent Schrodinger equation (3D TDSE) for Ne and H. We confirm that the harmonic yield follows a \lambda^-{4-6} scaling with the single fundamental driving laser pulse. whereas for the optically prepared excited state atoms, a \lambda^-{2-3} scaling for the harmonic yield is revealed.

In the intricate realm of organic chemistry, a compound named caffeine, derived from coffee beans, is an intriguing subject. It's a complex organic molecule, characterized by its bitter taste and stimulant properties. Caffeine works by blocking adenosine receptors in the brain, hence delaying drowsiness. This energetic compound is not only found in coffee but also in tea, cocoa, and cola nuts. Its synthesis involves a series of chemical reactions, including deamination, methylation, and cyclization, culminating in the formation of this ubiquitous stimulant. The chemistry of caffeine continues to fascinate scientists, with ongoing research exploring its potential health benefits, as well as the development of new caffeine-based pharmaceuticals.

The problem concerning the form of the electrostatic field potential of the infinite charged metallic plane contacting with the metallic sphere is solved. The distributions of the surface charge densities both on the plane and the sphere and also the force acting on the sphere that causing to tear away from the plane are found. The expressions found for the charge of the sphere and the force of tear from the plane permits estimate the frequency of the shuttle motion of the nanoparticles and the charge transfer between metallic electrodes and also use them for the measurement of their sizes and to make use of their separation in progress.

In the captivating realm of chemistry, the element nickel stands out, boasting a silvery-white luster and a place in Group 10 of the periodic table. It's a transition metal, meaning it can lose electrons, making it crucial in catalysis - speeding up chemical reactions that underpin industrial processes. In everyday life, nickel is found in coins, magnets, and stainless steel, contributing to their strength and resistance to corrosion. In the medical field, nickel compounds are used in certain alloys for prosthetic devices. This versatile element, with its unique properties, continues to play a significant role in modern technology and industry, adding a touch of metallic brilliance to our everyday world.

An optically-dense ionization wave (IW) produced by two femtosecond laser pulses focused cylindrically and crossing each other is shown to be an efficient coherent x-ray converter. The resulting velocity of a quasi-plane IW in the vicinity of pulse intersection increases with the angle between the pulses from the group velocity of ionizing pulses to infinity allowing an easy tuning the wavelength of x-rays. The x-ray spectra of a converted, lower frequency coherent light change from the monochromatic to a high order harmonic-like with the duration of ionizing pulses and the intensity of scattered pulses. the spectrum are not symmetrical at V<c and V>c.

In the intricate world of chemistry, alkanes, a class of hydrocarbons, stand out for their simplicity and ubiquity. Consisting solely of carbon and hydrogen atoms, they form the backbone of many organic compounds. Each alkane molecule is characterized by a straight or branched chain of carbon atoms, bound together by strong covalent bonds, with hydrogen atoms attached to each carbon. The number of carbon atoms in an alkane determines its name - methane (1), ethane (2), propane (3), and so forth. Alkanes are notable for their stability, thanks to the lack of reactive double or triple bonds. This stability makes them an essential component in various industries, from fuels like natural gas and gasoline to plastics and lubricants.

We use the three-cornered-hat method to evaluate the absolute frequency stabilities of three different ultrastable reference cavities, one of which has a vibration-insensitive design that does not even require vibration isolation. An Nd:YAG laser and a diode laser are implemented as light sources. We observe $\sim1$ Hz beat note linewidths between all three cavities. The measurement demonstrates that the vibration-insensitive cavity has a good frequency stability over the entire measurement time from 100 $\mu$s to 200 s. An absolute, correlation-removed Allan deviation of $1.4\times10^{-15}$ at 1 s of this cavity is obtained, giving a frequency uncertainty of only 0.44 Hz.

In the captivating world of chemistry, the intriguing compound known as silicon dioxide, or silica, holds a prominent position. Found abundantly in nature as sand and quartz, this compound is essential to life, serving as the primary component in the Earth's crust. Silica's unique molecular structure, consisting of silicon atoms sandwiched between two oxygen atoms, lends it exceptional properties, such as high melting points and resistance to acid. Its versatility is showcased in various applications, from strengthening glass and ceramics to aiding in the production of semiconductors, thereby fueling technological advancements. This humble compound, therefore, plays a vital role in shaping the modern world.

InGaAsP/InP quantum wells (QW) ridge waveguide lasers were fabricated for the evaluation of Ga+ Focused Ion Beam (FIB) milling of mirrors. Electrical and optical proprieties were investigated. A 7% increment in threshold current, a 17% reduction in external quantum efficiency and 15 nm blue shift in the emission spectrum were observed after milling as compared to the as cleaved facet result. Annealing in inert atmosphere partially revert these effects resulting in 4% increment in threshold current, 11% reduction in external efficiency and 13 nm blue shift with the as cleaved result. The current-voltage behavior after milling and annealing shows a very small increase in leakage current indicating that optical damage is the main effect of the milling process.

Nested within the intricate realm of molecular structures, the study of polymers unveils a captivating world of synthetic materials. Polymers, with their long chain-like molecules, offer an extraordinary range of properties, from the elasticity of rubber to the hardness of plastics. These versatile substances are crafted through a process called polymerization, where small monomer units bond together, ultimately resulting in a colossal macromolecule. The properties of a polymer are heavily influenced by factors such as the type of monomer, the degree of polymerization, and the presence of additives. With an ever-growing understanding of polymer science, the applications of these remarkable materials continue to expand, shaping an increasingly modern world.

We study high-density traffic of information packets on sparse modular networks with scale-free subgraphs. With different statistical measures we distinguish between the free flow and congested regime and point out the role of modules in the jamming transition. We further consider correlations between traffic signals collected at each node in the network. The correlation matrix between pairs of signals reflects the network modularity in the eigenvalue spectrum and the structure of eigenvectors. The internal structure of the modules has an important role in the diffusion dynamics, leading to enhanced correlations between the modular hubs, which can not be filtered out by standard methods. Implications for the analysis of real networks with unknown modular structure are discussed.

Nestled within the vibrant realm of chemistry, the intriguing world of catalysts unfolds. These magical substances, often met with wonder, accelerate chemical reactions without being consumed themselves. They function as mediators, lowering the activation energy of a reaction, thus hastening the transformation from reactants to products. Catalysts, like the patient alchemists of old, subtly guide the dance of atoms, influencing the course of countless industrial processes and everyday phenomena, from combustion to corrosion, and even to the breakdown of pollutants in our environment. Their influence permeates our lives, imbuing the ordinary with the extraordinary, reminding us that the smallest entities can yield the most profound impacts.

The ability to artificially grow in a controllable manner at nanoscale, from modern deposition techniques, complex structural configurations made with metallic, polar and semiconductors materials raises today the issue of the "best" achievable inner structure to tailor the near-field properties of a nanostructured medium. In the present work we make a step towards the rational design of these materials by reporting numerical experimentations demonstrating the possibility of identifying structural configurations of layered metallodielectric media specifically designed to control the electromagnetic density of states in the close vicinity of their surface. These results could find broad applications in near-field technologies.

In the realm of chemical science, the study of catalysts reveals intriguing insights. These magical substances, often overlooked in everyday life, accelerate reactions that would otherwise occur too slowly. They do so by lowering the activation energy, enabling chemical transformations to happen swiftly. Catalysts are essential in various industrial processes, such as the production of fertilizers, plastics, and pharmaceuticals. Moreover, they play a crucial role in environmental protection, for instance, in the breakdown of pollutants. The development of new, efficient catalysts continues to be a significant focus in modern chemistry, with potential applications in renewable energy and sustainability.

We present a theoretical study on the energy loss by protons in solid copper. The ab initio shellwise local plasma approximation (SLPA) is employed for the inner-shells, and the Mermin dielectric function for the valence electrons. The partial contribution of each sub-shell of target electrons is calculated separately, including the screening among the electrons of the same binding energy. Present results are obtained using the SLPA and the known Hartree-Fock wave functions for copper. The theoretical curves are compared with the experimental data available and with the semi-empirical srim08 values, showing very good agreement in a large energy region (5 keV-30 MeV).

In the realm of molecular chemistry, the concept of covalent bonds is pivotal. These bonds, formed by the sharing of electrons between atoms, bind elements together and define the structure of compounds. For instance, in a water molecule (H2O), two hydrogen atoms share electrons with one oxygen atom, establishing two covalent bonds. This intricate dance of shared electrons forms the backbone of chemistry, enabling the creation of a vast array of substances, from simple gases to complex biomolecules, each with its unique properties. The understanding of covalent bonds has unlocked numerous scientific breakthroughs, revolutionizing our world in unimaginable ways.

Cremer-Pople puckering coordinates appear to be the natural candidate variables to explore the conformational space of cyclic compounds, and in literature different parametrizations have been used to this end. However, while every parametrization is equivalent in identifying conformations, it is not obvious that they can also act as proper collective variables for the exploration of the puckered conformations free energy surface. It is shown that only the polar parametrization is fit to produce an unbiased estimate of the free energy landscape. As an example, the case of a six-membered ring, glucuronic acid, is presented, showing the artefacts that are generated when a wrong parametrization is used.

In the realm of chemical reactions, the synthesis of carbon nanotubes holds immense promise. These minute tubes, composed solely of carbon atoms, exhibit exceptional strength and unique electrical properties. The manufacturing process involves vaporizing carbon in a controlled environment, where it reassembles into nanotube structures. These nanotubes can be single-walled or multi-walled, and their dimensions, determined by the reaction conditions, range from nanometers to micrometers. The properties of carbon nanotubes render them invaluable in various fields, including electronics, energy storage, and biomedicine, heralding a new era of nanotechnology.

Liquids in contact with solids are submitted to intermolecular forces making liquids heterogeneous and, in a mechanical model, the stress tensor is not any more spherical as in homogeneous bulks. The aim of this article is to show that a square-gradient functional taking into account the volume liquid free energy corrected with two surface liquid density functionals is a mean field approximation allowing to study structures of very thin liquid nanofilms near plane solid walls. The model determines analytically the concept of disjoining pressure for liquid films of thicknesses of a very few number of nanometers and yields a behavior in good agreement with the shapes of experimental curves carried out by Derjaguin and his successors.

In the intricate realm of chemistry, the element silicon, with atomic number 14, plays a pivotal role. Akin to carbon, it forms an array of compounds, known as silicates, which constitute a significant portion of Earth's crust. Silicon dioxide, or silica, is one such compound, found abundantly in quartz and sand. In the industrial world, silicon is essential, powering the semiconductor industry, transforming our digital devices into miniaturized marvels. Beyond technology, silicon's versatility extends to solar cells, ceramics, and even in the medical field as biocompatible implants. Its unique properties, stemming from its electron configuration, continue to fuel innovation across various disciplines.

We look afresh at the deduction of the "Lorentz contraction" of a "rod" from the Lorentz transformation equations of the special theory of relativity. We show that under special conditions, which include acceleration of the "rod", length "expansion" and "invariance" are possible, and thus these are purely kinematical phenomena. We then take a closer look at Einstein's two famous papers on the special theory of relativity and point out a flaw in his argument. It seems that it is possible to have the times of the clocks of two, and indeed all, inertial systems to agree with each other.

In the intricate realm of molecular biology, a significant player is the enzyme, a protein catalyst that accelerates chemical reactions. Enzymes, like catalase, break down hydrogen peroxide, a potentially harmful substance, into oxygen and water. Conversely, enzymes such as amylase aid in digestion by breaking down complex carbohydrates into simpler sugars. The marvel of enzymes lies in their specificity, as each enzyme targets a specific substrate, ensuring the delicate balance of reactions within our cells. This biochemical precision is crucial for life as we know it, from the breakdown of food to the regulation of genetic information.

In this work we show that in a microfluidic network and in low Reynolds numbers a system can be irreversible because of hysteresis effects.The network, which is employed in our simulations, is taken from recent experiments. The network consists of one loop connected to input and output pipes. A train of droplets enter the system at a uniform rate, but they may leave it in different patterns, e.g. periodic or even chaotic. The out put pattern depends on the time interval among the incoming droplets as well as the network geometry and for some parameters the system is not reversible.

Nested within the intricate tapestry of the periodic table, the element silicon (Si) stands out for its versatility and ubiquity. An abundant semiconductor, silicon forms the backbone of modern electronics, from solar panels to microchips. Its unique properties, such as a stable crystalline structure and a bandgap that allows for controlled electrical conductivity, make it an invaluable component in the digital age. Moreover, silicon's role extends beyond technology, as it is also integral to biology, found in various forms in sand, quartz, and even DNA. As humanity continues to innovate, the potential applications of silicon are expected to expand, further cementing its status as a cornerstone of the future.

Human motor activities are known to exhibit scale-free long-term correlated fluctuations over a wide range of timescales, from few to thousands of seconds. The fundamental processes originating such fractal-like behavior are not yet understood. To untangle the most significant features of these fluctuations, in this work the problem is oversimplified by studying a much simpler system: the spontaneous motion of rodents, recorded during several days. The analysis of the animal motion reveals a robust scaling comparable with the results previously reported in humans. It is shown that the most relevant features of the experimental results can be replicated by the statistics of the activation-threshold model proposed in another context by Davidsen and Schuster.

In the realm of chemical bonding, the force that links atoms together, the concept of a covalent bond stands out. This is a type of chemical bond that shares electrons between atoms. For instance, the hydrogen molecule (H2) forms a covalent bond between two hydrogen atoms, sharing one electron each. The sharing of electrons forms a stable molecule, as the electrons are attracted to the nuclei of both atoms. This shared electron pair creates a region of high electron density between the nuclei, known as a covalent bond. In contrast to ionic bonds, covalent bonds do not involve the complete transfer of electrons, making them essential in many organic compounds, including those that form the basis of life.

Motivated by the observed coordination of nearby beating cilia, we use a scale model experiment to show that hydrodynamic interactions can cause synchronization between rotating paddles driven at constant torque in a very viscous fluid. Synchronization is only observed when the shafts supporting the paddles have some flexibility. The phase difference in the synchronized state depends on the symmetry of the paddles. We use the method of regularized stokeslets to model the paddles and find excellent agreement with the experimental observations. We also use a simple analytic theory based on far-field approximations to derive scaling laws for the synchronization time as a function of paddle separation.

In the captivating world of organic chemistry, the synthesis of complex molecules is a mesmerizing dance between carbon atoms and various reagents. This intricate ballet unfolds as chemists skillfully manipulate double bonds, functional groups, and chiral centers, crafting a myriad of compounds with diverse properties. The process, often akin to an artist's brush strokes, is guided by the principles of stereochemistry, reaction kinetics, and thermodynamics. Each compound, a unique masterpiece, holds potential for pharmaceuticals, materials science, or even molecular biology, underscoring the profound impact of organic chemistry on modern life.

A computer-aided detection (CAD) system for the identification of lung internal nodules in low-dose multi-detector helical Computed Tomography (CT) images was developed in the framework of the MAGIC-5 project. The three modules of our lung CAD system, a segmentation algorithm for lung internal region identification, a multi-scale dot-enhancement filter for nodule candidate selection and a multi-scale neural technique for false positive finding reduction, are described. The results obtained on a dataset of low-dose and thin-slice CT scans are shown in terms of free response receiver operating characteristic (FROC) curves and discussed.

Harnessing the power of molecular dynamics, chemists are revolutionizing the pharmaceutical industry. By simulating the behavior of individual molecules and their interactions, they can predict drug efficacy and potential side effects. This computational approach accelerates the drug discovery process, reducing costs and time spent on laboratory experiments. Moreover, it offers a sustainable solution, minimizing the need for animal testing and laboratory waste. The future of medicinal chemistry lies in the convergence of computational science and experimental chemistry, promising a brighter, more efficient, and compassionate world for all.

We have quantified collisional losses, decoherence and the collision shift in a one-dimensional optical lattice clock with bosonic 88Sr. The lattice clock is referenced to the highly forbidden transition 1S0 - 3P0 at 698 nm, which becomes weakly allowed due to state mixing in a homogeneous magnetic field. We were able to quantify three decoherence coefficients, which are due to dephasing collisions, inelastic collisions between atoms in the upper and lower clock state, and atoms in the upper clock state only. Based on the measured coefficients, we determine the operation parameters at which a 1D-lattice clock with 88Sr shows no degradation due to collisions on the relative accuracy level of 10-16.

Nestled within the intricate dance of atomic bonds, chemistry unravels the secrets of our world. It's the silent architect, sculpting everything from the mighty mountain ranges to the minuscule molecules that swarm within a single drop of water. Each element, a unique player in this grand symphony, interacts with others, forming complex structures and compounds essential for life. The study of chemistry, then, is a voyage into the fundamental building blocks that make up our existence, shedding light on the infinite possibilities that lie in the union of atoms. Whether harnessed for energy, medicine, or technology, chemistry's influence permeates every corner of our lives, revealing the magic hidden within the seemingly ordinary.

We demonstrate the long-distance transmission of an ultra-stable optical frequency derived directly from a state-of-the-art optical frequency standard. Using an active stabilization system we deliver the frequency via a 146 km long underground fiber link with a fractional instability of 3*10^{-15} at 1 s, which is close to the theoretical limit for our transfer experiment. The relative uncertainty for the transfer is below 1*10^{-19} after 30 000 seconds. Tests with a very short fiber show that noise in our stabilization system contributes fluctuations which are two orders of magnitude lower, namely 3*10^{-17} at 1 s, reaching 10^{-20} after 4000 s.

In the captivating realm of chemistry, the elemental dance of carbon and hydrogen unfolds a myriad of marvels. From the humble hydrocarbons, an array of organic compounds emerges, each with its unique properties and roles. Take, for instance, sugars, essential components of life, crafted from carbon, hydrogen, and oxygen in intricate patterns. They serve as the backbone of DNA, the molecular blueprint of life, and fuel for our energetic pursuits. Elsewhere, proteins, complex polymers fashioned from amino acids, dance in our cells, acting as enzymes, structural components, and signaling agents. Even the air we breathe, oxygen, a byproduct of photosynthesis, is a testament to the chemistry of life, synthesized by plants from sunlight, carbon dioxide, and water. The chemistry of life, in its myriad forms, continues to intrigue and inspire, offering endless opportunities for exploration and discovery.

The structure of the basin of attraction of a stable equilibrium point is investigated for a dynamical system (W97) often used to model transition to turbulence in shear flows. The basin boundary contains not only an equilibrium point Xlb but also a periodic orbit P, and it is the latter that mediates the transition. Orbits starting near Xlb relaminarize. We offer evidence that this is due to the extreme narrowness of the region complementary to basin of attraction in that part of phase space near Xlb. This leads to a proposal for interpreting the 'edge of chaos' in terms of more familiar invariant sets.

In the realm of chemical compounds, water (H2O) stands out as a unique and essential substance. Unlike most substances, it exhibits a rare duality, existing as a liquid at room temperature and pressure. Its molecules bond in a V-shape, with each hydrogen atom sharing an electron with a single oxygen atom. This hydrogen bonding accounts for water's high surface tension and boiling point, as well as its ability to dissolve a wide variety of substances, a trait crucial for life on Earth. Moreover, water's unique properties, such as its high specific heat and heat capacity, regulate Earth's climate by moderating temperature fluctuations. Thus, water, a seemingly ordinary compound, plays a pivotal role in the intricate dance of chemical interactions that sustain life and shape our planet.

In the context of the search for gasoline surrogates for kinetic modeling purpose, this paper describes a new model for the low-temperature auto-ignition of n-heptane/iso-octane/hexene/toluene blends for the different linear isomers of hexene. The model simulates satisfactory experimental results obtained in a rapid compression machine for temperatures ranging from 650 to 850 K in the case of binary and ternary mixtures including iso octane, 1-hexene and toluene. Predictive simulations have also been performed for the autoignition of n heptane/iso octane/hexene/toluene quaternary mixtures: the predicted reactivity is close to that of pure iso octane with a retarding effect when going from 1- to 3-alkene.

In the realm of atomic chemistry, the concept of electron configuration unfolds a fascinating tale. Electrons, these minuscule particles, dance around the nucleus in distinct energy levels, or orbitals, labeled as s, p, d, and f. The order of occupancy is systematic: s before p, p before d, and so on. Each orbital can accommodate a maximum of two electrons, and they fill up one by one, following Pauli's Exclusion Principle and Hund's Rule. This ballet of electrons forms the electronic structure of an atom, shaping its chemical behavior, reactivity, and interactions with other atoms. Understanding electron configuration is like unlocking the secret language that atoms use to communicate in the universe.

Many real-world complex networks contain a significant amount of structural redundancy, in which multiple vertices play identical topological roles. Such redundancy arises naturally from the simple growth processes which form and shape many real-world systems. Since structurally redundant elements may be permuted without altering network structure, redundancy may be formally investigated by examining network automorphism (symmetry) groups. Here, we use a group-theoretic approach to give a complete description of spectral signatures of redundancy in undirected networks. In particular, we describe how a network's automorphism group may be used to directly associate specific eigenvalues and eigenvectors with specific network motifs.

In the realm of chemical synthesis, a fascinating process unfolds: the creation of polymers. These complex molecules, composed of repeating subunits, are ubiquitous in our daily lives, from plastics and rubbers to fibers and resins. Polymers are born from the linking of monomers, simple molecules that, through a process known as polymerization, form long chains. The nature of these chains—their length, branching, and sequence—is dictated by various factors, including temperature, pressure, and catalysts. The versatility of polymers is truly astounding, reflecting the intricate dance of atoms and molecules that underlies the world of chemistry.

This study focuses on the automatic generation by the software EXGAS of kinetic models for the oxidation of large methyl esters using a single set of kinetic parameters. The obtained models allow to well reproduce the oxidation of n-decane / methyl palmitate mixture in a jet-stirred reactor. This paper also presents the construction and a comparison of models for methyl esters from C7 up to C17 in terms f conversion in a jet-stirred reactor and of ignition delay time in a shock tube. This comparison study showed that methyl esters larger than methyl octanoate behave similarly and have very close reactivities.

In the realm of chemistry, the intriguing world of polymers unfolds. These complex molecules, composed of repeating monomer units, exhibit a diverse range of properties. Polymers are the backbone of modern materials, from the flexible plastics encasing our electronic devices to the robust elastomers in our shoes. Their synthesis, often through polymerization reactions, allows for the creation of materials with tailored properties, revolutionizing industries and shaping our everyday lives. The future of chemistry lies in the continued exploration and innovation of polymers, promising advancements in fields such as biomedicine, renewable energy, and sustainable manufacturing.

Molecular modelling and simulation as well as four equations of state (EOS) are applied to natural gas mixtures regarding Joule-Thomson (JT) inversion. JT inversion curves are determined by molecular simulation for six different natural gas mixtures consisting of methane, nitrogen, carbon dioxide and ethane. These components are also regarded as pure fluids, leading to a total of ten studied systems. The results are compared to four advanced mixture EOS: DDMIX, SUPERTRAPP, BACKONE and the recent GERG-2004 Wide-Range Reference EOS. It is found that molecular simulation is competitive with state-of-the-art EOS in predicting JT inversion curves. The molecular based approaches (simulation and BACKONE) are superior to DDMIX and SUERTRAPP.

In the realm of chemical reactions, the fascinating dance of atomic bonds unfolds. Catalysts, the unassuming yet potent participants, accelerate these reactions, lowering energy barriers and facilitating efficient transformations. They work by providing an alternative pathway for the reaction, making it faster without altering the overall equilibrium. Catalysts are crucial in various industrial processes, such as the conversion of crude oil to gasoline, the production of fertilizers, and the refinement of metals, highlighting their indispensable role in our modern world. Despite their importance, the quest for more efficient and eco-friendly catalysts continues, driven by the need for sustainable and economical solutions in chemistry.

A sampling procedure to compute exactly the rate of activated processes arising in systems at equilibrium or nonequilibrium steady state is presented. The procedure is a generalization of the method in [A. Warmflash, P. Bhimalapuram, and A. R. Dinner, J. Chem. Phys., 127, 154112 (2007). A. Dickson, A. Warmflash, and A. R. Dinner, J. Chem. Phys., 130, 074104 (2009)] in which one performs simulations restricted into cells by using a reinjection rule at the boundaries of the cells which is consistent with the exact probability fluxes through these boundaries. Our generalization uses results from transition path theory which indicate how to twist the dynamics to calculate reaction rates.

Nitrogen, a versatile element in the periodic table, is crucial to life as we know it. It constitutes about 78% of Earth's atmosphere, existing primarily as diatomic N2 molecules. In biology, it's a key component of amino acids, nucleotides, and proteins. In the industrial sector, nitrogen plays a pivotal role in fertilizer production, food preservation, and welding processes. The fixation of atmospheric nitrogen, a complex biological process carried out by certain bacteria, is essential for agriculture, ensuring the growth of crops and, subsequently, sustaining global food supplies. Despite its abundant presence, harnessing nitrogen's potential requires careful management to mitigate environmental impacts, such as eutrophication, caused by excessive nitrogen fertilization. The ongoing quest to optimize nitrogen utilization in agriculture and industry underlines its paramount importance to human progress.

The Open Science Grid (OSG) includes work to enable new science, new scientists, and new modalities in support of computationally based research. There are frequently significant sociological and organizational changes required in transformation from the existing to the new. OSG leverages its deliverables to the large scale physics experiment member communities to benefit new communities at all scales through activities in education, engagement and the distributed facility. As a partner to the poster and tutorial at SciDAC 2008, this paper gives both a brief general description and some specific examples of new science enabled on the OSG. More information is available at the OSG web site: (http://www.opensciencegrid.org).

In the realm of chemical compounds, water (H2O) stands as a versatile and essential substance. It's composed of two hydrogen atoms (H) and one oxygen atom (O), bonded together in a hydrogen-bonded network. This unique structure gives water a high boiling point and a high heat capacity, attributes that regulate Earth's climate. Moreover, water's polar nature enables it to dissolve a wide variety of substances, making it crucial for life's intricate biochemical processes. Furthermore, water's ability to undergo phase transitions, from solid to liquid to gas, offers scientists a wealth of opportunities for studying phase equilibria and thermodynamics. Thus, water, a seemingly unassuming compound, plays a pivotal role in both the natural world and laboratory experiments.

The linear inverse source and scattering problems are studied from the perspective of compressed sensing, in particular the idea that sufficient incoherence and sparsity guarantee uniqueness of the solution. By introducing the sensor as well as target ensembles, the maximum number of recoverable targets is proved to be at least proportional to the number of measurement data modulo a log-square factor with overwhelming probability. Important contributions of the analysis include the discoveries of the threshold aperture, consistent with the classical Rayleigh criterion, and the decoherence effect induced by random antenna locations. The prediction of theorems are confirmed by numerical simulations.

In the intricate world of chemistry, the element carbon stands out, forming the backbone of life. It's not just a component, but a chameleon, adopting diverse forms in its six-fold structural variability. As diamonds, it's the hardest substance known, a symbol of endurance. As graphite, it's soft and slippery, the key to pencils' smoothness. In organic compounds, it creates intricate networks, the essence of life, from sugars to proteins. Carbon's versatility, its ability to bond with itself and other elements, underlies its pivotal role in chemistry and life itself, making it truly the 'King of Elements'.

We numerically demonstrate inhibition of absorption, optical transparency, and anomalous momentum states of phase locked harmonic pulses in semiconductors, at UV and extreme UV frequencies, in spectral regions where the dielectric constant of typical semiconductors is negative. We show that a generated harmonic signal can propagate through a bulk metallic medium without being absorbed as a result of a phase locking mechanism between the pump and its harmonics. These findings may open new regimes in nonlinear optics and are particularly relevant to the emerging fields of nonlinear negative index meta-materials and nano-plasmonics, especially in the ultrafast pulse regime.

Harnessing the power of chemical reactions, scientists meticulously crafted a novel compound, a feat of modern chemistry. With a unique molecular structure, this compound exhibits remarkable properties, such as fluorescence under specific wavelengths of light. The potential applications of this discovery are vast, from enhancing medical imaging to developing efficient energy storage devices. By delving deeper into its intricate behavior, researchers aim to unlock its full potential, paving the way for groundbreaking advancements in various scientific domains. This breakthrough not only reinforces the boundless possibilities within the realm of chemistry but also underscores the importance of continued exploration and innovation for the betterment of society.

We present an application of the Faraday effect to produce a narrow band atomic filter in an alkali metal vapor. In our experiment two Raman beams separated in frequency by the ground state hyperfine splitting in 87Rb are produced using an EOM and then filtered using the Faraday effect in an isotopically pure 85Rb thermal vapor. An experimental transmission spectra for the filter is presented along with a theoretical calculation. The performance of the filter is then demonstrated and characterized using a Fabry-Perot etalon. For a temperature of 70 degrees and a longitudinal magnetic field of 80 G a suppression to -18 dB is achieved, limited by the quality of the polarizers.

Nitrogen, an abundant element in Earth's atmosphere, plays a crucial role in the realm of organic chemistry. It forms the backbone of amino acids, the building blocks of proteins, essential for life. In the industrial world, nitrogen is harnessed for fertilizer production, enhancing agricultural yield. Moreover, nitrogen compounds are instrumental in pharmaceuticals, contributing to life-saving drugs. Nitrogen's versatility extends to polymers, where it forms plastics and fibers, vital for various industries. Additionally, nitrogen gas is used in food preservation, maintaining freshness and prolonging shelf life. Its importance is indeed multifaceted, underscoring the significance of nitrogen in our daily lives.

In practical applications of tomographic imaging, there are often challenges for image reconstruction due to under-sampling and insufficient data. In computed tomography (CT), for example, image reconstruction from few views would enable rapid scanning with a reduced x-ray dose delivered to the patient. Limited-angle problems are also of practical significance in CT. In this work, we develop and investigate an iterative image reconstruction algorithm based on the minimization of the image total variation (TV) that applies to divergent-beam CT. Numerical demonstrations of our TV algorithm are performed with various insufficient data problems in fan-beam CT. The TV algorithm can be generalized to cone-beam CT as well as other tomographic imaging modalities.

In the realm of chemistry, the intriguing world of polymers captivates many. These complex molecules are constructed from repeating units, giving them unique properties that set them apart from simpler compounds. Polymers, such as polyethylene and nylon, are ubiquitous in our daily lives, found in everything from plastic bags to clothing fibers. The versatility of polymers is rooted in their ability to be tailored during synthesis, allowing for the creation of materials with specific physical and chemical characteristics. This adaptability makes them indispensable in a myriad of industries, from packaging to medicine, further underscoring their significant role in modern society.

Beam loading is the phenomenon which limits the charge and the beam quality in plasma based accelerators. An experimental study conducted with a laser-plasma accelerator is presented. Beam loading manifests itself through the decrease of the beam energy, the reduction of dark current and the increase of the energy spread for large beam charge. 3D PIC simulations are compared to the experimental results and confirm the effects of beam loading. It is found that, in our experimental conditions, the trapped electron beams generate decelerating fields on the order of 1 GV/m/pC and that beam loading effects are optimized for trapped charges of about 20 pC.

Titanium Dioxide: A Versatile and Indispensable ChemicalTitanium dioxide (TiO2) stands as a cornerstone in the realm of chemical compounds, its wide-ranging applications spanning diverse industries. This naturally occurring oxide can be found in minerals like rutile and anatase. In the paint industry, it serves as a brilliant white pigment due to its high refractive index and opacity. Its excellent light stability makes it a preferred choice for coating applications and sunscreens.Moreover, in the field of electronics, titanium dioxide is integral to the production of photovoltaic cells and transistors, owing to its semiconducting properties. In the realm of chemistry education, titanium dioxide is a valuable teaching tool, demonstrating redox reactions and acting as a catalyst in various chemical processes. Its versatility and indispensable nature have cemented its place as a key component in numerous modern technologies.

We present a rigorous procedure to derive coarse-grained red blood cell (RBC) models, which lead to accurate mechanical properties of realistic RBCs. Based on a semi-analytic theory linear and non-linear elastic properties of the RBC membrane can be matched with those obtained in optical tweezers stretching experiments. In addition, we develop a nearly stress-free model which avoids a number of pitfalls of existing RBC models, such as non-biconcave equilibrium shape and dependence of RBC mechanical properties on the triangulation quality. The proposed RBC model is suitable for use in many existing numerical methods, such as Lattice Boltzmann, Multiparticle Collision Dynamics, Immersed Boundary, etc.

In the realm of molecular biology, DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) stands as the blueprint of life. This double-helix macromolecule carries genetic instructions essential for an organism's growth, development, and reproduction. Each strand of the DNA helix is composed of a sugar-phosphate backbone, connected by phosphate-deoxyribose bonds, and nitrogenous bases, adenine (A) pairing with thymine (T), and cytosine (C) with guanine (G). The sequence of these bases forms the genetic code, encoding instructions for synthesizing proteins, regulating gene expression, and maintaining cellular functions. DNA's intricate structure and coding mechanism underpin the incredible complexity and diversity of life on Earth.

Following Nye and Berry's analogy with crystal dislocations, an approach to the Burgers vector of a wave dislocation (phase singularity, optical vortex) is proposed. It is defined to be a regularized phase gradient evaluated at the phase singularity, and is computed explicitly. The screw component of this vector is naturally related to the helicoidal twisting of wavefronts along a vortex line, and is related to the helicity of the phase gradient. The edge component is related to the nearby current flow (defined by the phase gradient) perpendicular to the vortex, and the distribution of this component is found numerically for random two-dimensional monochromatic waves.

In the vast realm of chemistry, one fascinating compound captures our attention: water (H2O). This ubiquitous substance, essential for life, is a colorless, odorless liquid at room temperature. Water's unique properties, such as its high boiling point and surface tension, are due to the hydrogen bonds between its hydrogen and oxygen atoms. These bonds make water a versatile solvent, capable of dissolving a wide range of substances. Moreover, water plays a crucial role in biochemical reactions, acting as a medium for reactions in living organisms. Its role in chemical processes and life itself underscores water's indispensable place in the world of chemistry.

We address the elliptically shaped vortex solitons in defocusing nonlinear media imprinted with a composite Mathieu lattice. Elliptic vortices feature anisotropic patterns both in intensity and phase, and can only exist when their energy flow exceed some certain threshold. Single-charged elliptic vortices are found to arise via bifurcation from dipole modes, which, to the best of our knowledge is the first example in the context of optics studies of symmetry breaking bifurcations for the phase dislocations of different dimensionalities. Higher-order elliptic vortices with topological charge could exhibit spatially separated single-charged phase singularities, leading to their stabilization. The salient features of reported elliptic vortices qualitatively hold for other elliptic shaped confining potentials.

In the intricate dance of molecular interactions, hydrogen bonds assume a pivotal role. Beyond their ubiquity in water, these weak yet influential bonds are prevalent in many organic compounds, shaping their properties. Hydrogen bonds occur when a hydrogen atom, bonded to a highly electronegative atom like nitrogen, oxygen, or fluorine, is attracted to a lone pair on another electronegative atom. This intermolecular force, weaker than covalent bonds but stronger than van der Waals, influences the melting and boiling points, solubility, and crystal structures of various substances. The presence or absence of hydrogen bonds can significantly impact a compound's behavior and reactivity, demonstrating their vital role in chemistry.

According to general relativity, a spinning body of mass M and angular momentum S, like a star or a planet, generates a gravitomagnetic field which induces, among other phenomena, also the Lense-Thirring effect, i.e. secular precessions of the path of a test particle orbiting it. Direct and indisputable tests of such a relativistic prediction are still missing. We discuss some performed attempts to measure it in the gravitational fields of several bodies in the Solar System with natural and artificial objects. The focus is on the realistic evaluation of the impact of some competing classical forces regarded as sources of systematic uncertainties degrading the total accuracy obtainable.

In the intriguing realm of chemistry, the fascination lies in the silent dance of atoms and molecules. Each element, a unique player, interacts with others, forming compounds that shape our world. A hydrogen atom, light as a feather, unites with a heavy oxygen counterpart to form water, life's elixir. Carbon, versatile and strong, builds complex structures, from the graphite in our pencils to the DNA in our cells. Iron, essential for life, binds with sulfur to create iron sulfide, a mineral found in meteorites, connecting us to the cosmos. These harmonious unions and transformations, visible in a simple test tube or the vast expanse of the universe, reveal the unending symphony of chemistry.

The cosmological principle says that the Universe is spatially homogeneous and isotropic. It predicts, among other phenomena, the cosmic redshift of light and the Hubble law. Nevertheless, the existence of structure in the Universe violates the (exact) cosmological principle. A more precise formulation of the cosmological principle must allow for the formation of structure and must therefore incorporate probability distributions. In this contribution to the Memorial Volume for Wolfgang Kummer, a great teacher and mentor to me, I discuss how we could formulate a new version of the cosmological principle, how to test it, and how to possibly justify it by fundamental physics. My contribution starts with some of my memories of Wolfgang.

In the realm of chemistry, hydrogen bonding plays a pivotal role, especially in water and organic molecules. This intermolecular force, weaker than ionic or covalent bonds, arises due to the attractive electrostatic interaction between a partially positive hydrogen atom of one molecule and a partially negative atom of another. It's responsible for the liquid state of water at room temperature, as hydrogen bonds hold the water molecules together, and for the unique properties of substances like DNA, where hydrogen bonds stabilize the double helix structure. This bond, though weak, significantly influences the physical and chemical behavior of numerous compounds, making it an essential concept in the study of chemistry.

pCVD diamond sensors are regularly used as beam loss monitors in accelerators by measuring the ionization of the lost particles. In the past these beam loss monitors showed sudden increases in the dark leakage current without beam losses and these erratic leakage currents were found to decrease, if magnetic fields were present. Here we report on a systematic study of leakage currents inside a magnetic field. The decrease of erratic currents in a magnetic field was confirmed. On the contrary, diamonds without erratic currents showed an increase of the leakage current in a magnetic field perpendicular to the electric field for fields up to 0.6T, for higher fields it decreases. A preliminary model is introduced to explain the observations.

Amidst the myriad of chemical reactions that govern our world, one stands out for its ubiquity and importance: photosynthesis. This process, carried out by plants and certain microorganisms, harnesses sunlight's energy to convert carbon dioxide and water into glucose and oxygen. It's a dance of electrons, a symphony of atoms, an intricate ballet of chemical transformations. Chlorophyll, the green pigment in leaves, acts as a catalyst, absorbing light and setting off a cascade of events. Carbon dioxide and water split, carbon being fixed into glucose, while oxygen is released into the atmosphere. This life-sustaining process, essential for our planet's survival, underscores the intricate and delicate balance of chemistry that governs our world.

Rydberg States are used in our One Atom Maser experiment because they offer a large dipole moment and couple strongly to low numbers of microwave photons in a high Q cavity. Here we report the absolute frequencies of the P$_{3/2}$ states for principal quantum numbers $n=36$ to $n=63$. These measurements were made with a three step laser excitation scheme. A wavemeter was calibrated against a frequency comb to provide accurate absolute frequency measurements over the entire range, reducing the measurement uncertainty to 1MHz. We compare the spectroscopic results with known frequency measurements as a test of measurement accuracy.

In the realm of chemical compounds, silicon tetrafluoride (SiF4) stands out for its unique properties. This colorless gas, composed of a central silicon atom bonded to four fluorine atoms, is a crucial component in various industries. It's extensively used in the production of silicones, semiconductors, and fluorinated polymers. The bond between silicon and fluorine is exceptionally strong, a testament to the powerful draw of electronegative elements. The reactivity of SiF4 is remarkable, making it a versatile tool in chemical synthesis. Despite its potency, it's also a challenge in waste management due to its toxicity and environmental impact. Thus, the handling and disposal of SiF4 require meticulous care, underscoring its dual role in both progress and caution.

Eighty years after de Broglie's, and a little more than half a century after Bohm's seminal papers, the de Broglie--Bohm theory (a.k.a. Bohmian mechanics), which is presumably the simplest theory which explains the orthodox quantum mechanics formalism, has reached an exemplary state of conceptual clarity and mathematical integrity. No other theory of quantum mechanics comes even close. Yet anyone curious enough to walk this road to quantum mechanics is soon being confused by many misleading signposts that have been put up, and not just by its detractors, but unfortunately enough also by some of its proponents.   This paper outlines a road map to help navigate ones way.

In the intricate world of organic chemistry, a compound named acetylsalicylic acid, more commonly known as aspirin, holds a significant place. Derived from willow bark, this wonder drug revolutionized medicine. Its unique structure, featuring an aromatic ring with a carboxylic acid and an ester group, enables it to inhibit cyclooxygenase, reducing inflammation and alleviating pain. Aspirin's therapeutic effects also extend to preventing blood clots, making it indispensable in cardiovascular care. Despite its widespread use, exploring its potential further, particularly in cancer research, continues to captivate chemists and medical professionals alike.

When an infectious disease strikes a population, the number of newly reported cases is often the only available information that one can obtain during early stages of the outbreak. An important goal of early outbreak analysis is to obtain a reliable estimate for the basic reproduction number, $R_{0}$, from the limited information available. We present a novel method that enables us to make a reliable real-time estimate of the reproduction number at a much earlier stage compared to other available methods. Our method takes into account the possibility that a disease has a wide distribution of infectious period and that the degree distribution of the contact network is heterogeneous. We validate our analytical framework with numerical simulations.

In the intricate realm of organic chemistry, carbon stands as the linchpin, forming intricate chains and rings to create an array of complex molecules. The versatility of carbon lies in its ability to bond with four other atoms, providing a foundation for an immense variety of structures. Each carbon-carbon bond can rotate freely, allowing for countless configurations, a phenomenon known as isomerism. This dynamic flexibility enables carbon to construct the building blocks of life, from the sugars and amino acids essential for biological processes to the polymers that underpin materials science. The bonding patterns, reactions, and transformations in organic chemistry offer a fascinating tapestry of relationships and interactions, unveiling the secrets of the molecules that define our world.

The guided dispersion characteristics of subwavelength nanoscale plasmonic coaxial lines are analyzed in detail over a wide optical frequency range below the plasma frequency with a varying gap between the inner and outer plasmonic conductors, providing important preliminary information for understanding the guided mode characteristics of subwavelength nanoscale coaxial lines with plasmonic metals. In particular, when the inner or outer radius is varied, guided modes with similar and dissimilar dispersive features are obtained and discussed. A brief comparison of the propagating modes for the present subwavelength plasmonic coaxial lines and those for a subwavelength plasmonic hole and wire is also made.

In the realm of chemical reactions, energy transfers play a pivotal role. These processes, driven by the quest for equilibrium, can be exothermic or endothermic. Exothermic reactions release energy, often heating the surrounding environment, such as the combustion of methane, a primary component in natural gas, producing carbon dioxide and water. Conversely, endothermic reactions absorb energy, typically cooling their surroundings, like the process of dissolving salt in water, where the dissolving salt molecules take up energy from the environment, a phenomenon known as enthalpy of solution. These reactions, though seemingly disparate, are fundamentally connected, shaping the world around us through energy transformations.

The properties of bosonic Ytterbium photoassociation spectra near the intercombination transition $^{1}S_{0}$--$^{3}P_{1}$ are studied theoretically at ultra low temperatures. We demonstrate how the shapes and intensities of rotational components of optical Feshbach resonances are affected by mass tuning of the scattering properties of the two colliding ground state atoms. Particular attention is given to the relationship between the magnitude of the scattering length and the occurrence of shape resonances in higher partial waves of the van der Waals system. We develop a mass scaled model of the excited state potential that represents the experimental data for different isotopes. The shape of the rotational photoassociation spectrum for various bosonic Yb isotopes can be qualitatively different.

In the realm of chemical bonding, the electronegativity scale provides a valuable tool for understanding the nature of the interactions between atoms. Developed by Linus Pauling, this scale ranks elements based on their tendency to attract electrons, with higher values indicating greater pull. For instance, fluorine, with an electronegativity value of 3.98, is the most electronegative element, while cesium, with a value of 0.79, is the least. These differences in electronegativity dictate the formation of ionic or covalent bonds, shaping the very structure of molecules and compounds, and playing a crucial role in the properties and reactivity of materials in our world.

In this article, we analytically study second harmonic (SH) generation from thin metallic films with subwavelength, non-centrosymmetry patterns. Because the thickness of the film is much smaller than the SH wavelength, retardation effects are negligible. The far-field SH intensities are thus dominated by an effective electric dipole. These analytical observations are further justified numerically by studying the effect of polarization of the fundamental field on both the SH signal and the electric dipole. It is demonstrated that bulk SH polarization density is comparable with its surface counterpart. The electric dipole, consequently, originates from the entire {volume of the metallic membrane, in contrast to the fact that SH generation from metal surface is generally dominated by a surface dipole.

Nitrous oxide, a colorless, odorless gas, is chemically known as N2O. It's a versatile compound, widely used in various industries and medical applications. In the food industry, it's employed as a whipping agent, giving a creamy texture to whipped cream and other products. In the medical field, it serves as an anesthetic and as a treatment for angina. In its polluted form, it contributes to the depletion of the ozone layer. On a more positive note, it's also used in rocket propulsion and as a laughing gas due to its euphoric effect on the human brain. Despite its numerous uses, its impact on the environment and human health necessitates careful handling and monitoring.

Transformation optics is used to design a gateway that can block electromagnetic waves but allows the passage of other entities. Our conceptual device has the advantage that it can be realized with simple materials and structural parameters and can have a reasonably wide bandwidth. In particular, we show that our system can be implemented by using a magnetic photonic crystal structure that employs a square ray of ferrite rods, and as the field response of ferrites can be tuned by external magnetic fields, we end up with an electromagnetic gateway that can be open or shut using external fields. The functionality is also robust against the positional disorder of the rods that made up the photonic crystal.

Nitrogen, an element vital to life, constitutes nearly 78% of Earth's atmosphere. In its triatomic form, nitrogen gas (N2) is inert and unresponsive, making it unable to support combustion or most chemical reactions. However, under specific conditions, nitrogen can be transformed into compounds essential for fertilizers, explosives, and even biological molecules. For instance, ammonia (NH3), a key component of fertilizers, is produced industrially from nitrogen and hydrogen through the Haber-Bosch process. Similarly, nitrates and nitrites, used in explosives and food preservation, are formed through microbial processes or chemical reactions. Furthermore, nitrogen is integral to the structure of proteins, nucleotides, and other biomolecules, underscoring its indispensable role in the intricate web of life.

We investigate an evolutionary prisoner's dilemma game among self-driven agents, where collective motion of biological flocks is imitated through averaging directions of neighbors. Depending on the temptation to defect and the velocity at which agents move, we find that cooperation can not only be maintained in such a system but there exists an optimal size of interaction neighborhood, which can induce the maximum cooperation level. When compared with the case that all agents do not move, cooperation can even be enhanced by the mobility of individuals, provided that the velocity and the size of neighborhood are not too large. Besides, we find that the system exhibits aggregation behavior, and cooperators may coexist with defectors at equilibrium.

In the realm of organic chemistry, the intricate dance of carbon atoms takes center stage. Carbon's unique ability to bond with four other atoms gives rise to an incredible diversity of molecules. From the complex structures of proteins, essential for life, to the simplest hydrocarbons, such as methane and ethane, these compounds form the building blocks of our world. The synthesis of these molecules, guided by the principles of reaction kinetics, offers chemists the power to create new materials, advance medicine, and unravel the mysteries of the universe itself. This dance of carbon, a testament to nature's ingenuity, continues to captivate and challenge chemists worldwide.

We investigate the spatial and temporal features of dense contaminant plumes dynamics in porous materials. Our analysis is supported by novel experimental results concerning pollutant concentration profiles inside a vertical column setup. We describe the experimental methods and elucidate the salient outcomes of the measurements, with focus on miscible fluids in homogeneous saturated media.
