By resorting to a finite elements approach, we numerically solve the equations that rule the pollutants migration and compare the simulation results with the experimental data. Finally, we qualitatively explore the interfacial dynamics behavior between the dense contaminant plume and the lighter resident fluid that saturates the column.

In the realm of chemical bonding, the electronegativity difference between atoms dictates the nature of a bond. For instance, the stronger ionic bond between sodium and chlorine arises from the significant difference in electronegativity, causing chlorine to attract electrons predominantly, forming Na+ and Cl-. Conversely, the covalent bond between two carbon atoms, both exhibiting similar electronegativity values, results in a more even sharing of electrons. This fundamental principle governs the formation of compounds, influencing properties such as melting points, boiling points, and reactivity. Understanding electronegativity thus provides a key to deciphering the intricate dance of atoms in chemical reactions.

We present an efficient approach to evaluate two-center two-electron integrals with exponential functions and with an arbitrary polynomial in electron-nucleus and electron-electron distances. We show that the master integral with the single negative power of all distances can be obtained from the second order differential equation in $r$, the distance between nuclei. For particular values of nonlinear parameters corresponding to the James-Coolidge basis, we find a fully analytic expression. For integrals with arbitrary powers of all distances, we construct recursion relations which starts from the master integral. The presented approach opens a window for the high precision calculations of relativistic effects in diatomic molecules.

Amidst the vibrant world of chemistry, a fascinating entity captivates our attention: the molecule. These microscopic structures, formed by the bonding of atoms, dictate the properties of substances. From the simple water molecule, H2O, to the complex protein chains, they govern everything from the fluidity of liquids to the solidity of solids. The molecule's structure determines its behavior, be it the explosive nature of nitroglycerin or the cooling effect of menthol. As we delve deeper into the molecular realm, we unlock the secrets of matter, shedding light on the fundamental building blocks that make up our universe. The study of molecules, therefore, is not just a pursuit of academic interest. it's a key to understanding the very essence of life.

Solar UV emission has a profound impact on the upper terrestrial atmosphere. Because of instrumental constraints, however, solar proxies often need to be used as substitutes for the solar spectral variability. Finding proxies that properly reproduce specific spectral bands or lines is an ongoing problem. Using daily observations from 2003 to 2008 and a multiscale statistical approach, we test the performances of 9 proxies for the UV solar flux. Their relevance is evaluated at different time-scales and a novel representation allows all quantities to be compared simultaneously. This representation reveals which proxies are most appropriate for different spectral bands and for different time scales.

In the realm of chemical bonds, the covalent bond stands as a fundamental unit, connecting atoms in a myriad of organic and inorganic compounds. These bonds are formed when two atoms share one or more pairs of electrons, creating a stable electron configuration. For instance, in the hydrogen molecule (H2), each hydrogen atom contributes one electron, forming a mutual linkage. Conversely, in water (H2O), two hydrogen atoms share electrons with the oxygen atom, forming two covalent bonds and a lone pair. This simple yet profound phenomenon serves as the backbone for the vast diversity of matter we observe in the world.

In this article we report the release of a new program for batch processing and visualization of powder diffraction data. The program, which is free-of-charge for non-commercial use and can be obtained with its detailed documentation from our website www.scienceware.net, is currently in use by a number of researchers in University College London, University of Manchester, Utrecht University in the Netherland, European Synchrotron Radiation Facility (ESRF), and Diamond Light Source. The software is designed for the treatment of large volume of powder diffraction data, especially those obtained from the new generation of synchrotron detectors. The program has a great potential for future development to be a workbench for powder diffraction work.

In the captivating world of chemistry, the element carbon stands out with its versatile nature. Found in various forms, such as diamonds, graphite, and soot, carbon's unique structure, consisting of four electrons in its outer shell, allows it to form strong covalent bonds with other carbon atoms. This property underpins the creation of complex organic compounds, crucial to life on Earth. Carbon's ability to form chains, rings, and branches gives rise to an immense variety of molecules, each with unique properties and functions. From the intricate structure of DNA to the vibrant pigments in a paint set, carbon's influence is omnipresent, illuminating the profound impact chemistry has on our lives.

Critical phenomena were discovered by Cagniard de la Tour in 1822, who died 150 years ago. In order to mark this anniversary, the context and the early history of his discovery is reviewed. We then follow with a brief sketch of the history of critical phenomena, indicating the main lines of development until the present date.   Os fen\'omenos cr\'{\i}ticos foram descobertos pelo Cagniard de la Tour em Paris em 1822. Para comemorar os 150 anos da sua morte, o contexto e a hist\'oria initial da sua descoberta \'e contada. Conseguimos com uma descri\c{c}\~ao breve da hist\'oria dos fen\'emenos cr\'{\i}ticos, indicando as linhas principais do desenvolvimento at\'e o presente.

Nestled within the intricate dance of atoms and molecules, catalysts play a pivotal role in accelerating chemical reactions. These subtly tweaked compounds lower the activation energy of a reaction, enabling it to occur more swiftly at lower temperatures. The importance of catalysts extends far beyond the lab, as they are integral to numerous industrial processes, from the production of fuels to the manufacture of pharmaceuticals. In essence, catalysts are the unsung heroes of modern chemistry, propelling the world forward, one reaction at a time.

We present and discuss a variance-reduced stochastic particle method for simulating the relaxation-time model of the Boltzmann transport equation. The present paper focuses on the dilute gas case, although the method is expected to directly extend to all fields (carriers) for which the relaxation-time approximation is reasonable. The variance reduction, achieved by simulating only the deviation from equilibrium, results in a significant computational efficiency advantage compared to traditional stochastic particle methods in the limit of small deviation from equilibrium. More specifically, the proposed method can efficiently simulate arbitrarily small deviations from equilibrium at a computational cost that is independent of the deviation from equilibrium, which is in sharp contrast to traditional particle methods.

In the realm of molecular chemistry, the concept of resonance structures offers a fascinating glimpse into the unseen world of electrons. Resonance is a phenomenon where a molecule can't be accurately described by a single electron distribution, instead, it exists as a mixture of several structures, each representing a possible distribution of electrons. This concept, first introduced by Linus Pauling, allows us to understand the stability and reactivity of certain molecules, such as benzene, more accurately. It's a testament to the intricate dance of electrons, a ballet of charges that defies our initial perceptions of a molecule's structure. This understanding, in turn, opens doors to the exploration of chemical reactions, electronic properties, and even the design of new materials.

Bhabha's scientific research contributions are descibed in the context of his life and contemporary science. During the Cambridge period(1927-1939),he worked in Positron theory(Bhabha scattering),Cosmic rays (Bhabha- Heitler theory of cosmic ray showers,prediction of heavier electrons) and Meson theory.In Bangalore during 1939-1945, he worked on classical relativistic spinning particles (Bhabha-Corben equations),meson theory and initiated experimental work in cosmic rays in India.He then founded Tata Institute of Fundamental Research in1945 at Bombay and moved there. Here he started work on relativistic wave equations (Bhabha eqns.).He also initiated India's nuclear energy programme in 1948 and this was his main preoccupation later.

In the realm of molecular chemistry, the fascinating dance of atoms unfolds. Carbon, a versatile element, forms the basis of countless organic compounds, its four valence electrons facilitating intricate bonding patterns. Hydrogen, its lighter counterpart, often partners with carbon, adding hydrophobic properties to these compounds. Conversely, oxygen, with its affinity for sharing electrons, creates hydrophilic groups when bonded, enabling water's unique ability to dissolve many substances. These fundamental interactions shape the behavior and properties of countless substances, from the delicate structure of proteins to the combustible power of fuels, illuminating the profound impact of chemistry on our everyday world.

In this work we combine the large per-photon optical gradient force with the sensitive feedback of a high quality factor whispering-gallery microcavity. The cavity geometry, consisting of a pair of silica disks separated by a nanoscale gap, shows extremely strong dynamical backaction, powerful enough to excite giant coherent oscillations even under heavily damped conditions (mechanical Q=4). In vacuum, the threshold for regenerative mechanical oscillation is lowered to an optical input power of only 270-nanoWatts, or roughly 1000 stored cavity photons, and efficient cooling of the mechanical motion is obtained with a temperature compression factor of 13-dB for 4-microWatts of dropped optical input power.

Harnessing the Power of Catalysis: A Chemical RevolutionCatalysis, a phenomenon that accelerates reactions without being consumed, is revolutionizing modern chemistry. By lowering reaction energies and providing alternative pathways, catalysts expedite chemical transformations, enhancing efficiency and reducing waste. This advancement has far-reaching implications, from industrial manufacturing to environmental solutions. For instance, catalytic converters in cars convert harmful exhaust gases into less harmful byproducts, while catalytic hydrogenation streamlines the production of pharmaceuticals and fuels. The future of chemistry lies in the continued discovery and development of novel catalysts, offering sustainable solutions to complex problems.

Transformation-based cylindrical cloaks and concentrators are illuminated with non-monochromatic waves and unusual effects are observed with interesting potential applications. The transient responses of the devices are studied numerically with the Finite-Difference Time-Domain method and the results are verified with analytical formulas. We compute the effective bandwidth of several cloaking schemes as well as the effect of losses on the performance of the structures. We also find that narrowband behavior, frequency shift effects, time delays and spatial disturbances of the incoming waves are dominant due to the inherently dispersive nature of the devices. These effects are important and should be taken into account when designing metamaterial-based devices.

In the captivating realm of chemistry, the intrigue lies in the transformation of matter. Elements, the building blocks of the universe, combine and rearrange in a symphony of reactions, forming compounds that define our world. For instance, water, a compound essential for life, is composed of two hydrogen atoms and one oxygen atom, bound together in a hydrogen bond. These bonds, weak yet tenacious, allow water to flow and adapt to its surroundings, a testament to the fascinating properties of chemical bonds. In the lab or in nature, chemistry is the silent observer, the unseen force shaping our reality, revealing the world in a whole new light.

We report a 1.036 GHz gated Geiger mode InGaAs avalanche photodiode with a detection dead time of just 1.93 ns. This is demonstrated by full recovery of the detection efficiency two gate cycles after a detection event, as well as a measured maximum detection rate of 497 MHz. As an application, we measure the second order correlation function $g^{(2)}$ of the emission from a diode laser with a single detector which works reliably at high speed owing to the extremely short dead time of the detector. The device is ideal for high bit rate fiber wavelength quantum key distribution and photonic quantum computing.

In the realm of molecular biology, DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) stands as the blueprint of life. This double-helix structure, composed of nucleotides, carries the genetic instructions essential for the growth, development, and functioning of all known organisms. Each nucleotide consists of a sugar molecule, a phosphate group, and one of four nitrogenous bases: adenine, thymine, guanine, and cytosine. The sequence of these bases along the DNA strand encodes the genetic information, serving as the basis for protein synthesis and cellular reproduction. The intricate dance of DNA replication, transcription, and translation underscores the complexity and beauty of the chemical processes that sustain life.

In this brief report, a thermal lattice-Boltzmann (LB) model is presented for axisymmetric thermal flows in the incompressible limit. The model is based on the double-distribution-function LB method, which has attracted much attention since its emergence for its excellent numerical stability. Compared with the existing axisymmetric thermal LB models, the present model is simpler and retains the inherent features of the standard LB method. Numerical simulations are carried out for the thermally developing laminar flows in circular ducts and the natural convection in an annulus between two coaxial vertical cylinders. The Nusselt number obtained from the simulations agrees well with the analytical solutions and/or the results reported in previous studies.

Nitrogen, a diatomic element with the symbol N, is the most abundant gas in Earth's atmosphere, constituting approximately 78% of its composition by volume. This versatile element plays a crucial role in various biological processes, particularly as a key component of proteins, DNA, and amino acids. In industry, nitrogen is integral to the production of fertilizers, plastics, and explosives. The process of fixing atmospheric nitrogen into a usable form, known as nitrogen fixation, is a vital industrial process. It involves converting nitrogen gas into ammonia through a series of chemical reactions, primarily through the Haber-Bosch process. This process has revolutionized agriculture, enabling the growth of crops on a larger scale and contributing significantly to global food production. Despite its widespread use, concerns about the environmental impact of nitrogen fixation persist, prompting ongoing research to develop more sustainable methods.

We address the problem of how the survival of cooperation in a social system depends on the motion of the individuals. Specifically, we study a model in which Prisoner's Dilemma players are allowed to move in a two-dimensional plane. Our results show that cooperation can survive in such a system provided that both the temptation to defect and the velocity at which agents move are not too high. Moreover, we show that when these conditions are fulfilled, the only asymptotic state of the system is that in which all players are cooperators. Our results might have implications for the design of cooperative strategies in motion coordination and other applications including wireless networks.

In the vast realm of chemical compounds, water (H2O) stands out as a unique and essential substance. It's a versatile solvent, capable of dissolving a wide variety of substances, facilitating numerous chemical reactions. Water's anomalous properties, such as its maximum density at 4 degrees Celsius, contribute to its role in life on Earth, as it maintains a stable temperature range in our oceans and freshwater bodies. The hydrogen bonds within water molecules create a structured network, lowering its freezing point and boiling point, a phenomenon that significantly impacts Earth's climate. Furthermore, the polar nature of water molecules allows them to interact strongly with ionic compounds, playing a crucial role in the distribution of ions in living organisms. Indeed, water's myriad properties make it a vital component in chemistry and life itself.

Here we propose and demonstrate an all-optical wavelength-routing approach which uses a tuning mechanism based upon the optical gradient force in a specially-designed nano-optomechanical system. The resulting mechanically-compliant "spiderweb" resonantor realizes seamless wavelength routing over a range of 3000 times the intrinsic channel width, with a tuning efficiency of 309-GHz/mW, a switching time of less than 200-ns, and 100% channel-quality preservation over the entire tuning range. These results indicate the potential for radiation pressure actuated devices to be used in a variety of photonics applications, such as channel routing/switching, buffering, dispersion compensation, pulse trapping/release, and widely tunable lasers.

In the intriguing world of chemistry, one compound stands out for its versatility and ubiquity - water (H2O). This simple molecule, composed of two hydrogen atoms bonded to one oxygen atom, is crucial to life as we know it. It serves as a solvent, a medium for chemical reactions, and a fundamental component in cellular processes. Beyond its biological importance, water plays a significant role in industrial applications, from energy production to manufacturing. Its unique properties, such as surface tension and high heat capacity, make it an indispensable resource in numerous fields. Moreover, understanding water's behavior at various states and its interaction with other substances deepens our knowledge of chemistry and physics, offering endless opportunities for scientific discovery and technological advancement.

We introduce a new fundamental property of waveguides induced by the forces of the guided light, namely, the ability to self align or be in instability. A nanoscale waveguide broken by an offset and a gap may tend to self align to form a continuous waveguide. Conversely, depending on the geometry and light polarization, the two parts of the waveguide may be deflected away from each other, thus being in an unstable state. These effects are unique as they rely on the presence of both the guided mode and the scattered light. Strong self alignment forces may be facilitated by near field interaction with polarization surface charges.

In the realm of chemistry, the fascinating world of polymers unfolds. These complex molecules, composed of repetitive subunits, exhibit remarkable properties that make them indispensable in various industries. From plastics and rubbers to fibers and resins, polymers are ubiquitous. Their versatility stems from their ability to be tailored, allowing scientists to craft materials with specific properties. Through a process known as polymerization, these subunits are linked together, forming long chains that can be intricately structured. This structural diversity gives polymers their wide range of applications, from the tiny microscopic fibers used in filtration systems to the sturdy plastics that make up our everyday items. The study and application of polymers continue to evolve, promising a future filled with innovative and sustainable materials.

The present work studies the isotropic and homogeneous turbulence for incompressible fluids through a specific Lyapunov analysis, assuming that the turbulence is due to the bifurcations associated to the velocity field.   The analysis consists in the study of the mechanism of the energy cascade from large to small scales through the Lyapunov analysis of the relative motion between two particles and in the calculation of the velocity fluctuation through the Lyapunov analysis of the local deformation and the Navier-Stokes equations.   The analysis provides an explanation for the mechanism of the energy cascade, leads to the closure of the von K\'arm\'an-Howarth equation, and describes the statistics of the velocity difference.   Several tests and numerical results are presented.

Nitrogen, a versatile element in the periodic table, plays a crucial role in our world. It comprises 78% of Earth's atmosphere, essential for life as it forms a fundamental part of proteins, nucleic acids, and various vitamins. In industry, nitrogen is a key component in fertilizers, explosives, and plastics. The Haber-Bosch process, a groundbreaking innovation, converts atmospheric nitrogen into ammonia, a fundamental compound for these applications. Moreover, liquid nitrogen's extremely low temperature (-196°C) makes it valuable in preserving and freezing food, as well as in cryogenic medical procedures. The myriad uses of nitrogen underscore its indispensable role in modern society, from sustaining life to fueling technological advancements.

A novel method is presented for the beam shaping of far field intensity distributions of coherently combined fiber arrays. The fibers are arranged uniformly on the perimeter of a circle, and the linearly polarized beams of equal shape are superimposed such that the far field pattern represents an effective radially polarized vector beam, or discrete cylindrical vector (DCV) beam. The DCV beam is produced by three or more beams that each individually have a varying polarization vector. The beams are appropriately distributed in the near field such that the far field intensity distribution has a central null. This result is in contrast to the situation of parallel linearly polarized beams, where the intensity peaks on axis.

In the intricate world of organic chemistry, carbon, often dubbed the 'king of elements,' forms the backbone of countless compounds. It's the versatility of carbon that sets it apart, allowing it to bond with four other atoms, creating a diverse array of structures. This property, known as catenation, underpins the complexity of organic molecules, from the simple alkanes to the intricate biomolecules like proteins and nucleic acids. The reactions of these molecules, governed by principles such as electrophilic addition and substitution, play a pivotal role in synthesizing new substances, a process essential to various industries, including pharmaceuticals and materials science. The study of organic chemistry, therefore, offers a fascinating exploration into nature's building blocks and the transformations they undergo.

We realize a flat lens with graded negative refractive index by a two-dimensional phononic crystal. The index-grade is achieved by gradual modification of the filling fraction along the transverse direction to propagation. We demonstrate that this lens can realize the focusing and amplification of parallel incident acoustic waves. A formula for the refractive index profile is derived by which the lens with desired focal length can be precisely designed and the aberrations of image can be effectively reduced. This designable lens is expected to bear significance in applications such as coupling or integration with various types of acoustic devices.

In the intricate realm of organic chemistry, a compound named salicylic acid holds a significant position. Derived from phenolic compounds, salicylic acid is a beta hydroxy acid, a chemical class with exfoliating properties. It's found naturally in various plants, such as willow bark and wintergreen leaves, and is also synthesized industrially. Salicylic acid plays a crucial role in the human body, acting as a keratolytic agent, helping to shed dead skin cells and promoting cell turnover. This process is essential for maintaining healthy skin, making salicylic acid a popular ingredient in numerous skincare products, from acne treatments to anti-aging creams. Its unique properties, rooted in both chemistry and biology, continue to captivate researchers and skincare enthusiasts alike.

We have studied the nature of classical work ($W_{c}$) and thermodynamic work ($W$) fluctuations in systems driven out of equilibrium both in transient and time periodic steady state. As the observation time of trajectory increases, we show that the number of trajectories which exhibit excursions away from the typical behaviour i.e., $W_{c}<0$, $W<\Delta F$ and dissipated heat $Q<0$ decreases as anticipated for macroscopic time scales. Analytical expressions for such trajectories are obtained. Trajectory for which $W_{c}<0$ may not correspond to $W<\Delta F$ or $Q<0$. The applicability of steady state fluctuation theorems are discussed in our linear as well as nonlinear models.

In the realm of chemistry, the intriguing world of polymers unfolds. These complex compounds, composed of repetitive molecular units, exhibit a wide array of properties. From plastics and rubbers to fibers and resins, polymers permeate our daily lives. Their versatility is rooted in the ability to manipulate their structure, leading to diverse applications. For instance, polyethylene, a lightweight, flexible polymer, is used in packaging materials, while Kevlar, a strong, rigid polymer, is woven into bulletproof vests. The study of polymers continues to evolve, promising further innovations in materials science.

Optical mushroom shaped billiards offer a unique opportunity to isolate and study non-dispersive, marginally unstable periodic orbits. Here we show that the openness of the cavity to external fields presents unanticipated consequences for the far-field distribution, including directional emission. This is mediated by interactions of marginally unstable periodic orbits with chaotic modes and is potentially relevant for the design of microcavity lasers. We also show that such orbits are robust against perturbations to the shape of the cavity, despite the non-generic character of the classical counterpart and the lack of structural stability of the corresponding classical orbits.

Nitrogen, an element with the atomic number 7, is a vital component of Earth's atmosphere, comprising about 78% of its gaseous content. In its elemental form, it is a colorless, odorless, and non-reactive gas, making it essential for life as it forms a crucial part of proteins, nucleic acids, and various other biological compounds. Industrial applications of nitrogen are vast, ranging from fertilizers to explosives. The Haber-Bosch process, a nitrogen fixation method, enables the synthesis of ammonia on a large scale, serving as the basis for the production of various nitrogen-containing chemicals. Nitrogen's versatility and abundance make it an indispensable element in modern chemistry and industry.

The ALPS collaboration runs a light-shining-through-walls (LSW) experiment to search for photon oscillations into "weakly interacting sub-eV particles" (WISPs) inside of a superconducting HERA dipole magnet at the site of DESY. In this paper we report on the first successful integration of a large-scale optical cavity to boost the available power for WISP production in this type of experiments. The key elements are a frequency tunable narrow line-width continuous wave laser acting as the primary light source and an electronic feed-back control loop to stabilize the power build-up. We describe and characterize our apparatus and demonstrate the data analysis procedures on the basis of a brief exemplary run.

In the realm of chemistry, the fascinating world of polymers unfolds. These complex compounds, composed of repeating monomer units, display extraordinary versatility. Polymers can be synthesized through various methods, such as polymerization, a process that links monomers together to form long, chain-like structures. These structures imbue polymers with properties that make them indispensable in modern life. For instance, polystyrene, a common type of plastic, is renowned for its light weight and resistance to impact, making it ideal for packaging materials. On the other hand, polyethylene, with its excellent chemical resistance, is utilized extensively in the production of pipes and containers. The intricate dance of atoms in polymers not only fuels scientific curiosity but also propels technological advancement, underscoring their pivotal role in our everyday lives.

We present evidences of the diffusive motion of the ground and tunnels and show that if systematic movements are excluded then the remaining uncorrelated component of the motion obeys a characteristic fractal law with the displacement variance dY^2 scaling with time- and spatial intervals T and L as dY^2 \propto T^(Alpha)L^(Gamma) with both exponents close to 1. We briefly describe experimental methods of the mesa- and microscopic ground motion detection used in the measurements at the physics research facilities sensitive to the motion, particularly, large high energy elementary particle accelerators. A simple mathematical model of the fractal motion demonstrating the observed scaling law is also presented and discussed.

Delving into the fascinating realm of organic chemistry, we find ourselves engrossed in the synthesis of complex molecules. One such compound is aspirin, a staple in many households. Originally derived from willow bark, aspirin's chemical structure, acetylsalicylic acid, is a testament to human ingenuity. Through a process known as esterification, acetic acid and salicylic acid combine, forming this powerful pain reliever and anti-inflammatory agent. The reaction is catalyzed by a strong acid, like sulfuric acid, under controlled temperature conditions. This transformation, from nature's remedy to a laboratory-produced drug, exemplifies the profound impact chemistry has on our lives.

We analyze the Bombay stock exchange (BSE) price index over the period of last 12 years. Keeping in mind the large fluctuations in last few years, we carefully find out the transient, non-statistical and locally structured variations. For that purpose, we make use of Daubechies wavelet and characterize the fractal behavior of the returns using a recently developed wavelet based fluctuation analysis method. the returns show a fat-tail distribution as also weak non-statistical behavior. We have also carried out continuous wavelet as well as Fourier power spectral analysis to characterize the periodic nature and correlation properties of the time series.

In the realm of molecular biology, DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) stands as the blueprint of life. This double-helix structure, composed of nucleotides, encodes genetic information for an organism's growth, development, and function. Each nucleotide consists of a sugar molecule, a phosphate group, and a nitrogenous base—either adenine, thymine, guanine, or cytosine. The sequence of these bases along the DNA strand forms the genetic code, a language that dictates the synthesis of proteins essential for life. DNA replication, transcription, and translation are the intricate processes that ensure the faithful transmission of this code, shaping the very essence of life from generation to generation.

The previous twelve turnout rates of French national elections by municipality show regularities. These regularities do not depend on the national turnout level, nor on the nature of the election. Based on past statistical regularities we make three predictions. The first one deals with the standard deviation of the turnout rate by municipality. The second one refers to the continuity in time of the heterogeneity of turnout rates in the vicinity of a municipality. The last one is about the correlation between the heterogeneity of turnout rates in the vicinity of a municipality and the population in its surroundings. Details, explanations and discussions will be given in forthcoming papers.

In the intricate world of chemistry, the element silicon stands out, found abundantly in the Earth's crust. Notably, silicon forms the basis of silicon dioxide, commonly known as quartz, a mineral essential to sand and granite. Silicon's unique properties, such as its high thermal conductivity and resistance to chemical corrosion, make it indispensable in various industries. For instance, in electronics, silicon is the foundation of semiconductors, the heart of computers and smartphones, enabling the digital revolution. Furthermore, it's used in solar panels, ensuring a cleaner, more sustainable future. In daily life, silicon's derivatives, like silicone, are used in everything from cooking utensils to cosmetics, showcasing the element's versatility and indispensable role in modern technology and daily life.

We study two kinds of economic exchange, additive and multiplicative, in a system of N agents. The work is divided in two parts, in the first one, the agents are free to interact with each other. The system evolves to a Boltzmann-Gibbs distribution with additive exchange and condenses with a multiplicative one. If bankruptcy is introduced, both types of exchange lead to condensation. Condensation times have been studied. In the second part, the agents are placed in a social network. We analyze the behavior of wealth distributions in time, and the formation of economic classes was observed for certain values of network connectivity.

Unraveling the fascinating world of organic chemistry, we delve into the synthesis of complex carbon-based compounds. These substances, the building blocks of life, are meticulously crafted through intricate reactions, resulting in an array of diverse structures, each with its unique properties. For instance, the synthesis of aspirin, a common pain reliever, involves the transformation of salicylic acid under controlled conditions, illuminating the power of chemical reactions in creating substances that improve human health. Similarly, the production of plastics involves the polymerization of smaller molecules, highlighting the role of organic chemistry in our daily lives. The study of organic chemistry, thus, offers a captivating exploration into the fundamental structures and transformations that shape our world.

Imaging technologies such as dynamic viewpoint generation are engineered for incoherent radiation using the traditional light field, and for coherent radiation using electromagnetic field theory. We present a model of coherent image formation that strikes a balance between the utility of the light field and the comprehensive predictive power of Maxwell's equations. We synthesize research in optics and signal processing to formulate, capture, and form images from quasi light fields, which extend the light field from incoherent to coherent radiation. Our coherent cameras generalize the classic beamforming algorithm in sensor array processing, and invite further research on alternative notions of image formation.

Hydrogen peroxide, a colorless, odorless liquid, is a common household chemical. It's a compound of hydrogen and oxygen, with the formula H2O2. Unlike water (H2O), hydrogen peroxide contains an extra oxygen atom, making it unstable and capable of decomposing over time. This decomposition, catalyzed by transition metals such as iron or copper, produces oxygen gas and water. Hydrogen peroxide has various uses, from bleaching hair to sterilizing wounds due to its oxidizing properties. It's a versatile compound that, despite its simplicity, plays a significant role in both everyday life and laboratory research.

Possibilities and difficulties of applying the theory of magnetic field generation by convection flows in rotating spherical fluid shells to the Giant Planets are outlined. Recent progress in the understanding of the distribution of electrical conductivity in the Giant Planets suggests that the dynamo process occurs predominantly in regions of semiconductivity. In contrast to the geodynamo the magnetic field generation in the Giant Planets is thus characterized by strong radial conductivity variations. The importance of the constraint on the Ohmic dissipation provided by the planetary luminosity is emphasized. Planetary dynamos are likely to be of an oscillatory type, although these oscillations may not be evident from the exterior of the planets.

In the realm of chemical intrigue, the synthesis of complex organic molecules captivates researchers worldwide. Through the artful blend of carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, nitrogen, and other elements, chemists craft substances that underpin life as we know it. Polymers, for instance, are long-chain macromolecules essential to plastics, textiles, and pharmaceuticals. On a smaller scale, amino acids, the building blocks of proteins, are meticulously arranged to create life's structural and functional scaffolds. The dance between atoms, catalyzed by enzymes or chemical reactions, is an intricate symphony of transformation, shaping the world around us. This chemical ballet, a testament to human ingenuity, continues to unfold in laboratories, driving innovation and pushing the boundaries of our understanding.

We examine closely the motion of the south-pointing chariot on a surface by taking into account the fact that both wheels have to roll without slipping. We firstly develop a procedure of successive approximations. In the limit where the distance between the wheels tends to zero, we find again the result due to Santander that the pointer is parallel transported. This is longer true generally within the first-order approximation. We secondly determine in an exact manner the motion of the south-pointing chariot on the sphere. Then, we define a pointer and we prove that this one is parallel transported exactly.

In the intricate world of organic chemistry, a compound known as caffeine captivates the senses and stimulates the mind. Derived primarily from the leaves of the coffee plant, this alkaloid is a complex organic molecule with a unique structure. Its chemical formula, C_{8}H_{10}N_{4}O_{2}, belies the intricate dance of carbon, hydrogen, nitrogen, and oxygen atoms that form its structure. This dance, when triggered by heat or water, releases a powerful energy that awakens the brain, making caffeine an essential ingredient in our daily beverages, from coffee to tea. Beyond its stimulant properties, caffeine also demonstrates potential health benefits, such as improving focus and alertness, reducing headaches, and even lowering the risk of certain diseases. The chemistry of caffeine continues to intrigue scientists, offering a tantalizing glimpse into the boundless possibilities of organic compounds.

Analytical solutions are presented for the electromagnetic radiation by an arbitrary pulsed source into a homogeneous time-varying background medium. In the constant-impedance case an explicit radiation formula is obtained for the synchronous permittivity and permeability described by any positive function of time. As might be expected, such a medium introduces significant spectral shifts and spatio-temporal modulation, which are analized here for the linear and exponential time-variations of the medium parameters. In the varying-impedance case the solution is obtained for the fourth-order polynomial time-dependence of the permittivity. In addition to the spectral shifts and modulation this spatially homogeneous medium scatters the field introducing causal echoes at the receiver location.

Nestled within the realm of matter, ions play a pivotal role in shaping the properties of substances. Ions are atoms or molecules that have gained or lost electrons, thereby acquiring a positive or negative charge. Sodium, for instance, loses one electron to become a sodium ion (Na+), while chlorine gains one to form a chloride ion (Cl-). These ions interact in various chemical reactions, such as the formation of table salt (NaCl), a ubiquitous seasoning in cooking, or in the electrolysis of water, splitting it into hydrogen and oxygen. Ions are the dance of electrons, orchestrating the intricate ballet of chemical reactions that permeate our world.

The interaction of the two counter-propagating ultrashort laser pulses with a singular wavefronts in the thin slice of the underdense plasma is considered. It is shown that ion-acoustic wave is excited via Brillouin three-wave resonance by corkscrew interference pattern of a paraxial singular laser beams. The orbital angular momentum carried by light is transferred to plasma ion-acoustic vortex. The rotation of the density perturbations of electron fluid is the cause of helical current which produce the kilogauss axial quasi-static magnetic field. The exact analytical configurations are presented for an ion-acoustic current field and magnetic induction. The range of experimentally accessible parameters is evaluated.

In the realm of molecular biology, DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) stands as a testament to nature's intricate design. This double-helix structure, composed of nucleotides, is the carrier of genetic information, shaping the very essence of life. Each nucleotide, a combination of phosphate, sugar, and a nitrogenous base, forms a link in the chain. Adenine, thymine, guanine, and cytosine, the four nitrogenous bases, pair specifically, resulting in the stability and replication of DNA. This biological marvel, a product of chemical bonds, governs the growth, function, and reproduction of all living organisms, encapsulating the profound interplay between chemistry and life.

Tunneling electron-positron pair production is studied in a new setup in which a strong low-frequency and a weak high-frequency laser field propagate in the same direction and collide head-on with a relativistic nucleus. The electron-positron pair production rate is calculated analytically in the limit in which in the nucleus rest frame the strong field is undercritical and the frequency of the weak field is below and close to the pair production threshold. By changing the frequency of the weak field one can reduce the tunneling barrier substantially. As a result tunneling pair production is shown to be observable with presently available technology.

In the realm of molecular science, the concept of polarity plays a pivotal role. Polar molecules, such as water (H2O), possess an uneven distribution of electrons, creating a dipole moment. This dipole results from the partial negative charge on the oxygen atom and the partial positive charge on the hydrogen atoms. This polarity allows water to form hydrogen bonds, a unique intermolecular attraction that underpins its crucial role in life, such as facilitating chemical reactions and maintaining the structure of biological molecules. Meanwhile, nonpolar molecules, like carbon dioxide (CO2), have an equal distribution of electrons, leading to no dipole moment. The properties of both polar and nonpolar molecules significantly influence their behavior in chemical reactions and interactions within biological systems.

A scheme for an X-ray free electron laser is proposed, based on a Raman process occurring during the interaction between a moderately relativistic bunch of free electrons, and twin intense short pulse lasers interfering to form a transverse standing wave along the electron trajectories. In the high intensity regime of the Kapitza-Dirac effect, the laser ponderomotive potential forces the electrons into a lateral oscillatory motion, resulting in a Raman scattering process. I show how a parametric process is triggered, resulting in the amplification of the Stokes component of the Raman-scattered photons. Experimental operating parameters and implementations, based both on LINAC and Laser Wakefield Acceleration techniques, are discussed.

In the realm of organic chemistry, one fascinating compound is cellulose. Derived from glucose, cellulose is a polysaccharide that forms the primary structural component of plant cells. It's a long, linear chain of glucose molecules linked by beta-1,4 glycosidic bonds, giving it a rigid structure. This sturdy material is responsible for the toughness of plant fibers, from cotton to wood. Cellulose's unique chemistry allows it to be a sustainable and renewable source of raw materials, making it an integral part of numerous industrial applications, including textiles, paper production, and biofuel production. The study of cellulose continues to unravel its intricate chemistry, offering potential for innovative solutions to modern challenges in sustainability.

The KLOE experiment at the upgraded DAFNE e+e- collider in Frascati (KLOE-2) is going to start a new data taking at the beginning of 2010 with its detector upgraded with a tagging system for the identification of gamma-gamma interactions. The tagging stations for low-energy e+e- will consist in two calorimeters The calorimeter used to detect low-energy e+e- will be placed between the beam-pipe outer support structure and the inner wall of the KLOE drift chamber. This calorimeter will be made of LYSO crystals readout by Silicon Photomultipliers, to achieve an energy resolution better than 8% at 200 MeV.

Nitrogen, a colorless, odorless gas, is the central player in Earth's atmosphere, making up about 78% of its composition. This element, with atomic number 7, is vital for life, as it forms part of the structure of proteins, nucleic acids, and other essential organic compounds. In industry, nitrogen is used extensively in the production of fertilizers, explosives, and plastics. Ammonia (NH3), a basic nitrogen compound, is a key component in cleaning products and refrigerants. Nitric acid (HNO3), another nitrogen-based compound, is used in the manufacture of fertilizers, explosives, and automotive catalysts. The chemistry of nitrogen is vast and multifaceted, continually offering new insights and applications to benefit human life and advance technology.

Cathodoluminescence spectroscopy has been performed on silver nanoparticles in a scanning electron microscopy setup. Peaks appearing in the visible range for particles fabricated on silicon substrate are shown to arrive from excitation of out of plane eigenmodes by the electron beam. Monochromatic emission maps have been shown to resolve spatial field variation of resonant plasmon mode on length scale smaller than 25nm. Finite-difference time-domain numerical simulations are performed for both the cases of light excitation and electron excitation. The results of radiative emission under electron excitation show an excellent agreement with experiments. A complete vectorial description of induced field is given, which complements the information obtained from experiments.

In the realm of chemical bonding, the electronegativity difference between atoms plays a pivotal role in determining the nature of the bond. Atoms with a significant disparity in electronegativity, like fluorine and hydrogen, form ionic bonds, transferring electrons to form a stable ion pair. Conversely, when the electronegativity difference is minimal, as in a hydrogen bond between water molecules, a partial charge distribution occurs, creating a weak yet influential attraction. The understanding of electronegativity and its impact on bond formation is fundamental in the study of chemistry, shaping the properties and interactions of countless substances.

We present a new optoelectronic architecture intended for chaotic optical intensity generation. The principle relies on an electro-optic non-linear delay dynamics, which non linearity is performed by a 4-waves integrated optics interferometer involving 2 independent electro-optic modulation inputs. The setup allows both to have an ultra-fast dynamics up to several GHz frequencies, and potentially high dimensional chaos intended for encryption of optical data at the physical layer. We have built a mathematical model of the system and analyzed a number of its possible solutions: stable steady states, periodic and chaotic regimes. The experimental observations allowed to validate the dynamical model, through good qualitative agreements with the numerical simulations.

In the realm of chemical bonding, the mighty covalent bond plays a pivotal role. This type of bond, formed by the sharing of electrons, is responsible for the stability of countless molecules. From the intricate dance of hydrogen and oxygen in water, H2O, to the strong bond between carbon atoms in diamond, these links hold together the very fabric of our world. The length, strength, and even the shape of these molecules can be predicted by studying the properties of these bonds, a field known as quantum chemistry. Indeed, the covalent bond, a simple yet profound concept in chemistry, underpins the structure of all matter as we know it.

A cylindrical system is proposed that will store magnetic energy in a localized azimuthal field that can then be quickly released on Alfvenic timescales, accompanied by the formation of a flowing Z-pinch plasma. The magnetized plasma is MHD in character and will have unilateral axial momentum with Alfvenic speeds. Conventional plasma gun injectors (Marshall type) have a limited parameter space of operation. The "magnetic spring" momentum injector differs from Marshall guns in that it has an already stored strong magnetic field before release. The resulting parameter space is much broader. There are possible applications to momentum injectors for fusion and to plasma and rail guns.

Nestled within the realm of the periodic table, the element silicon (Si) stands out as a key player in the vast tapestry of chemistry. Silicon, with its atomic number 14, shares many properties with carbon, yet it forms a broader spectrum of compounds due to its larger size and enhanced reactivity. Silicon dioxide, or silica, is one such compound, prevalent in sand and quartz, while silicates, comprising over 90% of Earth's crust, are complex silicon-oxygen structures. Silicon's versatility extends to semiconductor technology, where it forms the basis of microchips, powering the digital age we live in today. This humble element, overlooked by many, plays a pivotal role in shaping our modern world.

Research work in the area of the Global Electric Circuit (GEC) has rapidly expanded in recent years mainly through observations of lightning from satellites and ground-based networks and observations of optical emissions between cloud and the ionosphere. After reviewing this progress, we critically examine the role of various generators of the currents flowing in the lower and upper atmosphere and supplying currents to the GEC. The role of aerosols and cosmic rays in controlling the GEC and linkage between climate, solarterrestrial relationships and the GEC has been briefly discussed. Some unsolved problems in this area are reported for future investigations.

In the realm of molecular biology, DNA's (deoxyribonucleic acid) intricate structure serves as the blueprint for life. Its double helix, a product of complementary base pairing (adenine with thymine, and cytosine with guanine), not only ensures genetic information transmission but also undergoes dynamic changes through processes like mutation and recombination. These alterations, whilst potentially harmful, are crucial for evolution, as they introduce variation necessary for adaptation in response to environmental pressures. On the other hand, proteins, complex chains of amino acids, are the workhorses of the cell, executing a myriad of functions, from catalyzing biochemical reactions to building cellular structures. The intricate dance between DNA and proteins, a symphony of synthesis and regulation, is the heartbeat of life at the molecular level.

Patterns of convection in internally heated, self-gravitating rotating spherical fluid shells are investigated through numerical simulations. While turbulent states are of primary interest in planetary and stellar applications the present paper emphasizes more regular dynamical features at Rayleigh numbers not far above threshold which are similar to those which might be observed in laboratory or space experiments. Amplitude vacillations and spatial modulations of convection columns are common features at moderate and large Prandtl numbers. In the low Prandtl number regime equatorially attached convection evolves differently with increasing Rayleigh number and exhibits an early transition into a chaotic state. Relationships of the dynamical features to coherent structures in fully turbulent convection states are emphasized.

In the realm of chemical synthesis, a pivotal process is the transformation of carbon-based compounds. This metamorphosis, often facilitated by catalysts, unfolds as the breaking and forming of bonds between atoms. The products of these reactions, known as intermediates, are transient species that play a crucial role in determining the overall structure and properties of the final compound. The art of manipulating these intermediates, through careful selection of reactants, conditions, and catalysts, is the very essence of organic chemistry, a field that continues to captivate and challenge chemists worldwide.

A simulation study of the magnetic electron drift vortex (MEDV) mode turbulence in a magnetoplasma in the presence of inhomogeneities in the plasma temperature and density, as well as in the external magnetic field, is presented. The study shows that the influence of the magnetic field inhomogeneity is to suppress streamer-like structures observed in previous simulation studies without background magnetic fields. The MEDV mode turbulence exhibits non-universal (non-Kolmogorov type) spectra for different sets of the plasma parameters. In the presence of an inhomogeneous magnetic field, the spectrum changes to a 7/3 power law, which is flatter than without magnetic field gradients. The relevance of this work to laser-produced plasmas in the laboratory is briefly mentioned.

In the captivating realm of chemistry, the intriguing compound known as silicon dioxide, or silica, enchants scientists and amateurs alike. Silica, symbolized as SiO2, forms the base for sand, quartz, and glass, transforming from a loose, granular substance to a rigid, transparent material through human intervention. Its unique properties, such as high melting point and hardness, have been harnessed for countless applications, from the construction of skyscrapers to the production of microchips. In nature, it shapes landscapes, forms precious gems, and even plays a crucial role in photosynthesis. The versatile and abundant silica continues to amaze, offering endless opportunities for exploration and innovation in the field of chemistry.

Electron-positron pair production is considered in the relativistic collision of a nucleus and an anti-nucleus, in which both leptons are created in bound states of the corresponding nucleus-lepton system. Compared to free and bound-free pair production this process is shown to display a qualitatively different dependency both on the impact energy and charged of the colliding particles. Interestingly, at high impact energies the cross section for this process is found to be larger than that for the analogous atomic process of non-radiative electron capture although the latter does not involve the creation of new particles.

In the realm of chemical science, the study of catalysts unfolds a fascinating tapestry. These substances, often metals or complex compounds, accelerate chemical reactions without undergoing permanent change themselves. They do so by lowering the activation energy, a hurdle that slows down reactions. This enables reactions to proceed at lower temperatures and speeds, making industrial processes more efficient and resource-friendly. Catalysts are pivotal in producing everyday items like plastics, fertilizers, and pharmaceuticals. Moreover, they play a crucial role in environmental protection, as they facilitate the breakdown of pollutants. The art and science of catalysis continue to captivate chemists, offering endless possibilities for innovation and sustainability.

We have developed an interface which allows to perform rigorous electromagnetic field (EMF) simulations with the simulator JCMsuite and subsequent aerial imaging and resist simulations with the simulator Dr.LiTHO. With the combined tools we investigate the convergence of near-field and far-field results for different DUV masks. We also benchmark results obtained with the waveguide-method EMF solver included in Dr.LiTHO and with the finite-element-method EMF solver JCMsuite. We demonstrate results on convergence for dense and isolated hole arrays, for masks including diagonal structures, and for a large 3D mask pattern of lateral size 10 microns by 10 microns.

Nested within the intricate dance of elements, the chemistry of life unfolds. Proteins, the workhorses of our bodies, are intricate chains of amino acids, each with a unique structure defining its function. Carbohydrates, essential for energy, are complex sugar molecules, some serving as structural components, others as vital signaling agents. Fats, or lipids, offer a dense energy source and are crucial for cell membrane structure and hormone production. DNA, the blueprint of life, encodes the instructions for creating proteins and other essential components. This intricate web of chemistry, orchestrated by enzymes, drives the myriad processes sustaining life. From the microscopic realm of molecules to the grand scale of organisms, chemistry is the silent maestro, conducting the symphony of life.

We demonstrate how the shape of femtosecond laser pulses can be tailored in order to obtain maximal ionization of atoms or molecules. For that purpose, we have overlayed a direct-optimization scheme on top of a fully unconstrained computation of the three-dimensional time-dependent Schrodinger equation. The procedure looks for pulses that maintain the same total length and integrated intensity or fluence as a given pulse that serves as an initial guess. It allows, however, for changes in frequencies -- within a certain, predefined range -- and overall shape, leading to enhanced ionization. We illustrate the scheme by calculating ionization yields for the H2+ molecule when irradiated with short (~5 fs), high-intensity laser pulses.

Unraveling the intricate dance of atoms, chemistry delves into the fundamental building blocks of our universe. It's the silent guardian that holds compounds together, the architect who designs the structure of molecules, and the artist who paints the vibrant palette of colors in a flame. From the humblest water molecule, H2O, to the complex proteins that form our very cells, chemistry illuminates the hidden world within, revealing the secrets of life itself. It's a ceaseless journey of discovery, a testament to the boundless curiosity of the human spirit, forever chasing the elusive, yet fascinating, world of elements.

We present a fully {\it ab initio}, non-perturbative, time-dependent approach to describe single and double ionization of helium by proton and antiproton impact. A flexible and accurate finite-element discrete-variable-representation is applied to discretize the problem on the radial grid in spherical coordinates. Good agreement with the most recent experimental data for absolute angle-integrated cross sections is obtained over a wide range of incident projectile energies between 3 keV and 6 MeV. Furthermore, angle-differential cross sections for two-electron ejection are predicted for a proton impact energy of 6 MeV. Finally, the time evaluation of the ionization process is portrayed by displaying the electron density as a function of the projectile location.

Nitrogen, a versatile element in the periodic table, is the lifeblood of our planet's atmosphere, constituting approximately 78% of air by volume. It plays a pivotal role in various biological processes, including proteins' formation and DNA synthesis. In industry, nitrogen is indispensable, used in the production of fertilizers, plastics, and explosives. The Haber-Bosch process, a Nobel Prize-winning innovation, transforms atmospheric nitrogen into ammonia, a key ingredient in fertilizers, disproving the belief that nitrogen was an inert, unreactive gas. This transformation has revolutionized agriculture, enabling increased crop yields and feeding a growing global population.

We examine the stability of intense flat bunches in barrier buckets used in the Recycler. We consider some common stationary distributions and show that they would be unstable against rigid dipole oscillations. We then discuss an analytical model for the line density that best describes measured bunch profiles. We include space charge in this model to predict the bunch intensity at which Landau damping would be lost. The dependence of this threshold on the bunch length is studied and related to the results of an experimental study with shorter bunch lengths. The threshold for the microwave instability is estimated. These studies will be followed by more detailed numerical studies.

In the realm of organic chemistry, the synthesis of polymers is a fascinating pursuit. Polymers, long chains of repeating molecules, are ubiquitous in our daily lives, from plastics and rubbers to fibers and resins. Their properties, such as strength, flexibility, and heat resistance, can be tailored by altering the monomer units, the length of the chains, and the branching patterns. For instance, polyethylene, a simple hydrocarbon polymer, is used in packaging materials due to its low density and excellent barrier properties. On the other hand, nylon, a polyamide, is known for its toughness and resistance to abrasion, making it ideal for fabrics and carpets. The study and creation of new polymers continue to expand the boundaries of material science, offering solutions to a myriad of practical problems and opening up exciting possibilities for the future.

This contribution replies to H. M. Zhang's paper "What Faster-than-traffic Characteristic Speeds Mean for Vehicular Traffic Flow", which comments on the manuscript "On the Controversy around Daganzo's Requiem for and Aw-Rascle's Resurrection of Second-Order Traffic Flow Models" published in this issue of Eurpean Physical Journal B. The author clarifies several points and agrees that suitable experiments can be a way of deciding the controversy on the existence of propagation speeds faster than the speed of vehicles. Moreover, he proposes to aim at an integrated theory, which is both, theoretically consistent and practically relevant.

In the intricate world of chemistry, the element carbon stands out, forming the basis of life on Earth. Carbon's unique ability to bond with four other atoms creates a diverse range of compounds, from the simple methane to complex biomolecules like DNA and proteins. This versatility is also displayed in the realm of allotropes, where carbon appears in various forms, such as diamond, graphite, and fullerene, each exhibiting distinct properties. Moreover, carbon's role in photosynthesis, where it is converted from carbon dioxide into organic matter, underscores its pivotal role in the carbon cycle, a process that regulates Earth's climate. Thus, carbon, with its myriad of forms and functions, remains a captivating subject in the study of chemistry.

Non-relativisitic second-order corrections to the wave function at origin in muonic and exotic atoms are considered. The corrections are due to the electronic vacuum polarization. Such corrections are of interest due to various effective approaches, which take into account QED and hadronic effects. The wave function at origin plays a key role in the calculation of the pionium lifetime, various finite nuclear size effects and the hyperfine splitting. The results are obtained for the $1s$ and $2s$ states in pionic and muonic hydrogen and deuterium and in pionium, a bound system of $\pi^+$ and $\pi^-$. Applications to the hyperfine structure and the Lamb shift in muonic hydrogen are also considered.

In the intricate world of chemical reactions, the synthesis of polymers stands out as a fascinating process. Polymers, often referred to as 'plastics', are large molecules composed of repeating structural units, known as monomers. Through a process called polymerization, these monomers link together to form long chains. The properties of polymers can be tailored by manipulating their structure, such as the type of monomer, the arrangement of the links, or the presence of additives. This versatility makes polymers indispensable in various industries, from packaging materials to medical devices, demonstrating their profound impact on our daily lives.

We re-examine past suggestions of a close link between terrestrial climate change and the Sun's transit of spiral arms in its path through the Milky Way galaxy. These links produced concrete fits, deriving the unknown spiral pattern speed from terrestrial climate correlations. We test these fits against new data on spiral structure based on CO data that does not make simplifying assumptions about symmetry and circular rotation. If we compare the times of these transits to changes in the climate of Earth, not only do the claimed correlations disappear, but also we find that they cannot be resurrected for any reasonable pattern speed.

In the realm of molecular dynamics, the concept of polarity plays a pivotal role. Polarity, in essence, is the uneven distribution of electrons within a molecule, leading to a partial positive and negative charge. This distinction dictates a molecule's behavior towards other substances, influencing solubility, reactivity, and even the formation of bonds. For instance, water, H2O, is polar due to its unequal sharing of electrons between hydrogen and oxygen atoms. This polarity allows water to form hydrogen bonds, a key factor in its unique properties like high boiling point and solvent capabilities. Similarly, polar molecules tend to mix with other polar substances, while nonpolar molecules prefer nonpolar environments, a fundamental principle in chemistry that underpins myriad phenomena.

Single vehicle data obtained from magnetic loops on an expressway allowed us to measure velocity correlations and velocity differences between non--neighbor vehicles on the same lane, showing some strong correlations even for platoons of 7 or 8 vehicles. The corresponding time headway distribution for non--neighbor vehicles is also presented. We were also able to get some informations about inter--lane structures, through crossed time headway distributions. It should be noticed that these last results on crossed time headways are meaningful only because the subset of data we used corresponds to a unique stationary traffic state -- and still contains a large amount of data, with a large fraction of short time headways. The link with passing maneuvers is discussed.

In the realm of inorganic chemistry, transition metals captivate with their versatile properties. These elements, with their partially filled d-orbitals, exhibit unique electronic configurations, responsible for their colorful hues and catalytic prowess. Copper, for instance, is a prime example, catalyzing reactions in everything from food preparation to industrial processes. Its ability to form complexes with various ligands expands its reactivity, enabling it to participate in redox reactions, often as a mediator. Nickel, too, demonstrates remarkable versatility, found in everything from stainless steel to batteries. Its role in numerous catalytic processes, such as hydrogenation reactions, is invaluable in modern chemistry and industry. Transition metals, with their dynamic electronic structure and catalytic capabilities, continue to intrigue chemists, offering endless opportunities for discovery and innovation.

We are used to describe the detection of light in terms of particles and its propagation from the source to the detection, by waves. For instance, the slowing down of light in a transparent medium is always explained within the electromagnetic wave framework. We propose to approach that phenomenon through a purely corpuscular description. We find expression for the refractive indices which differ slightly from the usual Maxwell wave approach. We thus compare these expressions against experimental refractive indices and we show that both reproduce well the data. We show also how this corpuscular framework gives a very natural interpretation to the self focusing Kerr effect. Finally an experimental expectation of fluctuation of the speed of light is presented.

In the intricate dance of elements, hydrogen and oxygen unite to form water, a fundamental substance essential for life on Earth. This union, known as a covalent bond, occurs when electrons are shared, creating a stable and harmonious structure. Water's unique properties, such as its high boiling point and high heat capacity, are a testament to the strength of this bond. It serves as a solvent, dissolving a multitude of substances, and plays a crucial role in chemical reactions, acting as a medium for numerous transformations. The versatility of water, along with its ubiquity, makes it an invaluable compound in both natural and industrial processes.

After describing Bhabha's early life at Bombay, now Mumbai, we discuss his research career at Cambridge, where he made many distinguished contributions to positron physics, cosmic rays and the meson theory. These include theory of positron-electron scattering (Bhabha scattering), Bhabha-Heitler theory of cosmic ray showers and prediction of heavier electrons (ie. muons). Later in his life, after 1945, Bhabha worked in India at Bangalore and Mumbai. In India Bhabha laid foundations of modern nuclear science and technology. He emerged as a successful institution builder founding Tata Institute of Fundamental Research at Mumbai and the Laboratories of Atomic Energy Establishment at Trombay, now renamed as Bhabha Atomic Research Center.

In the realm of molecular biology, DNA (deoxyribonucleic acid) stands as the blueprint of life. A double helix structure composed of nucleotides, it carries all genetic information, encoded in a sequence of adenine, thymine, guanine, and cytosine bases. The arrangement of these bases determines an organism's traits, from eye color to hair texture. Genetic engineering, a modern application of this knowledge, manipulates these sequences to introduce desirable traits or correct genetic defects, shaping the course of evolution in a more deliberate manner. This technology, while promising, raises ethical questions about the boundaries of human intervention in natural processes.

A crab cavity is required in the CLIC to allow effective head-on collision of bunches at the IP. A high operating frequency is preferred as the deflection voltage required for a given rotation angle and the RF phase tolerance for a crab cavity are inversely proportional to the operating frequency. The short bunch spacing of the CLIC scheme and the high sensitivity of the crab cavity to dipole kicks demand very high damping of the inter-bunch wakes, the major contributor to the luminosity loss of colliding bunches. This paper investigates the nature of the wakefields in the CLIC crab cavity and the possibility of using various damping schemes to suppress them effectively.

Nitric acid, a pivotal compound in the realm of chemistry, is a strong acid characterized by its corrosive properties and pungent smell. Its chemical formula, HNO3, reveals the presence of nitrogen, oxygen, and hydrogen atoms. Naturally found in minute quantities in the atmosphere, it is also produced industrially through the Ostwald process. Nitric acid plays a significant role in various applications, including fertilizer production, explosives synthesis, and as a key component in the manufacturing of automotive catalytic converters. Moreover, it serves as a crucial reagent in numerous laboratory experiments due to its ability to oxidize and nitrate other substances. Its versatility and indispensable role in chemistry make nitric acid an essential compound in both industrial and academic settings.

We address the stability of light bullets supported by Bessel optical lattices with out-of-phase modulation of the linear and nonlinear refractive indices. We show that spatial modulation of the nonlinearity significantly modifies the shapes and stability domains of the light bullets. The addressed bullets can be stable, provided that the peak intensity does not exceed a critical value. We show that the width of the stability domain in terms of the propagation constant may be controlled by varying the nonlinearity modulation depth. In particular, we show that the maximum energy of the stable bullets grows with increasing nonlinearity modulation depth.

In the vibrant world of chemical synthesis, the reaction of sodium and chlorine yields a familiar product: sodium chloride, or table salt. This process, known as an ionic bond formation, occurs when the electronegative chlorine atom attracts electrons from the sodium atom, forming positively charged sodium ions (Na+) and negatively charged chloride ions (Cl-). The resulting ions then arrange themselves in a crystal lattice, creating the familiar white crystal structure that seasons our meals. This reaction demonstrates the fundamental principles of electrochemistry, highlighting the interplay between atoms, electrons, and energy in chemical reactions.

We present numerical simulations of the magnetic field generated by the flow of liquid sodium driven by two counter-rotating impellers (VKS experiment). Using a dynamo kinematic code in cylindrical geometry, it is shown that different magnetic modes can be generated depending on the flow configuration. While the time averaged axisymmetric mean flow generates an equatorial dipole, our simulations show that an axial field of either dipolar or quadrupolar symmetry can be generated by taking into account non-axisymmetric components of the flow. Moreover, we show that by breaking a symmetry of the flow, the magnetic field becomes oscillatory. This leads to reversals of the axial dipole polarity, involving a competition with the quadrupolar component.

Nitrogen, a versatile element, constitutes approximately 78% of Earth's atmosphere. It exists in three forms in nature: diatomic nitrogen (N2), nitric oxide (NO), and nitrous oxide (N2O). Diatomic nitrogen, the most abundant, is biologically inert and unavailable for most biological processes. However, nitrogen fixation, primarily performed by bacteria like Rhizobium, converts this inert gas into ammonia (NH3). This ammonia is crucial for plant growth, serving as a building block for proteins, nucleic acids, and other essential compounds. Nitric oxide and nitrous oxide, while minor components of the atmosphere, play significant roles as signaling molecules in living organisms and as greenhouse gases, respectively. Understanding nitrogen's various forms and their interactions is vital for advancing agriculture, environmental conservation, and human health.

We discuss the influence of a single or double fullerenes shell upon photoionization and vacancy decay of an atom, stuffed inside the fullerenes construction. The main manifestations of this influence are additional structures in the photoionization cross-section and variation of the vacancy decay probability. The main mechanisms, with which fullerenes shells affect the processes in caged atoms is the scattering of the outgoing electrons by the fullerenes shell and modification of the photon beam due to fullerenes shell polarization. General consideration will be illustrated by numeric calculations where C60 and C240 will be chosen as fullerenes and Ar and Xe as caged atoms.

Amidst the vibrant world of chemical synthesis, one compound stands out for its versatility and ubiquity: carbon dioxide (CO2). This colorless, odorless gas is a crucial component of our atmosphere, playing a pivotal role in the Earth's carbon cycle. In the natural world, plants absorb CO2 during photosynthesis, converting it into oxygen and glucose, a process essential for life on our planet. Conversely, human activities such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation release CO2 into the air, contributing to global warming and climate change. Understanding and managing carbon dioxide emissions is a critical challenge for scientists and policymakers alike, as they strive to balance the needs of industry with the health of our environment.

In order to assess the performance of liquid xenon detectors for use in positron emission tomography we studied the scintillation light and ionization charge produced by 511 keV photons in a small prototype detector. Scintillation light was detected with large area avalanche photodiodes while ionization electrons were collected on an anode instrumented with low noise electronics after drifting up to 3 cm. Operational conditions were studied as a function of the electric field. Energy resolutions of <10 % (FWHM) were achieved by combining the scintillation light and ionization charge signals. The relationship between scintillation light and ionization signals was investigated. An analysis of the sources of fluctuations was performed in order to optimize future detector designs.

In the intriguing realm of chemistry, the study of polymers unfolds a fascinating tale. These complex molecules, made up of repeating subunits, are integral to our daily lives, from plastics and rubbers to biologically crucial proteins and DNA. Polymers exhibit unique properties due to their large molecular weight and extended structure, such as high melting points, low electrical conductivity, and remarkable resistance to degradation. Synthetic polymers, crafted in laboratories, offer versatility and durability, while biopolymers, found in nature, have sparked advancements in biomedicine and sustainable materials. The exploration of polymers continues to unravel their potential, paving the way for innovations in technology, medicine, and beyond.

Five new correlations between sunspot activity and orbiting position of the Jovian planets are detected. In order to explain these correlations it is suggested that the resonance of the outer planets destabilizes the orbit of Kuiper Belt Objects and generates a cyclical impact frequency on the Sun. The vaporization of the object initiates a shock way disrupting the upwelling of the plasma resulting in a sunspot formation. The proposed model is able to explain the length of the cycle, the latitude distribution of the sunspots and the extremely long term stability of the cycles. Calculating the positions of the Jovian planets at conjunction and opposition allows the long term prediction of the solar activity.

Nestled within the realm of matter, hydrogen stands as the lightest and most abundant element in the universe, constituting approximately 75% of its total mass. Hydrogen's unique atomic structure, composed of a single proton and an electron, lends itself to a remarkable property – fusion.
